Name of case: United States of America v. Henry Tarrio
Charges: DC Code 7:2506.01(b) possession of large capacity ammunition feeding device [2 counts]
Additional details: Resident of Miami, FL
Short narrative: On January 4, 2021, Henry Tarrio was arrested for burning a Black Lives Matter flag outside of a Black church in December. Following his arrest, police found two high-capacity firearms magazines from his bookbag. Tarrio claimed that he was selling the magazines, and they were returned to him when he mailed them so he had planned on delivering them to his customer while he was in Washington, D.C. The magazines depicted Proud Boys logos and images. Tarrio is the national chairman of the Proud Boys according to the affidavit.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, Local news articles

Name of case: District of Columbia v. Thomas Alexander Grokek
Charges: 22 DC code 4504(a-1) Carrying A Rifle or Shotgun (Outside Home or Place of Business)
Additional details: From Asheville, North Carolina
Short narrative: Thomas Gronek, 46, of Asheville, North Carolina, was on a multicolored school bus along Constitution Avenue (Northwest D.C.) that matched the description of a "Be On the Lookout" or BOLO vehicle and was spray painted with "Hippies 4 Trump" and other pro-Trump messages. Gronek and the driver were stopped and questioned. The officers performed a secondary sweep of the vehicle due to its clutter and discovered firearms. Gronek was charged with carrying a rifle/shotgun outside a home or place of business.

Name of case: District of Columbia v. Ashanti Smith
Charges: D.C. Code 22:404 Assault
Additional details: counter protestor; Resident of MD
Short narrative: Ashanti Smith was a counter-protestor self-affiliated with the BLM movement who was arrested for punching a supporter of the Capitol raid in the face after a scuffle over a mobile phone. She was arrested alongside Anne Lorenz who was also charged with simple assault after she then followed Smith and punched her. Smith was wearing full uniform and was “on a Civil Disturbance Unit (CDU) mountain bike deployment” during the incident, according to court documents. Although it does not state if she worked for Capitol Police.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: District of Columbia v. Kristina V. Malimon
Charges: 22:3302(b)DCMR Unlawful Entry (public property)
Additional details: Resident of Portland, OR; Vice chairman of Young Republicans of OR; Born in Moldova; Related to Kristina V. Malimon; Shares address with Yevgemya I. Malimon; Has rejected the prosecution’s plea offer and requested a jury trial; "Found guilty on 10/13/22, following bench trial in the Superior Court of the District of Columbia, of unlawful entry onto public property, a District of Columbia offense. Sentenced the same day to one year of probation, 100 hours of community service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Kristina V. Malimon, 28, of Portland, OR, was arrested in relation to the Jan 6th Capitol riot for curfew violation at Peace Circle/Peace Monument Circle, which is a part of Capitol grounds. Malimon was charged with Unlawful Entry (public property) to encompass the property and curfew violation. Malimon is the vice chairman of Young Republicans. In an Instagram video, Malimon said she was born in Moldova, but her citizenship status is unclear. Malimon was arrested alongside her mother, Yevgemya I. Malimon, with whom she shares an address. Kristina V. Malimon's case is currently pending. Malimon was arrested as part of a large group arrested at Peace Circle/Peace Monument Circle for violating curfew and property violation.
Source description: Charging document, Court documents, Local news article, Other (MPD arrest Data)

Name of case: United States of America v. Anthime Joseph Gionet
Charges: 18:1752 (a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 40:5104(e)(2) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds
Additional details: Arrested in and from Houston, Texas; Previous misdemeanor charges in Arizona for assault; "Gionet Sentenced 1/10/23 to 60 Days incarceration, 24 months Probation, Restitution $500, $2,000 Fine, Special Assessment $10."
Short narrative: January 2021, Anthime Joseph Gionet, 33, was arrested and charged with Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; and Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds. Gionet is known to be a far-right media personality nicknamed “Baked Alaska” known for live streaming himself participating in illegal activity. While in the Capitol building he carried out a 27-minute livestream video. Gionet has pending misdemeanor assault charges in Arizona.
Source description: News Articles, Charging Document, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Lonnie Leroy Coffman
Charges: 18:5861(d), 5841, 5845(f), 5871 Possession of an Unregistered Firearm; 22 DC code 4504(a) Carry Pistol W/O Lic -Outside Home/Business; 22 DC Code 4504(a-1) Carrying a rifle or shotgun without a license [2 counts]; 7 DC Code 2506.01(b) Possession of a large capacity ammunition feeding device; 7 DC Code 2502.01(a) Possession of an Unregistered Firearm [5 counts]; 7 DC Code 2506.01(a)(3) Unlawful Possession of Ammunition [5 Counts]; 26:5861(d) possession of destructive device; 22 DC code 4504(a) Carry Pistol W/O Lic -Outside Home/Business
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of AL; Pretrial release denied based on defendant's affiliation with a militia in 2014; Also pled guilty in Northern District of AL; Coffman will be placed on three years of supervised release following his prison term.
Short narrative: Lonnie Leroy Coffman, 70, of Falkville, Alabama was arrested after USCP Bomb Squad members subsequently searched a vehicle registered to Coffman vehicle parked behind the Library of Congress and secured one handgun, one M4 Carbine assault rifle along with rifle magazines loaded with ammunition, hundreds of additional rounds of ammunition, a crossbow, several machetes, camouflage smoke devices, a stun gun, and components for the construction of eleven “Molotov Cocktails” in the form of mason jars filled with ignitable substances, rags, and lighters. Coffman was subsequently searched and found to have on his person a additional 9mm Smith & Wesson handgun, a 22-caliber derringer style handgun, and two sets of vehicle keys that matched the truck. In his truck was a notepad with contact details for Senator Ted Cruz, Sean Hannity, and a list of "good" people and "bad" people, including a judge. Subsequent investigations linked him to militia activity in 2014, including locating contact information on his person linked to a Southeast Texas militia group called the America patriots. Investigations also showed that Coffman had driven around the Capitol and attempted to reach Senator Cruz's house on 12/11/20 as well as calling the Senator's office the same day.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Mark Jefferson Leffingwell
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers or Employees; 18:1752(a)(l1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Building
Additional details: Iraq war veteran; Former member of Washington National Guard.; "Sentenced 2/10/2022, six months of incarceration, 24 months of supervised release, 200 hours of community service, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: Mark Jefferson Leffingwell, 51, of Seattle, Washington was charged with Civil Disorder, Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers or Employees, Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building, Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, and Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Building. The complaint against Leffingwell alleges he attempted to push past police officers inside the Capitol. When they stopped him, Leffingwell allegedly punched a Capitol police officer “repeatedly with a closed fist.” The officer was allegedly struck on a helmet and in the chest. Officers then took Leffingwell into custody, it said he apologized for striking the officer. He served in the Washington National Guard from 2005 to 2009 and deployed with the 81st Brigade to Iraq
Source description: News Articles, Court Documents, Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Christine Priola
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 40:5104(e)(2) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(f) Unlawful Activities on Capitol Grounds, Parades, Assemblages and Display of Flags

Priola submitted her resigned from her job as a therapist in Cleveland schools following the riot with a letter that contained conspiracy content, including that she was "switching paths to expose the global evil of human trafficking and pedophilia, including our government agencies and children's services agencies", consistent with QAnon ideolody.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Justin Stoll
Charges: 18:875(c) Interstate Threats; 18:1512(b)(3) Tampering with a witness by threat
Additional details: Resident of OH
Short narrative: Justin Stoll, 40, of Wilmington, Ohio, has been charged with making interstate threats and Tampering with a witness by threat. The charges are related to Stoll's online communications related to his participation in the Jan. 6 Capitol riots. Under the username “Th3RealHuckleberry” on the app Clapper and on YouTube, Stoll posted videos related to his participation in the Capitol protests. In one video, asking viewers if he should wear a black United States flag shirt to D.C., Stoll stated, “Basically, if you are an enemy combatant, you will be shot on sight…I know this is the end-all flag…” Stoll also allegedly posted videos of himself outside the Capitol with other protesters in which he said, among other things, “D.C.’s a war zone!...You ain’t got enough cops, baby! We are at war at the Capitol…. We have taken the Capitol. This is our country.” According to the court document, Stoll received comments from concerned citizens in response to his YouTube videos, including from one user who said (s)he had saved Stoll’s video. Stoll responded via another video, in which he said, in part: "Well, that shows your f------ ignorance because, clearly, the capitol building is owned by the people, so again, nothing will happen. Secondly, I never admitted I went into it, did I? Go watch the video again. Daddy’s not stupid. [Wink.] Third, if you ever in your f------ existence did something to jeopardize taking me away from my family, you will absolutely meet your maker. You can play that for the D.A. in court, I don’t care. If you ever jeopardize me, from being with my family, you will absolutely meet your mother f------ maker, and I will be the one to arrange the meeting." (DOJ press release)"
Source description: Charging documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and release, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Nicolas Anthony Moncada
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1),(2) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 40:5104(e)(2)(A) and (G) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds
Additional details: From Bay Terrace, New York; "Nicolas Moncada Sentenced 11/8/23 to a term of 36 months (3 years) of Probation. The Defendant is further sentenced to pay a $10 special assessment and $500 in restitution."
Short narrative: Nicolas Anthony Moncada, 20, of Bay Terrace, New York was arrested at his home, for his participation in the Capitol riot..."The feds were able to track down Moncada because he live streamed the Jan. 6 assault on the US Capitol building on Instagram...According to federal court records, Moncada’s classmates and faculty at the Fashion Institute of Technology turned him in after recognizing him from photos and videos during the Capitol siege...Moncada was snapped in several locations in the building, including outside House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s office, the records show. He also exchanged IMs with friends during the rioting. “what is going on?” one friend messaged. “Storming the Capitol Building,” Moncada allegedly replied. (NY Post)". Moncada is a former student at the Fashion Institute of Technology and numerous classmates and faculty identified him for officers as well. Moncada was charged with knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority, and violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds.
Source description: Charging documents, Court Documents, New Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Andrew Wrigley
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Indicted via Information Sheet; Resident of Jim Thorpe, PA; "Sentenced 12/2 to 18 months probation, $2,000 fine, and $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Andrew Wrigley, of Jim Thorpe, PA was arrested for illegally entering the Capitol Building on January 6. The FBI began to investigate Wrigley when screenshots of his Facebook page with pictures of him in the Capitol were sent to them as a tip. Facebook posts showed Wigley with a 1776 flag outside of Capitol grounds, and of him entering the Capitol building through the west terrace door, where he stayed for about a minute, taking a "selfie" (Local News). Wrigley was charged with four charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building, Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Wrigley accepted a plea deal, pleading guilty to parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building and having to pay a $500 restitution fine. Wrigley's sentencing is pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Hector Emmanuel Vargas Santos

Additional details: Resident of NJ; Indicted by Bill of Information; Defendant remains on personal recognizance; USMC field radio operator 2011-2015; Defendant allegedly stole monetary donations he collected for members of the community in May 2020; "Hector Vargas Santos Found guilty 12/12/22 by jury on Counts 1, 2, 3, and 4."
Short narrative: Hector Vargas, 34, of Jersey City, New Jersey was charged with knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority and violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds for his involvement in the capitol riot on January 6th. The FBI received a tip from the public on January 7th that Vargas posted and was seen in photographs and videos on Facebook of Vargas in the Capitol building rotunda. A tipster then identified Vargas in a series of photos posted on Facebook and provided clear photos of Vargas.Vargas pleaded not guilty to all charges and remains on personal recognizance.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND Supports organized political violence AND State speech act
Name of case: United States of America v. Eduard Florea
Charges: 18:875(c) and 3551 Transmission of threats to injure; 18:922(g)(1), 924(a)(2) and 3551 Felon of possession of ammunition
Additional details: Resident of Queens, New York; Applied to be a member of Proud Boys
Short narrative: In 2021, in Queens, New York, Eduard Florea, 40, was arrested and charged with Transmission of threats to injure and Felon in possession of ammunition. Florea used Parler to make general threats to carry out violence as well as specific threats toward the Georgia democratic senator Warnock. When arrested, officers discovered ammunition and 75 military-style combat knives. Florea has a previous illegal weapons charge.As set forth in greater detail below, EDUARD FLOREA, who has previously been convicted of a firearms-related felony, posted threatening statements online on and around January 6, 2021, including statements about killing a United States Senator-elect and about intending to travel to Washington, D.C. as part of a group armed with firearms that was ready to engage in violence (although evidence gathered in this investigation to date indicates that EDUARD FLOREA did not ultimately travel to Washington, D.C. on that date). A search of FLOREA’s residence revealed that he was in possession of more than a thousand rounds of ammunition, including ammunition manufactured outside of the State of New York.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. William Vogel
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; *18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly Engages in Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in any Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Pled guilty to 5104(e)(2)(G) which carries a maximum sentence of 6 months in prison, up to 5 years probation and a maximum $5000 fine (DOJ). Will be sentenced in June 2023 (Patch)
Short narrative: William Vogel, 26, of Pawling, NY, was charged with Knowingly Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority, Knowingly Engaging in Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in any Restricted Building or Grounds, and Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds following Vogel's participation in the January 6, 2021 capitol riot. Vogel's participation was made evident through his own filming of the incident. While illegally entering the Capitol building, Vogel filmed the experience on Snapchat. His identity was also confirmed via other social media platforms and several tipsters. According to Patch.com, "The FBI said Vogel shot video of the riot and posted it to two Snapchat accounts and was “very vocal” about being at the Capitol. Authorities said a license plate reader captured Vogel in his car traveling to and from the nation’s capitol.The complaint against Vogel said there were phone records linking him to a Facebook account that had photos of him during the riot. He also communicated with a Facebook friend about the events of that day." Vogel has pled guilty to 1 count of parading, demonstrating, or picketing in any of the Capitol Buildings. He will be sentenced in June 2023.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, News article

Name of case: United States of America v. Hunter Allen Ehmke
Charges: 18:1361 Destruction of Government Property; *18:1521(c)(2) Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Sentenced 5/13/22 to four months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, $2,821 in restitution.
Short narrative: Hunter Allen Ehmke, 20, of Glendora, CA was charged with Destruction of Government Property; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his role in the January 6th riot. "Ehmke jumped onto a window ledge and smashed several panes out of a six-pane window that led to an office space inside the Capitol" (DOJ Press Release). Ehmke was initially apprehended by Capitol police before being released due to the nature of the crowd. Ehmke pled guilty to Destruction of Government Property and was sentenced to four months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, and $2,821 in restitution.

Name of case: United States of America v. Gina Michelle Bisignano
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; and Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1361 and 2 Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Beverly Hills, CA
Short narrative: In 2021, in Washington DC, Gina Michelle Bisignano, 52, of Beverly Hills, CA, was arrested following her participation in the Capitol riot. Bisignano was identified via at least 6 tips provided to the FBI, as well as numerous photos and videos of her amid the Capitol riot. Bisignano confirmed to the Beverly Hills Courier that she traveled to Washington, D.C., where she found herself among the mob who stormed the Capitol building on Jan. 6th. In one video, Bisignano is holding a megaphone on a ledge of the Capitol and yells, "Everybody, we need gas masks, we need weapons. We need strong, angry patriots to help our boys, they don't want to leave. We need protection." Bisignano was charged with obstruction of an official proceeding, aiding and abetting, civil disorder, destruction of government property, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Edward Jacob Lang
Group affiliation: North American Patriot and Liberty Militia (Napalm)
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder [3 counts]; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon [2 counts]; *18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104 (e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
Additional details: Judge Carl J. Nichols of the District Court for the District of Columbia, wrote that Lang's trial will begin on January 9, 2023 (The Sullivan Times)
Short narrative: Edward Jacob Lang, 25, of NY, was charged with three counts of Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; two counts of Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings for his role in the January 6th Capitol Riot. Lang posted multiple posts on Instagram of his participation. Additionally, photos from news outlets revealed Lang attacking Capitol officers with a baseball bat and with a police riot shield during the riot. Charge 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting was dropped, and the case is set to proceed on January 9, 2023. According to an investigation by Wired Magazine, Lang has also been involved with antisemitic streaming shows, or trashing his jail cell, and managing an online network of armed militias from jail. According to Wired, "While in prison, Lang has published a book, helped produce several films, hosted his own podcast, and raised millions of dollars for inmates and their families—all related to the January 6 attack."
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, News article

Name of case: United States of America v. Timothy Louis Hale-Cusanelli
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) and 2 Civil disorder and Aiding and abetting; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and Aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; 18:1752(a)(3) Impeding ingress and egress in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: U.S. Army Reserves demoted May 2021 to private and then given 'other than honorable discharge' after a 12 year military career; Contractor at Naval Weapons Station Earle with a "secret" security clearance; White supremacist/neo-Nazi ideology; From Colts Neck, New Jersey; "Timothy Louis Hale-Cusanelli, 32, of Colts Neck, New Jersey, was found guilty of a felony charge of obstruction of an official proceeding, and four related misdemeanors: entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building. The verdict followed a trial in the District of Columbia."; "Sentenced 9/22/22 to 48 months in prison, three years of supervised release, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: Army reservist, Timothy Louis Hale-Cusanelli, 31, of Colts Neck, NJ, was charged with Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted building or grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his participation in the Capitol riot. Hale-Cusanelli is a "well-known white supremacist and Nazi sympathizer," (CNN) described as "having extremist or radical views pertaining to the Jewish people, minorities and women,” (Seattle Times), and hosts a show on YouTube which is known to "promote far right and anti-semitic views" (LocalNews). Hale also works as a contractor at Naval Weapons Stations Earle, where he has a "secret" security clearance. Naval investigators began looking into Hale-Cusanelli after receiving a tip from an informant who said Hale-Cusanelli admitted to breaking into the Capitol building as part of the mob on Jan. 6. Hale-Cusanelli showed the informant videos on his phone, which depicted Hale-Cusanelli "making harassing and derogatory statements toward Capitol Police officers both inside and outside the Capitol building".
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, Local news article, Governmental reports and release (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Richard Barnett
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a dangerous or deadly weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a dangerous or deadly weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) Entering and remaining in certain rooms in the Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in the Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in the Capitol building; 18:641 Theft of government property
Additional details: Resident of Gravette, Arkansas; Has connections to QAnon conspiracy; "Richard Barnett Sentenced 5/24/23 to 54 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, and a $2,000 fine."
Short narrative: On January 6, 2021, Richard Barnett, 60, of Gravette, Arkansas, a "self-described white nationalist" was charged with Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a dangerous or deadly weapon; Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a dangerous or deadly weapon; Entering and remaining in certain rooms in the Capitol building; Disorderly conduct in the Capitol building; Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in the Capitol building; and Theft of government property for his role in the Jan 6th Capitol Riot. Barnett was photographed seated at Nancy Pelosi's desk, and took an envelope that was sitting on her desk. Barnett was photographed in other parts of the Capitol building and spoke to media outlets regarding his participation. Barnett has pled not guilty, and this case is currently still pending, with a next trial date set for March 10, 2023.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, Government reports and releases (DOJ), Local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Jesus Rivera
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Served USMC 2002-2012, deployed to Iraq; charged via information sheet; Resident of Pensacola, Florida; "Found guilty after bench trial on 6/17/22, of entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building."; "Sentenced 11/3/22 to 8 months of incarceration, one year of supervised release, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Jesus Delamora Rivera, 37, a Marine veteran and resident of Pensacola, Florida, was arrested by FBI in Florida for his role in the 1/6/21 Capitol attack. "According to federal court documents, Rivera uploaded a five-minute video to his Facebook account showing a crowd in the U.S. Capitol crypt. Approximately 13 seconds into the video, Rivera changed the direction of the camera toward himself. Rivera uploaded two other videos to Facebook that allegedly show him approaching the U.S. Capitol and then on the U.S. Capitol grounds surrounded by individuals demonstrating or protesting. (ABC News)". Over the last 6 months, Rivera has become increasingly vocal about his support of Donald Trump as he started a FaceBook page called "Chicano Patriot" where he would talk about his military service while wearing a hat 'Latinos for Trump'. Rivera was charged with knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing a Capitol buildings
Source description: Court Documents, Local News Articles, Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Mark Simon
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Released on $25,000 bond; Charged via Information sheet; From Hunington Beach, California; Sentenced 12/7 to 35 days incarceration and $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Mark Steven Simon, 49, of Hunington Beach, California, has been charged with entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building or grounds, parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. Simon recorded himself in the Capitol building, saying "in the Capitol, baby, yeah!' and "2021 Donald Trump". Simon is known in Hunington Beach as rightist activist. Simon has a lengthy criminal history involving driving under the influence and drug usage, including accusations of methamphetamine and cocaine use, and pleading guilty in February 2019 to carrying a loaded unregistered gun in public.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News, News article

Name of case: United States of America v. Thomas Baranyi
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct at the Grounds and in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, and Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of NJ; Sentenced 6/17/22 to 90 days in jail, one year of supervised release, 60 hours of community service and $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Thomas Baranyi, 28, is facing charges of entering a restricted building or grounds and violent entry. He was identified by an interview he gave after leaving the Capitol where he showed Ahsli Babbitt's blood on his hands. In a Facebook post, Baranyi’s father said his son graduated from the College of New Jersey, joined the Peace Corps, and also went into basic training for the U.S. Marine Corps but was discharged. While in the Peace Corps, he worked with a team of international volunteers in a government-led youth project from 2018 to 2019. After the Peace Corps, Baranyi enlisted in the Marine Corps, in July 2020, but left active duty before completing entry-level training on Parris Island in South Carolina.
Source description: Charging Documents, local news, News Article, Governmental Reports and Release

Additional details: From Sacramento, CA: Charged by information; "Sentenced - 12/8/22 to 21 months of incarceration, 36 months of supervised release, $2,000 restitution"
Short narrative: Tommy Frederick Allan, 52, was charged for his role in the Jan. 6th Capitol riot with Theft of Government Property, Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress, Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Name of case: United States of America v. Gracyn Dawn Courtright
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1)(2) - Knowingly entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds, engaging in disorderly conduct in a restricted building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building; *18:641 - Theft of government property
Additional details: Resident of WV; Univ. of Kentucky student; took plea bargain; "Sentenced 12/17/21 to 30 days of incarceration, followed by 12 months of supervised release, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: On February 3, 2021, Gracyn Courtright, 23, of West Virginia, was charged with knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without law authority, knowingly engaging in disorderly or disruptive conduct in any restricted building or grounds, violent entry and disorderly conduct on capitol grounds, and theft of government property. Courtright entered the Capitol Building on January 6 in connection with the riots. Her actions were motivated by her rightist: anti-government beliefs. She took a plea bargain where she was only charged for entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds in violation of 18:1752(a)(1).
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and release, Local news articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Karl Dresch
Charges: *18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Objection of an Official Proceeding; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: $500 restitution, sentenced to 6 months
Short narrative: On February 2, 2021, Karl Dresch, 40, was originally charged with Objection of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his participation in the raid of the United States Capitol Building in Washington, DC. Dresch was discovered via a tip and was confirmed by Dresch's Facebook page where he posted extensively about his being inside the Capitol (photos, videos, and conversations with other users). "In their case against Dresch, federal prosecutors shared photographs posted on Facebook, including one with the title “We are in" that a U.S. Capitol police officer confirmed shows the inside of the U.S. Capitol Building. The photo shows "specifically, the 'Crypt,' a location under the rotunda in the center of the Capitol," according to a court filing. Dresch was inside the Capitol for approximately 25 minutes, entering through a door on the Senate side and exiting through a window." (The Detroit News) Dresch pled guilty to a misdemeanor, Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. All other charges were dismissed as part of the plea deal. He was sentenced to 6 months (time served) and required to pay $500 in restitution.
Source description: Court Documents, Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Release, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Josiah Benjamin Colt
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and Aiding and abetting; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Idaho District Court; Boogaloo affiliation; "Plea agreement hearing held 7/14 where Colt pleaded guilty to one count of obstruction of an official proceeding." (DOJ); Listed by crowd-sourced police project the Seditionist; "Josiah Colt Sentenced 5/10/23 to 15 months in prison for obstruction of an official proceeding, 36 months of supervised release and $1,000 in restitution."
Short narrative: Josiah Benjamin Colt, 34, of Meridian, Idaho, is charged federally with knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority and violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds. "[Colt] was allowed out of jail ahead of his trial as long as he abided by requirements including location monitoring, not possessing any guns or other weapons, and staying at least 1,000 feet away from both the Idaho Statehouse and the James A. McClure Federal Building, a judge ruled...Colt turned himself in to the FBI's Joint Terrorism Task Force at the Ada County Jail...FBI Special Agent Matthew J. Gano wrote in an affidavit that photos of Colt taken inside the Capitol Building and his own statements on social media prove he participated in the attempted insurrection, which was aimed at stopping lawmakers from certifying Joe Biden as the next president of the United States...The FBI agent noted that Colt also admitted to participating in the riot in a statement given to CBS News, in which he says he got "caught up in the moment" and was sorry for what he had done. (KTVB 7 news)"
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, News articles, Local news article, Governmental reports and release

Name of case: United States of America v. Crase & Williams
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of KY; "Sentenced 1/20/22 to 36 months of probation, including 15 days of incarceration, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Dalton Ray Crase and Troy Dylan Williams are charged with with Entering and Remaining in Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. A witness alerted the FBI to the men and both are photographed in numerous images in an around the Capitol. Both men also admitted to illegally being in the Capitol. The men told investigators they went inside the Capitol building after the doors were breached but didn’t participate in any violence or vandalism. Crase then said they both entered the Capitol building with several others after the riots started.

Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: From Wisconsin; charged by Bill of Information; Sentenced 3/15/22, three years of probation, including 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution; Pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building, in violation of Title 40, United States Code, Section 5104 (a)(e)(2)(G)
Short narrative: Kevin Daniel Loftus, 52, of WI, was initially charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his role in the January 6th riot. Loftus admitted to walking into the Capitol and taking several photos in an interview with the FBI. Additionally, pictures posted on Facebook and other social media sources of the man identified as Loftus holding an America flag and smiling inside the Capitol in the halls of Congress. The complaint shows social media comments by Loftus saying “One of 700 inside” and “That’s right folks some of us are in it to win it.” Loftus pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and was sentenced to three years of probation, including 60 hours of community service, and $500 restitution.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, Government reports and release, Local news articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Ayres & Perna
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:2 - Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: From PA; released on a $20,000 unsecured bond; "Sentenced 9/22/22 to 24 months of probation, 100 hours of community service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: On February 5, 2021, Stephen Michael Ayres and Matthew Perna were indicted on charges of Obstruction of Justice/Congress, Unlawful Entry into Restricted Buildings or Grounds, and Violent Entry or Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds. The two men attempted to obstruct members of congress as they were certifying President Joe Biden's election, and destroyed federal property in the process. Their actions were motivated by their rightist: government-focused ideology. Ayres and two other individuals made a video describing their experience inside the Capitol and then posted it to both Facebook and YouTube. Ayres pleaded not guilty to all counts.
Source description: Charging documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Lewis Easton Cantwell
Charges: 18:231(a)(3),2 Civil Disorder and Aiding and abetting; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building and Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building and Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Sylva, NC; "Sentenced - 12/6/22 to 5 months of incarceration, followed by 36 months of supervised release, $2,000 restitution"
Short narrative: Lewis Easton Cantwell, 35, of Sylva, NC, was arrested and charged for his connection with the January 6th, 2021 Capitol protests. Cantwell was charged with Civil Disorder and Aiding and abetting, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and abetting, Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building and Grounds, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building and Grounds, Parading, and Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Cantwell insists that he did not take part in the riot, didn't enter the Capitol building, didn't attend the rally, and was simply in the wrong place at the wrong time. However, Cantwell made several posts to social media that show himself present at the riot and suggest he did in fact hear Trump's speech and took part in the day's events. These posts have since been deleted. "According to an Army spokesperson, Cantwell is a U.S. Army veteran who served as an explosive ordnance disposal specialist at the rank of private from December 2005 to November 2007. He earned the Parachutist Badge during his time in the service" (Smoky Mountain News). This case is currently pending.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Robert Sanford

Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a deadly Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: Retired Firefighter; From Boothwyn, Pennsylvania; "Robert Sanford Sentenced 4/11/23 to 52 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, $2,000 restitution to the Architect of the Capitol and $3,798 in restitution to the medical expenses of the U.S. Capitol Police officer he injured."
Short narrative: January 2021, in Washington DC, Robert Sanford, 55, a retired firefighter from PA, is charged with Civil Disorder; Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a deadly Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; and Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building after his role in the January 6th insurrection. Sanford is alleged to have thrown a fire extinguisher at a group of police officers, striking three officers in the head.

Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and Aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building

Gold is the founder of America's Frontline Doctors, a right-wing political organization that has been spreading false information about Covid-19. Strand is the communications director for the organization.

He was calling for a revolution on his social mediaaccounts...[i]ndividual broke into the capitol building and is paid to promote propaganda on his website… Law enforcement agents retrieved a driver’s license photograph of both [STRAND and GOLD] both residents of California, and confirmed each were consistent in appearance with the pictures above…

Name of case: United States of America v. Jacob Lewis
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building (Misdemeanor); 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building (Misdemeanor); 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent and Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building (Misdemeanor)

Short narrative: Jacob Lewis, 37, from Victorville, California was charged for his role in the Capitol riots. Lewis posted videos of himself on Instagram from inside the Capitol. On 1/11/21 FBI received a telephone tip identifying Lewis from the defendant's friend. Lewis had previously asked this individual to get him ammunition after showing him pictures of guns he claimed to own. Lewis admitted entering the Capitol to interrogators be claims he was "escorted" by police and not prevented from entering. Lewis is shown in the court records wearing a red Trump winter hat. Lewis was charged with misdemeanor charges of entering and remaining in a restricted building, disorderly and disruptive in a restricted building, violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building.

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND State speech act
Name of case: States of Florida v. Peter Jacob Heneen
Charges: Florida Statute 836:10 Written threats to kill, do bodily injury, or conduct a mass shooting or an act of terrorism
Additional details: Resident of FL
Short narrative: A member of the Polk County Sheriff’s Office, Peter Heneen, has been placed under arrest for threats made regarding the violence at the U.S. Capitol. He has been arrested and charged with written threats to kill, do bodily injury, or conduct a mass shooting or an act of terrorism, which is a 2nd degree felony in Florida. A Sheriff says the charges stem from a private Facebook message conversation between Heneen and another PCSO officer which occured the evening of January 6, 2021 following the violent riots at the U.S. Capitol. Haneen had written multiple messages laced with profanity, violence and threats regarding the US Capitol, the FBI, and tyrants among other figures. In the messages, the other officer seemingly attempted to talk Heneen out of threats he made, but to no success. The intended target of Heneen's threats include members of the Federal Government, whom of which make up a population of the State of Florida.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v, Klete Derik Keller
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Former olympic swimmer; Resident of Colorado; Sentenced to 36 months probation, 6 months home confinement, and 10 hours community service
Short narrative: In 2021, in the District of Columbia, Klete Keller, 38, was charged by the FBI with Obstructing Law Enforcement Engaged In Official Duties Incident to Civil Disorder, Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority, and Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds. Keller took part in the raid on the U.S. Capitol on January 6th, 2021. A video shows Keller inside of the Capitol Building with other rioters wearing a U.S.A. written on the back and a "United States Olympic Team" badge on the front. Keller accepted a plea deal and was sentenced to 36 months probation, 6 months home confinement, and 10 hours community service.

Name of case: United States of America v. Tam Dinh Pham
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building (Misdemeanor); 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building (Misdemeanor); 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building (Misdemeanor); 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building (Misdemeanor)
Additional details: Former Houston Police officer (active at time of Jan 6th Raid, since resigned and facing disciplinary proceedings); Indicted via information sheet; Resident of Houston, Texas; Sentenced 12/10 to 45 days incarceration, $1,000 fine and $500 restitution.
Short narrative: On January 6th 2021, former Houston Police officer Tam Dinh Pham, 46, entered the Capitol Building in Washington DC, taking pictures of the rotunda and selfies in front of the protesting crowd. On January 10th these pictures were sent to the chief of Houston Police, and Pham was relieved of duty three days later. He was indicted via information sheet on January 19th after FBI agents found deleted images from the raid in his phone. Pham was charged with entering and remaining in a restricted building, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building, violent entry and conduct in a Capitol building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Robert Keith Packer
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2) - Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of VA; Indicted by Bill of Information; Seen wearing 'Camp Auschwitz' shirt on 1/6 and search warrant of home locates Nazi and white power items; Virginia court records show that Packer has a criminal history that includes three convictions for driving under the influence and a felony conviction for forgoing public records. In 2016, he was charged for trespassing, though the case was dismissed.; "Sentenced 9/15/22 to 75 days in jail, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Robert Packer, 56, is charged with Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building and Violent entry and disorderly conduct amidst the Capitol riot. Packer was the individual wearing the "camp Auschwitz" sweatshirt and was identified via photographs taken inside and outside the Capitol. His sweatshirt also included the phrase "Work Brings Freedom" which is a rough translation of, "Arbeti macht frei." These were German words that were welded onto an iron arch that stood over one of the gates of the death camp where millions of people were killed during World War II.
Source description: Charging documents, News article, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Joseph Foy
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and Aiding and abetting; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: USMC sergeant 2015-2019 as an engineer equip-ment manager but did noit deploy; "Michael Foy Found guilty 6/23/23 at a stipulated trial in the District of Columbia on Thursday, June 22, 2023, of two felony charges for his actions Jan. 6, 2021."; Sentenced To Concurrent Terms Of Forty (40) Months Incarceration as to Count(s) 1ss and 2s. The Defendant Is Further Sentenced To Serve Concurrent Twenty-Four (24) Months Terms Of Supervised Release as to Count 1ss and 2s. The Defendant Is Also Ordered To Pay A Special Assessment Of $200.00.
Short narrative: Michael Joseph Foy, 30, of Wixom, MI, was arrested in connection to the Jan.6 Capitol Protests in Washington, D.C. and charged with Civil disorder; Obstruction of an official proceeding and Aiding and abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; and an Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building. The FBI received a tip on its Twitter account that Foy killed a police officer by hitting him repeatedly with a hockey stick. While there was no evidence that Foy killed a police officer, the tip initiated investigating Foy. In a video of the riots the New York Times found, the FBI identified Foy beating an individual laying on the ground. He is a former marine who was caught on multiple videos beating multiple cops with a hockey stick.
Source description: Charging documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles, Database (NPR)

Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building (misdemeanor)
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of WI; Sentenced to $500 restitution; Pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building, in violation of Title 40, UnitedStates Code, Section 5104(e)(2)(G)
Short narrative: David Charles Mish Jr., 42, of WI, was arrested as part of the Jan 6th breach of the capitol building. Mish was initially charged with Entering and remaining in a restricted building; Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; Violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; and Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. Mish called the FBI to share information about the murder of Ashli Babbitt and was arrested because of the information he shared and pictures captured by media outlets. He was part of the first group to enter the building. Mish took a plea deal, and pled guilty to Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. Mish was sentenced to 30 days incarceration and $500 restitution.
Source description: Court Documents, Charging Documents, Local News, Governmental Reports and Release

Other names/aliases: Doobie Smoker; Alvear Gonzalez Eduardo Nicolas; Nicolas Alvear
Name of case: United States of America v. Eduardo Nicolas Alvear Gonzalez
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Expressed support for QAnon. Charged via Information sheet; From Ventura, California; pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 3/3/2022 to two years of probation, including 200 hours of community service, $1,000 fine, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: In 2021, Eduardo Nicolas Alvear Gonzalez (A.K.A. Doobie Smoker, Alvear Gonzalez Eduardo Nicolas, Nicolas Alvear), 32, of Ventura, California was charged with entering and remaining in restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. "Multiple witnesses tipped the FBI identifying Alvear Gonzalez, reporting social media posts and a Zoom video he broadcast on the day after the riot, narrating photos and videos from inside the Capitol. When the video showed him breaking into the west side of the Capitol with other rioters, according to court documents, he said: 'We're taking our country back.' Wearing a pair of America flag printed pants, he recorded video of himself yelling 'time to smoke weed in here' and handed the camera to someone to record him smoking in the Capitol, the FBI stated. The documents also show he said he smoked three 'joints' and discovered he had an additional eight, some of which he shared with other rioters. In the video, Alvear Gonzalez explains he has "gnarlier footage on Twitter" and shows the account profile for his Good Lion Films, the FBI stated. That Twitter account posted pro Trump messages before and after the riot, and shared videos during the Capitol riot. At 9:14 p.m. on Jan. 6, the account tweeted: "last tweet. What a day. One last time ... we were livid. We were encouraged. People saw we wanted to get in, and they pushed us further and cheered us on. Glass was broken, offices were barged into, Pelosi's pen was stolen, Anger was let out with screams. People got hurt" (USA Today).
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Article

Strong strongly adheres to Qanon ideology stating he had "Q clearance" and that World War III was going to occur on Jan. 6th, flying a flag that read "WWG1WGA", which is a Qanon slogan for "where we go one we all go". Strong was identified via two witnesses and numerous photographs and written communication from Strong himself demonstrating that he was illegally inside the US Capitol.

Name of case: United States of America v. Brian McCreary
Charges: *18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Sentenced 4/1/22 to 36 months of probation, including 42 days of intermittent incarceration and two months of home detention, $2,500 fine, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: On February 17th, 2021, Brian McCreary was indicted on charges of 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (2) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building following his involvement in the January 6th Capitol Riot. McCreary plead guilty to Charge 2 of the indictment. Sentencing INformation is pending. "A Domino's Pizza employee, McCreary told a co-worker that he raided the Capitol and sent multiple videos of rioters inside the building, the FBI stated in court documents. McCreary is seen in several photos next to the horned, fur hat-wearing Jacob Chansley. The FBI said McCreary reported he traveled to D.C. for the rally because he was frustrated an audit wasn't performed to address allegations of fraud in the 2020 election. McCreary told the FBI that because the activity "felt like Antifa" he was trying to take pictures and document crimes. The FBI stated he admitted leaving the building after being asked to by an officer and then re-entering through a different door. (USA Today)"
Source description: Charging documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Joshua Matthew Black
Charges: *18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Dangerous or Deadly Weapon; *18:1752(a)(3) and (b)(1)(A) and 2 Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; 40:5104(e)(1)(A) Unlawful Possession of a Dangerous Weapon on Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(A) Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(E) and 2 Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings and Aiding and Abetting
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of AL; Sentenced 5/16/23 to 22 months in prison for three felony charges and two misdemeanors, 24 months of supervised release and restitution of $2,000; Arrested in Northern Alabama on 1/14/2021; "Found guilty 1/13/23 after a trial in the U.S. District Court in the District of Columbia of entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; unlawful possession of a dangerous weapon on Capitol grounds or buildings; entering and remaining on the floor of Congress; and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building.";
Short narrative:
Joshua Matthew Black, 44 of Alabama, was found guilty at trial of Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Unlawful Possession of a Dangerous Weapon on Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building. He was sentenced to 22 months incarceration for his role in the January 6 Capitol raid. Hit in the face with a projectile from police during the protests causing a gouge in his cheek but refused treatment from Capitol officials. He took a knife into the Capitol, according to the DOJ.

"Joshua Black was photographed as part of a group of rioters who made it inside the Senate chamber. In the photos, he is wearing a camouflage jacket and yellow gloves and seems to be bleeding from his left cheek, according to court documents. Two days after the Capitol attack, he uploaded a video to YouTube detailing his account of the insurrection. "There was a glass door, and it said ‘U.S. Senate’ on it. I said I need to get in there," Black says in the video, which is detailed in the court documents, "So I was about to break the glass, and I thought, 'No, this is our house — we don’t act like that.' I was tempted to, I’m not gonna lie. 'Cause I’m pretty upset, you know? They stole my country.” Once inside the chamber, he says, he "praised the name of Jesus on the Senate floor." More than 24 hours after the insurrection, then-President Donald Trump condemned the Capitol riot and called it a "heinous attack," in a video on social media. Black, in his own video, mentions seeing Trump's denunciation. "I guess the hopes of getting a pardon are out the window,” Black says." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News Articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Felipe Marquez
Charges: *18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(C) Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Florida; Plea agreement entered 9/10/21 and pleaded guilty to count 3; Sentenced 12/10 to 18 months probation, including three months of home detention, and $500 restitution
Short narrative: Felipe Marquez, 25, was arrested and charged with knowingly entering the Capitol Building or the grounds of it without lawful authority as well as violent entry and disorderly conduct with regards to the January 6, 2021 Capitol protests. According to the South Florida Sun Sentinel, Marquez made his way up to Washington, D.C., for planned rallies in support of former President Donald Trump on Jan. 6. Throughout the trip, Marquez, 25, shot a series of clips on Snapchat while driving his Tesla and vaping. A longtime ride-share driver, Marquez said he went to D.C. to protest the “normalization of prostitution” and Communism. He said he became a Trump supporter after learning more about economic disparities between races and policies that he believed helped close them. He felt dismayed by the way Trump was treated in office. “I feel Trump was done like Richard Nixon but to a greater scale.” In D.C., Marquez uploaded clips of himself participating in outdoor rallies. Before entering the Capitol Building, Marquez uploaded a clip showing people scaling a wall on the building, according to his criminal complaint. In his very next video, he is inside a private office belonging to Sen. Jeff Merkley, of Oregon. He smokes his vape pen and shows off his red “Keep America Great” hat. On 9/10/21, Marquez pled guilty to Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds and was sentenced to 18 months probation, including three months of home detention, and $500 restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Government reports and release, Local news article

Everybody followed us" (affidavit). Daughtry posted multiple times on Facebook, explaining his preperation and intent to travel to the Capitol, as well as "anti-liberal" views.

Short narrative: Benjamin Henry Torre, of GA, was charged with Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority and Violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds following his participation in the Capitol riot. Torre was identified via a tip provided to the FBI and photos/videos taken from inside the Capitol.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Derek Jancart
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a Restricted Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Charged by Bill of Information; Sentenced to 45 days incarceration and $500 restitution
Short narrative: On February 23, 2021, Derek Jancart was indicted for his participation in the Capitol riot on charges of *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Jancart was identified via a photograph taken inside the US Capitol that he posted to his personal Facebook account with the caption "we're in." as well as two tipsters identifying Jancart in images from bodycams. He plead guilty to Count Three of the Information, Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, in violation of Title 40, United States Code, Section 5104(e)(2)(D), and was sentenced to 45 days incarceration and $500 restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Jacob G. Hiles
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Charged by Bill of Information; Released on a personal recognizance bond; Sentenced to a term of 24 months of probation. Special Assessment of $10.00, and Restitution in the amount of $500.00 were imposed.
Short narrative: On February 24th, 2021, Virginian, Jacob Hiles, who wrote "Feeling cute... might start a revolution later, IDK - in Capitol Hill" was indicted for breaking and entering into the Capitol building on Jan 6, 2021. Hiles was charged with *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building and plead guilty to count 4. He was sentenced to 24 months probation, $10 special assessment, and $500 restitution.

Name of case: United States of America v. Jorden Robert Mink
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:641 - Theft of government property; 18:1361 - Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain officers;
Additional details: Defendant remains committed; Resident of PA; "Jordan Mink Sentenced, 6/2/23 to 51 months in prison for assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon, a felony, theft of government property, and aiding and abetting and 36 months of supervised release and restitution of $2,000."
Short narrative: On January 15, 2021, FBI Pittsburgh Division received a tip that an individual by the name of Jorden Mink was depicted in images that show the unlawful, violent entry into the Capitol building and the destruction and theft of property on the exterior and interior of the building and grounds on January 6, 2021. Mink was seen spitting on officers and weilding a flagpole, in addition to breaking 2 windows of the capitol building with a baseball bat. . Mink was indicted via superseding indictment on February 24th, 2021 on charges of 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:641 - Theft of government property; 18:1361 - Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain officers. Mink pleaded not guilty to all counts and sentencing information is pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. James Douglas Rham, Jr.
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2) Obstruction of Justice/Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of NJ; Son also arrested; Rahm was initially arrested Feb. 5, but the statement of facts accompanying that warrant wasn't released until three weeks later. Court documents show he was released on a $100,000 bond with the stipulation that he submit to random drug testing and refrain from excessive use of alcohol.; "James Rahm Jr Found guilty 10/13/22 at bench trial in which both sides agreed to a set of stipulated facts. Charges included obstruction of an official proceeding, a felony, and four related misdemeanor offenses, including entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly or disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building."
Short narrative: On February 24th, 2021, James Douglas Rham, Jr. of New Jersey, was indicted on charges of 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2) Obstruction of Justice/Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. According to FBI case notes, Rahm allegedly wrote to a friend that he "pissed in her [Nancy Pelosi's] office." Rahm pleaded not guilty to the charges and sentencing information is pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles, Governmental Reports and Release
