Name of case: United States of America v. Thompson & Lyon
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2),2- Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:641,2- Theft of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752 (a)(1)&(2) - Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds ; 18:1752 (a) (2)- Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D)- Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 5104 (e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of OH; Defendant remains on recognizance; "Sentenced 9/22/2022, 40 days of incarceration, one year of supervised release, $1,000 fine, $2,000 restitution"
Short narrative: Dustin Byron Thompson, 36, and Robbery Anthony Lyon, 27, of Ohio, were stopped by two US Capitol Police agents due to their attire indicating they had participated in the recent riot. When the USCP agents directed Thompson and Lyon to a location where an Uber could pick them up, Thompson picked up a coat rack behind him that appeared to have been taken from the inside Capitol building. When the agents noticed this, Thompson fled on foot and escaped, but Lyon was cooperative, identified Thompson, and later consented to providing photos, videos, and text messages on his phone from the event. Thompson and Lyon had decided to drive together from Ohio to Maryland the day before the riot to participate. Thompson and Lyon are charged with knowingly entering or remaining in restricted building/grounds without lawful authority, violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds, and theft of government property.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Kuehne, et. al.
Charges: 18:371 Conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and abetting; 18:231(a)(3)(2) Obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder and Aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds and carrying a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds and carrying a deadly or dangerous weapon
Additional details: Proud Boys Kansas Chapter; Resident of Jackson County, Missouri; "Louis Enrique Colon (Proud Boy) Sentenced 7/9/24 to twenty-four (24) months probation (with conditions), $100.00 Special Assessment and Restitution in the amount of $2000.00."
Short narrative: February, 2021, in DC, Proud Boy members Ryan Keith Ashlock, 21, William Norman Chrestman, 47, siblings Felicia Konold, 26 and Cory Konold, 25, Louis Enrique Colon, 44, and Christopher Charles Kuehne, 47, all Kansas Chapter Proud Boys member, have been indicted together and charged with Conspiracy; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and aiding and abetting; Obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder and aiding and abetting; Threatening a Federal officer; Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds and carrying a deadly or dangerous weapon; Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds and carrying a deadly or dangerous weapon. In addition, Chrestman has also been charged with Threatening a Federal Officer. Numerous photos depict the group participating in the march with the Proud Boys on Constitution Ave. as well as interacting with other known Proud Boys members just before the Capitol was breached. Kuehne is a retired Marine Corps officer after 22 years of service. Chrestman is a veteran of the US army. The Konold siblings are from Arizona.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental reports and release, News Article, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Christian Alexander Secor
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; *18:231(a)(3), 2 Civil Disorder; *18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(A) Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; *40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; *40:5104(e)(2)(C) Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of CA; "Sentenced 10/19/22 to 42 months in prison, three years of supervised release, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: Christian Alexander Secor, 22 of California, pled guilty to Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and was sentenced to 42 months of incarceration. On January 6, Secor entered the Capitol through the Senate doors, entered House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's office, and sat in Vice President Mike Pence's chair on the Senate Floor. He was also charged with assaulting police officers within the Capitol, but this charge and others were later dropped. He made prior comments about civil war and wrote on his Twitter account that "We're legit in the Turner Diaries timeline." He was a UCLA student at the time of the riot and wore a red Make America Great Again hat and carried an America First flag. "The FBI said Secor is a self-identified Groyper, a network of "alt right figures who are vocal supporters of white supremacist and 'America First' podcaster Nick Fuentes. The FBI stated a tipster reported Secor founded the campus organization "America First Bruins" and is a member of Bruins Republicans. The FBI stated Secor can be seen in a group of rioters pushing their way into the building. Court documents state a tipster told the FBI that Secor moved back in with his mother after the riot, got rid of his phone and car and bragged that he would not be caught for his involvement." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Robert Maurice Reeder
Charges: 18:1752(a)(l) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Indicted by Bill of Information; Sentenced to 3 months imprisonment and $500 restitution
Short narrative: Robert Maurice Reeder was wearing a red Make America Great Again hat and chanted: "Fight for Trump" as he approached an open door in the Capitol. He's heard on the video asking an officer for water, with the officer directing him outside, the court record stated. But Reeder entered the building, and video captures him shouting at people not to destroy anything. Court documents indicate Reeder's video compilation showed he roamed around in the Capitol, possibly going out and back in again, for more than 90 minutes. At the end of the video, he recorded himself saying he'd been in for more than half an hour and had been gassed several times inside the building and many times outside. He has pled guilty to count four of his charges, parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building, allowing prosecutors to not prosecute on the further charges.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Bissey & Morgan-Lloyd
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a Restricted Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Charged by Bill of Information; Sentenced to 36 months probation, 120 hours of community service, $500 in restitution; Connection to QAnon is not well established - friend of Dona Sue Bisey a strong QAnon follower
Short narrative: On March 3rd, 2021, Dona Sue Bissey, 52, and Anna Morgan-Lloyd, 49, of Bloomington, Indiana, were indicted after going to the Capitol riot together, posting photos tagging each other on Facebook and interacting in the comment section. Two confidential witnesses identified the two women and submitted tips to the FBI about Bissey and Morgan-Lloyd's attendance and participation in the riot. Morgan-Lloyd was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. She took a plea deal, pleading guilty to Count Four of the Information: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Morgan-Lloyd was sentenced to 36 months probation, 120 hours of community service, $500 in restitution, but no jail time.
Source description: Charging documents, Local News Article

Bissey was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Name of case: United States of America v. James Allen Mels
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Shelby Township, MI; Charged via Indictment sheet; "Sentenced 10/28/22 to 36 months of probation, including 90 days of home detention, 60 hours of community service, $500 in restitution."
Short narrative: James Allen Mels, 56, of Shelby Township, MI, was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building, for his involvement in the January 6th protest. Mels took pictures of himself within the Capitol building; additionally, a long-time associate of Mels submitted a tip to the FBI concerning Mels' involvement in the January 6th protest. Mels has pled not guilty. This case is currently pending.

Other names/aliases: dan.egtvedt (FaceBook), dane0039 (Pinterest), DanEgtvedt (Twitter), danegtvedt (LinkedIn), Daniel Egtvedt
Name of case: United States of America v. Daniel Dean Egtvedt
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain officers; 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: " Bench Trial 12/16/22 Directed verdict of Guilty as to Counts 1s-6s and 8s. Directed verdict of Not Guilty as to Counts 7s and 9s." Sentencing to be conducted 3/16/2023
Short narrative: Daniel Dean Egtvedt, 57, was charged with violating 18:111(a)(1); 18:231(a)(3); 18:1512(c)(2); 18:l752(a)(1), (2), and (4); 40:5l04(e)(2)(D) and (F) following his participation in the Capitol riot in Washington DC on January 6th, 2021. Egtvedt was continuously noncompliant as officers attempted to remove him from the Capitol building and his behavior was caught on cameras inside the Capitol, on officers' bodycams, and at least one livestream video another rioter filmed during the raid. He was seen taking swipes and grabbing at several officers as they tried to remove him from the Capitol.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Daniel Ray Caldwell
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol; 40:5104 (e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
Additional details: Sentencing to be conducted 2/1/2023; History of anti-Black racist activity and speech
Short narrative: Daniel Ray Caldwell, 49, was charged with Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers or employees; Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; and Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds following his participation in the Capitol riot. Caldwell was identified through numerous video sources showing him spraying several federal officers with mace.

Costianes, 42, was charged with Obstruction of Congress; Unlawful Entry on Restricted Buildings or Grounds; and Violent Entry, Disorderly Conduct, and Other Offenses on Capitol Grounds for his involvement in the Capitol riots in Washington DC on January 6th, 2021. Name of case: United States of America v. Steve Omar Maldonado
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) - Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Next court date is 3/27/2023
Short narrative: Steve Omar Maldonado, 40, was arrested and charged for his involvement in the Capitol riots in Washington DC on January 6th, 2021. Security footage from inside and outside the Capitol showed Maldonado entering multiple areas of the building. The FBI also obtained videos Maldonado recorded himself, showing him inside of the Capitol. Maldonado was charged with entering and remaining in restricted buildings or grounds and violent entry or disorderly conduct and parading, demonstrating or picketing on capitol grounds. He pleaded not guilty and his trial is still ongoing.
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Joseph Cable Barnes
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official proceeding18:1752(a)(1) and (2) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Case dropped 7/6/21 after defendant's 6/12/21 death in a motorcycle crash, Austin, TX
Short narrative: Joseph Barns, a real estate executive from Austin Texas, was charged relating to his role in the Jan 6, 2021 Capitol building protests. According to CNN, Barnes was "dressed in a dark beanie and an America flag gaiter around his neck inside the Capitol building in footage captured by British broadcaster ITV News...[and] seen yelling: "This is our house! This is our country! This is our country!"" He died in a motorcycle crash June 2021 and the case was not prosecuted.

The government intends to dismiss that case should this court authorize the complaint requested in connection with this statement of facts." [NOTE: see associated case 01072021_DAB]

Name of case: United States of America v. Paul Allard Hodgkins
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of FL; 2nd conviction of Capitol cases; 1st to be sentenced to jail time; 24 months supervised release, $2000 restitution
Short narrative: Hodgkins was identified to federal agents by a confidential witness who provided a photo of Hodgkins inside the senate chamber which had been posted on Parler. According to an agreed upon set of facts presented in court, Hodgkin traveled to DC from Tampa, FL via bus, wore a Trump t-shirt, carried a Trump 2020 flag, and in his backpack carried protective eyewear and latex gloves.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Greg Rubenacker
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a capitol building 40:5104(e)(2)(e) Impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of NY; Sentenced 5/22/22 to 41 months in prison, three years of supervised release, $2,000 restitution
Short narrative: ""America, baby. What a time," Greg Rubenacker said to the camera as he filmed a Snapchat clip while vaping inside the Capitol rotunda, according to the FBI. One of Rubenacker's acquaintances saw the Snapchat story he created from video clips and alerted the FBI. In another clip, Rubenacker, a DJ, was with a group of people smoking marijuana in the rotunda. Court documents show he looked into the camera and said: "Smoke out the Capitol, baby." (USA Today)" He was charged with 10 counts related to his activity in the January 2021 Capitol protests.
Source description: Charging documents, News Articles, Local News, Governmental Reports and Release

No Fine Imposed. Total Special Assessment is $605.00."
Short narrative: Oregon man, Richard Lee Harris, 40, was charged federally in connection to the Capitol cases. According to his father, Harris is not affiliated with far-right groups such as the Proud Boys or the Oath Keepers.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Ryan Scott Zink
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Son of congressional candidate Jeff Zink; resident of Lubbock, TX; "Ryan Scott Zink, 34, of Lubbock, Texas, was found guilty 9/13/23 after a jury trial in U.S. District Court. Zink was convicted of obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting, a felony offense, as well as two misdemeanor offense of entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds and disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds."
Short narrative: In 2021, Ryan Scott Zink, 32, of Lubbock, TX, son of congressional candidate, Jeff Zink, was charged with Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building following his participation in the Capitol riot. Zink was identified via a tip provided to the FBI and subsequently numerous videos taken by Zink himself which clearly place Zink at the riot, and multiple Facebook posts from Zink detailing his experience in the Capitol. In one of the videos Zink says "We knocked down the gates! We're storming the Capitol! You can't stop us" (statement of facts). "Zink posted videos on Facebook discussing his participation in the riot, the FBI stated in court documents, including one in which he states: 'We knocked down the gates! We're storming the Capitol! You can't stop us.' He could also be heard in a video urging listeners to storm their own state capitols, the FBI stated. In a private message, documents show Zink stated: 'Broke down the doors, pushed Coungress out of session I took two flash bangs I'm ok I'll be posting pictures in a little bit when we get back I'm hurt but we accomplished the job'" (USA Today). Jeff Zink has articulated that he did not participate in the riot with his son.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, Government reports and release, News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Zachary Jordan Alam
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; 18:231(a)(3) and 2 Civil disorder and Aiding and abetting; 18:1361 Destruction of government property; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and Aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and remaining in a restricted building with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: From D.C.
Short narrative: Zachary Jordan Alam, 29, was charged with Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Destruction of Government Property; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his participation in the Capitol riot. Alam was identified via surveillance footage which shows Alam illegally inside the US Capitol and shows him breaking a glass panel, kicking and punching it, and hitting it with a helmet. Alam also pushed his body against one of the officers guarding the Speaker’s Lobby door as the crowd began shouting obscenities at police. Alam's participation was also confirmed by several anonymous tips from family members of Alam.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental reports and release (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Jackson Kostlosky
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry and disorderly conduct and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Released on $250,000 bail; "Sentenced 1/11/22 to three years of probation, including 30 days of home detention, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: On March 9, 2021, Jackson Kostolsky, 32, was charged with multiple federal offenses for his activites at the United States Capitol Building on January 6, 2021, after he was identified to the FBI by numerous witnesses. Kostolsky was found to have scaled the wall of the Capitol's West Terrace, entered the building, and taken a video inside--which he later deleted. He also took several videos and photos while outside on the grounds; some of these he offered up to law enforcement during an interview, and others were obtained by them later.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Troy Anthony Smocks
Charges: 18:875(c) Threats in Interstate Communications; *18:875(c) Threats in Interstate Communications
Additional details: Resident of Dallas, TX; Three years of supervised release in addition to sentence; Smocks has previous felony charges including bank fraud, and impersonating an officer or US employee
Short narrative: Troy Anthony Smocks, 58, of Dallas, TX, was charged with two charges of threats in Interstate Communications for his post threats on the social media app, Parler, during the January 6th riot. The posts "included that he and others would return to the U.S. Capitol on January 19, 2021, carrying weapons and massing in numbers so large that no army could match them. Smocks threatened that he and others would 'hunt these cowards down like the Traitors that each of them are,' specifically threatening 'RINOS, Dems, and Tech Execs' (DOJ Press Release). Smock initially pled not guilty to the charges, but later pled guilty in exchange for one of the charges to be dropped. Smocks was found guilty and was sentenced to 14 months of incarceration with three years of supervised release.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and releases (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Deborah Sandoval, Salvador Sandoval Jr.
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder [3 counts]; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain officers [3 counts]; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of IA; Mother also arrested; "Salvador Sandoval Found guilty 12/16/22 of four counts of assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers for assaulting Metropolitan Police Department (MPD) officers; one count of obstruction of an official proceeding; one count of civil disorder; and the following misdemeanors: entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building; and parading demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. The verdict followed a bench trial, yesterday, before U.S. District Judge Thomas Hogan." 36 months of supervised release and ordered to pay $2k in restitution.
Short narrative: On March 9, 2021, in Washington D.C., Deborah Sandoval, of Iowa, age 54, was charged with obstruction of an official proceeding; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. Her son, Salvador Sandoval Jr., of Iowa, age 23, was charged alongside her on allegations of civil disorder [3 counts]; assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers [3 counts]; obstruction of an official proceeding; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building; and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. The two entered the Capitol Building during the January 6 riots. During these events, Salvador pushed two Metropolitan Police Officers and wrestled for control of a third officer’s riot shield. The two were motivated by their rightist: anti-government ideology.
Source description: Local News, Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Suarez & Todisco
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(C) - Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Sentenced 7/12/22 to 36 months probation, $2,000 fine, $500 restitution, 60 hours community service
Short narrative: Patricia Todisco and Marissa A. Suarez traveled together to DC and were both arrested and charged with 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(C) - Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building for their role in the Capitol protests on Jan 6, 2021. Both women plead guilty to the count of Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and were each sentenced on 7/12/22 to 36 months probation, $2,000 fine, $500 restitution, 60 hours community service. Suarez is a probationary corrections officer at Monmouth County Corrections Facility (the "MCCF").

Name of case: United States of America v. Martin, et al.
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Indicted via Information sheet; from Springfield, Missouri; Sentenced 3/17/22, 36 months of probation, $1,000 fine, 60 hours of community service.
Short narrative: In 2021, Zachary Hayes Martin, a.k.a. Zac Martin, of Springfield, MO is accused of participating in the 1/6/21 siege of the US Capitol. Martin was identified by an individual who saw his public social media posts (including a livestream) and alerted the FBI. At least two additional witnesses identified Martin from his livestream, and a fourth witness told the FBI that Martin had told them of his plans to travel to DC beforehand. Martin is charged with two federal counts: being on restricted buildings or grounds; as well as unlawful activities on Capitol grounds including disorderly conduct or demonstrating in the U.S. Capitol. Martin was charged via information sheet along with brothers Michael Aaron Quick, Stephen Brian Quick, and Kari Dawn Kelley with entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building or grounds, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building, although they did not conspire to enter the Capitol together (excluding the Quick brothers). It appears there is no connection between these four individuals beyond the siblings.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Other (FBI Social Media, Twitter)

Name of case: United States of America v. Jonathan Gennaro Mellis
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a deadly Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(3) and (b)(1)(A) - Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(E) - Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: Resident of VA; "Jonathan Mellis Sentenced 12/20/23 to 51 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $20,000 in fines"
Short narrative: "The FBI found a trove of information on Mellis' Facebook page, according to court documents. He posted "Storming the castle. The world heard US!!! Finally not ignored." A screen shot shows he also posted the following: "Don't you dare try to tell me that people are blaming this on antifa and BLM. We proudly take responsibility for storming the Castle." Mellis is seen in photos and videos, including one where the FBI concluded he appeared to be striking or trying to strike officers with a large stick between their helmets and body armor, where they weren't protected, which would be "more than sufficient to cause serious physical injury or death." Two tipsters told the FBI that Mellis had posted on social media with increasing frequency about the politics and media coverage around the presidential election." (USA Today) Jonathan Gennaro Mellis was arrested on 2/26/21 and indicted on 3/10/21 following his involvement in the January 6th Capitol raid. Mellis pleaded Not Guilty to all counts of the indictment and had a status hearing on 4/28/21. He has a status conference hearing scheduled for 6/16/2021 at 2 pm and remains committed. Sentencing details are pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Releases, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Leo Brent Bozell IV
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1361, 2 Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Son of prominent conservative media pundit Leo Brent Bozell III; "Leo Bozell Found guilty 9/8/23 of 10 charges, including five felonies. The verdict followed a bench trial before U.S. District Judge John D. Bates, who scheduled a sentencing hearing for January 9, 2024."; "Brent Bozell IV Sentenced 5/17/24 to Forty-Five (45) months on each of Counts 1s, 3s, 4s and 5s; Twelve (12) months on each of Counts 2s, 6s and 7s; andSix (6) months on each of Counts 8s, 9s and 10s. All terms of imprisonment to run concurrently. Defendant also sentenced to Supervised Release of Twenty-Four (24) months on Counts 1s, 3s, 4s and 5s and Twelve (12) months on Counts 8s, 9s and 10s, all terms of supervised release to run concurrently. Special assessment of $100 on each of Counts 1s, 3s, 4s and 5s, $25 on each of Counts 2s, 6s and 7s, $10 on each of Counts 8s, 9s and 10s (for a total of $505). Restitution in the amount of $4729.00."
Short narrative: On March 12, 2021, Leo Brent Bozell IV, 41, was formally charged with Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Destruction of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his participation in the January 6 U.S. Capitol riots. Bozell, the son of conservative media pundit Leo Brent Bozell III, was seen in photos entering the Senate chamber and jumping from the Senate balcony. Bozell remains on personal recognizance, and all further updates regarding his case are pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Additional details: From Swoyerville, PA
Short narrative: Annie C. Howell, of Swoyerville, PA, was charged with Obstruction of an Official Proceeding, Aiding and Abetting, Entering and Remainingin a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Capitol Building, Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol building for her role in the Jan. 6th protests. A Facebook group chat shows Howell refusing to leave the building. In a separate Facebook conversation, Howell's father warned her to “'Stay off the clouds!'" (York Daily Record). Additionally, videos filmed by Howell of her participation were submitted by tipsters.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local news articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Chad Barrett Jones
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) and 2 Civil disorder and aiding and abetting; 18:1361 Destruction of government property exceeding $1,000; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and remaining in a restricted building with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in Capitol
Additional details: Resident of Coxs Creek, KY; "Chad Jones Found guilty 7/26/23 of all nine charges against him following a bench trial."
Short narrative: Chad Barret Jones, 42, from Coxs Creek, Kentucky was charged for his role in the January 6, 2021 Capitol protests. A criminal affidavit describes video footage showing Jones in a red hooded jacket and gray skullcap from inside the capitol forcefully striking the glass door panels leading to the Speaker's Lobby at least 10 times with a long wood flagpole. A U.S. Capitol Police officer inside the Speakers’ Lobby, facing the door with a gun raised, can be seenin the video in the close vicinity of the doorway. The window broken by Jones was the same window Ashli Babbitt tried to climb through before she was shot by Capitol police. The case is still pending. Jones has pleaded not guilty to all 9 charges.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Khater & Tanios
Charges: *18:372 Conspiracy to Impede or Injure an Officer; *18:111(a)(1)(b) and 2 Assault on a Federal Officer with a Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; *18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1), (b)(1)(A), (b)(1)(B) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Causing Significant Bodily Injury; 18:1752(a)(2), (b)(1)(A), (b)(1)(B) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Causing Significant Bodily Injury; *18:1752(a)(4), (b)(1)(A), (b)(1)(B) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Causing Significant Bodily Injury; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: Sentenced to time served, $500 resitution, 12 months supervised release, 100 hours community service; Resident of Morgantown, WV
Short narrative: On March 17th, 2021, Julian Elie Khater and George Pierre Tanios were indicted as a result of their involvement in the January 6th Capitol Riot. The DOJ states that "according to the affidavit in support of the criminal complaint, Khater and Tanios were at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and were observed in video footage working together to assault law enforcement officers with an unknown chemical substance by spraying officers directly in the face and eyes. " The duo is specifically tied to the injuries sustained by Brian Sicknick, a capitol police officer who died as a result of those injuries. In the indictment, Khater and Tanios are charged with Conspiracy to Impede or Injure an Officer; Assault on a Federal Officer with a Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Causing Significant Bodily Injury; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Causing Significant Bodily Injury; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Causing Significant Bodily Injury; and Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building. Tanios accepted a plea deal pleading guilty to a bill of information of two counts and was sentenced to time served.
Source description: Court Documents, News Articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Matthew Mark Wood
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of NC; Pleaded guilty 5/27/22; "Sentenced 11/28/22 to three years of probation, including 12 months of home detention, 100 hours of community service, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: Following his involvement in the January 6th insurrection, Matthew Mark Wood was charged with 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Wood pleaded guilty 5/27/22, but the plea agreement has not yet been released. "On Jan. 25, Matthew Mark Wood called the FBI to identify himself in one of the wanted photographs the bureau had released. Wood told the FBI that he was inside the U.S. Capitol building and inside House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's office, though he said he was pushed toward a window and entered the building only to avoid being trampled, according to court documents. An FBI review of videos from the riot indicate Wood was inside the building for a little more than an hour. On Jan. 6, Wood posted twice on his since-deactivated Facebook account. "Our election was stolen. The system is against us. I stood up to our tyrannical government," he wrote. "We sent those politicians running. We sent a resounding message to Washington."" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governemntal Reports and Releases, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Treniss Jewell Evans III
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of TX; Pleaded guilty 3/10/22; "Sentenced 11/21/22 to 36 months of probation, including 20 days of intermittent incarceration, $5,000 fine, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Treniss Jewell Evans, III, of Canyon Lake, was arrested and charged for his role in the Capitol Insurrection in January 2021. Evans was charged with 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Buildingand pleaded guilty on 3/10/22 to 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. Evans was seen taking shots of fireball while in Nanci Pelosi's office once inside the building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governemntal Reports and Releases, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Christopher Patrick Moynihan
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(A) Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of NY; "Moynihan Found guilty by the Court on 8/23/22 of obstruction of an official proceeding, after admitting to a stipulated set of facts. Defendant also pleaded guilty to five related misdemeanor charges"; "entenced 2/1/23 to 21 months in prison. 36 months of supervised release and restitution of $2,000."
Short narrative: On March 17, 2021, Christopher Patrick Moynihan, 30, was formally charged for his participation in the US Capitol riots on January 6, 2021. Witnesses who entered the Senate floor with Moynihan stated that he snapped photos of election documents, hoping to "find something we can use against these fucking scumbags" (NBC New York, 2021). Moynihan has pleaded not guilty to all counts, and remains on personal recognizance.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Khater & Tanios
Charges: *18:372 Conspiracy to Impede or Injure an Officer; 18:111(a)(1)(b) and 2 [2 counts]; Assault on a Federal Officer with a Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; *18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; *18:1752(a)(1), (b)(1)(A), (b)(1)(B) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Causing Significant Bodily Injury; *18:1752(a)(2), (b)(1)(A), (b)(1)(B) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Causing Significant Bodily Injury; *18:1752(a)(4), (b)(1)(A), (b)(1)(B) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Causing Significant Bodily Injury; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: sentenced to $2000 restitution, a fine of $10000, and 36 months of supervised release; Resident of PA
Short narrative: On March 17th, 2021, Julian Elie Khater and George Pierre Tanios were indicted as a result of their involvement in the January 6th Capitol Riot. The DOJ states that "according to the affidavit in support of the criminal complaint, Khater and Tanios were at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and were observed in video footage working together to assault law enforcement officers with an unknown chemical substance by spraying officers directly in the face and eyes. " The duo is specifically tied to the injuries sustained by Brian Sicknick, a capitol police officer who died as a result of those injuries. In the indictment, Khater and Tanios are charged with Conspiracy to Impede or Injure an Officer; Assault on a Federal Officer with a Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Causing Significant Bodily Injury; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Causing Significant Bodily Injury; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Causing Significant Bodily Injury; and Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building. Khater pleaded guilty to counts two and three of the indictment and was sentenced to 80 months in prison.
Source description: Court Documents, News Articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND Supports organized political violence
Name of case: United States of America v. Andrew Ryan Bennett
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Arrested 1/21/21; Pled guily to single misdemeanor; "Sentenced 10/1 to two years of probation, the first three months of which are to be served in home confinement; $500 restitution to the Architect of the Capitol; 80 hours of community service."
Short narrative: Andrew Ryan Bennett, a Columbia, Maryland Proud Boy, "Live Streamed from inside the Capitol on Jan. 6. In the four videos Bennett broadcast to Facebook, he wears a baseball hat adorned with the “Proud Boys” motto. In one of the videos, Bennett says, “ if you can hear me, share my stream in Discord for me,” seemingly referring to the messaging platform that’s been used by the alt-right. At one point, he chanted “break it down!” with a crowd—referring to a door located in the Speaker’s Lobby that was barricaded by police. Air Force veteran Ashli Babbitt, one of the four pro-Trump protesters who died on Jan. 6, was fatally shot by a police officer while attempting to break into the Speaker’s Lobby...Bennett shared conspiracy theories online prior to the insurrection. On Jan. 4, Bennett posted a conspiracy-laden message, including his belief that President Joe Biden stole the election and Hunter Biden’s laptop....On Jan. 11, Bennett admitted to federal agents that he went to D.C. and “that he knew it was wrong” to storm the Capitol. (Daily Beast)"
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Kenneth Grayson
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of PA; Defendant remains on release; Expressed support for QAnon; "Sentenced 12/19/22 to two months incarceration and 24 months of supervised release, pay $2,000 in restitution and a $100 special assessment."
Short narrative: Kenneth Grayson, 51, from PA, was arrested in PA, and charged with knowingly entering or remaining in a restricted building; disorderly conduct impeding government business; disruptive conduct in the Capitol building; and parading, demonstrating or picketing in the Capitol; and obstructing an official proceeding. Grayson's illegal entry inside the Capitol building on January 6, 2021 was well documented via his own recordings, and was verified through many electronic communications (e.g. selfies he took) and a tip provided to the FBI. Grayson's initial appearance was in Pittsburgh but he is being prosecuted in the District of Columbia. Grayson pleaded not guilty to all counts on 04/16/21. Investigators believe he has expressed support for QAnon.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Releases, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Eric Gene Barber
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 22 DC Code 3212 - Theft II
Additional details: Indicted by a bill of Information; Former councilman from Parksburg, WV. Criminal Complaint Affadavit suggests federal as well as DC Criminal Code charges; Sentenced 6/14/22 to 45 days in jail, 24 months of probation, $500 restitution to the Architect of the Capitol and $52.95 to C-SPAN.
Short narrative: In 2021, Eric Gene Barber, 43, a former Parkersburg, WV City Councilman was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 22 DC Code 3212 Theft II following his participation in the Capitol riot. Barber was identified via 7 tips provided to the FBI as well as Facebook posts made by Barber and CCTV footage that clearly show Barber inside the US Capitol. Barber was specifically captured searching through media equipment and taking an item from the stand. This item was likely a $52 portable power station.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local news articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Barnard & Witcher
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: USMC then Army, Resident of Texas; "Sentenced 2/4/22 to 12 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: On March 19th, 2021, Jeffrey Shane Witcher and Richard Franklin Barnard, two US Marine Corps veterans, were indicted for their role in the Capitol protests in January 2021. Barnard was charged with Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Barnard pleaded not guilty to all counts, and his sentencing is pending.

Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

Witcher was charged with Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Name of case: United States of America v. Patrick Edward McCaughey , et. al.
Charges: 18:111(a)(1), 2 Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Aiding and Abetting [4 counts]; 18:111(a)(1) and *(b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(2) and *(b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Washington DC; Restitution imposed in the amount of $2,000. Fine imposed in the amount of $3,000
Short narrative: Federico Guillermo Klein, 42 of Washington DC, was found guilty to multiple charges related to his participation at the Capitol Riot. Klein, a former midlevel State Department aide, used a riot shield to assault an unknown number of police officers, only retreating when an officer sprayed the defendant with pepper spray. Klein worked on Donald Trump's presidential campaign in 2016 and worked at the State Department in 2017 until he resigned on Jan. 19, 2021.
Source description: Charging Documents; National News Article; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. William Robert Norwood III
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:641 Theft of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Greer, SC
Short narrative: was indicted on charges of Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Theft of Government Property; Knowingly Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. "Norwood bragged in a family Facebook chat that he assaulted law enforcement and stole police equipment inside the Capitol." (Post and Courier). According to a government affadavit, Norwood admitted to entering the U.S. Capitol, claiming that two U.S. Capitol Police Officers were waving people inside and also claimed he wanted to leave but could not because of the crowd. He pleaded not guilty on all charges.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental reports and release (DOJ), Local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Richard Michetti
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grouds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of PA; "Sentenced 9/6/22 to nine months of incarceration, 24 months of supervised release, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: Michetti, 28 of Pennsylvania, pleaded guilty to one count of Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting. He was reported to law enforcement by a former romantic partner. They provided evidence of his involvement in the January 6th Capitol riot including pictures, videos, and text messages that confirmed his presence inside the Capitol Building. He is charged with entering restricted buildings, disorderly conduct on restricted grounds, and obstructing an official proceeding. Michetti was arrested on 2/23/21 in Ridley Park, PA. Michetti initially pleaded not guilty to counts 1-5 of the indictment, but changed his plea on count 1 to guilty in 2022. He was sentenced to nine months of incarceration.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Bustle & Bustle
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Charged by Bill of Information; Husband also arrested; Resident of VA; Pled guilty to misdemeanor disorderly conduct; first two defendants to enter guilty pleas for the Capitol riots; Couple sentenced to two years of probation and 40 hours of community service. Both were also sentenced to home confinement: 30 days for him and 60 days for her, based in part on comments she made supporting the rioters afterward.
Short narrative: On March 22nd, 2021, Jessica Louise Bustle and her husband Joshua Kahle Bustle were charged with Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; Knowingly Engaging in Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in Restricted Building or Grounds; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in Capitol Buildings following their participation in the Capitol riot. Jessica Bustle posted about their participation in the Captiol riot extensively on her multiple FaceBook accounts. Joshua and his wife were the first defendants from the insurrection to accept a plea deal, pleading guilty to a misdemeanor charge of disorderly conduct. The couple was sentenced to two years of probation and 40 hours of community service. Both were also sentenced to home confinement: 30 days for him and 60 days for her, based in part on comments she made supporting the rioters afterward.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Nicholas Burton Reimler
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Indicted by Bill of Information; Sentenced to 36 months probation, $500 restitution and 60 hours community service
Short narrative: Reimler was arrested and charged for his role in the Jan 6 Capitol protests. Reimler posted comments to Facebook supportive of Trump and critical of Biden and Democrats. On Dec. 31, he reposted “JANUARY SIXTH, SEE YOU IN DC!” from then-President Trump. "His only other public court record in Missouri is related to a Dec. 21, 2014, arrest on a DWI charge after he was caught driving about 78 mph on Highway 55." - St.Lous Post- Dispatch
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Lawrence Earl Stackhouse
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of NJ; Sentenced 6/17/22 to 14 days in jail (intermittent, two 7-day periods), 90 days home confinement, 36 months of probation, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Lawrence Earl Stackhouse, 33, of South Jersey was arrested and charged for his role in the Capitol protests. He was found through tips from fellow employees aware of how his political outspokenness clashed with his employer's policy as well as AT&T phone records that traced his cell phone to the cell site within the U.S. Capitol at the time of the riot. He was charged by the U.S. Attorney for the District of Columbia with four counts; he pled guilty to the fourth count of Parading, Picketing, or Demonstrating in a Capitol Building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. John Lolos
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Charged by information; Sentenced to 14 days incarceration and $500 restitution
Short narrative: On January 8, 2021, John Lolos was detained from a Delta Airlines flight at Ronald Reagan International Airport for disturbing other passengers by loudly yelling "Trump 2020!" It was after he was brought to the gate that the airport police officer holding him scrolled through his Instagram feed to see a video of the January 6 Capitol riot in which Lolos was shouting and waving a "Trump 2020 Keep America Great" flag; Lolos was identifiable because he was wearing the same shirt at the airport that he had been at the Capitol. After the airport security guard contacted the proper authorities, Lolos was arrested. He was charged with multiple counts by the U.S. Attorney for the District of Columbia and eventually plead guilty to the fourth, being sentenced to 14 days of incarceration and $500 restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Ryals & Griffith
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of OK; Defendant remains on personal recognizance; "Guilty on Counts Two, Three, Four and Five"; "Anthony Griffith Sentenced 9/1/23 as to Count(s) 2, Six (6) Months incarceration followed by Twelve (12) Months term of Supervised Release and a Special Assessment of $25.00; Count(s) 3, Six (6) Months incarceration followed by Twelve (12) Months term of Supervised Release to run concurrently to Count 2 and a Special Assessment of $25.00; Count(s) 4, Six (6) Months incarceration followed by Twelve (12) Months term of Supervised Release to run concurrently to Counts 2 and 3 and a Special Assessment of $10.00; Count(s) 5, Six (6) Months incarceration followed by Twelve (12) Months term of Supervised Release to run concurrently to Counts 2,3, and 4 and a Special Assessment of $10.00 for a total of $70.00."
Short narrative: Anthony Alfred Griffith, Sr. was charged with 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his involvement in the January 6th insurrection at the Capitol. Griffith pleaded not guilty and setencing information is pending. "Griffith, who owns an electric business, admitted to the FBI that he went into the Capitol after attending the rally for President Trump. Both men went into the Capitol, left and then went inside again. The FBI reported Griffith said he thought the Capitol Police were letting people inside the building, even though he admitted seeing people breaking windows and the officers holding riot shields in front of them." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Releases, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Weeks & Carlton
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Released on conditions; "Bradley Weeks, 44, of Macclenny, Florida was found guilty of five charges in total, including one felony. The verdict followed a bench trial before U.S. District Judge Thomas F. Hogan. Weeks was found guilty of obstruction of an official proceeding, a felony; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a capitol building; parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building."; "Bradley Weeks Sentenced 8/22/23 to Ten (10) Months Incarceration on each of Counts 1, 2 and 3, to run concurrently, and Six (6) Months Incarceration on each of Counts 4 and 5, to run concurrently with each other and with Counts 1, 2 and 3; Twenty-Four (24) Months Supervised Release on Count 1, and Twelve (12) Months Supervised Release on each of Counts 2 and 3, to run concurrently with each other and with Count 1; $100.00 Special Assessment on Count 1, $25.00 Special Assessment on each of Counts 2 and 3, and $10.00 Special Assessment on each of Counts 4 and 5, for a Total Special Assessment of $170.00; Restitution in the amount of $2000.00 and Fine in the amount of $500.00 imposed."
Short narrative: On March 24th, 2021, Jonathan Daniel Carlton and Bradley Wayne Weeks were indicted after they traveled to D.C. together to attend Trump's speech and both participated in the ensuing riot. Carlton and Weeks were inititally charged separately, however later were indicted together. Weeks was charged with Obstruction of an official proceeding; Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly conduct in a capitol building; and Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building, and his sentencing is pending.
Source description: Court Documents, Local News Articles, Charging documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Shane Leedon Jenkins
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:641 - Theft of government property; 18:1361 - Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: Resident of TX; Defendant remains committed; "Shane Jenkins Found guilty 3/29/23 for Corruptly Obstructing an Official Proceeding of Congress; Interfering with Law Enforcement Officers During a Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Law Enforcement Officers with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Destruction of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; and Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon, all felonies, as well as misdemeanors including: Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol building; and Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings."; "Shane Jenkins sentenced 10/6/23 to 84 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $5,176 in restitution."
Short narrative: Shane Leedon Jenkins was arrested and charged with 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:641 - Theft of government property; 18:1361 - Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building following his involvement in the January 6th, 2021 Capitol insurrection. Jenkins pleaded not guilty, and sentencing details are pending. "Federal agents located a video showing Jenkins remove a metal survival hatchet from a backpack, put on black gloves and smash a window to the left of the Lower West Terrace tunnel, according to court records. The window repair cost roughly $1,500, officials said. Security and body-worn camera footage shows Jenkins throw a pole, a desk drawer, a metal rod and flagpole at a group of Metropolitan Police Department and U.S. Capitol Police officers, striking some of them in the head as they attempted to prevent the crowd from infiltrating a tunnel, court documents allege."- Houston Chronicle
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Releases, Local News

Other names/aliases: Muckbang01 (Facebook); suzannekaye3 (Facebook); Angry Patriot Hippie (Facebook); @suzannekaye (Instagram); @suzannekayeX (Tik Tok)
Name of case: United States of America v. Suzanne Ellen Kaye
Charges: 18:875(c) did knowingly and intentionally transmit in interstate commerce a communication containing a threat to injure the person of another
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Boca Raton, FL; Expressed support for QAnon
Short narrative: Suzanne Ellen Kaye, 58, of Boca Raton, FL, was charged with knowingly and intentionally transmitting in interstate commerce a communication containing a threat to injure the person of another, following the FBI's inquiry to her participation in the January 6th riot. The FBI called Kaye to inquire about her travel to Washington DC surrounding the riot. Kaye asked if the FBI had proof of her travel, and denied an interview with the FBI. The FBI then received an online tip with a link to a video titled "F*** the FBI!!" on one of Kaye's Facebook pages, "Angry Patriot Hippie". In the video, Kaye said the FBI called about her travel to Washington D.C., but she would not speak to the FBI without counsel. Kaye proceeded to state that she would exercise her "second amendment right to shoot your f****** a** if you come here". This video was also uploaded to Kaye's Instagram and Tik Tok. Kaye has a criminal history, having been arrested in January 2010 for domestic battery, and arrested in February 2020 for aggrevated assault and possession of a deadly weapon without intent to kill and battery. The February 2020 charges were dropped and abandoned. Kaye pled not guilty. Kaye was found guilty of one charge of of interstate transmission of a threat to injure, and was acquitted of a second charge. Kaye faces a possilbe five years in prison, but the sentencing date has not been announced, as Kaye fainted towards the end of the trial.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, Local news articles
