Name of case: United States of America v. Ronnie Brian Presley
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a capitol building; *40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Additional details: Resident of TN; "Sentenced 11/30/22 to 12 months of incarceration, 26 months of supervised release, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: Ronnie Brian Presley, 42 of Tennessee, pled guilty to civil disorder and was sentenced to 12 months of prison for his role in the January 6 Capitol riot. He was identified by videos posted on social media where he announced himself by his name and home state. He appears to be grabbing a police officer's shield in one of the pictures. He also physically confronted a law enforcement officer by leaning into the officer’s baton, which the officer was holding and using in an attempt to push the defendant toward the exit.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Troy E. Sargent
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: Resident of MA; "sentenced 12/12/22 in the District of Columbia to 14 months in prison for felony charges of assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers during the breach of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, civil disorder, and four related misdemeanor offenses. In addition to the term of incarceration, he was ordered to complete two years of supervised release and to pay $500 restitution and a $285 special assessment."
Short narrative: "The Justice Department's case against Troy Sargent began after the government received tips from multiple members of the public who allegedly told the FBI that they recognized Sargent from photos and videos from the Capitol on Jan. 6. One witness allegedly told investigators that Sargent is known for participating in rallies in the Pittsfield, Mass., area, and that he posted on Facebook ahead of the Jan. 6 Trump rally: "I ain't missing this." Federal prosecutors say that Sargent is visible in footage from police body cameras on Jan. 6. At one point, according to court documents, Sargent "appears to throw a punch with his right hand at a police officer, inadvertently strikes another member of the crowd, and then retreats back into the crowd." At another point, "Sargent approaches the front of the crowd of rioters, confronts the line of police officers attempting to hold the crowd back, and physically engages with one of the officers with his right hand while holding what appears to be a cell phone in his left hand."" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, News articles, Governmental reports and release

Name of case: United States of America v. Mark K. Ponder
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; *18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; *18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of D.C.; "Sentenced 7/26/22 to 63 months in prison, three years of supervised release, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: Mark K. Ponder, 55 of DC, pled guilty to Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and was sentenced to 63 months in prison. He was recorded on open source video and body cam footage participating in the Capitol riots and attacking U.S. Capitol Police Sgt. Aquilino Gonell with a pole. The officer sustained injuries such as a shattered foot and shoulder injuries. He has previously been charged with robbing a bank, stealing a car, and domestic assault.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeremy J. Vorous
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) and (2) Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) and (G) Violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of any official proceeding
Additional details: Resident of PA
Short narrative: "Jeremy J. Vorous of Venango has been charged with knowingly entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol Grounds; and obstruction of any official proceeding...According to the 12-page affidavit filed by FBI Agent Peter Wall against Vorous, Vorous gained entry inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6. The FBI received two tips which included screenshots of Vorous’ Facebook page where Vorous wrote “Yeah we in dis mofo” and “Bout to rush in again diff door.” Vorous’ Facebook page also included photos taken of the riot, including inside the U.S. Capitol...Vorous posted on Facebook a photo showing himself in the “Capitol Crypt in front of the bust of Abraham Lincoln saying ‘does that look staged to you I promise the beanbags were real the mase is still burning on me aft a shower and 6hrs, the gas was real the flash grenades were also real the dead girl was 10ft from me’.” Vorous also is depicted in the photo wearing a dark long-sleeved shirt with “Not Today Liberal” in white letters and holding a red, white and blue cowboy-style hat, the affidavit said. According to the affidavit, “Vorous also posted to Facebook a photo showing himself in front of a statute with the caption ‘We will take what we want' which the FBI obtained from an online tip by an identified individual.” “In the photo, Vorous is depicted wearing the same clothing as in Figure One,” the affidavit said. “The statute Vorous poses in front of is the statue of John Caldwell Calhoun of South Carolina, which is also located in the Crypt of the Capitol.” The affidavit said, “Vorous also posted messages on Facebook talking about the ‘coordination’ of the attack on the Capitol, as well as the fact that ‘we took’ the Capitol Building, which your affiant obtained from an anonymous online tip to the FBI.” The affidavit said the FBI reviewed a recording from the FBI’s National Threat Operations Center that Vorous made to the FBI Jan. 10. “In that recording, Vorous called to report that he was in the U.S. Capitol building on January 6, 2021,” The affidavit said. “He said he was in the building and went to the Capitol Police the next day to report himself. Vorous said that he absolutely did not participate in the rioting or take anything.” The affidavit said there were at two separate YouTube videos of Vorous being interviewed during the riot, and the FBI “was able to review footage from the Capitol that shows Vorous in the Crypt area of the U.S. Capitol building. The footage shows Vorous walking around inside the Capitol.” In addition, the affidavit said footage showed Vorous entering the U.S. Capitol building. Also, the FBI said it “learned from separate sources that at the time of his (Vorous’) entry, loud audible alarms were going off in the area and the windows adjacent to point of entry were broken out.” (Medville Tribune)
Source description: Local News, Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Russell Dean Alford
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly COnduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Hokes Bluff, AL; Indicted via Information sheet; "Found guilty 10/5/22 by a jury of entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building."; "Alford Sentenced 2/2/23 to 12 months incarceration, 12 months supervised release, $70 special assesment, $500 Restitution."
Short narrative: In 2021, Russell Dean Alford, 60, of Hokes Bluff, AL, was charged with entering and remaining in a restricted building, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building, and violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building for his role in the Jan. 6th riot. Alford posted videos of his participation in the riot on his Facebook and personal YouTube page. "I wondered when y’all were going to show up. Guess you’ve seen the videos on my Facebook page,” Russell Alford said when FBI agents went to his house to detain him, according to court documents.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News article

Name of case: United States of America v. Bryan Wayne Ivey
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Indicted by Bill of information; Sentenced 3/30/22, to three years of probation, including 60 days of home detention, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: "The Department of Justice says a "close contact" of Bryan Wayne Ivey contacted investigators in late January after recognizing him in photos from the Capitol riot, wearing a brown jacket, brown hat and sunglasses. The witness allegedly told investigators that Ivey also admitted entering the Capitol that day. Federal prosecutors say Ivey can also be seen in surveillance footage from inside the Capitol on Jan. 6 as he "attempts to assist others in entering the building." The FBI arrested Ivey on March 4 in Cookeville, Tenn." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeffrey Mckellop
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers [4 counts]; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon [2 counts]; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: Resident of Augusta, VA; Retired US Army Special Forces and military contractor
Short narrative: In 2021, Jeffery A. McKellop, was charged with four counts of Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers, two counts of Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon, Civil Disorder, Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly Weapon, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon, Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon, Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, and Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building. McKellop is a military contractor working for the CIA and a retired Green Beret. Footage shows McKellop attacking several police officers, jabbing one officer in the face with a flagpole during the riot, and attempting to grab officers' pepper spray. McKellop served for 22 years and did two tours in Iraq and Afghanistan.
Source description: Charging documents, Court Documents, News article

Name of case: United States of America v. Sean Carlo Cordon
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) and (2) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) and (G) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds
Additional details: Brother also arrested; Identified after appearing on Finnish TV, indicted by bill of information; Sentenced to 2 months’ probation, $4000 fine
Short narrative: Brothers Kevin Francisco Cordon, 33, and Sean Carlo Cordon, 35, of California, have both been charged following their participation in the Capitol riot. The Cordon brothers were identified after they were seen in a video posted on a Finnish news site. While they were on the same criminal complaint, they were later seperated and given their own information/indictment. Sean Cordon has accepted a plea deal, pleading guilty to parading, demonstraining, or picketing in the Capitol building in order to get the rest of the charges dropped.
Source description: Charging Documents, National News

Physical target: Federal site: non-U.S. embassy or consulate
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

Short narrative: Ethan C. Seitz, 31, of Bucyrus, OH, was charged with Obstruction of an Official Proceeding, Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds,v Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol building for his role in the Jan. 6th riot. Seitz was identified via tips provided to the FBI as well as Facebook posts made by Seitz, Capitol security footage, and a YouTube video interview of Seitz in which he describes his experience and motivation. "I did storm the f***** capitol and climb in through a window. Got gassed and pepper sprayed. Flash bombs thrown at me. And f***** rubber bullets shot at me" (statement of facts). Seitz states that he took part in the riot because of "election integrity".

Name of case: United States of America v. Johnny Harris
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) and (2) Entering and remaining in a restricted building and disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Shelby, NC; Indicted by Bill of Information
Short narrative: Johnny Harris, 56, of Shelby, NC was charged with Entering and remaining in a restricted building, Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building, Violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building for his involvement in the January 6, 2021 U.S. capitol riot. Harris's involvement is chronicled in the documentary, “January 6th,” which places him at the scene of the riot. "A law enforcement filing in federal court alleges that Johnny Harris posted photos of himself from inside the Capitol during the insurrection. Investigators tracked him down after an anonymous tipster flagged photos that Harris had allegedly posted on his Facebook page. In four photos gathered by investigators, including from body camera and security camera footage from inside the Capitol, Harris can be seen holding a flag inside the Capitol rotunda. According to prosecutors, two individuals who traveled with Harris to Washington, D.C., identified Harris as the individual pictured in several photos apparently taken inside the Capitol." (NPR). Harris has pled not guilty and this case is currently pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND Supports organized political violence AND State speech act

Name of case: United States of America v. Scott Kevin Fairlamb
Charges: 18:111(a)(1); ASSAULTING/RESISTING/IMPEDING OFFICERS/EMPLOYEES; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18 U.S.C. 1512(c)(2) and 2; TAMPERING WITH A WITNESS, VICTIM OR INFORMANT; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; *18 U.S.C. 231(a)(3); CIVIL DISORDER; * 18 U.S.C. 1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A); TEMPORARY RESIDENCE OF THE PRESIDENT; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18 U.S.C. 1752(a)(2); TEMPORARY RESIDENCE OF THE PRESIDENT; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18 U.S.C. 1752(a)(3); TEMPORARY RESIDENCE OF THE PRESIDENT; Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18 U.S.C. 1752(a)(4); TEMPORARY RESIDENCE OF THE PRESIDENT; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D); VIOLENT ENTRY AND DISORDERLY CONDUCT ON CAPITOL GROUNDS; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40 U.S.C. 5104(e)(2)(E); FEDERAL STATUTES, OTHER; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; *40 U.S.C. 5104(e)(2)(F); FEDERAL STATUTES, OTHER; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; *40 U.S.C. 5104(e)(2)(G); FEDERAL STATUTES, OTHER; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *40 U.S.C. 5104(d); FEDERAL STATUTES, OTHER; Stepping, Climbing, Removing, or Injuring Property on the capitol Grounds
Additional details: Resident of New Jersey; QAnon supporter; 36 months supervised release, $2000 restitution
Short narrative: Scott Kevin Fairlamb, 44, from New Jersey, was charged for his role in the Jan. 6th Capitol riot after four concerned citizens submitted footage to the FBI of Fairlamb participating and verbally confirming his participation in the riot. Fairlamb was additionally identified in a video shoving and punching an officer. He traveled to Washington on Jan. 6 to attend the “Stop the Steal” rally. Fairlamb was part of a large crowd that forcibly pushed through a line of police officers and metal barricades. He obtained a collapsible police baton from the ground and posted a video to Facebook displaying the baton which he later hit police with. In the video he said, “What Patriots do? We f****** disarm them and then we storm the f****** Capitol.” Fairlamb pleaded guilty to counts two and three of the superseding indictment that charged him with obstruction of an official proceeding and assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers. The ex-MMA fighter Scott Fairlamb was sentenced to approximately three and a half years in prison and three years probation for assaulting an officer while he was part of the violent mob that stormed the U.S. Capitol on January 6 in support of former President Trump. He was the first person to be sentenced in the Capitol cases.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeffrey Alexander Smith
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(D) and (G) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol building; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building
Additional details: Indicted by Bill of Information; Sentenced 3/15/22, 90 days of incarceration, 2 years of probation, $500 in restitution, 200 hours of community service.
Short narrative: "Following the events on January 6, 2021, the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) received tips at the FBI National Threat Operations Center (NTOC) from individuals who reported that they identified JEFFREY ALEXANDER SMITH, aka ALEX SMITH, as being involved in the events at the Capitol. On January 7, 2021, one individual (“Witness-1”) who identified themselves and who has known SMITH for an extended period of time had discovered a photo of SMITH inside the Capitol on social media which had been posted to Instagram by @homegrownterrorists. The photo depicts SMITH wearing a black jacket and a Trump hat, with a red cell phone in his right hand which is raised in the air. On January 8, 2021, a tip was received by the FBI Tipline from an individual (“Witness- 2”) who grew up with SMITH in Coronado, California, and who texted with SMITH via Instagram after the riots. Witness-2 provided screen shots of the messages which included SMITH writing, “I’m a Patriot”, “I stormed the capitol” (sic). In the text, SMITH stated that his purpose was “To send a message that Americans are[n’] t going to take a fraudulent election.” SMITH also wrote to Witness-2, “There is no way in hell I was going to drive 38 hours from San Diego and not walk right through the front of the capitol (sic) building.” Witness-2 also observed that SMITH had since deleted his Instagram account...SMITH told the [FBI] agent that he drove 38 hours to Washington, DC, to attend the speech by President Trump on January 6, 2021. SMITH said that his girlfriend traveled by air and met him in Washington, D.C. SMITH told his girlfriend to remain at the hotel instead of getting into all the chaos at the U.S. Capitol. SMITH also identified the hotel he stayed at in Washington, D.C. SMITH admitted that when he approached the U.S. Capitol it was a chaotic scene. He heard people on loudspeakers, he saw tear gas, and heard what he thought were flash bangs going off. SMITH admitted he walked into the Capitol on January 6, 2021 and remained in the Capitol for about 30 minutes. SMITH admitted to deleting his Instagram account after he began receiving threats related to his involvement in the Capitol events." (DOJ Statement of Facts) Smith was an Army Sergeant and was seen moving the bench barricades from the rotunda doors.
Source description: Charging Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Sibick, Head, & Young
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and Aiding and abetting; 18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; 18:2111 Robbery; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(3) Impeding ingress and egress in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impedinng passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physcial violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Buffalo, NY; "Sibick Sentenced 7/28/23 to Fifty (50) months incarceration with credit for time already served to run concurrently with the term of incarceration imposed in Counts 2ss and 3ss, followed by Thirty-Six (36) months of supervised release to run concurrently with the term of supervised release imposed in Counts 2ss and 3ss. Special Assessment of $100.00 on Count 1ss. Restitution for the entire case in the amount of $7,500.79 was Ordered. Counts 2ss-3ss: Sentenced to Fifty (50) months incarceration on Count 2ss with credit for time already served to run concurrently with the term of incarceration imposed in Counts 1ss and 3ss. and Twelve (12) months incarceration on Count 3ss with credit for time already served to run concurrently with the term of incarceration imposed in Counts 1ss, and 2ss, followed by Thirty-Six (36) months of supervised release on Count 2ss to run concurrently with the term of supervised release imposed in Counts 1ss and 3ss and Twelve (12) months on supervised release on Count 3ss to run concurrently with the term of supervised release imposed in Counts 1ss and 2ss. Special Assessment of $100.00 on Count 2ss and $25.00 on Count 3ss. Restitution for the entire case in the amount of $7,500.79 was Ordered. Oral Motion by the Government to Dismiss all Remaining Counts: 1,1s,3,3s,4,4s,6,6s,8,8s,9,9s,10,10s,11,11s,12,12s,13,13s was GRANTED."
Short narrative: "Albuquerque Cosper Head, 41, of Kingsport, Tennessee; Kyle James Young, 37, of Redfield, Iowa; and Thomas Sibick, 35, of Buffalo, New York, were indicted on charges related to their assault of Metropolitan Police Department (MPD) Officer Michael Fanone, as well as other crimes, committed during the breach. All are charged with obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct on restricted building or grounds; impeding ingress and egress in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence on restricted building or grounds; impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; and acts of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings. Sibick is charged with an additional count of robbery; Head is charged with an additional count of civil disorder; and Young is charged with additional counts of civil disorder, assault on an officer, and robbery." (DOJ Press release)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and release

Name of case: United States of America v. Christopher Worrell
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of FL; Found guilty on 5/12/23, of assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon, obstruction of an official proceeding of Congress, and obstructing, impeding, or interfering with officers during the commission of a civil disorder, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon, engaging in physical violence with a deadly or dangerous weapon all felonies, and an act of physical violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings, a misdemeanor; "Christopher Worrell Sentenced 1/4/24 to a term of One Hundred and Twenty (120) months on Counts One, Two, Four, Six, and Thirteen; Sixty (60) months on Count Ten; and Six (6) months on Count Eight, with all such terms to run concurrently. The Defendant is further sentenced to serve a Thirty-Six (36) month term of supervised release as to each of Counts One, Two, Four, Six, Ten and Thirteen, with all such terms to run concurrently. In addition, the Defendant is ordered to pay restitution in the amount of $2,000, as well as a special assessment of $610 ($100 for each of Counts One, Two, Four, Six, Ten and Thirteen; $10 for Count Eight)"
Short narrative: Christopher Worrell, 49, of FL, was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; Civil Disorder; and Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; for his participation in the January 6th Capitol riot. Worrell is a member of Proud Boys. Worrell was seen on camera spraying pepper spray gel into the crowd at the riot. Worrell has pled not guilty. This case is currently still pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Douglas Austin Jensen
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Des Moines, Iowa; Expressed support for QAnon; "Found guilty 9/23/22 of all seven counts. These include five felony offenses: assaulting, resisting, or impeding a law enforcement officer, obstruction of an official proceeding, interfering with a law enforcement officer during a civil disorder, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a dangerous weapon, and disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a dangerous weapon. They also include misdemeanor offenses of disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building."
Short narrative: Douglas Austin Jensen, 41, of Des Moines, Iowa, was charged with Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his participation in the Capitol riot. Jensen has been identified as taking part in the Capitol siege after Jensen truned himself in to local law enforcement. Jensen led a crowd of rioters into the Capitol and was seen chasing a Capitol officer up the stairs in videos taken from inside the Capitol. Jensen has expressed support for QAnon saying that he wanted to be one of the first individuals in the Capitol "because he was wearing his 'Q' t-shirt and he wanted to have his t-shirt seen on video so that “Q” could 'get the credit'." (affidavit). Jensen originally pled not quilty to all counts, but now has taken a plea deal, intending to plea guilty to aggrevated felony.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, News articles, Local news articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeffrey Grace
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of WA; Indicted by Bill of Information; Pleaded guilty in April 2022 to one count of entering and remaining in a restricted builing or grounds; "Jeffrey Grace Sentenced 8/3/23 to Seventy-Five (75) Days of Incarceration; Followed by Twelve (12) Months of Supervised Release; A $25.00 Special Assessment is imposed; Restitution is imposed in the amount of $500.00."
Short narrative: Jeffrey Grace, 61, was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his role in the January 6th riot. Grace admitted to traveling to DC and entering the Capitol building amidst the raid. A tipster provided this information to the FBI and was verified by photographs taken by others inside the Capitol as well as Grace's own admission. His son, Jeremy Grace, was also arrested in the Capitol protests. Grace has pled not guilty and the case is currently pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Mariposa Castro
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of CA; Indicted by Bill of Information; Sentenced 2/23/22 to 45 days in jail, $5,000 fine.
Short narrative: Bay area yoga studio owner, Mariposa Castro, from Gilroy, CA, was charged with two misdemeanors in connection with the Jan. 6 Capitol protests. She entered the Capitol through a smashed window and recorded her participation on video shared on Facebook.
Source description: Charging documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Stephen Ethan Horn
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Raleigh, NC; Indicted via Bill of Information
Short narrative: Stephen Ethan Horn, 23 has been arrested and charged with his role in the January 2021 Capitol protests. Horn claims he was there as a journalist to document what was happening. "FBI agents say Horn walked over a fence on the ground with a “No trespassing” sign before walking into the Capitol building during the attack and making his way to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s office" (Spectrum News 1) and was heard chanting U.S.A. on a video posted to his Facebook page. In a post on his personal Facebook page, Horn wrote, “I did not enter the capitol building as part of the protest, or for cheap thrills, but to accurately document and record a significant event that was taking place.” (WBTV). The FBI became aware of Horn after being notified by an individual who has known Horn for years after seeing a picture of Horn on a NY Times Magazine social media page. Horn has pled not guity and this case is currently pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. John Clarence Wilkerson
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Indicted by Bill of Information; Resident of MD; "Defendant is sentenced to a term of 36 months (3 years) of Probation as to Count 4 of the Information. The Defendant is further sentenced to pay a $10 special assessment, a fine of $2,500 and to perform 60 hours of community service. The Government's oral motion to dismiss the remaining counts (1-3) of the Information is GRANTED."
Short narrative: John Wilkerson has been identified by tipsters that said he attended the Capitol protests in January, 2021. He is from Maryland. "A person who knew John Clarence Wilkerson IV from a decade earlier but still followed him on social media turned him in to the FBI. That person called the FBI after seeing a photo of Wilkerson at a bar on Jan. 6 with the caption "today was a good day, we got inside the Capitol," according to court documents. Wilkerson also allegedly said he wouldn't be posting photos or videos from inside the U.S. Capitol “for obvious reasons.” According to court documents, Wilkerson lives on a boat in Maryland." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Jason Riddle
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 18:641 - Theft of government property; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of NH; US army Reserves Motor Transport Operator 2011-2016; Indicted by Bill of Information; Sentenced 4/4/22, 90 days in jail, followed by three years of probation, including 60 hours of community service, restitution of $754.
Short narrative: Jason Riddle, 32, has been arrested and charged for this role in the Capitol protests on January 6th, 2021. When he arrived to the Capitol, he drank a glass of wine from a bottle he found in a refrigerator in the Office of the Senate Parliamentarian and took a selfie with the bottle. He stated in a later interview that he was a military veteran. While Riddle was in the Capitol, he told the FBI he took two things, a small FOX News football and an old-looking, reddish-brown leather book from the same office where he found the wine. He then sold the book outside the Capitol for $40. "At some point, Riddle tried to delete messages, photos and videos from his phone, but the FBI was able to recover the digital evidence and found a photo of the book, titled "Senate Procedure." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Von Bernewitz & Von Bernewitz
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of VA; Released on recognizance; Brother also arrested; Charged by information; Sentenced 4/26/22 to 24 months of probation, including 60 days home confinement, $500 restitution, $1,000 fine.
Short narrative: Brothers Eric V. Von Bernewitz, 46, and Paul H. Von Bernewitz, 50, both of Virginia, both pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for their role in the January 6 Capitol raid. Eric was sentenced to 24 months probation. The defendants "were identified by law enforcement after a witness saw their sister post on Facebook that her brother had been inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and had FaceTimed with her inside the building. The sister didn't specify which brother she was referring to. When the FBI interviewed Eric Von Bernewitz, he admitted to being inside the Capitol that day and that he was there with his brother, according to court documents. Eric Von Bernewitz told the FBI that "he got caught up in the excitement of the crowd, went in the Capitol Building unexpectedly, and left within ten minutes." (NPR)
Source description: Local News, Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Von Bernewitz & Von Bernewitz
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of VA; Released on recognizance; Brother also arrested; Charged by information; Sentenced 4/26/22 to 30 days in jail, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Brothers Eric V. Von Bernewitz, 46, and Paul H. Von Bernewitz, 50, both of Virginia, both pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for their role in the January 6 Capitol raid. Paul was sentenced to a month in jail. The defendants "were identified by law enforcement after a witness saw their sister post on Facebook that her brother had been inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and had FaceTimed with her inside the building. The sister didn't specify which brother she was referring to. When the FBI interviewed Eric Von Bernewitz, he admitted to being inside the Capitol that day and that he was there with his brother, according to court documents. Eric Von Bernewitz told the FBI that "he got caught up in the excitement of the crowd, went in the Capitol Building unexpectedly, and left within ten minutes." (NPR)
Source description: Local News, Charging Documents, Court Documents

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND State speech act
Name of case: United States of America v. Jon Schaffer
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of an Official proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1),(b)(1)(A) Entering and remaining in a restructed building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon
Additional details: Resident of Columbus, Indiana; Indicted by Bill of Information; Described by DOJ as "founding" member of the Oath Keepers
Short narrative: Jon Ryan Schaffer, 53, from Columbus, Indiana was charged with Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon following his participation in the Capitol riot where Schaffer sprayed "bear spray" at Capitol officers. Schaffer is a member of the Oath Keepers and has long held far-right opinions. Schaffer is also the founder of the heavy metal band "Iced Earth". Schaffer was the first person to enter a guilty plea in the Capitol riot investigation, and agreed to cooperate against others in the case.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND Supports organized political violence AND State speech act
Name of case: United States of America v. Pezzola, Pepe & Greene
Charges: 18:731 Conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding; 18:231(a)(3), 2 Civil Disorder; 18:1361, 2 Government property or contracts; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4), 2 Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds
Additional details: Also facing three unrelated, state-level gun charges; Resident of Syracuse, NY
Short narrative: Matthew J. Greene, 33, of Syracuse, NY, and William Joseph Pepe, 31, of Beacon, NY were charged with Conspiracy, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding Abetting, Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting, Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting, Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds and Aiding and Abetting for their participation in the January 6th Capitol raid. Both Green and Pepe are memebers of Proud Boys and communicated with other Proud Boys memebrs prior to and during the Capitol raid. Additionally, Pepe posted a video of his presence inside the Capitol building, and Greene communicated via encrypted messaging channels confirming his participation. Greene initially pleaded not guilty, but later pleaded guilty per a plea bargain. The case is currently pending. [Note: Greene and Pepe were initially charged with Dominic Pezzola (A.K.A. Spazz, Spaz, Spazzo, Spazzolini; Case ID: 06062022_DP_4PROUDBOYS6), but Pezzola was removed from the case. Pezzola was named 3/7/22 in superseding indictment in new case, replacing 1:21-cr-52, and named again in a supersceding indictment 6/6/2022, having been added to the 4PROUDBOYS group case.)
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and releases (DOJ), News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Wagner & Tutrow
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Facial tatoos; Indicted by Bill of Information; From Greenfield, Indiana; Sentenced to a term of Thirty Six (36) months of Probation. Special Assessment of $10.00 and Restitution in the amount of $500.00 were imposed.
Short narrative: High school classmates, Joshua Wagner and Israel David Tutrow, 22, both of Indiana have been charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following their participation in the Capitol riot. Wagner and Tutrow sent messages on Facebook messenger prior to the riot coordinating their arrival and during the riot. Wagner and Tutrow were identified via numerous photographs taken at the Capitol and through tips provided to the FBI.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court documents; Government report or release (DOJ), News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Wagner & Tutrow
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Indicted by Bill of Information; Resident of Greenwood, IN; sentenced to 30 days, $500 restitution
Short narrative: High school classmates, Joshua Wagner and Israel David Tutrow, 22, both of Indiana have been charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following their participation in the Capitol riot. Wagner and Tutrow sent messages on Facebook messenger prior to the riot coordinating their arrival and during the riot. Wagner and Tutrow were identified via numerous photographs taken at the Capitol and through tips provided to the FBI. Wagner was sentenced to 30 days of incarceration.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court documents; Government report or release (DOJ), News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Russell James Peterson
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Indicted by Bill of Information; "Sentenced 12/1 to 30 days incarceration and $500 restitution."
Short narrative: "Peterson, 34 of Pennsylvania, streamed video live from inside the Capitol at least twice on Jan. 6, the FBI found through a search warrant issued for his Facebook account five days later. Court records state Peterson attended the rally with his mother, Shelly, and wife Elizabeth. A tipster reported to the FBI that Peterson's mother posted on Facebook that her son stormed the Capitol and 'sat in Pelosi's chair.'" (USA Today) Peterson pled guilty to one of the charges and was sentenced to 30 days.
Source description: Charging Document, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Kenneth Kelly
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Additional details: Resident of Florida; Family member told federal agents that Kelly "held extreme political views and had mentioned 'QAnon' a couple months before the January 6 riot." Charged by Bill of Information; "Sentenced 1/14/22 to 12 months of probation, including 60 days of home detention, $500 restitution."; "Andrew Jackson Morgan Sentenced 9/22/23 to one hundred ten (110) days of Incarceration followed by twelve (12) months of Supervised Release (with conditions). $25.00 Special Assessment and Restitution in the amount of $500.00."
Short narrative: Kenneth Kelly, 58 of Florida, was identified as taking part in the Capitol riot via a tip provided to the FBI from a family member, CCTV footage from inside the Capitol building, and many photographs and texts sent from Kelly's personal phone throughout the incident. Kelly self-surrendered in the Middle District of Florida (Ocala, FL). He made his initial appearance and was released on a $25,000 unsecured bond.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Andrew Jackson Morgan Jr.
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Expressed support fort QAnon; From Maxwell, Texas;
Short narrative: Andrew Jackson Morgan Jr., 59, of Maxwell, TX, was charged with Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; for his role in the January 6th riot. Morgan was charged after a tip was submitted with a video of Morgan's participation. Morgan has pled not guilty to the charges, and the sentencing Information for this case is currently pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Database (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Bennett & Williams
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of TX; Partner Bradley Stuart Bennett also arrested
Short narrative: Elizabeth Rose Williams and Brad Bennett were arrested and charged with knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct, and obstruction of an official proceeding after allegedly entering the US Capitol building during the January 6th insurrection. According to court documents, Williams and Bennett were seen on Capitol grounds and inside the building in security camera footage and social media posts that Bennett had posted onto Facebook.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Bennett & Williams
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Expressed support for QAnon; Partner Elizabeth Rose Williams also arrested
Short narrative: Elizabeth Rose Williams and Brad Bennett were arrested and charged with knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct, and obstruction of an official proceeding after allegedly entering the US Capitol building during the January 6th insurrection. According to court documents, Williams and Bennett were seen on Capitol grounds and inside the building in security camera footage and social media posts that Bennett had posted onto Facebook.

Name of case: United States of America v. Larocca & Cortez
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of TX; "Sentenced 8/10/22 to 60 days in jail, one year of supervised release, 60 hours of community service, $2,000 fine, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Benjamin LaRocca, 27, was charged with Obstruction of an Official Proceeding, Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, and Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds after participating in the Capitol riot on 6 January. LaRocca, accompanied by his friend Christian Cortez, 27, allegedly filmed a crowd of rioters pushing toward a line of law enforcement officers inside the Capitol. Later in the video, Larocca appears to flip the camera to himself and chants, “Our house!” in response to other rioters chanting, “Whose house?” He is currently on recognizance.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Larocca & Cortez
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:111(a)- Assaulting a Federal Officer
Additional details: Resident of TX.; "Sentenced 8/31/22 to 4 months of incarceration, 36 months of supervised release, 60 hours of community service, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: Christian Cortez, 27, was charged with Assaulting a Federal Officer, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding, Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his participation in the Capitol riot on 6 January 2021. Cortez, accompanied by his friend Benjamin LaRocca, 27, allegedly hurled expletives at police officers in the Capitol building doorway and egging them on to fire at him with pepper spray and fire extinguishers as they tried to force the doors closed. He is currently released on recognizance.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. James Leslie Little
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; *18:1752(a)(2); Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D); Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NC; Indicted by Bill of Information; Sentenced 3/14/22 to 60 days of incarceration, to be followed by 36 months of probation, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: James Leslie Little, 62 of North Carolina, pled guilty to Parading or Demonstrating in Capitol Building following his participation in the Capitol riot. He was sentenced to 2 months in prison. He was identified via a relative providing information to the FBI and his identity was confirmed through photographs taken inside the Capitol. Before January 6, Little posted online warning of a "civil war" if the U.S. Supreme Court did not side with then-President Donald Trump in winning the 2020 election.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Caleb Jones
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of OH; "Sentenced 12/1 to 24 months probation including two months home confinement, and $500 restitution."
Short narrative: On April 26, 2021, Caleb Jones, 23, of Columbus, Ohio was charged with several federal offenses for his activities at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. Jones was identified after he was identified by numerous witnesses who either recognized him in television coverage of the event or were told in conversations with him over text and Facebook that he had participated in the riot. One such witness provided photos and videos they had received of Jones scaling a wall of the building in an effort to get inside and then joining in with the crowd occupying the inside of the building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeremy Ryan Sorvisto
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of MI; Indicted by Bill of Information; Special assessment of $10.00; Restitution of $500; Sentenced 12/15/2021 to 30 days in jail;
Short narrative: Jeremy Sorvisto, Sr., 37 of Michigan, and his fiance Ashley Aho pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing a Capitol Building. He was sentenced to a month in prison. His charges grew out of the investigation into Karl Dresch, who was arrested in January. "A court affidavit says a former grade-school classmate sent photos posted on Ashley Aho’s social media accounts to the FBI taken inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, showing her and Jeremy Sorvisto, whom she identifies online as her fiancé. Posts included in the affidavit show Sorvisto and Aho in the backseat of a car traveling from Michigan’s Upper Peninsula to Washington, D.C., captioned with the hashtag “#trump2020.”" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Danielle Nicole Doyle
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Additional details: Resident of OK; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 10/1 to two months probation, $3,000 fine, and $500 restitution to the Architect of the Capitol."
Short narrative: Danielle Doyle, 37 of Oklahoma, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for her participation in the January 6, 2021 Capitol riot. She was sentenced to 2 months probation. "According to the FBI, Danielle Doyle can be seen on surveillance video entering the Capitol through a broken window and walking around. Two witnesses came forward identifying Doyle as a former co-worker, according to court documents. The Oklahoma City Thunder NBA team confirmed to local media that Doyle was a former employee who worked as an account manager for the team until December of last year." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Boyd Allen Camper
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of MT; Indicted by BIll of Information; Sentenced to 60 days incarceration and $10 special assessment
Short narrative:
Boyd Allen Camper, 54 of Montana, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his participation in the Capitol riot. He was sentenced to 2 months of prison. 

"Multiple witnesses confirmed to the FBI that Camper went inside the U.S. Capitol building carrying a GoPro camera on a stick. Days later, Camper told FBI agents in an interview that “in my mind, we were going to take the Capitol steps.” He also said he entered the building through a small door that led to the Rotunda and then proceeded to a room “with statues.” According to court documents, Camper told the FBI they couldn't review the footage he took on his camera if they would use the content against him. In a sentencing memorandum filed in federal court, Camper is identified as having military service. In that memo, a U.S. prosecutor wrote: "While Camper’s military service is laudable, it renders his conduct on January 6 all the more egregious. As a former military member, Camper was well aware that taxpayer status does not bestow upon a person the right to enter restricted government buildings. His voluntary decision to storm a guarded government building is nothing short of shocking in light of his former military service and training."" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Robert Scott Palmer
Charges: 18:111(a(1) and (b); ASSAULTING/RESISTING/IMPEDING OFFICERS/EMPLOYEES; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon, Inflicting Bodily Injury; *18:231(a)(3); CIVIL DISORDER; *18:111(a)(3); ASSAULTING/RESISTING/IMPEDING OFFICERS/EMPLOYEES; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A); TEMPORARY RESIDENCE OF THE PRESIDENT; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon [3 counts]; *40:5104(e)(2)(D); VIOLENT ENTRY AND DISORDERLY CONDUCT ON CAPITOL GROUNDS; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F); VIOLENT ENTRY AND DISORDERLY CONDUCT ON CAPITOL GROUNDS; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
Additional details: As of 12-21-21 this was the longest prison sentenced levied
Short narrative: "Palmer, who owns a cleaning service in Largo, Florida, was dubbed #FloridaFlagJacket by online sleuths, because he wore a jacket styled like an America flag with the word Trump on the front and a Trump campaign pin to the Capitol. The FBI reported he threw a wooden plank at officers, sprayed the contents of a fire extinguisher toward officers, threw the fire extinguisher at them and then picked it up and threw it at them a second time. Court records in Pinellas County, Florida show Palmer has been in trouble with authorities more than a dozen times over 35 years, including a 1989 felony charge of fraud and theft and a 1998 felony charge of false imprisonment. Records show he declared bankruptcy in 2014 and was ticketed with driving on a sidewalk or bike path in 2018:" (USA Today)
Source description: National news; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jonathan Joshua Munafo
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and Aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and remaining on restricted grounds with a dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Act of physical violence against property on restricted grounds with a dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) Act of physical violence against person on restricted grounds; 18:641 Theft of Government property; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence on the Capitol grounds
Additional details: Resident of NY; 33 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $2,000 in restitution
Short narrative: Jonathan Joshua Munafo, A.K.A. John Joshua Munafo, 34, of Albany, NY is charged with Civil Disorder; Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; Obstruction of an official proceeding and Aiding and abetting; Entering and remaining on restricted grounds with a dangerous weapon; Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a dangerous weapon; Act of physical violence against property on restricted grounds with a dangerous weapon; Act of physical violence against person on restricted grounds; Theft of Government property; Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; and Act of physical violence on the Capitol grounds for his participation in the Jan 6th Capitol riot. "According to court documents, Munafo was on the Lower West Terrace outside the tunnel where he was captured on video striking a U.S. Capitol Police officer twice in the head and body with a closed fist. Munafo then violently ripped the officer’s riot shield out of his hands and passed it back to others in the crowd behind him. At one point, Munafo used a wooden flagpole to strike a window of the Capitol in an attempt to break it. (DOJ Press Release)". Munafo has pled not guilty. He was sentenced to 33 months in prison. Munafo is currently already in the dataset within the summer-fall 2020 protest cases as he was involved in another arrest during a protect surrounding George Flloyd. Munafo is also already serving a 24-month federal prison sentence for an unrelated case in Michigan, where he was accused of sending threats to the governor, Gretchen Whitmer.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News article

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Fitzgerald
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds
Additional details: Resident of Janesville, Wisconsin
Short narrative: Michael Fitzgerald was charged and arrested for his role in the January 6 Capitol protests. He wore a shirt that stated "There will be a wild protest. January 6, 2021" on the front of it. The complaint does not say whether Fitzgerald himself assaulted any officers. Photos show him near the front of the line, “participating in the push against law enforcement officers.” In total, it appeared that he was in the Capitol for about 40 minutes before he left through a window.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Luke Russell Coffee
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon [2 counts]; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(3) and (b)(1)(A) - Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(E) - Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: Resident of TX; Believer in QAnon conspiracy
Short narrative: Luke Russell Coffee, 41, of TX, was charged with Civil Disorder; two counts of Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; and Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building following his participation in the Capitol riot and his alleged assault of a DC metropolitan police officer with a crutch. There is extensive video footage of Coffee at the US Capitol with the crutch beating several cops. Coffee has pled not guilty. This case is currnetly pending.
Source description: Charging documents, Court Documents, Local news article, Governmental reports and release (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Dovid Schwartzberg
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Brooklyn, NY; Indicted by Bill of Information; "Sentenced 9/7/22 to 45 days of incarceration, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: On May 3, 2021, Dovid Schwartzberg, 19, of Brooklyn, New York, was charged with numerous federal offenses for his activities in Washington, D.C. on January 6, 2021. Schwartzberg was identified through Capitol Building security cameras that show him entering the building through a broken window; in an interview with the FBI, he asserted that he was not the one who broke the window. A tipster identified him through photos and a video uploaded to Facebook. The same tipster also provided photos of Schwartzberg in the Capitol Building, a video link on Twitter showing Schwartzberg exiting it.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Article, Local News Article, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Derrick Evans
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Impeding, Obstructing or Interfering with law enforcement during a civil disorder;
Additional details: Resident of WV; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 6/22/22 to three months in jail, three years of supervised release, $2,000 fine, $2,000 restitution.
Short narrative: Derrick Evans, 35 of West Virginia, pled guilty to Impeding, Obstructing or Interfering with Law Enforcement During a Civil Disorder for his role in the January 6 Capitol riot. He was sentenced to 3 months in prison. During the event, the West Virginia Delegate live streamed footage of himself entering the Capitol building in Washington DC. Evans, a newly elected state representative from West Virginia, reportedly deleted the video soon after the siege ended, but it soon re-emerged on Reddit. Days later, Evans resigned from his office in the House of Delegates.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeramiah Caplinger
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) and (G) Violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; 40:5104(d) Climbing on U.S. Capitol grounds;
Additional details: Resident of MI; Charged by bill of information; "Sentenced 8/1/22 to 35 days in jail, followed by 24 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution"
Short narrative:
Jeramiah Caplinger, 25 of Michigan, pled guilty to Stepping, Climbing, Removing, or Injuring Property on the Capitol Grounds. He was sentenced to 35 days in prison. He attended the protest in Washington D.C. on January 6 and ended up inside the Capitol building. He described the damage he saw inside, including seeing someone urinating in a corner and seeing officers with their guns drawn. 

"According to court documents, Jeramiah Caplinger told a Detroit news website in mid-February that he scaled the U.S. Capitol's wall and went inside the building during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot. Caplinger told the news organization the events of 2020 “fueled outrage” among former President Trump’s supporters and “being told the election was stolen was one poke too many." Videos from social media show Caplinger wearing a red bucket hat labeled Trump 2020 and carrying an America flag attached to a tree branch through the halls of the Capitol, according to court documents. Caplinger also told the Detroit news website he hopes to run for political office some day and said, “My rage towards the establishment, Democrats and RINO Republicans is great. Think of Pompeii when it was destroyed by Mount Vesuvius.”" (NPR
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Nelson & Markofski
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry or disorderly conduct; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of WI; WI Army National Guard PFC Delta Company, 1st Battalion, 128th Infantry Regiment; Sentenced 12/10/2021 to 24 months probation, $500 restitution and $1,000 fine.
Short narrative: On May 6th, 2021, Abram Markofski and Brandon Nelson were indicted on charges of *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry or disorderly conduct; and 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. Both took a plea deal and pleaded guilty to the charge of 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. Sentencing is pending. Of note is that Markofski joined the National Guard in 2019 and is currently a private. An FBI affidavit says Nelson told agents that he and Markofski drove to Washington to see President Donald Trump’s political rally and both he and Markofski admitted to entering the Capitol.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Nelson & Markofski
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry or disorderly conduct; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of WI; Sentenced to 24 months probation, $500 restitution and $1,000 fine
Short narrative: On May 6th, 2021, Abram Markofski and Brandon Nelson were indicted on charges of *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry or disorderly conduct; and 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. Both took a plea deal and pleaded guilty to the charge of 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. Sentencing is pending. An FBI affidavit says Nelson told agents that he and Markofski drove to Washington to see President Donald Trump’s political rally and both he and Markofski admitted to entering the Capitol.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Glen Mitchell Simon
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of GA; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 8/12/22 to 8 months of incarceration, 12 months of supervised release, $1,000 fine, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: On May 7, 2021, Glen Mitchell Simon, 30 from GA, was indicted for his involvement in the Capitol raid. "He was identified via social media by multiple tipsters, including one who attended school with him. Photos and videos posted on Simon's Facebook account showed him inside the U.S. Capitol, with one video saying, "We weren't invited, we broke in here," according to court documents. One photo shows him on the steps of the Capitol building, embracing a person wearing a rubber mask shaped like a bald eagle. Simon reportedly deleted many of the posts, but FBI agents tracked him down via a search of publicly available databases." (NPR) He pled guilty to the charge of Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds and was sentenced to 8 months incarceration and 12 months of supervised release.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Duke Edward Wilson
Charges: 18:111(a)(1),2 Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds: 18:1512(c)(2),2 Obstruction of an Official proceeding; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings
