Name of case: United States of America v. Kevin James Lyons
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building ; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disruption of Official Business; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting
Additional details: Resident of IL; Lyons was separately charged in July 2014 with obstructing a Chicago police officer; Charged by Bill of Information then Indicment; didn't accept a plea bargain but did did agree to the facts in a stipulated trial allowing him to agree to conviction without admitting guilty; additionally sentenced to 36 months supervised release and $2000 restitution
Short narrative: On February 3, 2021, Kevin James Lyons, 40, of Chicago, Illinois, was charged with entering and remaining in a restricted building, entering and remaining in certain rooms in the Capitol Building, and disorderly donduct in the Capitol Building. Lyons entered the Capitol Building on January 6 in connection with the riots. Hisactions were motivated by his rightist: anti-government beliefs. Lyons refused a plea deal but did agree to the facts presented in a stipulated trial allowing him to agree to conviction without having to truly admit guilt. He was sentenced to 51 months prison, 36 months supervised release, and $2000 restitution.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, Local news articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Hunter Palm
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2),2 Obstruction of an official proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) Entering and remaining in certain rooms in the Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of CO
Short narrative: "Palm narrated a video as he walked through the Capitol, documenting people searching for and screaming about House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, including one who stated: "We're gonna kill her." A family member identified Palm to the FBI, saying he had entered the Capitol when police allowed the crowd to enter, court records show. Palm handed over his photos and video to the FBI on a flash drive during an interview with his attorney present on Feb. 6, court records show. He also took along the clothes he'd been wearing. Although Palm told the agents he was pushed into the door of the Capitol, the FBI stated he could be seen walking into the building and holding up his phone to record, with no one pushing him. In Palm's video, as they yelled about Pelosi, the crowd approached a closed door marked "OFFICE OF THE SPEAKER." He then enters the office as someone screams an obscenity about Pelosi and then approaches a laptop on a conference room table and asks "Who's good at hacking." Eventually Palm sits down and puts his feet on the table and said "I think I like my new dining room. I pay for it."" (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Emanuel Jackson
Charges: 18:111(a) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; 18:111(a) and (b) Obstructing or impeding certain officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building
Additional details: Resident of Washington, D.C.
Short narrative: Emanuel Jackson, 20 was arrested for his role in the 1/6/21 Capitol siege and for attacking capitol and Metropolitan police with a baseball bat. He is facing a number of charges including assault on a federal law enforcement officer with a dangerous weapon; knowingly engaging in any acts of physical violence against any person or property in any restricted building or grounds; and knowingly entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds without lawful authority. An indictment alleges Jackson is observed on U.S. Capitol video surveillance footage making a fist and repeatedly striking a U.S. Capitol Police officer while attempting to forcefully enter the building. Jackson was part of a violent and aggressive crowd and is also clearly observed in surveillance video of the West Terrace entrance armed with a metal baseball bat. The defendant is observed repeatedly striking a group of both U.S. Capitol and Metropolitan Police Department uniformed officers with the baseball bat. This case is currently pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Release (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Christian Kulas
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building and grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Illinois; Sentenced 4/26/22 to six months of supervised probation, including 60 days home detention, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: On June 11, 2021, Christian Kulas, 24, was harged with multiple federal offenses for his participation in the January 2021 Capitol protests. Kulas travelled to Washington D.C. with his brother and posted several videos of himself inside and outside the Capitol Building with the crowd of protestors to his Instagram account. One of the videos shows him wearing a "Keep America Great" hat and gleefully smiling.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Nicole Prado
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Violent entry and disorderly conduct and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of MD; Wearing MAGA hat; Sentenced 2/7/22, 12 months of probation, including 60 hours of community service, $742 fine, $500 restitution
Short narrative: On June 14, 2021, Nicole Prado, 30, of Gaithersburg, Maryland was charged with multiple federal offenses stemming from her activities at the United States Capitol Building on January 6, 2021. THe FBI first received an anonymous tip about her on January 7. Having obtained her description from the Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration, they found her to have appeared in a video posted to the Instagram account of a person whose name remains redacted in the statement of facts. The person narrating the video says, "Please meet the new Congresswoman... she uh, she just was in the Capitol for the first time today. She stormed the Capitol, she's the new Congresswoman. She's the new Speaker of the House." Additionally, CCTV footage captured her, wearing a MAGA hat and carrying a small American flag, walking about the interior of the Capitol Building and taking photos that also appeared on the unnamed accomplice's Instagram account.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Sara Carpenter
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) and 2 Civil disorder and Aiding and abetting; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and Aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 18:1752(a)(2); Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D); Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; *40:5104(e)(2)(G); Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Richmond Hills, Queens, NY; NYPD police officer; Initially charged via Information sheet, later charged by supersceding indictment; "Sara Carpenter found guilty 3/9/23 after a trial in U.S. District Court of civil disorder, obstruction of an official proceeding, both felonies, and five misdemeanors."; "Sara Carpenter Sentenced 12/19/23 to 22 months in prison and 24 months of supervised release"
Short narrative: Sara Carpenter, 51, a retired NYPD officer who lives in Queens, drove to Washington, DC to participate in the Capitol Protests. According to Department of Justice documents, On or about January 7, 2021, an anonymous tip was submitted to the FBI stating that Sara Carpenter had called a relative and stated that she was inside the Capitol Building on January 6, 2021 and was teargassed, then returned home that night. Members of FBI JTTF conducted a voluntary interview of Sara Carpenter. During this interview, Carpenter stated that she left her residence in New York and drove to Washington, D.C. on or about the evening of January 5, 2021. Carpenter said she went to the rally point where President Donald J. Trump’s Twitter page had instructed all supporters to meet to hear about the election fraud and began to walk witha large group of people to the Capitol. Carpenter stated that she entered the Rotunda of the Capitol and told FBI agents that police were yelling for individuals to get out, then pushing and shoving the crowd. Carpenter he exited the Capitol building after she was trampled and pepper sprayed. During the January 18, 2021 interview with FBI, Carpenter stated that she had taken video of the interior of the Capitol Building on January 6, 2021 using her cellular phone and voluntarily sent me a text message containing video footage of the Capitol. Carpenter has pled not guilty and this case is currently pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Article, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Leonard Pearson Ridge IV
Charges: *18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of PA; Sentenced 1/4/22 to 14 days of incarceration, one year of supervised release, 100 hours of cmmunity service, $1,000 fine, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Leonard Pearson "Pearce" Ridge, 19 of Pennsylvania, pled guilty to Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds and was sentenced to 14 days of prison. "In the days following Jan. 6, a confidential witness contacted the FBI, stating that Ridge uploaded multiple pictures and videos of himself inside and outside the Capitol to a Snapchat messenger group. “Currently making history,” one caption read. Additional footage and geodata show Ridge walking inside the rotunda. “I got tear gased [sic] and maced five times,” he wrote to a friend that same day in the evening. “Yeah man so epic I have a video of me fighting riot police in the capitol [sic] building.”" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Anton Lunyk
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NY; Indicted by Bill of Information; "Sentenced 9/15/2022 to 12 months of probation, including two months of home confinement, $742 fine, $500 restitution, 60 hours of community service."
Short narrative:
Anton Lunyk, 26 of New York, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and was sentenced to 12 months probation for his role in the Capitol Raid. According to the NYTimes, a phone from the White House called Lunyk on January 6, but is unknown who placed the call and whether the call was answered or went to voicemail.

"A person that went to college with Anton Lunyk contacted the FBI after recognizing him in the background of a New York Post Twitter image from the Jan. 6 U.S. Capitol riot, court documents say. The photo in which Lunyk allegedly appears is from inside the Capitol building, and it is a screenshot from a video Live Streamed by well-known far-right personality Tim Gionet, known as Baked Alaska. Ahead of Jan. 6, Lunyk also allegedly posted on his Instagram account, "This is going to be an interesting next few weeks . . . who else is going to DC this week?” Law enforcement used license plate reading technology from New York City and Washington, D.C., to capture Lunyk's travel to the Capitol as well as surveillance footage from the Capitol to confirm his presence inside the building, court documents say." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. John Juran
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NY; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 2/23/22 to three years of probation, including two months of home detention, $500 fine, $500 in restitution.
Short narrative: John 'Jack' Juran, 51 of New York, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and was sentenced to three years of probation for his role in the Capitol Raid. According to NPR's WBFO, "[a]uthorities said cell phone analysis indicated he was in the building for only about 10 minutes and left when told to do so by police. Juran has since expressed his regret for participating in the uprising."
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Daniel Warmus
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NY; Indicted by Bill of Information; "Sentenced 9/27/22 to 45 days of incarceration, 24 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Daniel Warmus, 37 of New York, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and sentenced to 45 days incarceration for his role in the Capitol raid. "A tipster had reported to the FBI that they overheard him in a dentist's office talking about smoking a marijuana cigarette inside the Capitol on Jan. 6 and refusing officers requests to leave. Agents began surveillance at his home and his business and matched photos of him with video taken inside the Capitol. The FBI stated he was seen in photos taken outside the Capitol carrying a large flag on a tree branch that stated "(expletive) Antifa."" (USA Today) He wore a Trump 2020 hat and 'CNN is Fake News' sweatshirt.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, Local News articles

Other names/aliases: William Tyrone, Bill Tryon, Billy Tryon
Name of case: United States of America v. William Tryon
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Selkirk, New York; Indicted by Bill of Information; "Sentenced 1/14/22 to 50 days of incarceration, followed by 12 months of supervised relese, $1,000 fine, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: On June 21, 2021, William Tryon was indicted on charges of Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The defendant's rmade incriminating remarks on a Facebook page for a group called "Liberty Bell Alliance 76," of which Tryon is the founder, according to footage included in the complaint. Tryon accepted a plea deal in which he pled guilty to Count 1 of the charges, and was ultimately sentenced to 50 days in prison and 12 months of unsupervised released. He was also ordered to pay a $1,000.00 fine and $500.00 restitution. "A 70-year-old Coeymans man who staunchly opposes what he called "ungodly socialist forces" was arrested by the FBI on Tuesday and charged in U.S. District Court with taking part in the Jan. 6 insurrection at the U.S. Capitol in Washington, D.C. William Tryon, whose attendance at the Jan. 6 storming of the Capitol was caught on YouTube.com - and also by a relative who turned him in - was charged with three federal misdemeanors: knowingly entering a restricted building without authority, knowingly engaging in disorderly conduct in a restricted building and violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds." - Times Union.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Eric J. Bochene
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NY; Indicted by Bill of Information; "Eric Bochene Sentenced 11/3/23 to 90 days incarceration with credit for time served; 12 months supervised release; 25.00 special assessment and 500.00 restitution."
Short narrative: Eric J. Bochene, A.K.A Eric Festo, A.K.A. Eric Bochenek, 49, of New York, was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; for his role in the January 6th Capitol riot. Bochene was reported by multiple tipsters regarding his participation. Additionally there are text messages and photos from inside the Capitol building confirming Bochene's participation. Bochene has pled guilty to all counts and sentencing is currently pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Parks & Baggot
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:641 - Theft of government property
Additional details: Resident of TN; Indicted by Bill of Information; "Stewart Parks Sentenced 11/16/23 to eight (8) months of incarceration and twelve (12) months of supervised release. As to Counts 3 and 4 of the 15 Information, the Defendant is sentenced to six (6) months of incarceration. All terms of incarceration and supervised release shall run concurrently."
Short narrative: Stewart Parks, 29, of Middle Tennessee, was arrested on June 3rd in Columbia, TN, for entering the capitol building with Matthew Baggot during the January 6th riots. He was carrying a Don't Tread on Me flag and stole a handheld metal detector.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Philip Edward Kramer
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:641 Theft of government property
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Ontario, CA; Sentenced 5/12/22, 30 days in jail, 100 hours of community service, $2,500 fine, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: On June 21, 2021, Philip Edward Kramer, A.K.A. Phil Kramer, 61, of Ontario, CA, was indicted for his role in the Capitol riot on January 6, 2021, having been charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Theft of government property. He confessed to attending the riot and willingly interviewed with the FBI. He brought a snowboard helmet and a walking cane into the building which he claims were for self-defense, as well as a Master Lock and climbing rope “in case someone was coming at [his] throat or something.” He also stole a "do not enter" sign from the building and disposed of it when he returned to California (DOJ Complaint). Kramer accepted a plea deal, pleading guilty to parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building, and was sentenced to 30 days in jail, 100 hours of community service, $2,500 fine, $500 restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental reports and release

Name of case: United States of America v. Parks & Baggot
Charges: 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of TN; Indicted by Bill of Information
Short narrative: Matthew Baggot, 28, was arrested on May 30th in Murfreesboro, TN for entering the capitol building with Stewart Park during the Jan 6th riots and throwing an object at police officers.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND Supports organized political violence
Name of case: United States of America v. John Maron Nassif
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of FL; Indicted by Bill of Information; "John Nassif found guilty of entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building."
Short narrative: John Maron Nassif, 55, from Florida, bragged on Facebook about having attended the Capitol riot. Federal officials arrested him after discovering posts where he said, "I was there." Nassif, if convicted, could face a year in prison, a year of probation, and a hefty $100,000 fine.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles, Governmental Reports and Releases

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND Supports organized political violence
Name of case: United States of America v. Sean David Watson
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of TX; Wore 3% t-shirt to Capitol riot though no additional confirmation is available; Joined Oath Keepers in 2012; Also arrested 1/5/21 by MPD for "crossing a police line during a protest" accorign to affidavit; "Sentenced 9/6/22 to 24 months of probation, including seven days of incarceration, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution" (DOJ)
Short narrative: "Sean David Watson showed a coworker videos on his cellphone that he claimed to have taken inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, court documents indicate. That coworker then called the FBI to turn him in. In an initial interview with the FBI, Watson said he had participated in the Jan. 6 rally but denied being inside the Capitol building. In a second interview with agents, the FBI seized Watson's cellphone, and he admitted that he had entered the building. On that seized phone, law enforcement found photos from inside and outside the building and texts sent shortly after the riot, one of which read "I was one of the people that helped storm the capitol building and smash out the windows . We made history today. Proudest day of my life!” According to local news reports, Watson’s home is covered with messages, including “COVID1984," “Democrats stole the election" and "Veterans for Trump." NPR was not able to confirm his military history." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Kurt Peterson
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1361 - Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of KY; "Kurt Peterson Sentenced 11/2/23 to Forty-Five (45) Days of Incarceration followed by a term of Sixty (60) Days of Supervised Release to be served as Home Incarceration (with conditions). Defendant further Ordered to pay $4,700.00 of Restitution and $100.00 Special Assessment."
Short narrative: "On Jan. 10, Kurt Peterson alllegedly posted a lengthy message on Facebook indicating that he had been inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6. The message, detailed in court documents, begins: "To my family and friends who are able to see this, I am writing it with a voice recognition program while driving. I feel the need to keep moving and trying to keep my phone wrapped such that it can’t be traced most of the time." He then described the pro-Trump rally as peaceful and loving, but added "When there are huge crowds and there are people that are inciting violence, the crowds will many times be pulled in to this action." In the post, Peterson reportedly stated that he was with three military veterans and that he was not there to hurt anybody or damage anything, but was there as a "show of solidarity to right the wrongs of the past election." According to court documents, Peterson indicated that he was there when a woman, presumably Ashli Babbitt, was fatally shot by police. Peterson reportedly added that "Nonlethal force could have been used without the lethal shot that was made by this bodyguard in the speaker's lobby" and that he offered to provide first aid but was denied. Phone records obtained from Samsung reportedly place Peterson in the Capitol that day as well. He also appeared in police body camera footage and in at least two publicly posted videos, including one from the location where Babbitt was shot, according to court documents. In one video, Peterson can allegedly be seen using his fist to smash a window on the outside of the Capitol and shouting, “This is our house. Let us in. Our house.” (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Larry Rendall Brock
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive Conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(3),2 Impeding ingress and egress in a restricted building or grounds and aiding and abetting; 40:5104(e)(2)(A) Entering and remaining on the Floor of congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Engaging in Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct on the Capitol Buildings or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(E),2 Impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings and aiding and abetting; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of TX; "Brock was a lieutenant colonel and an A-10 pilot in the Air Force, serving on active duty from 1989 to 1998, according to the Air Force. He retired from the Air Force Reserves in 2014." (NPR); "Larry Brock Sentenced 3/17/23 to 24 months in prison, $2,000 in restitution."
Short narrative: On January 6, 2021, in Washington, D.C., Larry Rendell Brock, 53, of Texas, was initially charged with one count each of knowingly Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Impreding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds and Aiding and Abetting (later dropped); Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress, Disorderly Conduct in a capitol Building, and Impeding Passage Through the capitol Grounds or Buildings and Aiding and Abetting (later dropped). A superseding indictment charged Brock with Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a capitol Building. Brock, an Air Force veteran, traveled to Washington, D.C. on or about January 6th to participate and encourage forcible entry into the U.S. Capitol. Two witnesses, one of which was Brock's ex-wife, called the FBI National Threat Operations Center to report that they recognized Brock in a picture taken inside the Capitol building during the riot. He was photographed in a military-style helmet and tactical vest carrying flex cuffs. Brock was found guilty 11/16/22 of the felony offense of obstruction of an official proceeding, and five misdemeanor offenses: entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a Capitol Building; entering and remaining on the floor of Congress; disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building. Brock is to be sentenced on Feb. 14, 2023.
Source description: Charging Documents, Government reports and release

Name of case: United States of America v. Nicholas Patrick Hendrix
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of ME; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Carried sign reading "Stop the communist & terrorist revolution"; "Sentenced - 12/9/22 to 30 days incarceration, 36 months supervised release, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: "Hendrix faces charges of unlawfully entering a restricted building and disorderly or disruptive behavior inside a restricted building, which are Class A misdemeanors with a maximum penalty of one year in prison, $100,000 in fines, and one year of probation.The other two charges of violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds, and parading, demonstrating or picketing inside a Capitol building are petty misdemeanors, and carry maximum penalties of six months in prison and a $5,000 fine." - Pressherald. Hendrix, 34, turned him self in and has been reported to only have been inside the Capitol building for a minute or two.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Kene Brian Lazo
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of VA; Indicted by a Bill of Information; $500 restitution under Plea Agreement; separately arrested on charges of rape, aggravated sexual batter of a minor under 13 years of age, and assault and battery of a family member
Short narrative: On May 28, 2021, Kene Brian Lazo, a Filipino America of Norfolk, Virginia, was arrested for his role in the January 6 riot at the Capitol. He is charged with: Knowingly Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority, Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds or in a Capitol Building, and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The FBI investigated him and learned of his participation through Facebook, where he went by "Fam Council".
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles, Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Savannah Danielle McDonald, Nolan Harold Kidd
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Wearing Trump hat; Photographed holding a handwritten sign reading "If the dead can vote just wait and see what the living can do"; Indicted by Bill of Information; Sentenced 5/10/22 to 21 days in jail, $500 in restitution
Short narrative: "Savannah McDonald and Nolan Kidd allegedly traveled together to Washington, D.C., the day before the assault on the U.S. Capitol. According to court documents, they can be seen in many of the most familiar photos of Jan. 6 -- near the man who became known as the “QAnon Shaman.” On Jan. 14, the FBI received a tip that McDonald had been inside the Capitol building and then interviewed her at her home days later. Court documents say that when she was shown a picture from the riot, McDonald acknowledged that the person circled in it was her. A photo returned from a search of Kidd’s phone shows pictures of the two smiling for the camera. In a video posted by the Young Patriot Society and credited to Kidd, McDonald allegedly can be seen with Kidd, confirming they were “part of the first 100 people to enter the Capitol.” Agents also reviewed video footage of Kidd and McDonald heading to the Upper West Terrace of the Capitol, with McDonald holding a sign above her head reading, “If the dead can vote just wait and see what the living can do,” court documents say. Kidd and McDonald, along with a group of rioters, allegedly pushed through a line of law enforcement and headed into the building through a fire door. A search warrant for a Snapchat account McDonald claimed was hers returned images of a group video chat in which McDonald reportedly says, “I’m the only girl that made it into the Senate.”" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Savannah Danielle McDonald, Nolan Harold Kidd
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Wearing MAGA hat; Indicted by Bill of Information; Sentenced 5/9/22 to 45 days in jail, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: "Nolan Kidd and Savannah McDonald allegedly traveled together to Washington, D.C., the day before the assault on the U.S. Capitol. According to court documents, they can be seen in many of the most familiar photos of Jan. 6 -- near the man who became known as the “QAnon Shaman.” On Jan. 11, the FBI received a tip that Kidd had been inside of the Capitol building, which included a screenshot of an account believed to be his, showing an album of pictures of the day captioned, “Just made it home, I have tons of photos and videos to share with you guys.” Federal prosecutors say that agents interviewed Kidd at his home days later, and he said that “the doors to the U.S. Capitol were wide open.” A photo returned from a search of Kidd’s phone shows pictures of him and McDonald smiling for the camera, and Kidd showing a “thumbs up.” Kidd can also reportedly be seen in a video posted by the Young Patriot Society and credited to himself, alongside McDonald saying, “[W]e got in from the back.” Agents also reviewed video footage of Kidd and McDonald allegedly heading to the Upper West Terrace of the Capitol with a group of rioters that pushed through a line of law enforcement and headed into the building through a fire door. A search warrant for a Snapchat account McDonald claimed was hers returned images of a group chat in which a user believed to be Kidd reportedly says, “Me and Savannah are F***ING STORMTROOPERS.”" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Adams
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of VA; Indicted by Bill of Information; Defendant was arrested 4/22/21 and released on personal recognizance - information filed 6/24/21 and arraignment dates set for 7/8/21 and 7/16/21 where defendant failed to appear; Considered a fugitive according to the DOJ as of 06/22/22; "Michael Adams Sentenced 9/22/23 to sixty (60) days of Incarceration, $10.00 Special Assessment, and Restitution in the amount of $500.00. Counts 1, 2, and 3 DISMISSED ON ORAL MOTION OF THE GOVERNMENT."
Short narrative: "Adams carried a longboard skateboard with orange wheels and a large blue flag with him to the Capitol, the FBI stated in court documents. He was seen inside the Capitol in video footage at 2:46, 2:49 and 2:59 p.m., according to the FBI, and again in body-worn camera video on the steps at 4:21 p.m. The FBI also used a geofence with cell phone data to determine that Adams was within the Capitol grounds from 2:45 to 4:59 p.m. A witness reported him to the FBI, which identified him by a drivers license photo and a booking photo taken on Jan. 5 for something unrelated to the Capitol charges." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Releases

Charges: 24:2203.4DCMR Violation of Emergency Order or Regulation - Curfew
Additional details: Resident of MD
Short narrative: Alexander Kimmich, 21, of MD, was arrested in DC and is facing a charge of curfew violation as recorded in MPD "Unrest-Related Arrest Data as of January 7 2021". His case is still pending.

Charges: 24 DCMR 2203.4 Curfew Violation; 24 DCMR 2100.3Crossing Police Line
Additional details: Resisent of Wisconsin
Short narrative: Daniel Cleene, 60, of Wisconsin, was arrested for violating curfew as well as crossing police lines, both misdemeanors. Cleene was charged accordingly with Violation of emergency order or regulation - curfew, and Crossing police lines, entering police area.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, Local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Trevor Brown
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of MI
Short narrative: "At least three people contacted the FBI after seeing posts on Trevor Brown's Facebook and Instagram accounts indicating he participated in the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol, including breaching the building, according to court documents. Brown is allegedly seen in multiple videos from the day, including one where he is yelling through a bullhorn as rioters attempt to breach a tunnel going into the building, court documents indicate. Shortly after that video was taken, police apprehended Brown and placed him in handcuffs, but he was later released without any charges being filed. On Jan. 7, Brown allegedly posted on Facebook, "People should be storming that Brothel we call the Capitol everyday for what goes on in there. ... Today thise [sic] elitist creeps are getting the same thing we live with everyday, fear for their own safety." In another post, he reportedly wrote, "I made it into the Capitol. I almost died getting in but I made it.” Since at least November, Brown had posted content on social media that questioned the legitimacy of the presidential election, court documents indicate." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Samuel Christopher Fox
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 4/5/22 to 36 months of probation, including 60 days home detention, $2,500 fine, $500 restitution
Short narrative: Samuel Christopher Fox, 32 from Pennsylvania, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and was sentenced to 36 months of probation for his role in the Capitol Raid. He posted pictures and videos of himself inside the Capitol and bragged about being one of the first ones inside. He has since deleted these posts and videos. He allegedly admitted to stealing paperwork as well.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND Supports organized political violence
Name of case: United States of America v. Mark Grods
Charges: 18:371 - Conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting;
Additional details: Indicted by Bill of Information; Coordinated with Oath Keepers via Signal and provided firearms to be stored in a VA hotel; Resident of Mobile, AL
Short narrative: "Federal prosecutors allege that Mark Grods coordinated with members of the extremist anti-government militia known as the Oath Keepers to interfere with the certification of the Electoral College vote on Jan. 6. Ahead of the Capitol riot, court documents state, Grods joined a group chat named on the encrypted messaging app Signal called "DC OP: Jan 6 21." Grods "brought firearms to Washington, D.C., and eventually provided them to another individual to store in a Virginia hotel," while Grods stayed with other members of the group at the Mayflower Hotel in D.C., prosecutors say. While the Capitol riot was ongoing, Grods allegedly rode in a golf cart with others members of the Oath Keepers to the Capitol, then breached the building while carrying what prosecutors describe as a "large stick." Soon after, Grods exited the building as law enforcement used pepper balls to try to force people out of the Capitol, the court documents state. Later, he allegedly met with other members of the Oath Keepers outside the Capitol building, and, in the days after the riot, said he had deleted his messages on Signal. As part of a plea agreement, Grods has agreed to testify in court and sit for interviews with investigators." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Lesperance, Cusick & Cusick
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of FL; Indicted by Bill of Information; Remains on personal recognizance
Short narrative: On June 29, 2021, Casey Cusick, 35, and his father James "Jim" Varnell Cusick Jr., 72, who lead the Global Outreach Ministries church in Melbourne, were indicted on charges of 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. David Lesperance, 69, a member of their church, was with them at the Capitol and was arrested on similar charges. Casey Cusick plead not guilty, and sentencing data is pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Ariticles

Name of case: United States of America v. Brian Mock
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; 18:1752(a)(1),(2) Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorders; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in any of the Capitol buildings or grounds
Additional details: "Brian Christopher Mock, 44, of Minneapolis, was found guilty of all 11 charges following a bench trial before Chief Judge James E. Defendant sentenced to concurrent terms of thirty-three (33) months as to counts 1ss-6ss, twelve (12) months incarceration as to counts 7ss-10ss, six (6) months incarceration as to count 11ss, followed by a twenty-four (24) month concurrent term of Supervised Release, Special Assessments totaling $710, and Restitution in the amount of $2000."
Short narrative: Brian Mock, 42, is charged in Washington D.C. with assaulting a federal officer; unlawful entry on restricted buildings or grounds; and acts of physical violence on Capitol grounds.

Name of case: United States of America v. Andrew Alan Hernandez
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Expressed support for QAnon; Signed up as an Oath Keepers in 2012; "A review of the accounts suggests that Hernandez adheres to multiple ideologies including: Q-Anon, health and science related conspiracies, financial conspiracies, and various conspiracies associated to US political figures" (Statement of Facts); "Sentenced 1/30/23 to 18 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release and $2,000 restitution"
Short narrative: Andrew Alan Hernandez, 44 of California, pled guilty Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and was senteced to 18 months of incarceration for his role in the Capitol raid. "Andrew Hernandez was identified by a manager at his workplace after a photo of him wearing a shirt and hat bearing the company’s name and logo during the Capitol riot was published on the cover of The New York Times Magazine. After being confronted by the company’s management, Hernandez was subsequently terminated for misrepresenting the company in illegal activities, according to court documents. Hernandez was also seen in Capitol security camera footage carrying a flag with a GoPro camera zip-tied to the flagpole, according to the FBI. In the footage he can allegedly be seen with a group of rioters violently pushing their way into the building. A review of his social media accounts suggests that Hernandez adheres to multiple ideologies, including Q-Anon, health and science-related conspiracies, financial conspiracies and various conspiracies associated with U.S. political figures, according to the FBI. In a Twitter post, days before the Jan. 6, 2021, riot, Hernandez wrote, “Happy New Year to You and your Family Courageous Mr. President. You are the Greatest President These United States of America Has Had! We the People are Honored to Stand with You, Fight and Defeat this [hidden] ENEMY Once and For All. For God and Country We Fight!”" (NPR)
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Jonathan Davis Laurens
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; *40:5104(e)(2)(A) - Entering and remaining on the floor of Congress; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of GA; Indicted by a Bill of Information; took a plea deal 2/2/22; Sentenced 6/10/22 to 60 days of home detention, 12 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $742 fine, $500 in restitution.
Short narrative: On July 2, 2021, Jonathan Davis Laurens, 38, was indicted by a bill of information for his activities at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. According to the statement of offense, Laurens was among the first to enter the building through a Senate exterior door and, from there, walked throughout many areas of the building interior--including the rotunda, the Rayburn Reception Room, Statutory Hall, the Crypt, and the House of Representatives wing--and took selfies of himself wearing an orange hat, a black face mask, and a “Trump 2020: No More Bullshit” flag as a cape. In Facebook posts, Laurens reacted to the event by saying "we got into the capitol (sic), walked around, chanted some slogans and stuff. A few bad apples were trying to break windows and kick on doors, but most of us put that s**t to bed real fast. We weren’t there to tear s**t up, just disrupt the system. All in all, I had fun! Lol."
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles, Government Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Suzanna Ianni
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; Member of Super Happy Fun America and organizer of the Boston 'Straight Pride' parade; Resident of Natick, Massachusets; Sentenced 12/2 to 15 days of incarceration, 30 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Suzanne Ianni, 59, of Natick, Massachusetts pled guilty to Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building. Ianni is a senior member of of Super Happy Fun America (formerly ResistMarxism), a group that advocates for the "straight community". Ianni was pictured on a chartered bus with members of SHFA on the night on January 5th. On January 6th she was seen entering the Capitol building. Ianni and Sahady are involved in Super Happy Fun America together and coordinated their joint trip to the Capitol riot. She was sentenced on 12/2/2022 to 15 days of incarceration, 30 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution. [NOTE: Sahady and Ianni are not charged together]
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Ryan Seth Suleski
Charges: 18:641 Theft of Government Property; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of VA; "Sentenced 10/14/22 to 60 days of incarceration, 60 hours community service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Ryan Seth Suleski, 33, a resident of Virginia pled guilty to his involvement in the capitol Raid. "According to court documents, Ryan Suleski, a federal firearms licensed dealer, was found after a text tip from a TikTok user who sent a link to a video on the social media platform that appeared to be a recording of Suleski speaking to the camera about the riot at the U.S. Capitol. After another search, investigators found a longer video in which Suleski says, "Today was fucking nuts. But we got our point across. We showed how weak their defense was. And we showed Congress that America is tired of being f***ing quiet and that we're about that life." Another witness called in a tip to the FBI and identified Suleski as a person of interest in a photograph on the Metropolitan Police Department's website. That witness also said he had heard from a relative of Suleski who alleged that he had stolen mail from the Capitol." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Kenneth John Reda
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of FL; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 3/30/22 to three years or probation, including 60 days of home detention and 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution
Short narrative: Kenneth John Reda, 54 of Florida, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and was sentenced to three years of probation in connection with the Capitol Riot. He used Parler to communicate his success in entering the Capitol building. He is a physical education teacher at Viera High School in Florida. On Parler, he wrote "We have got to get to DC on January 6th it is IMPERATIVE every single person that VOTED for Trump has to flood DC." His presence in the Capitol was corroboated by CCTV footage inside the building and Gmail account data.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Jackman, et al.
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) - Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:641, 2 - Theft of government property
Additional details: Resident of FL; Remains on personal recognizance
Short narrative: Arthur Jackman, 30, and four others face several charges following their participation in the U.S. Capitol riots on 6 January 2021. Jackman, who at one point reportedly served as vice president of the Central Florida Proud Boys, was seen in news footage taking a selfie inside the Senate chamber, and texted a selfie to a childhood friend who messaged him to ask if he was involved in the riot. The accompanying text from Jackman read, “We stormed and took over,” according to a screenshot in the report. Jackman allegedly also stole an America flag and a flagpole of less than $1,000 in value. The defendant has pleaded not guilty to all charges, and is currently released on personal recognizance.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Short narrative: Kevin A. Tuck, 51, has been charged with Obstruction of an official proceeding, aiding and abetting, Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, Entering and remaining in the gallery of Congress, Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and Parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building following his participation in the Capitol riots on 6 January 2021. Do you remember what conservative means, Republicans? Hear me out: We are embracing the homosexual lifestyle as if this is normal.” Tuck has pleaded non guilty to all charges, and is currently released on personal recognizance.

Name of case: United States of America v. Anthony Michael Puma
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Brownstown Township, MI; "Anthony Puma sentenced 3/21/23 in the District of Columbia to nine months in prison for obstruction of an official proceeding, two years of supervised release, a $500 fine, and restitution of $2,000."
Short narrative: Anthony Michael Puma, 49, of Brownstown Township, MI, pled guilty to Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting and was sentenced to 9 months incarceration in relation to his role in the Capitol riot. An anonymous tip was submitted to the FBI Puma's involvement. The FBI then located publically available photos on Puma's Facbook of his participation in the riot. Puma was wearing a GoPro during his participation and live streamed his participation to his Facebook. Federal agents accused Puma of scaling a wall outside the Capitol, breaking in through a window and encouraging others involved in the insurrection, according to an FBI statement obtained by The Detroit News.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Anthony Joseph Scirica
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Winston-Salem, NC; Indicted by Bill of Information; "as to Count 4, that the Defendant is sentenced to 15 days on incarceration (7 intermittent weekends), with credit for time served (1 day). The Defendant is furthered ordered to pay a $500 fine and $500 in restitution. Government's oral motion to dismiss the remaining counts of the information is hereby GRANTED. Counts 1-4 are dismissed."
Short narrative: Anthony Joseph Scirica, 25, of NC, was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his role in the January 6th Capitol riot. Scirica was identified to law enforcement by at least two former co-workers as having been inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6. An additional tipster provided Scirica's Snapchat stories of his participation in the riot. Capitol security footage and location records obtained from Verizon also place Scirica in the Capitol that day. Scirica accepted a plea deal, pleading guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Scirica was sentenced to 15 days of incarceration, $500 fine, $500 restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and release (DOJ), News article

Name of case: United States of America v. Brian E. Stenz
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; Stenz pleaded guilty in January in Montgomery County Magisterial District Court to providing false statements while attempting to purchase a pistol in 2018 from a ; Sentenced 2/17/22 to 36 months of probation, including 14 consecutive days of incarceration and two months of home detention, $2,500 fine, $500 restitution.West Norriton Township gun store. Though he had pleaded guilty in 2007 to stalking, he answered “No” on his firearms forms when asked about previous convictions. He was sentenced to one year of probation.
Short narrative: Brian E. Stenz, 51, from Norristown, PA, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and was sentenced to 14 days incarceration for his role in the Capitol raid. "Stenz allegedly texted a selfie from inside the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, to someone he knew, who then told someone else, who then told the East Norriton Police Department in Norristown, Pa., who then told the FBI. In a subsequent interview with the FBI, Stenz said he traveled to Washington, D.C., on the morning of Jan. 6 and admitted to having entered the Capitol after he saw others go in. Stenz's attorney told The Philadelphia Inquirer that Stenz regrets going to Washington that day." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Andrew William Griswold
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder;
Additional details: Resident of FL; "Sentenced 7/13/22 to 75 days in jail, two years of supervised release, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: Andrew William Griswold, 28, of Niceville, Florida pled guilty to civil disorder and was sentenced to 75 incarceration for his role in the Capitol raid. "“We took the building. They couldn’t stop us. And now they know we can do it again and we will f***ing do it again,” said Andrew Griswold in a video obtained by the FBI, according to court documents. “Pelosi, Schumer, all you mofos, back off, this is our country, we are willing to do whatever it takes to keep it. Don’t mess with us…We showed 'em today. We took it. They ran. And hid,” he added. A witness, who told the FBI she grew up with Griswold and saw him frequently, identified Griswold based on multiple images and footage taken outside and inside the Capitol building, including the Senate Chamber." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Devlyn Thompson
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:111(b) - Assault on a Federal Officer;
Additional details: Resident of WA; Attorneys said in a court filing that he has autism spectrum disorder.
Short narrative: "Devlyn Thompson, 28, of Seattle, Washington, was among a crowd of individuals on the lower west terrace who were pushing against and assaulting MPD and U.S. Capitol Police (USCP) officers in the tunnel leading into the U.S. Capitol. Thompson admitted that he and others in the tunnel yelled obscenities at police and encouraged the continued assault. According to his plea, Thompson was part of a group that threw objects and projectiles at the officers, including flag poles, and grabbed and stole the officers’ riot shields to prevent them from defending themselves against the violence. Thompson personally observed police order rioters to stop, physically push the crowd back and deploy pepper spray in an effort to try to stop the ongoing assault. Later, Thompson picked up a metal baton from the floor of the tunnel and swung it overhead and downward against the police line in an apparent effort to knock a can of pepper spray from an officer’s hand and stop the officer from pepper-spraying the rioters. After more pepper spray was deployed by the rioters and the officers, Thompson retreated from the archway area...Thompson pleaded guilty to a criminal information charging him with assaulting, resisting or impeding officers while using a dangerous weapon. He is scheduled to be sentenced on Sept. 27 at 2 p.m. He faces up to 20 years in prison, as well as three years of supervised release and a $250,000 fine." (DOJ press release)
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Brittiany Angelina Dillon
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds
Additional details: Resident of MD; Indicted by Bill of Information; 60 days home detention, 3 years probation, $500 restitution
Short narrative: Brittiany Angelina Dillon, 35 of California, pled guilty to Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building and Grounds and was sentenced to three years of probation. "Dillon texted back and forth with accused rioter Bryan Betancur in the days leading up to the riot and on Jan. 6, according to federal charging documents. The pair had been texting back and forth about election fraud and plans to attend the rally in the days leading up to the siege at the Capitol. "I was there. I got pepper sprayed at the door of the capitol and tear gassed 3 times making my way up to it," she stated in one text on Jan. 6. "I fought hard .. I fell in the door and they tried to beat me with batons so I backed off and they pepper sprayed my eyes." Video footage from the Capitol shows her pushing through the crowd trying to get into the Capitol, and at one point she fell over the threshold, an FBI agent stated in the documents. She pushed forward against law enforcement again but was eventually repelled by an officer with a baton." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Munn, et al.
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of TX; Charged with husband and 3 kids; "Sentenced 10/12/22 to 36 months of probation, including 14 days of intermittent incarceration to be served in two 7-day periods, 90 days of home confinement, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative:
Dawn Marie Cooke Munn, 55 of Texas, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and was sentenced to 14 days incarceration for her role in the January 6 Capitol raid. She was charged with four other family members including three children and her husband. The family of 6 was charged except the youngest child who was too young to be charged. A picture of the family trailer from Tom Munn's Facebook page appeared to show him hauling a trailer with a QAnon sign posted on the back

"According to news reports, Dawn Munn is the mother of three of the Munns charged (Joshua, Kristi and Kayli) and partner to Thomas Munn. On Jan. 6, 2021, an additional family member, who appears not to have been at the Capitol and has not been charged, posted photos of some of the Munn family members, including the caption: "The biggest and best female empowerment I have ever seen before in my life!!!! ... These women stormed OUR capitol and demanded OUR House and Country back!!!!" Security footage from inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, also indicates that Dawn Munn entered the building with other family members, court documents indicate. Dawn Munn was also identified by an employee at a college in Borger, Texas, who had taught both her and her daughter Kristi Munn. On Jan. 6, 2021, in a Facebook conversation the FBI obtained, Dawn Munn allegedly wrote: “We were in capitol!! … I do mean IN the building!!”" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Local news, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Munn, et al.
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of TX; Charged with wife and 3 kids; "Sentenced 10/12/22 to 36 months of probation, including 14 days of intermittent incarceration to be served in two 7-day periods, 90 days of home confinement, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Thomas Munn, 54 of Texas, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and was sentenced to 14 days incarceration for his role in the January 6 Capitol raid. He was charged with four other family members including three children and his wife but one of his children was too young to be charged. A picture of the family trailer from Tom Munn's Facebook page appeared to show him hauling a trailer with a QAnon sign posted on the back. "On Dec. 28, 2020, Thomas Munn reportedly posted an image on Facebook that indicated that then-President Donald Trump had "requested your attendance" in Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6. According to court documents, Thomas Munn captioned the image: “Our President has only asked two things from us, so far... #1 Vote #2 January 6, 2021.” On Jan. 5, 2021, he allegedly wrote on Facebook, “We made it to our hotel just outside DC … 1,600 miles in 24 hrs!” and included a photo of a trailer passed on the highway with a sign that said, "D.C. Bound. We are Q." On the afternoon of Jan. 6, 2021, he posted a photo of himself with the four other family members charged and the child who has not been identified, court documents indicate. He reportedly wrote: "Made it back to the hotel about an hour ago . . . Have lots of pics and video to follow. ... The only damage to the capitol building was several windows and sets of doors. Nothing inside the capitol was damaged. I can tell you, patriots NEVER made it to the chamber. There was no violence in the capitol building, the crowd was NOT out of control . . . they were ANGRY!!!” Security footage from inside the Capitol that day indicate that Thomas Munn entered the building with his family, according to court documents." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Local news, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jon Mott
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of AK; Sentenced to 30 days in prison, three years probation, 60 hours of community service and $500 restitution
Short narrative: On July 13, 2021, Jon Thomas Mott, 38, of Flippin, Arkansas was charged with multiple federal offenses for his actions at the United States Capitol on January 6, 2021. Mott was captured on video pushing away the baton of a police officer while inside the Rotunda of the U.S. Capitol. He was later seen putting himself in the way of law enforcement officers as they attempted to move rioters out of the building. Mott was identified by three witnesses who contacted federal law enforcement and by a GoFundMe fundraiser set up by his wife to raise funds for the trip to D.C. The FBI conducted an interview with Mott at his place of work and connected him to the riot footage through a distinctive tattoo on his ring finger.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Erik Rau
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of OH; Sentenced to 45 days incarceration and a $500 restitution
Short narrative: Erik Rau, 43, a resident of Ohio pled guilty to his involvement during the capitol Raid. "In February, Erik Rau’s friend Derek Jancart was arrested in connection with the Jan. 6 insurrection, court documents show. Jancart told prosecutors he entered the U.S. Capitol with Rau, and the FBI says Jancart identified Rau in photos from the Capitol. On the same day of Jancart's arrest, Rau called the U.S. Marshals Service in Columbus, Ohio, asking to turn himself in, according to court documents. Both Jancart and Rau gave the FBI Rau’s phone number, according to prosecutors. The FBI says that it served a search warrant on Google, and that a mobile device associated with Rau’s number was determined to be in the Capitol for 39 minutes on Jan. 6." (NPR)
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Leon Brock
Charges: 18:111(a) and (b) (Felony) - Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder
Additional details: Resident of Mississippi
Short narrative: Michael Leon Brock, 54, or Walls Mississippi was arrested for his crimes related to the breach og the US Capitol on Jan 6. He is charged with federal offenses that include assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers and obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder, among other charges. He charged at law enforcement officers while holding what appeared to be a four-foot-long rod as the officers attempted to control the crowd. Michael Brock also has no known relationship with Larry Brock, another Capitol riot defendant from Texas.
Source description: Governmental Reports and Release, Local News, Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Lois Lynn McNicoll
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Wore Trump hat and California flag as cape; Resident of CA; "Sentenced 9/6/22 to 24 months of probation, 80 hours of community service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Lois Lynn McNicoll, 69, of San Clemente, was arrested on federal charges of knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority and violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds. She travelled from California to DC in order to watch President Trump's speech and later join the protests happening at the Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Munn, et al.
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others

Short narrative: On January 9, 2021, the FBI received information from a tipster that Kristi Munn entered the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. During a follow-up interview, the tipster reported that Kristi Munn and other members of her family traveled from Texas to Washington, D.C. for the rally that occurred on January 6, 2021.One of the Facebook screenshots provided by the tipster was a post of a photograph of Kristi Munn and five additional individuals who were “tagged” in the post as Facebook users Tom Munn, Dawn Munn, Kayli Munn, Minor Child 1, and Josh Munn.
