Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND Supports organized political violence
Name of case: United States of America v. Micajah Joel Jackson
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of AZ; Wore orange armband presumed to be signaling affiliation with Proud Boys, and was photographed marching with PBs, but denies affiliation with group. Micajah Jackson sentenced 3/24/22 to 36 months of probation, including 90 days in a residential re-entry center, $1,000 fine, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: "Jackson, whose social media pages say he's a 100% disabled Marine, surrendered to the FBI on May 18: The FBI stated in court documents that he posted photos on social media of himself on Jan. 6 in a plaid shirt and other clothing he wore to the riot, photos agents later used to identify him. He was dubbed #TartanPlaidPB by online sleuths who are researching those who participated in the Capitol riot, then turning that information over to the FBI. Jackson is seen in photos numerous times on Jan. 6 with Proud Boys from Arizona, and wore one of their orange arm bands, the FBI stated. However, in an interview with the FBI at his home, agents said Jackson told them he is not affiliated with the Proud Boys and doesn't support their ideology. He said they gave him the orange band and he stayed with them for protection because he had traveled to Washington, D.C. alone. However, the FBI noted that in December, one of his social media connections tagged him in a post about a group of Proud Boys being in New York City. In a social media post included in the court records, Jackson said he didn't agree with the "MAGA tribalism," and didn't commit any violence. Jackson stated in the post that he had evidence of BLM, Antifa, police officers and "Non Trump" extremists "causing the mayhem." Jackson also stated that he's a college student studying to be a political science professor. "My only love is the United States of America," he wrote. At the Capitol, records show he carried a U.S. flag and was with a crowd singing The Star-Spangled Banner after the detonation of an explosive device in the crowd. He then pointed toward the Senate Wing of the Capitol and moved that direction. The agents noted he was seen on video in Statuary Hall and other locations inside the Capitol." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Kerry Wayne Persick
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of TX; Indicted by Bill of Information; "Sentenced 7/14/22 to 36 months of probation, including 90 days of home detention, $5,000 fine, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: "On the very day of the Capitol riot, a tipster sent a note to the FBI identifying Kerry Wayne Persick, who was wearing a red Make America Great Again ballcap in the crowd, the agency stated in charging documents. The FBI was able to identify Persick in surveillance video inside the Capitol, and then obtained a search warrant for phone records that place him at the Capitol, documents show. Persick was arrested in Fort Worth, Texas." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Noah S. Bacon
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) - Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting;
Additional details: Resident of MA; Wore 'I love Trump shirt'; "Noah Bacon found guilty on 3/3/23 on all charges by unanimous jury"; "Noah S. Bacon, 30, of Somerville, Massachusetts, was sentenced by U.S. District Judge Christopher R. Cooper to 12 months in prison, two years of supervised release, and ordered to pay $2,000 in restitution."
Short narrative: "Noah Bacon was reported to the FBI after he allegedly appeared in a video published by The New Yorker. In the video, prosecutors say, Bacon can be seen opening a door to the balcony area of the U.S. Senate Chamber inside the Capitol for himself and others. Bacon allegedly spent about 10 minutes in the chamber, sitting in the back row in an "I ♥ Trump" t-shirt, fist-bumping others. Verizon phone records obtained by the FBI also place Bacon in the Capitol that day, as does security camera footage, court documents indicate. On Instagram the day before the riot, Bacon allegedly posted about his plans to go to "Trump's special Jan 6th event" and that "we are on the precipice of something beautiful."" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jamie N. Buteau, Jennifer Peck Buteau
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of FL; Husband also arrested; "Jennifer Buteau Sentenced 11/20/23 to 90 days incarceration; $10 special assessment; $500 restitution."
Short narrative: "Jennifer Peck Buteau entered the U.S. Capitol building, alongside her husband, through a broken door on Jan. 6, according to court documents. Her husband is allegedly seen on footage from inside the Capitol assaulting two police officers by throwing a chair at them, and hitting one, as they were trying to move away from the rioters. Multiple tipsters, including a family member, contacted the FBI and reported that Buteau had posted live Facebook videos from within the building that she later deleted. “Antifa was infiltrating Trump supporters for the cameras, to cause Chaos,” Buteau allegedly wrote on Facebook. An additional tipster alerted the FBI that both Buteaus appeared in HBO’s Vice News Tonight report from August 2018 on QAnon believers. The FBI later confirmed that the video indeed featured the couple." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jamie N. Buteau, Jennifer Peck Buteau
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of FL; Wife also arrested; "Jamie Buteau Sentenced 11/20/23 to twenty-two months incarceration; two- four months of supervised release; $100 special assessment; $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: "Footage inside the U.S. Capitol building allegedly shows Jamie Buteau throwing a chair at two U.S. Capitol Police officers as they are retreating from the crowd, hitting one of the officers. Multiple tipsters, including a family member, contacted the FBI identifying both Jamie Buteau and his wife, Jennifer Peck Buteau, as having been inside the building on Jan. 6, based on live videos they posted on Facebook that were later deleted, according to court documents. Other footage also allegedly shows Jamie Buteau dragging a second chair after the first incident, which he ends up leaving in one of the hallways. An additional tipster alerted the FBI that both Buteaus appeared in HBO’s Vice News Tonight report from August 2018 on QAnon believers. The FBI later confirmed that the video indeed featured the husband and wife." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. William Michael Sywak, William Jason Sywak
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Additional details: Resident of NY; Father also arrested; Indicted by Bill of Information; Sentenced to 12 months probation with first 2 months to be served on home detention with electronic monitoring, $500 restitution
Short narrative: On July 27, 2021, William Jason Sywak, 27, and William Michael Sywak, 45, were indicted for their actions at the United States Capitol on January 6, 2021. The father and son pair from Buffalo and they were identified after a photo from the riot was matched with a mugshot of William Michael Sywak from a prior arrest. William Michael Sywak revealed his son involvement in his interview with the FBI, and federal law enforcement soon identified his son in footage thereafter. The pair were seen entering and illegally walking about the interior of the U.S. Capitol.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. William Michael Sywak, William Jason Sywak
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Son also arrested; Indicted by Bill of Information; Sentenced 6/9/22 to 24 months of probation, including four months of home detention, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution
Short narrative: "In an interview with the FBI, William Michael Sywak said he and his son traveled to Washington, D.C., together to "see the protests" on Jan. 6, but he denied going inside the U.S. Capitol building. However, law enforcement later placed Sywak inside the Capitol that day through surveillance footage, a YouTube video and Google location records, court documents indicate. During the interview, FBI agents showed Sywak a photo of himself on the U.S. Capitol grounds and he confirmed to the agents that it was him, saying he was surprised his hair looked so neat, since he had been wearing a beanie." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeremy Grace
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly conduct in a restricted building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in the Capitol building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of WA; Sentenced 7/8/22 to 21 days in jail, 12 months of supervised release, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Jeremy Grace, 37 of Washington, and his father, Jeffrey Grace, were arrested and charged for their role in the Capitol riot. Jeremy Grace pled guilty to Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds and was sentenced to 21 days in prison. They were among the first people to enter the Capitol and took selfies.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. William Rogan Reid
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1361 Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:1512(c)(1) Tampering with Documents or Proceedings; 18:1512(c)(1) Corruptly Altering, Destroying, Mutilating, or Concealing a Record, Document, or Other Object;
Additional details: "William Reid Found guilty by Court on 8/23/22 of obstruction of an official proceeding and corruptly altering, destroying, mutilating, or concealing a record, document, or other objects, both felonies, as well as five related misdemeanor offenses. Misdemeanors include entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; destruction of government property; disorderly and dispruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building, Defendant agreed to a stipulated set of facts."; "Sentenced 12/8/22 to an aggregate term of thirty-seven (37) months of incarceration, thirty-six (36) months of supervised release, $2,443 in restitution and $295 special assessment."
Short narrative: William Rogan Reid, 36, a resident of Florida pled guilty to his involvement in the capitol Raid. "A person who knows William Rogan Reid called the FBI a few weeks after Jan. 6, 2021, to tell about seeing a video on Reid's Instagram that showed the inside of the U.S. Capitol building and in which Reid's voice could be heard. That Instagram account led federal investigators to what they believe is Reid's Discord account. According to court documents, Reid posted on Discord on March 11, 2021, that "The 6th was our Boston Tea Party." Two days later, he wrote, "I rushed the Capitol," "Hi, Feds," and "I'LL F***IN DO IT AGAIN." A search warrant of AT&T records indicated Reid was in the vicinity of the Capitol, including its interior, on the day of the riot, according to prosecutors." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Anthony Antonio
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1361, 2 - Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) - Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of DE; Case transferred to D.C.
Short narrative: Anthony Antonio, 27, of Delaware, surrendered to police and was charged with knowingly entering or remaining on restriected grounds, violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds, obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder, obstruction of an official proceeding, and destruction of government property for his role in the Capitol riot. [NOTE: Article was found the day after Antonio surrendered to police. Searched on RECAP, PACER, Delaware Court, and D.C. Court, but could not find any additional information. Possibly still sealed?]
Source description: Local News Article; Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Mark Sami Ibrahim
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(d) - Injuries to Property; 40:5104(e)(1)(A)(i) - Firearm and Dangerous Weapons on Capitol Grounds; 18:1001(a)(2) - False Statement and Representations;
Additional details: Resident of CA; DEA agent
Short narrative: Mark Sami Ibrahim, 33, from Orange County, California, is charged with federal crimes in relation to his participation in the January 6, 2021. He is a former Drug Enforcemeent Administration agent who entered Capitol grounds with a gun and his badge. He climbed the Peace Memorial andlater lied to the feds about why he was there. According to the DOJ, "On January 6, 2021, IBRAHIM was a Special Agent with the Drug Enforcement Administration and at all times relevant to the below chronology, was carrying his DEA-issued firearm. IBRAHIM was a probationary employee of the DEA and had, several weeks prior to the events of January 6, 2021, given notice to the DEA of his intention to resign. On January 6, 2021, IBRAHIM was on personal leave from the DEA. He was not on duty for the DEA and had no role as a law enforcement officer on the Capitol Grounds."
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Daniel Lyons Scott
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) and (a)(2) Knowingly entering and disorderly conduct in any restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) Knowingly engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) and (e)(2)(F) Disorderly conduct and act of physical violence on Capitol grounds; *18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) - Obstruction of justice/Congress; 18:111(a)(1) Assault on a federal officer with physical contact and intent to commit another felony;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of FL; Sentenced on 7/12/2023 to 60 months incarceration; 36 months of supervised release; special assessment of $200; restitution of $2,000
Short narrative: Daniel Lyons "Milkshake" Scott, 28 of Florida, pled guilty to obstruction of justice/Congress and assault on a federal officer with physical contact and intent to commit another felony for his role in the January 6 Capitol raid. He was sentenced to 60 months of incarceration. He self-identifies as a Proud Boy member and wore a black ballistic vest, goggles, and a carabiner on his vest into the Capitol. He "has a tattoo of the organization on his left arm, according to the FBI. In a Wall Street Journal video from Jan. 6, Scott is seen walking alongside known members of the Proud Boys in Washington, D.C. On the same video, a man is heard screaming: “Let’s take the f***ing Capitol.” Another individual then answers: “Let’s not f***ing yell that, all right?” Ethan Nordean, one of the most powerful leaders in the organization, then responds: “It was Milkshake, man, you know … idiot.” Later at the Capitol, additional footage from various sources shows Scott pushing two police officers backward up the steps. Scott appears to be one of the first people to initiate contact with law enforcement and is seen later pulling officers into the crowd." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Releases, Local News Articles

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND State speech act
Name of case: United States of America v. Daniel Christmann
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of NY; former state Senate candidate, plumber; "Twenty-five (25) Days incarceration and a Special Assessment of $10.00."
Short narrative: On August 2, 2021, Daniel Christmann, 38, was charged with numerous federal offenses in a bill of information relating to his activities at the United States Capitol on January 6, 2021. From Brooklyn, NY, Christmann formerly ran for NY State Senate under the New Moderate Party. He was identified by law enforcement after numerous tipsters submitted posts he made on social media that depicted him walking through numerous restricted areas within the U.S. Capitol Building. Additionally, security camera footage from within the building captured a man matching Christmann's description among the crowd illegally parading about the interior.
Source description: Charging Documents, News Article, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Glenn Allen Brooks
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of CA; Indicted by Bill of Information
Short narrative: "Glenn Brooks “boasted” about his role at the Jan. 6 riot and sent selfies from inside the U.S. Capitol to members of his church prayer group, according to a criminal complaint. A member of that text message group chat forwarded them to the FBI in January. The FBI says surveillance footage shows Brooks climbing through a broken window near the Senate wing and taking pictures inside, wearing plaid scarf and a hat with the word "Trump" emblazoned on it. Court documents show Brooks was arrested on July 29. According to his LinkedIn profile, the 60-year-old Brooks owns a home-remodeling firm called Brooks Works Corp. in Huntington Beach, Calif. Court documents say that surveillance conducted on Brooks by the FBI shows him exiting a vehicle with the name of the company on the side." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Andrew C. Ericson
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of OK; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 12/10 to 24 months probation which includes 20 days of jail to be served on consecutive weekends, and $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Andrew Craig Ericson, 23, of Muskogee, OK, was arrested 1/22/21 and charged with unlawful entry on restricted buildings or grounds and violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds. After arrest, he was held at the Muskogee County jail. Ericson was charged after discovering Snapchat photographs showing Ericson at the Capitol. FBI investigation showed Ericson used his cell phone to photograph himself and live streamed himself entering the Capitol. The pictures on Ericson’s Snapchat story included his full name.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local news

Name of case: United States of America v. Luke Wessley Bender
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) Obsturction of an official proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(A) Entering and remaining on the floor of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disroderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of VA; "Luke Bender Sentenced 4/20/23 to serve concurrent terms of incarceration of twenty-one (21) months as to Count 1, twelve (12) months as to Counts 2 and 3, and six (6) months as to Counts 4, 5, and 6; the Defendant is further sentenced to serve concurrent terms of supervised release of thirty-six (36) months as to Count 1, and twelve (12) months as to Counts 2 and 3; he is ordered to pay a special assessment of $180.00 which consists of $100.00 as to Count 1, $25.00 as to Counts 2 and 3, and $10.00 as to Counts 4, 5, and 6; and $2,000.00 restitution payable to the Clerk of Court for the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia for its disbursement to the victim, Architect of the Capitol."
Short narrative: "“Patriots Its [sic] time to come together in DC. And fight for our country. Just like our President Donald Trump has done for us. It’s time we fight for him. See yall in DC Jan 6th,” posted Luke Wessley Bender on TikTok days before the storming of the Capitol, according to court documents. An anonymous tipster who identified themselves as a co-worker wrote to the FBI on Jan 13: “Luke Bender was bragging about being present during the insurrection at the US Capitol … He has photos of himself and with others inside of the US Capitol Building. Some of the people he has photos with have already been arrested for their participation in this insurrection.” Images from Jan. 6 show Bender wearing a black cowboy hat, a camouflage jacket and a big blue Trump flag on the National Mall. Footage also shows him walking around the Capitol Rotunda and, later, entering the Senate chamber, where he appeared to use his phone to photograph documents left on senators’ desks. The court documents also show images of Bender pictured on the dais on the Senate floor." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Stephanie M. Baez
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Indicted by Bill of Information
Short narrative: Stephanie M. Baez, 28, was charged with Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; and Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds following her participation in the Capitol riot. Baez posted a video of herself taken outside the US Capitol in which she explains she is looking for a Proud Boy. There are numerous photographs that show Baez inside the Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Caldwell, et al.
Charges: 18:371 Conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2),2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; 18:1361, 2 Destruction of government property and aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1512(c)(1) Tampering with documents or proceedings; 18:231(a)(3), 2 Civil Disorder and aiding and abetting
Additional details: Pled to 2 charges (18:371 and 18:1512(c)(2)) in the 4th superseding indictment and seperated from larger case; US Army veteran and Navy reservist
Short narrative: Young is the brother of Steele. "According to the superseding indictment, Kelly Meggs is the self-described leader of the Florida chapter of the Oath Keepers, of which Connie Meggs, Young, and Steele also are alleged to be members." "CALDWELL, CROWL, WATKINS, SANDRA PARKER, BENNIE PARKER, YOUNG, STEELE, KELLY MEGGS, and CONNIE MEGGS, planned with each other, and with others known and unknown, to forcibly enter the Capitol on January 6, 2021, and to stop, delay, and hinder the Congressional proceeding occurring that day. Arrested 2/15/21 in the Middle District of Florida. Charged via superseding indictment on 2/19/21 and was arraigned on 3/11/21 where he pleaded not guilty to counts 1-4 and 6.
Source description: Charging documents, court documents, local news articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND Supports organized political violence AND State speech act

Additional details: USMC veteran; Resident of Florida; Likley removed cache of firearms from home prior to arrest according to FBI comments; Pleaded agreement entered 9/15. Pleaded guilty to counts 1 and 2, (18:371 and 18:1512(c)(2),2) sentencing date TBD
Short narrative: Joseph Hackett, 51, Jason Dolan, 44, William Isaacs, 21, and Jonathan Walden, 46, were added to the Oathkeepers 4th superseding indictment. Each face multiple counts for their participation in the January 2021 Capitol protests. Specifically, Hackett is accused of conspiracy; obstruction of an official proceeding, and aiding and abetting; destruction of government property, and aiding and abetting; and illegally entering a restricted building or grounds.
