Name of case: United States of America v. Janet West Buhler
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of UT; Sentenced 6/1/22 to 30 days in jail, 36 months of probation, $500 in restitution.
Short narrative: Janet West Buhler, 57, of UT, was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for her participation in the January 6th Capitol riot. Buhler traveled to Washington, D.C., along with her stepson-in-law, Michael Lee Hardin. Buhler can be seen in footage taken from inside the building during the riot. Buhler pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building, and was sentenced to 30 days in jail, 36 months of probation, $500 in restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and release (DOJ), News article

Name of case: United States of America v. William Watson
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; *18:1361, 2 Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Alabama; bond was revoked; "William Watson Found guilty 11/18/22 by Court after agreeing to a stipulated set of facts of obstruction of an official proceeding and entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a dangerous weapon."; "William Watson Sentenced 3/9/23 to 36 months in prison and 36 months of supervised release."
Short narrative: William Wright Watson, 23 of Alabama, pled guilty to Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon for his role in the Capitol raid. He was sentenced to 36 months of incarceration. "According to a criminal complaint, William Watson traveled to Washington, D.C., to "support the patriots, support Trump, support freedom. ... I guess the overriding thing for why we were there that day is because they were certifying the fraudulent election that day, and so we, to protest that." Watson said he was following a schedule that conspiracy theorist Alex Jones promoted for Jan. 6,2021, which, according to Watson, directed people to meet at the Ellipse at 9 a.m. and the U.S. Capitol at 1 p.m., around the time of the certification. In an interview with the FBI, Watson initially denied commiting any acts of violence, trespassing, vandalism or other “criminal activity." He then said he entered the Capitol building through a broken window and approached a police officer. "I went straight up to the first cop and literally got on my knees and was like, 'Listen, I want to be peaceful here ... I want to help you get these people peaceful so that we can have a conversation.' " Watson said he had a can of mace and a pocketknife on him at the time he breached the building. According to court documents, Watson was out on bond from a summer drug trafficking case and violated the conditions by participating in the Capitol breach. He was charged in July with possession of controlled substances and drug trafficking of LSD and marijuana, felonies under Alabama law." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Matthew Thomas Purse
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of CA
Short narrative: Matthew Thomas Purse, 44, from Irvine, California, is charged with entering and remaining in a restricted building, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building for his participation in the January 6, 2021 raid. Purse was captured inside the Capitol by surveillance cameras.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Edward McAlanis
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Violent entry and disorderly conduct and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; sentenced to 2 years on probation and was ordered to do 60 hours of community service and pay $500 restitution.
Short narrative: On August 10, 2021, Edward McAlanis, 41, was charged in a bill of information with numerous federal offenses for his participation in the events at the United States Capitol on January 6, 2021. McAlanis was identified by the FBI after a tipster submitted pictures of him both inside and outside the United States Capitol Building. Additionally, the cell phone number associated with McAlanis was found to have been serviced by the cell site connected to the interior of the building during the time in which the events were occuring. None of the evidence shows McAlanis engaging in an act of violence on Capitol grounds.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Patrick Edward McCaughey , et. al.
Charges: 18:111(a)(1), 2 Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of OH; also worked with anti-abortion groups; "Found guilty 9/13/22 of a total of four offenses. They include two felony charges: aiding and abetting in assaulting, resisting, or impeding law enforcement officers, and interfering with a law enforcement officer during a civil disorder. The two misdemeanor charges include: disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building and aiding and abetting in committing an act of violence in the Capitol Building or grounds."; Sentenced 2/24/23 to 14 months in prison, 24 months of supervised release
Short narrative: David Mehaffie, 62 of Ohio, was found guilty and sentenced to 14 months in prison and 2 years of probation for his involvement in the January 6 Capitol Raid. He charged against police officers and gained entrance into the Capitol with his other co-defendants. "According to HuffPost, Mehaffie was known by the online group Sedition Hunters as the "#TunnelCommander" over his alleged role in giving orders to rioters attacking police officers at one entrance to the Capitol building. The Sedition Hunters group seeks to help federal investigators in identifying the rioters. In the past, Mehaffie has also been a member of an anti-abortion group in Ohio that would protest outside abortion clinics, HuffPost reported." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Patrick Edward McCaughey , et. al.
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (2) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers and aiding and abetting [2 counts]; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; 18:1512(c)(2) and (2) Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings
Additional details: Resident of Carrollton, TX; "David Lee Judd Sentenced 3/1/23 to a term of 32 Months of incarceration to run concurrently, followed by a term of Twenty-Four (24) Months of Supervised Release, to run concurrently. $100 Special Assessment imposed on each count for a total of $200. Restitution imposed in the amount of $2,000. Fine imposed in the amount of $5,691."
Short narrative: David Lee Judd, 35, of Carrollton, Texas, was charged with assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers/employees of the United States and civil disorder for his role in the January 6th riot. Judd was identified from a Youtube video and surveillance footage entering a tunnel of the Capitol building, attempting to organize protesors to form a shield wall, and throwing a firecracker at a line of law enforcemnet officers. Additionally a witness provided an advertisemen Judd posted on social media asking for a ride to to the riot.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Patrick Edward McCaughey , et. al.
Charges: 18:2111 Robbery; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; 18:111(a)(1) and (2) Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers and aiding and abetting [3 counts]; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon [2 counts]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings
Additional details: Resident of Virginia; "Geoffrey Sills Sentenced 3/21/23 to 52 months in prison for obstruction of an official proceeding, assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers with a dangerous weapon and robbery, all felonies."
Short narrative: Geoffrey William Sills, of Mechanicsville, Virginia, was arrested on 10 charges in connection with the Capitol riot, among them assaulting federal officers using a dangerous weapon, robbery, obstruction of an official proceeding and engaging in physical violence in a restricted building with a dangerous weapon. In a new superseding indictment filed last week, Sills was charged with five co-defendants for allegedly joining the mob that assaulted Capitol and D.C. police trying to hold a line in the Capitol tunnels.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Patrick Edward McCaughey , et. al.
Charges: 18:111(a)(1), 2 Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain officers, Aiding and Abetting [3 counts]; *18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder [4 counts]; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Dangerous Weapon [2 counts]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of FL; Arrested by FBI Jacksonville 2/5/21; 2 co-defendants have slightly different combination of charges; "Found guilty 9/13/22 of a total of nine offenses. They include five felony charges: four counts of aiding or abetting or assaulting, resisting, or impeding law enforcement officers, and one count of interfering with a law enforcement officer during a civil disorder. The four misdemeanor charges include: disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building, and committing an act of violence in the Capitol Building or grounds."; "Tristan Stevens Sentenced 3/10/23 to 60 months in prison, 24 months of supervised release, $2,000 restitution, and a $500 fine."
Short narrative: Tristan Chandler Stevens, 25, of Pensacola was found guilty of four counts of aiding or abetting or assaulting, resisting, or impeding law enforcement officers, and one count of interfering with a law enforcement officer during a civil disorder for his role in the Capitol raid. The four misdemeanor charges include: disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building, and committing an act of violence in the Capitol Building or grounds. He was sentenced to 5 years of incarceration. "Federal prosecutors say Tristan Stevens, a computer engineering student at the University of West Florida, clashed with police at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. In video surveillance footage, Stevens can be seen among a crowd of rioters using police shields and police riot batons to combat police officers, according to a criminal complaint. At one point, he allegedly grabbed one of the shields that was being passed around and pushed his way to the front of the line of rioters, where he tried to take a baton from an officer." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Patrick Edward McCaughey , et. al.
Charges: 18:2111 Robbery; 18:2111 and 2 - Robbery and Aiding and Abetting [2 counts]; 18:111(a)(1) and (2) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Aiding and Abetting [2 counts]; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) and 18:2 - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) and 18:2 - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;
Additional details: Resident of PA; "Robert Morss Sentenced 5/24/23 to 66 months in prison, 24 months of supervised release and restitution of $2000."
Short narrative: Robert Morss, 27, a former Army Ranger and substitute teacher in Pennsylvania, was arrested on charges in connection with the Capitol Riot, among them assaulting federal officers, robbery, obstruction of an official proceeding and engaging in physical violence in a restricted building. During the action, Morss attempted to rip a police baton away from an officer and ripping a fence away from them. Throughout, he can be heard saying things like "You guys are betraying us" and "take a look around, back up, we are going to take our Capitol back." In bodycam footage taken within the tunnel, he is seen taking a riot shield away from an officer, passing shields and batons back into the crowd, and instructing others to form a "shield wall" that can push forward down the tunnel. He could later be seen climbing through a broken window into the Capitol. After the events, Morss was identified to law enforcement by several aquaintances and associates who recognized him in high-definition photos taken on January 6th. He was thereafter arrested and charged for his actions. He is a co-defendant in a case including rioters McCaughey, Stevens, Judd, Quaglin, and Sills.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles, Government Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Patrick Edward McCaughey , et. al.
Charges: 18:111(a)(1), 2 Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain officers, Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder [3 counts]; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon [2 counts]; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Arrested 1/19/21 in the Southern District of NY; 2 co-defendants have slightly different combination of charges; "Found guilty 9/13/22 of a total of nine offenses. They include seven felony charges: three counts of aiding or abetting or assaulting, resisting, or impeding law enforcement officers, including one involving a dangerous weapon; one count of obstruction of an official proceeding; one count of interfering with a law enforcement officer during a civil disorder; one count of disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon, and one count of engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon. The two misdemeanor charges include: disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building and committing an act of violence in the Capitol Building or grounds."; "Patrick McCaughey Sentenced 4/14/23 to 90 months in prison for nine offenses, 36 months of supervised release and restitution of $2,000."
Short narrative: Patrick Edward McCaughey III was charged with assaulting D.C. Metropolitan Police Officer Hodges during the breach of the U.S. Capitol grounds on Jan. 6, 2021. He was seen crushing this officer between the doors of the Capitol.
Source description: Court Documents; Charging documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Patrick Edward McCaughey , et. al.
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers [2 counts]; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Inflicting bodily injury on certain officers; 18:111(a)(1) and (2) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers and aiding and abetting [2 counts]; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon [2 counts]; 18:1512(c)(2) and (2) Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon [2 counts]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol Grounds or buildings
Additional details: Resident of New Jersey; "Christopher Quaglin Sentenced 5/24/24 to 144 months in prison, 24 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $2,000 in restitution"
Short narrative: Christopher Quaglin, of North Brunswick. N.J. was arrested April 7, 2021 on federal charges accusing him of participating rduring the Jan. 6, 2021 attack on the U.S. Capitol. Dressed in a MAGA shirt, "Christopher Quaglin Attacked USCP and MPD Officers, Sprayed Them with Chemical Irritant, and Stole their Riot Shields" -DOJ
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Patrick Edward McCaughey , et. al.
Charges: 18:111(a)(1), 2 - Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers and aiding and abetting; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; 18:2111, 2 - Robbery and aiding and abetting; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; 18:231(a)(3) - Civil disorder; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Universal City, TX; "Steven Cappuccio, 53, of Universal City, Texas--identified as #stripesguy by Sedition Hunters--and Federico Guillermo Klein, 45, of Falls Church, Virginia, were found guilty 7/20/23 of 14 felony charges. The verdict followed a bench trial before U.S. District Judge Trevor N. McFadden."; "Steven Cappuccio Sentenced 11/3/23 to a term of Eighty-Five (85) Months of Incarceration on Counts 28s, 29s, 30s, 42s, 50s; a term of Sixty (60) Months of Incarceration on Count 35s; a term of Six (6) Months of Incarceration on Count 53s, with all terms to run concurrently, followed by a term of Twenty-Four (24) Months of Supervised Release on Counts 28s, 29s, 30s, 35s, 42s, 50s, to run concurrently. Special Assessment of $100 imposed on Counts 28s, 29s, 30s, 35s, 42s, 50s; $10 imposed on Count 53s, for a total of $610. Restitution imposed in the amount of $2,000."
Short narrative: On August 10, 2021, Army veteran Steven Cappuccio, 52, of Universal City, Texas, was charged with multiple federal offenses in a superseding indictment including many other defendants who also participated in the riot at the United States Capitol on January 6, 2021. According to court documents, Cappuccio--who was later identified by online sleuths with the moniker #stripesguy--was involved in the "heave-ho" effort against law enforcement in the lower west terrace tunnel. There, Cappuccio attacked an officer crushed between metal doors and a riot shield, forcefully pulling his gas mask off his face, stealing his baton, and striking him about the face with it.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Steven C. Billingsley
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds;
Additional details: Resident of OH; Indicted by a Bill of Information before Criminal Complaint released; "Sentenced - 12/6/22 to 24 months of probation, including 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: "Steven Billingsley may never have made into the U.S. Capitol building, but his words on restricted grounds were violent, prosecutors say. “We do want to hurt [House Speaker Nancy] Pelosi. I do. Yeah, I would hang her from that big -- you see that tree over there? We’d put [up] a rope and hang her. We hang her and [Senate Majority Leader Chuck] Schumer over there, they’ll all go, ‘Oh s***,' ” Billingsley said, according to court documents. Billingsley Live Streamed his time on the Capitol grounds via Facebook, a tipster told the FBI. The account where the videos were posted, prosecutors say, was closed in March. Billingsley narrated the first-person videos and turned the camera to show his face at least once, according to prosecutors, who matched the image to the photo of Billingsley’s driver’s license. Those videos, court documents say, show Billingsley undoing a metal barricade and breaching it. The FBI also says Billingsley shouted at police officers saying, “We’re going through. We can do it the nice way or the hard way. … You guys turned on us.” He also repeatedly said, “This is war,” prosecutors say. Court documents include photos from outside the Capitol that the tipster told the FBI resemble Billingsley." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Wilson & Temple
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of OH; Mother also arrested; Cole Temple Sentenced 7/5/23 to Thirty-six (36) Months Probation and a Special Assessment of $10.00.
Short narrative: "Temple has been charged with his mother, Jodi Wilson, with entering the Capitol on Jan. 6, where the FBI says they were seen on surveillance footage for about 17 minutes. Both admitted in August interviews with the FBI that they had been inside the Capitol. While inside the Capitol, Temple posted a video of himself yelling "just broke in this bitch."" (USA Today). Cole Temple Sentenced 7/5/23 to Thirty-six (36) Months Probation and a Special Assessment of $10.00.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Wilson & Temple
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of OH; Son also arrested; "Jodi Wilson Sentenced 6/5/23 to Twenty (20) days incarceration; Thirty-six (36) Months term of Probation; and a Special Assessment of $10.00."
Short narrative: "The FBI began investigating Wilson and her son Cole Temple in January, according to federal charging documents. Their cell phones showed up on geo-locating software the FBI has often used to place people inside the Capitol building on the 6th. Court records show that Wilson told a court-appointed guardian at litem in a custody case involving a minor child that she went into the Capitol with Temple, and said she'd been invited onto the steps by an unidentified man whom she assumed to be a Congressman. Afterwards, she stated, a police officer told her and her son that they were allowed to go in. Records show the pair was in the Capitol for at least 17 minutes. Initially, the FBI said, she denied being inside the Capitol but admitted it after the agents showed her photos of her inside the building carrying an America flag." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeffrey Xavier Finley
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of WV
Short narrative: Jeffrey Finley, of West Virginia, was charged with Knowingly Enter and Remain in any Restricted Building or Grounds without Lawful Authority and Engage in Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in any Restricted Buildings or Grounds; and Engage in Disorderly Conduct in any of the Capitol Buildings following his participation in the Capitol riot. Finley was identified via photos taken inside the US Capitol, and it was verified by his cell phone location.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Alan William Byerly
Charges: *18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 18:113(a)(4) - Striking, Beating, or Wounding of Another Person Within the Territorial Jurisdiction; *18:113(a)(5) - Simple Assault within the Territorial Jurisdiction;
Additional details: Resident of PA; "Sentenced 10/21/22 to 34 months in prison, three years of supervised release, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: Alan William Byerly, 55 of Pennsylvania, pled guilty to Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Striking, Beating or Wounding of Another Person within the Territorial Jurisdiction at the Capitol Riot. "He assaulted a photographer for The Associated Press and also used a Taser or Taser-like device "meant to deliver a debilitating electric shock" to assault police officers protecting the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6. Byerly, court papers say, charged toward a police line in front of the West Terrace of the Capitol while activating the Taser-type device; police were able to remove the device from Byerly, but he continued to "physically strike, and push against officers," court documents say. [...] Separately, around that time, Byerly is accused of joining members of a violent mob that pushed, shoved and dragged the AP photographer outside the Capitol. After the FBI posted photos of the incident and requested tips from the public, a witness reportedly contacted investigators." (NPR) He was sentenced to prison for 34 months.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Perretta & Vukich
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:641 Theft of Government Money, Property, or Records; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of PA; "Sentenced 1/5/22 to 30 days of incarceration, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: Nicholas J. Perretta, 27 of Pennsylvania, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his participation in the Capitol riot alongside co-defendant Michell Paul Vukich. The men claim to have been in the Capitol for 25 minutes where they smoked marijuana. When Vukich was presented with images from the Capitol's video footage, he admitted to his own involvement and positively identified Perretta as well. The men attended the earlier pro-Trump rally, before heading to the Capitol. While inside, Perretta admitted that they took “three-month-old congressional papers” and later disposed of them outside the Capitol. He was sentenced to a month in prison.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Jonathon Owen Shroyer
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in Capitol grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(E) Obstructing and impeding assage through the Capitol grounds or buildings
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of TX; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Inforwars talk-show host with show "The War Room With Owen Shroyer"; Defendant violated a 2020 Deferred Prosecution Agreement begun after he disrupted a House Judiciary Committee meeting 12/9/19. He was charged with a violation of (1) 10 D.C. Code Section 503.16(b)(4) (2001 ed.), Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct on United States Capitol Grounds, and (2) 10 D.C. Code Section 503.16(b)(7) (2001 ed.), Obstructing and Impeding Passage on United States Capitol Grounds; Sentenced to 2 months in prison
Short narrative: On August 25, 2021, Jonathon Owen Shroyer was charged in a bill of information for his role in the riot at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. A host of a show on Alex Jones' Infowars site who is based in Austin, Texas, Shroyer was previously barred from demonstrating on Capitol grounds in an agreement resolving an earlier Washington D.C. legal dispute when he disrupted a meeting of the U.S. House Judiciary Committee in late 2019. Nevertheless, Shroyer advertised his attendance at the events in Washington on the day in question in the leadup. On January 6, 2021, he attended the rally at the Ellipse before leading other protestors in a chant as they marched to the U.S. Capitol grounds together. There, Shroyer stood with Alex Jones as he addressed the crowd occupying the Capitol grounds. Shroyer did not enter the actual building or cause any evidenced property damage while there, but was charged with illegally occupying the area by the U.S. Attorney for the District of Columbia.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Document, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Jacob Travis Clark
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an official proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Additional details: Resident of CO; "Jacob Clark Sentenced 10/27/23 to thirty-three (33) months of incarceration, twelve (12) months of supervised release and $180 special assessment."
Short narrative: Jacob Travis Clark, of Trinidad, was arrested and released on a $10,000 bond, according to documents filed in U.S. District Court in Denver. He is accused of unlawfully entering a restricted building, disorderly and disruptive conduct, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building, violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds, obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder, and obstruction of justice and Congress. Apparently, while inside the U.S. Capitol on January 6th, he hit a law enforcement officer over the head with a 2 x 4 wooden plank and then proceeded to walk about the building interior.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Fi Duong
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of VA; Part of self-styled militia with meetings called "Bible Study"
Short narrative: Fi Duong, 27, from Alexandria, Virginia, was arrested and charged with multiple federal crimes in relation to his participation in the Capitol raid. An undercover Metropolitan Police Department FBI agent observed and spoke with Duong for months after they met on January 6, 2021 at the Capitol. Duong appears to be a part of a "self-styled militia that referred to its meetings as "Bible study"'. At the time of his arrest he was in possession of several guns and the materials to make 50 molotov cocktails.
Source description: Charging Documents, News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Timothy Allen Hart
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of OH; Sentenced 7/27/23 to 36 Months of Probation with conditions. Special Assessment: $100.00. Restitution: $2000.00.; QAnon
Short narrative: Timothy Allen Hart, 52 of Ohio, pled guilty to civil disorder for his involvement in the Capitol Riot. He expressed support for QAnon and wore Q hoodie and hat to Capitol. He also smoked mariuana while inside the Capitol. Hart was among the rioters who helped to remove barricades surrounding the Capitol building and told others to come nearer to the building. An Instagram video posted to an account called “brotunda" shows Hart inside the Capitol. Hart was identified through subscriber information for his YouTube channel and a mobile phone tied to his wife. Hart is from Ohio and owns a paintball center there.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Perretta & Vukich
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:641 Theft of Government Money, Property, or Records; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of PA; QAnon connection link is unsubstantiated; "Sentenced 1/5/22 to 30 days of incarceration, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Mitchell Paul Vukich, 25 of Pennsylvania, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his participation in the Capitol riot alongside co-defendant Nicholas Perretta. The men claim to have been in the Capitol for 25 minutes where they smoked marijuana. After the riot, he tweeted, "I was one of the first 15 people in the #Capitol. Wild stuff." Vukich was identified via 7 anonymous tips provided to the FBI, numerous tweets posted by Vukich himself, and surveillance footage that placed Vukich inside the US Capitol at the time of the riot. He and Perretta were sentenced to a month in prison.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Joseph Rusyn
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of PA; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 1/11/22 to 24 months of probation, including 60 days of home confinement, $2,000 fine, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Michael Rusyn self-surrendered on April 9, 2021 and had his initial appearance the same afternoon. He has been charged with Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. He is a volunteer firefighter and EMT. He pleaded not guilty to all counts on 4/26. Rusyn told investigators that he was actully injured himself while there when he was trying to take weapons away from members of the crowd, such as a broom stick with hooks and nails affixed to the end of it.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Deborah Lynn Lee
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Short narrative: Deborah Lynn Lee, 55, of PA, was charged with Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following her participation in the Capitol riot. Lee was identified via photos and posts made to Lynn's Facebook account.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Carey Jon Walden
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: USMC and Navy veteran for 12.5 years total; Resident of MO; Sentenced to 3 years of probation, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: In a bill of information filed on August 31, 2021, Carey Jon Walden was charged with a federal crime following his participation in the Capitol riot. A veteran of both the Navy and the Marine Corps, Walden was identified via a tip provided to the FBI as well as a Facebook post from Walden himself. In voluntary communication with law enforcement, Walden provided the photos he took during the event and also described his activities. Evidently, Walden entered the U.S. Capitol building through a broken window and illegally walked about the interior without breaking anything before leaving.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Tanner Bryce Sells
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of OK; "Sentenced 1/18/22 to 24 months probation, including 90 days of home detention, 50 hours of community service, $1,500 fine, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: On August 31, 2021, Tanner Sells, 25, was charged with willfully and knowingly parading, demonstrating, and picketing in the US Capitol building on January 6th, 2021 during the Capitol protests. He was identified after images of him walking throughout the Captiol interior on the day in question were matched with the picture from his Oklahoma drivers license. Sells walked about the Capitol and documented the goings-on inside with his cell phone, later posting some of the footage online.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND State speech act
Name of case: United States of America v. Pamela Anne Hemphill
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of ID; Hemphill pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentenced to 60 days in jail, supervised release for three years and $500 restitution.
Short narrative: On September 1, 2021, Pamela Anne Hemphill, 68, of Boise, Idaho was charged with multiple federal offenses for her activities at the United States Capitol on January 6, 2021. Hemphill was identified by the FBI through a tip that pointed them to numerous postings on her Facebook page and YouTube channel. A Facebook post of Hemphill's from December 28, 2020, read "It's not going to be a FUN Trump rally that is planned for January 6th, it's a WAR!" and another from January 1, 2021 announced that she was traveling to Washington, D.C. for the event, featuring a photo of her brandishing a large firearm. A YouTube video from Pam Hemphill showed footage taken at a January 5 event hosted by Alex Jones, with Hemphill in the background saying “Let’s do this; let’s go to the Capitol. We did it in Boise.” This remark was found to be in reference to the storming of a legislative session of the Idaho Legislature in August 2020, in which protestors raging against COVID-19 restrictions broke through a glass door at the Statehouse; Hemphill was determined to have participated in this event. On January 6, Hemphill slipped through the barricades set up outside the U.S. Capitol; when law enforcement ordered her to go back behind the barriers, she encouraged others to cross over with her. After the other rioters broke through, Hemphill was at the front of the line opposing the law enforcement officers. She entered the building through the East Rotunda, knowingly and illegally. After walking about the Rotunda for about ten minutes, Hemphill asked an officer to escort her out of the building, allegedly fearful that she would suffer an injury. Afterwards, Hemphill stayed outside the East Rotunda entrance, taking videos of the other rioters until the rest were dispersed.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Robert Flynt Fairchild, Jr.
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; *18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL; "Sentenced 10/20/2022 to six months of incarceration, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: "Robert Fairchild Jr. was identified after law enforcement posted photos of him on the FBI website, asking tipsters to help find an individual who had allegedly assaulted a federal officer. Law enforcement subsequently asked Fairchild's brother-in-law, who worked at the Troup County, Ga., Sheriff's Office whether he knew the person in the photos, and the brother-in-law identified Fairchild. The FBI alleges that Fairchild is observed on body camera and surveillance footage pushing against security barriers protecting the U.S. Capitol, helping to remove those barriers and walking inside the building. Federal law enforcement said he appeared to be taking a video of himself with his cellphone and at one point seemed to be yelling, "Fight for Trump," while on the Senate side of the building. [...] Fairchild pleaded Guilty to one charge: Civil Disorder. Sentenced on 10/20/2022 to 6 Months of Incarceration; Special Assessment of $100; Restitution of $2,000" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Benjamin J. Martin
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding;
Additional details: Resident of CA
Short narrative: "Benjamin Martin, a real estate agent from California, came to the attention of federal prosecutors after a tipster recognized Martin from footage of the riot at the U.S. Capitol, charging papers say. The tipster allegedly told investigators they knew Martin from high school and had seen his political posts and videos on Facebook, including videos saying he was going to Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6. Before the riot, according to court papers, Martin was part of a group chat on the encrypted messaging platform Telegram, where he discussed plans to go to Washington. He allegedly said in that group chat on Jan. 6 that “I just spoke to Peggy Hall she said we need to meet." Hall is a far-right activist from California who opposes vaccination and the use of masks to mitigate COVID-19, and who was in Washington on Jan. 6. Hall is not facing any criminal charges related to the Capitol riot. On Jan. 15, Martin gave an interview to FBI investigators, court documents say, and claimed that he was at the Capitol attempting to calm demonstrators who had gathered at the doors of the building. Subsequently, the FBI allegedly reviewed footage showing Martin inside the Capitol building as well as footage from the Capitol grounds, where Martin told law enforcement officers, "You guys are not doing your job. You swore an oath. You’re bound by your word. Move out of the way and let us in. Move out of the way and let us in.” At one point, officers allegedly deployed chemical spray toward Martin while protecting the building." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Other names/aliases: Uliyahu Ben'arie Hayah, Wiyaha B Hayah, Uliyahu Benarie Hayah, Lemon Raetheon Williams, Le Mon Williams
Name of case: United States of America v. Uliyahu Hayah
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Identified with aid from Sedition Hunters; Resident of VA/MD; On parole supervised by VA DOC; Arrested in 2017 on assault charges for pointing a gun at a driver on the highway
Short narrative: On September 8, 2021, Uliyahu Hayah, 45, of Silver Spring, Maryland, was indicted on several charges, including Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his participation in the U.S. Capitol riots on January 6, 2021. Hayah allegedly entered the Capitol building with a gas mask, laid his hands on a Metropolitan police officer, and pushed him approximately 10 feet into the crowd (Newsone). Hayah is currently on supervised parole through the Virginia Department of Corrections in Fairfax County, Virginia. Hayah was previously arrested after he pointed a handgun at a woman on Interstate I-95. After a further investigation, Maryland State Police troopers also found two rifles—one was an assault rifle—along with a shotgun and ammunition in the man's vehicle. We decided not to include this as a previous similar crime as the motivation was not the same and there were no charges related to firearms with this case.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. David Nicholas Dempsey
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:111(a)(1) and 2 Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) and 2 Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: Resident of CA; Identified with aid from Sedition Hunters; Was arrested 10/1919 for spraying anti-Trump protestors with bear spray; "David Dempsey Sentenced 8/9/24 to 240 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $2,000 in restitution"
Short narrative: "David Dempsey came to the attention of federal investigators through public tips from the Sedition Hunters -- people researching the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol. On the day of the Capitol riot, federal prosecutors allege, Dempsey wore an America flag-themed neck gaiter as well as a combat-style helmet, camouflage pants and a tactical vest. In one video described in court documents, Dempsey stood in front of a gallows erected outside the Capitol and said that Democrats in Congress "need to hang from these motherf****** [pointing to gallows]," and that "Hopefully one day soon we really have someone hanging from one of these motherf******." During the riot, Dempsey allegedly used a lacrimal agent -- such as pepper spray -- as well as a crutch and a metal pole to attack police officers guarding the Capitol building. Dempsey was arrested in Santa Monica, Calif., in 2019 over allegedly using bear spray to attack anti-Trump protesters there. Dempsey pleaded no contest to a charge stemming from that incident. The Justice Department notes in its court filings that Dempsey can be seen in multiple photos from Jan. 6 wearing a black- and yellow-colored bracelet. Black and yellow are the colors associated with the far-right extremist group known as the Proud Boys. In one photo described in court documents, Dempsey made the OK sign while standing next to people wearing Proud Boys attire. The "OK" sign, which the Proud Boys frequently use, is often associated with supporters of white supremacy, according to the Anti-Defamation League. Dempsey was arrested on Aug. 26." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Gary Wilson
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding & Abetting; 18:1752(a)(l) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: "Gary Wilson Sentenced 7/2/24 on Count 11 to 3 days incarceration followed by 12 months supervised release; $500.00 restitution and $25.00 special assessment"; Resident of Salt Lake City, Utah
Short narrative: Federal prosecutors allege that Gary Wilson breached the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, along with two other men: Patrick Montgomery and Brady Knowlton. Wilson wore a T-shirt from the far-right conspiratorial news site Infowars depicting a Revolutionary War soldier with an automatic weapon, according to charging documents. Wilson was in close proximity to multiple violent clashes between rioters and police in and around the Capitol, prosecutors say, though they do not accuse Wilson of committing violence himself. During one confrontation with police, Wilson allegedly told officers, "We came all the way from our jobs to do your job and the freaking senators’ job.” Charging documents state that federal investigators confirmed Wilson's presence in the Capitol through flight records, cellphone records, an interview with a family member of Wilson and videos from multiple sources at the Capitol. The FBI arrested Wilson on Sept. 13, 2021. (NPR) Gary Wilson Sentenced 7/2/24 on Count 11 to 3 days incarceration followed by 12 months supervised release; $500.00 restitution and $25.00 special assessment.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Landon Kenneth Copeland
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of UT; born in MO; Previous charges for "Marijuana/False Statements" and "Burglary of barracks" from US Army in 2013. Other previous charges include DUI, Disorderly Conduct, Carrying firearm in vehicle, all in Montana.; "Landon Copeland Sentenced 5/10/23 to 36 months in prison for assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers, 36 months of supervised release and a fine/restitution of $2,000."
Short narrative: Landon Kenneth Copeland, 33, was identified by the FBI in the days after the January 6th riot at the U.S. Capitol through photos posted to the Facebook account lostforevermore; the photos, posted on January 16, showed Copeland posing with an unidentified woman at numerous Washington D.C. landmarks, wearing the same clothing of one of the more prominent rioters. U.S. Capitol Police footage as well as videos from YouTube and Instagram show a man matching Copeland's appearance grappling with officers outside the U.S. Capitol on the day in question. The footage shows Copeland shoving another rioter into the line of police, grabbing at an officer's riot shield and jacket, and pushing back against them as they attempted to force him away. The Instagram footage specifically showed Copeland and other rioters using a metal bike rack, previously deployed by police as a barricade, to fight back against officers. Interviews with those who knew Copeland revealed that he had taken a week off work during the week in question to travel to Our Nation's capitol. A U.S. Army veteran who had been deployed to Iraq twice as part of a tank unit, Copeland was himself interviewed and admitted to all that was shown in the video footage. He was then charged with multiple federal crimes, including assaulting officers with a deadly weapon. (DOJ)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles, Government Reports and Releases

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND State speech act
Name of case: United States of America v. Joshua Dressel
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of MO; Sentenced to 14 days of imprisonment, total fine of $1,010
Short narrative: On September 13, 2021, Joshua David Dressel, 31, of Missouri, was charged with multiple federal offenses for his participation in the January 6th 2021 Capitol protests. Dressel illegally entered the U.S. Capitol through the Senate Wing Door and walked about areas of the interior, including the Crypt and the northern corridor before exiting through a broken window; altogether, he spent about one hour and forty-five minutes inside the building. The FBI became aware of Dressel after a tipster recognized him in footage from an MSNBC broadcast of the riot as well as livestreamed video from Dressel's Facebook account. Records from Dressel's Facebook account revealed a messaging conversation Dressel had with another user in which he confirmed that he participated in the protests. Additionally, phone records revealed that the phone connected to Dressel utilized cell service sites from inside in the U.S. Capitol on the day in question.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles, Court Documents

"Wilson is a first-grade teacher at Dayspring Christian School in Springfield, Mo., which has released a statement saying she had been put on administrative leave, according to news reports." (NPR)

Name of case: United States of America v. Jacob Kyle Wiedrich
Charges: *18:1752(a)(I) Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of UT; "Sentenced 1/19/22 to three years of probation, including three months of home detention, 100 hours of communitiy service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Jacob Kyle Wiedrich, 23 of Utah, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and was sentenced to three years of probation for his role in the Capitol riot. He posted a SnapChat video where he screams, "It's wartime!... Charge! Charge the motherf***er!....We ride for Trump, we die for Trump!" under the username of “Jacob Weed.” "Wiedrich wore a red "Make America Great Again" hat and a T-shirt with a partial picture of the space shuttle. According to the FBI, footage shows Wiedrich entering the Capitol through a broken window, and once inside, he is seen screaming and taunting a police officer. He was apparently so confrontational that another member of the mob is seen restraining him. He was arrested in Salt Late City." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Robert Ballesteros
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds;
Additional details: Resident of NY; Sentenced 4/28/22 to 36 months of probation, including 40 hours of community service, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Robert Ballesteros, 27 of New York, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and was sentenced to 36 months of probation for his role in the Capitol Raid. "On Jan. 6, Robert Ballesteros posted a video on his Instagram account from inside the U.S. Capitol, according to court documents. The next day, a person who had known him for years turned him into the FBI, which later recovered a conversation on his Instagram account. In the exchange, Ballesteros is asked whether he stormed the building. He replies: "Put my foot in that door" and "Made my stand."" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Guy Wesley Reffitt
Group affiliation: Three Percenters (III Percenters, 3%ers); Texas Freedom Force
Charges: 18:231(a)(2) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(a)(2)(C) Obstruction of Justice – Hindering Communication Through Physical Force or Threat of Physical Force
Additional details: member of III%ers; 1st defendant convicted via trial
Short narrative: Guy Wesley Reffitt, 48, of Wylie, TX, has been charged with obstruction and knowingly entering a restricted building or grounds without lawful authority, related to siege at the US Capitol on 1/6/21...Reffitt's affidavit states hat he is a member of "a militia extremist group,"..."and allege he threatened members of his family following the attack on the Capitol....He was located in surveillance video and the FBI located his cell phone in the area at he time of the crime...He, along with his spouse, daughter and adult son were there at the time the warrant was being served, according to the affidavit...His son explained to authorities that Reffitt told him and other family members he had gone to D.C. to "protect the country" and that he had brought a gun [AR-15 and pistol] with him...He had allegedly told his son and others though, that "we stormed the Capitol," according to the document. The son said he had also recorded footage of the events on the GoPro camera he had been wearing on his helmet...Federal officials allege Reffitt tried to stop his family members from contacting law enforcement about a federal offense, an obstruction of justice, in addition to unlawfully entering Capitol grounds." (ABC News)
Source description: Charging documents, Government reports and releases, news articles

Charges: 18:1512(k) - Conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1), 2 - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3), 2 - Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds;
Additional details: Resident of NV; Boogaloo affiliation

DeGrave, age 31, of Las Vegas, Nevada, was charged with assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers, civil disorder, obstruction of an official proceeding, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a capitol building, impeding passage through the capitol grounds or buildings, parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a capitol building, and acts of physical violence in the capitol grounds or buildings. DeGrave entered the Capitol building during the January 6 riot and shoved a Capitol police officer while inside. His actions were motivated by his rightist: anti-government beliefs.

Name of case: United States of America v. Brandon Straka
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:641 Theft of Government Money, Property, or Records; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds;
Additional details: Resident of NY; "Sentenced 1/24/22 to 36 months of probation, including three months of home detention, $5,000 fine, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Brandon Straka, 45 of New York, pled guilty to Engaging in Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in the Capitol Building or Grounds and was sentenced to 36 months probation. Straka was charged after the FBI received a tip that he had posted videos and comments on his Twitter of his participation in the Capitol riot. He is the founder of #WalkAway Campaign, a movement to discourage liberal participation as a former liberal himself. He spoke at the rally the day before the riot and also invoked the QAnon slogan "Where we go one we go all" at the Jan 6 Stop the Steal rally in D.C.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Ferrigno & Connor
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and distruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of NY; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 9/15/2022 to 12 months of probation, including two months of home confinement, $371 fine, $500 restitution, 60 hours of community service."
Short narrative: Antonio Ferrigno, 26, and his co-defendant Francis Connor who both reside in Brooklyn, New York pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol building. He was sentenced to 12 months probation. "The FBI identified Antonio Ferrigno Jr. in an Instagram photo posted by Anton Lunyk, who is also charged in the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection. The photo shows Ferrigno posing inside the U.S. Capitol alongside Lunyk and another man charged in the riot, Francis Connor, court documents indicate. In text messages obtained by the FBI and sent by Ferrigno to Lunyk, Ferrigno denied being inside the Capitol. In one message, he claimed an earlier video he sent of Connor climbing out a Senate Wing window, was "air dropped" to him, court documents indicate. In another, he reportedly wrote: "I wasn't in the Capitol so idc." However, the FBI identified him in security camera footage from inside the building and in the background of a video shot by the far-right figure known as "Baked Alaska," according to court documents." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Ferrigno & Connor
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and distruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of NY; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 9/15/ 22 to 12 months of probation, including three months of home confinement, $371 fine, $500 restitution, 60 hours of community service."
Short narrative: Francis Connor, 23, and his co-defendant Antonio Ferrigno who both reside in Brooklyn, New York pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol building for his involvement in the Capitol riot. He was sentenced to 12 months probation. "Law enforcement identified Francis Connor in an Instagram photo posted by another person charged in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot, Anton Lunyk. The photo allegedly shows Connor, Lunyk and a third man charged, Antonio Ferrigno Jr., standing inside the U.S. Capitol. The FBI was able to link both Connor and Ferrigno to the photo based on the email addresses used to log into Instagram, court documents indicate. Connor and Ferrigno also reportedly appear in a Live Streamed video shot by the far-right media personality known as "Baked Alaska." In a group message on Instagram with Lunyk and Ferrigno, Connor also allegedly wrote, "I was in the Capitol building."" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. James Douglas Rahm III
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of NJ; Father also arrested; "James Douglas Rahm III Sentenced 1/25/24 to a term of 45 days. The Defendant is further sentenced to serve a term of 12 months of supervised release, to pay $500 in restitution and a $25 special assessment."
Short narrative: On September 17, 2021, Douglas Rahm III was indicted on charges of Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; knowingly attempting to impede or disrupt the orderly conduct of government business; obstruction of Congress; violent entry and disorderly conduct following his involvement in the January 6th Capitol Riots. ..."The FBI field office in Newark, New Jersey tweeted that Rahm had been arrested on Feb. 5. No information on his charges is available, but court documents show he was released on a $100,000 bond with the stipulation that he submit to random drug testing and refrain from excessive use of alcohol." (USA Today). Rahm pleaded not guilty and sentencing information is pending. Rham's father, James Douglas Rham, Jr., was also arrested following his involvement at the Capitol on January 6th, 2021.

Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;

Schubert, 71, along with his wife Amy Schubert from Crest Hill, IL, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his role in the Capitol raid. She sentenced to 18 months of probation, $750 fine, $500 restitution and $10 special assessment; 100 hours of community service. She is a member of III%ers

Name of case: United States of America v. Oliver Louis Sarko
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of OH; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 4/29/22 to 30 days in jail and 36 months of probation, and $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Oliver Louis Sarko, 25, of OH, was initially charged with Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; and Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds via complaint, but was officially charged via Information Sheet with Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;for his role in the January 6th Capitol riot. Sarko posted several videos on Jan. 6 to his Snapchat account, with videos taken from both inside and outside the U.S. Capitol building. In one, Sarko can be heard saying, "We are storming the Capitol out here," “We’re actually breaking in right now," and "Bring out Pelosi." One video has the caption, "We're in," and shows a room that appears to be inside the Capitol. Law enforcement also identified Sarko on surveillance video taken from inside the building, court documents say." (Statement of Facts). Sarko pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; and was sentenced to 30 days in jail and 36 months of probation, and $500 restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and release (DOJ), News article

Short narrative: Matthew Eugene Loganbill, 55, of Missouri, was charged with Obstruction of a Congressional Proceeding; Unlawful Entry; Violent Entry or Disorderly Conduct following his participation in the Capitol riot.

Name of case: United States of America v. Joshua Dillon Haynes
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1), (2), and (4) Unlawful entry on restricted grounds, disorderly conduct, act of physical violence on grounds; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding; 18:1363 Destruction of property in special maritime and territorial jurisdiction; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry or disorderly conduct; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical violence on grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parade, dmonstrate, or picket in any of the Capitol Buildings
Additional details: Resident of VA, "Sentenced 2/2/23 to 32 months in prison, restitution, to be determined at a future date, and 36 months of supervised release"
Short narrative: Joshua Dillion Haynes, 39 of Virginia, pled guilty to Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Destruction of Property in the Territorial Jurisdiction. He was sentenced to 32 months in prison for his role in the Capitol Raid. He was recorded on video attacking members of the media at a staging area near the Capitol, crushing their equipment and stealing their camera. According to local news reporting, Haynes was angry specifically at CNN. "Court documents also show images taken from another video that allegedly show Haynes, along with two others, attempting to pull an air conditioning unit from outside the Capitol building. Haynes was identified by a tipster who used publicly available facial recognition software to match images from photos with a post from a Parler profile, and agents subsequently pulled the subscriber records to find a phone number and email address. Search warrant records for the phone reportedly show that Haynes used it the day of the riot to take pictures inside the Capitol and at the media staging area, and to text with friends. One selfie depicted Haynes inside the office of a U.S. senator, court documents indicate. Later, texts were allegedly exchanged between Haynes and other individuals that indicated he had broken windows and crawled into the Capitol. Prosecutors say one friend texted Haynes the message “dont [sic] be like antifa tearing stuff up.” Haynes replied, “ahhhh tooooo late,” “broke lotsa stuff,” and then “lol.” Haynes reportedly indicated he was seen destroying media equipment, saying "i Kicked the fake news a**" and "I am in the video destroying stuff but I'm wearing a mask." FBI agents went to Haynes' house and interviewed him at length. Haynes allegedly said he believed riot suspects were being treated badly in contrast to people who had participated in Black Lives Matter protests and that he respected those who used force against law enforcement to "stop the election from being stolen." Haynes attended a Proud Boys meeting in late 2020, court documents indicate, but denied he was a member of the far-right extremist group, saying he "would have joined the chapter, but it was too far away and there were no members of the Proud Boys in his local area."" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Article

Wiersma, 66, of Posen, IA, was charged alog with Dawn Frankowski (09222021_DF_FRANKOWSKI1) with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his role in the January 6th Capitol riot. Wiersma was reported via online tip to the FBI. Wiersma pled guilty and was sentenced to 18 months of probation, $500 in restitution, 100 hours community service, and a fine of $1,500.
