Name of case: United States of America v. Krzywicki & Lavin
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of CT; Mother also arrested; Sentenced 4/22/22, 36 months of probation, including 90 days of home detention, $500 restitution
Short narrative: Jean Lavin, 56, and daughter Carla Krzywicki, 19, were arrested on several charges following their participation in the breaching of the U.S. Capitol on 6 January 2021. Both women can allegedly be seen on video wearing pro-Trump clothing and walking throughout the Capitol, while Lavin allegedly carried a sign with the message "Trump Won" and "Don't allow seven states of cheaters to hijack our election." Both women have pled guilty to the single charge of parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building. As they await sentencing, they have been ordered to $500.00 in restitution for damage to the Captiol building.

Name of case: United States of America v. David Antionio Ticas
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of CA; USMC veteran; "Sentenced 7/15/22 to 14 days of incarceration, 24 months of probation, 60 hours community service, and $500 restitution."
Short narrative: David Antonia Ticas, 40 of Georgia, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and was sentenced to 14 days of incarceration and 24 months of probation for his role in the Capitol Raid. "According to court documents, Ticas appears in the Crypt of the U.S. Capitol giving a thumbs up, with the caption, "Storm the capitol [sic]! #StopTheSteal #DemocratsAreCriminals..." The witness identified Ticas as a veteran of the U.S. Marine Corps from their prior service together. The day after the riot, Ticas allegedly posted a picture of the outside of the Capitol that was removed as a community guidelines violation. He added later, "I guess only the clowns of BLM & Antifa can post their peaceful protests." Later messages on his Instagram page allegedly record Ticas saying: "These politicians are straight up criminals. There is a reason for this non-pandemic to continue, it’s the nwo trying to get rid of Trump.” Google location data places Ticas at and inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, court documents indicate. In addition, surveilliance footage also allegedly shows him entering the building, walking through the Crypt, and exiting the building. Additional body camera footage captures him yelling "God damn politicians, don’t f***ing touch me" on his way out, according to court documents." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Christopher Michael Cunningham
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and distruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of TN; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 6/27/22 to 12 months of probation, including 3 months of home detention, $1,113 fine, $500 restitution, community service."
Short narrative: Christopher Cunningham, of Tennessee, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and was sentenced to a year of probation for his role in the Capitol Raid. The FBI received tips that Cunningham had breached the Capitol building, which was corroborated by CCTV footage inside the Capitol. Cunningham was further identified by cell phone records and photos of him inside the building.

Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others

Short narrative: Gary Laird Wickersham, 80, was charged with Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; Knowingly Engages in Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in Restricted Building or Grounds; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds for his role in the Janaury 6th Capitol riot. Wickersham's digital footprint and video of his participation confirmed his participation, in combination with text messagesd Wickersham sent to friends and familty during his participation. Wickersham pled guilty to Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds and was sentenced to 36 months of probation, including 90 days of home detention, $2,000 fine, $500 restitution.

Name of case: United States of America v. Justin McAuliffe
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NY; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 1/28/22 to 36 months of probation, including 60 days of home detention, no use of social media, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Justin McAuliffe, 39 of New York, pled guilty to knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority and was sentenced to 3 years of probation for his role entering the Capitol Raid. McAuliffe was the subject of numerous tips submitted the FBI call centers based on his Facebook posts. FBI agents were able to locate McAuliffe's Telegram and Facebook, both of which contains his picture and real name. The Facebook posts shows McAuliffe in front of the US Capitol and a crowd waving Trump flags, and his other posts reads "yeah I was in one of the offices...Cops came in and weee [sic] like Okay guys really? They didn't even ask us to leave right away. They let us sit down and hang out and relax." A picture of him was taken in a member of Congress' office, which he later used as his Telegram profile picture. His location inside the Captiol was further corroborated by his phone records. (Statement of Facts)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Getsinger & Hargis-Getsinger
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of SC; Husband also arrested; Cites Donald Trump and Alex Jones as influencing her actions that day; Indicted by Bill of Information; "Sentenced 7/12/22 to 60 days in jail, three years of probation, 100 hours of community service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: In a bill of information issued on September 30, 2021, John Hubert Getsinger Jr., 52, and Stacie Ann Hargis-Getsinger, 43, were charged with several federal offenses for their action on January 6, 2021, including entering a restricted building without lawful authority to do so as well as disrupting the orderly conduct of government business. CCTV footage from inside the U.S. Capitol on the day in question show two individuals, who law enforcement judged to match the descriptions of the Getsingers, illegally entering the building and remaining inside the Rotunda and other areas for an extended period of time before absconding. According to a criminal complaint, four people contacted the FBI’s tip line separately to report that the couple had traveled from Hanahan to participate in the protest and subsequent riot at the U.S. Capitol building in Washington, pointing to interactions and posts on Facebook indicating their involvement. Further, a search warrant for the Getsingers' Facebook accounts revealed exchanges between them and other users showing them discussing their participation in the events at the U.S. Capitol.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeremy Brown
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds;
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; former US Army Special Forces and former Congressional candidate
Short narrative: Retired Green Beret, Jeremy Brown, was arrested and charged for his involvement in the January 6, 2021 Capitol protests. Brown was charged with knowingly entering a restricted building or grounds without lawful authority and knowingly disrupting the orderly conduct of government business or official functions. Brown joined the Army in October 1992, according to military service records, and retired as a master sergeant in October 2012. He served as an infantryman, a Special Forces communications sergeant, and a Special Forces senior sergeant during his career. Brown deployed to combat four times during his career, including stints in Iraq from October 2007 to May 2008 and from January to July 2009, and deployments to Afghanistan from January to March 2005 and May to August 2011.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Donald Smith
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Additional details: Resident of NJ; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Case dismissed 11/3/2022
Short narrative: On October 6, 2021, Donald Smith was charged with multiple federal offenses for his participation in the January 6, 2021 riot at the U.S. Capitol Building. Smith allegedly walked through the Capitol, spending at least half an hour in the building. He was captured on CCTV footage walking about the building interior. The criminal complaint states that returned to work on January 7 and bragged about his participation to his coworkers, including showing them images of the event. Law enforcement became aware of Smith after several of these coworkers came forward and notified the FBI of this.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Anthony Vuksanaj
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
