The other charges are dismissed; Sentenced 4/29/22 to three years of probation, including. 42 days of intermittent confinement to be served in three 14-day increments, three months of home detention, $2,000 fine, $500 restitution
Short narrative: Anthony Vuksanaj, 52 of New York, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and was sentenced to 42 of incarceration for his role in the Capitol Raid. "According to the FBI, Vuksanaj's phone was subsequently identified as being in an area that included the grounds of the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6. After reviewing video footage from inside the Capitol, the Westchester County detectives were able to confirm that Vuksanaj was in the building, court documents indicate. A video shot by a reporter for National Geographic also allegedly shows Vuksanaj walking around the building, recording on his cellphone." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Philip S. Young
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of Sewell, NJ; "Sentenced 1/31/23 to 8 months in prison, $2,000 restitution, and 36 months of supervised release."
Short narrative: Philip S. Young, 59, a resident of Sewell, NJ, pled guilty to seven charges during the capitol riots. NPR states "Philip Young allegedly pushed a barricade into police officers protecting the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection. The criminal complaint says he was identified from videos and photos, one of which showed him letting the air out of the tire of a U.S. government vehicle while wearing a distinctive America flag bandana over his head. Court documents indicate that the jacket he was wearing in that photo bore the unique logo associated with the Boilermakers Union Local 28, located in Eastampton, N.J. When FBI agents later interviewed witnesses who identified Young from the pictures, one witness confirmed that he is a retired member of that union. Footage from officers' body cameras also show Young involved in the violent struggle with police officers and the barricades at the Capitol (NPR)."
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Erik Herrera
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of El Cajon, CA; "Sentenced 1/13/23 to 48 months in prison for felony and misdemeanor charges, also ordered to three years of supervised release, $2,000 restitution, a fine of $1,000, and a special assessment of $170."
Short narrative: Erik Herrera, 33, a resident of California, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his role in the Capitol Raid "“I’m reclaiming Aztlan because I love America. Querer es poder! ... #chicanohistory #mexicanamerican,” Erik Herrera allegedly wrote on Instagram as a caption to a picture of him holding a large stack of papers inside one of the offices in the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6. Aztlán is the ancestral home of the Aztec people. Querer es poder, translated from Spanish, means “where there’s a will, there’s a way.” The FBI identified Herrera after a tip and later obtained a federal search warrant for his social media accounts. In a personal message to another user, Herrera allegedly wrote he was in Washington, D.C., “for both photojournalism and our people,” and stated his dissatisfaction with the election results. Additionally, when asked on Instagram, “What was going through your mind while holding what appeared to be a stack of government documents?” he allegedly responded: “I wasn’t thinking much, I just wanted a goofy ‘f*** you’ picture.” According to the FBI, Herrera later admitted on social media that the “press patch” he wore was purchased online and was not issued by a media organization. “I don’t have a monopoly on press badges. They’re on Amazon for like $8 … No special permission to buy.”" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Riley June Williams
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; *18:641, 2 Theft of Goverment Property and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of PA; Bellingcat investigation shows her with a Siege mask (popular with accelerationist neo-Nazis), a Schwarze Sonne hat (nazi-era fascist symbol), and makign a Roman (Nazi) salute (Source: https://www.bellingcat.com/news/americas/2021/02/24/woman-accused-of-stealing-nancy-pelosis-laptop-appears-in-video-making-nazi-salute/); "Riley Williams Found guilty by jury on 11/21/22 of interfering with law enforcement officers during a civil disorder, and resisting or impeding law enforcement officers, both felonies, as well as four related misdemeanor offenses: entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building. The jury was unable to reach a verdict on two other charges, including obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting in the theft of government property."; "Riley June Williams Sentenced 3/23/23 to 36 months in prison for interfering with law enforcement officers during a civil disorder, and resisting or impeding law enforcement officers, both felonies, as well as four related misdemeanor offenses, and 36 months of supervised release and $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: Riley June Williams, 22 of Pennsylvania, was found guilty of civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding law enforcement officers; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building; and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building for her role in the Capitol raid. She was sentenced to 36 months of prison. Williams is alleged to have stolen the laptop of Speak of the House Nancy Pelosi, though an aid to the speaker said it was a laptop used only for presentations. Video from the incident shows her directing other rioters upstairs. According to her mother whom she lives with, Williams, "had taken a sudden interest in President Donald Trump’s politics and 'far-right message boards.'" (AP)
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Steven Thurlow
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; Resident of MI.; "Sentenced 8/30/22 to 24 months of probation, 80 hours of community service, and $500 in restitution."
Short narrative: Steven Thurlow, 50 of Michigan, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his role in the Capitol Raid."A witness contacted the FBI identifying Steven Thurlow as having been inside the Capitol building on Jan. 6, according to court documents. "The witness also provided screenshots of Thurlow’s Facebook posts, including one in which he is seen wearing camouflage tactical gear with a “Boogaloo” patch on his chest. The extremist Boogaloo movement anticipates a second civil war in America, and some adherents even seek to bring about that conflict. “Ahh nothing like a new pair of 511’s and fresh set of level IV SAPI’s in the plate carrier to go “peacefully protest” with, the caption to the picture read, referring to a high-level ballistic body armor plate, Thurlow had allegedly purchased. According to the FBI, Thurlow served in the Army from 1988 until 1991. A second witness told the FBI that Thurlow had become something of a “conspiracy theorist” after joining the military. Inside the Capitol building, photos show Thurlow lying on what appears to be a conference room table. He is also seen walking around the hallways recording on his cellphone, wearing a camouflage jacket, a yellow scarf and white rimmed sunglasses.""(NPR) He served in the US Army 101st Airborne 1988-1991, served abroad in Saudia Arabia for 6 months in 1990.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Julia Jeanette Sizer
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Husband also arrested; Resident of PA; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 2/1/22 to one year of probation, $2,000 fine, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Julia Sizer, 38, a resident of Pennsylvania, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for her role in the Capitol Raid. Her husband, Brian Douglas Sizer was also arrested. According to NPR, "Julia Sizer came to the attention of the FBI via a tip from a person who'd obtained a video allegedly taken by the defendant that showed her "in the [U.S.] capitol building during the insurrection," court documents indicate. The criminal complaint says that after reviewing the video, agents reached out to Sizer, who denied being in the Capitol at the time of the Jan. 6, 2021, riot and subsequently acquired counsel. Sizer's phone was not shown to be among those that showed up in records provided by Google in a search warrant, but after a later interview with the FBI in the presence of her legal counsel, she admitted she was inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021."
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Eckerman
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; *18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *50:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of KS; "Michael Eckerman Sentenced 3/8/23 to 20 months in prison, 24 months of supervised release and $2,000 in restitution."
Short narrative: Eckerman, 37 of Kansas, pled guilty to Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers or Employees for his role in the Capitol raid. He was sentenced 3/8/2023 to 20 months incarceration. "Mike Eckerman ⁠— wearing a red hat, neon gloves and a load-bearing tactical vest ⁠— is captured on body camera footage yelling at law enforcement outside the U.S. Capitol, according to court documents. Once inside the building, he is allegedly seen on surveillance cameras pushing an officer backward several feet. According to court documents, the pushed officer loses his balance and falls down a set of stairs. A different individual then proceeds to spray that officer with a fire extinguisher in the face. As Eckerman makes his way further in, he is seen pushing several other officers, court records indicate. Once back outside, Eckerman is reportedly captured on video discussing his motivation for going inside and also comments on the shooting of Ashli Babbitt. “I don’t know her name, all I know is we went there (Capitol) as patriots. She is dead because we’re here. These mother f***ers are traitors, they are f***ing traitors!” he allegedly says." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Mitchell Todd Gardner
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding; *18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; *18:1361, 2 Destruction of government property; *18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority (Misdemeanor); *18:1752(a)(2) Engages in disruptive conduct with intent to disrupt ordinary government business (Misdemeanor); *18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Utter loud, threatening, or abusive language, or engage in disorderly or disruptive conduct (Misdemeanor); *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings (misdemanor); *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parade, demonstrate, or picket inside the Capitol building (Misdemeanor)
Additional details: Resident of FL; "Gardner Sentenced 3/16/23 to 55 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, and restitution of $3,500."
Short narrative: Mitchell Gardner, 33 of Florida, pled guilty to Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon. He was sentenced to 55 months of incarceration for his role in the Capitol raid. He was seen on a ledge outside the Senate portion of the building, using a red canister in a black case to break a window. He then entered the building and gestured for others to join him. Gardner was also seen spraying what was later identified as pepper spray at two Capitol police officers (at least). (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Release, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Derek Gunby
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of SC; Served in US Army; listed job on Facebook as "sleeper/agent", and noted he was a "Former Vice President/Member Board of Directors at the Father's Rights Movement" and former satelite communications non-comissioned office in the US Army
Short narrative: "A day before the riot at the U.S. Capitol, Derek Gunby reportedly posted a photo of himself in a car on Facebook with the caption “Halfway to The capitol.” Later that day, having arrived in Washington, D.C., he took a picture of several bags of bricks, placed by law enforcement, with the caption: “Cops in leftist-controlled areas of the US seem to assist with this type of thing for leftist terrorism. We’re ready. We know you, we know what you are and what you bring to play with. We‘re also smarter and are willing to die for our belief whereas you are not," according to court documents. On Jan. 6, Gunby also allegedly Live Streamed himself riding on the D.C. Metro with another individual heading to then-President Donald Trump's rally. In the video, he is reportedly heard saying: “Your congressional leaders are not afraid of you. …They’re more afraid of left-wing media. And they are more afraid of antifa and Black Lives Matter than they are of the America patriot, the America conservative, the America libertarian.” According to court documents, FBI agents interviewed Gunby, who said he entered the Capitol following the rally and walked around the building with a large group of people and recorded on his cellphone. According to news reports, Gunby served in the U.S. Army." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Richard Bryan Watrous
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NY; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 4/21/22 to 36 months of probation, including 14 days in jail, 60 days of home confinement, $2,500 fine, $500 restitution.
Short narrative:
Richard Bryan Watrous, 59, a resident of New York, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his role in the Capitol Raid. 
"Richard Watrous was initially identified from surveillance footage of the riot at the U.S. Capitol, according to a criminal complaint. FBI agents say he was wearing a distinctive red "Trump" hat when he entered the Capitol and then could be seen leaving after a few minutes inside. When he was interviewed by law enforcement, Watrous allegedly said his trip to Washington, D.C., was planned as soon as he heard former President Trump urging people to go. He allegedly said he drove to D.C. from his New York home despite the fact that he did not feel he could have any effect on the proceedings in Congress. According to court documents, Watrous attended the rally at the Ellipse the morning of Jan. 6 and then made his way to the Capitol, where he said there were already people there, and he could hear flashbangs and was aware of tear gas even though he was fairly far away from the building. When he allegedly entered the Capitol building, he told agents, he heard someone yell, "they just killed a girl!"; agents believe that the person was referring to the shooting of Ashli Babbitt. Once inside, Watrous reportedly said that he felt uncomfortable and thought, “This is crazy. What the hell is going on here?” He went on to say that people around him "seemed like troublemakers and did not seem like peaceful protestors," court documents indicate. He claims he witnessed a man who had said he was going into House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's office holding a bottle of wine and saying "I got Nancy Pelosi's wine!" Watrous told agents that he was inside the Capitol for about five minutes before he left, going back into the Rotunda briefly before returning to his hotel."' (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Angelo Riley
Charges: 18:1512(b)(2)(B) Obstruction; 18:1512(c)(1) Obstruction
Short narrative: Michael Riley, a veteran officer with the U.S. Capitol Police, was arrested for allegedly encouraging a suspect in the Jan. 6 Capitol riot to hide evidence of their involvement in the attack. He is facing two counts of obstruction of justice, and has been placed on administrative leave while the case is ongoing.The officer, Michael Angelo Riley, has worked for the Capitol Police for nearly 25 years and most recently served as a technician with the K-9 unit. There is no evidence in the indictment that Riley has links to any known extremist organizations. Still, the indictment suggests that he harbored some sympathy for an alleged participant in the Capitol riot, an incident that the FBI has classified as an act of “domestic terrorism.”
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jason Michael Comeau
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 11/15/22 to 12 months of probation, including 2 months of home confinement, 60 hours community service, $371 fine, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: Jason Michael Comeau, 40, a resident of Florida, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his role in the Capitol Raid. "Less than a week after the Jan. 6 U.S. Capitol riot, a relative of Jason Comeau contacted the FBI and said that Comeau had admitted to breaching the building, according to charging documents filed in federal court. Comeau later gave a voluntary interview to FBI agents, court papers state, during which he said he had attended the pro-Trump rally earlier in the day and then marched toward the Capitol building. Comeau allegedly told agents that he climbed the stairs heading into the building and that after the crowd repeatedly chanted "Let us in," Capitol police moved aside, allowing the crowd to enter the building. Comeau allegedly told FBI agents that he believed he was allowed to enter the building and that he only progressed as far as a hallway. Prosecutors now allege that surveillance footage and cellphone video show Comeau going as far as the Capitol's Statuary Hall and remaining in the building for approximately 20 minutes. He also allegedly joined chants of "stop the steal," a slogan adopted by President Donald Trump and some of his supporters that falsely asserts that Trump won the 2020 presidential election. From July 2000 to December 2002, Comeau served in the U.S. Army as a combat engineer, an Army spokesperson confirmed to NPR. Comeau did not have any combat deployments and held the rank of private at the end of his service, the spokerson said." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Clifford James Meteer
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of TN; Carried a sign reading 'Stop the Steal/Save the Republic'; Sentenced 4/21/22 to 60 days in jail, followed by 36 months of probation, including 60 hours of community service and $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Clifford James Meteer, 66, a resident of Tennesee, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his role in the Capitol Raid. "Clifford Meteer left a stream of public comments on Facebook in the days following the U.S. Capitol riot, along with private messages to at least three people containing photos from inside the building, according to a criminal complaint. “I was one of those idiots scaling the wall,” he reportedly wrote to one friend, describing news coverage of the event as “extremely overblown.” “I saw no violence. I saw no destruction. Are you surprised he media is distorting reality?” he wrote in a public comment on Jan. 7, the complaint indicates. “I saw 2 kids trying to kick in a door and we told them to stop and they did. As to violence, I was right around the corner from the vet who was murdered.” Meteer’s relative and a former classmate both sent photos to the FBI in January, claiming they showed Meteer at the Jan. 6 riot, according to the complaint. The classmate told the FBI he’d seen several now-deleted posts of Meteer’s Facebook page, including a photo of Meteer holding up a sign reading “Save the republic.” The complaint alleges that video footage shows Meteer in various parts of the Capitol throughout a half-hour span." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Messer & Borgerding
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of OH; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Walter Messer Sentenced 9/12/23 to twenty-four (24) months of Probation (with conditions). $10.00 Special Assessment and Restitution in the amount of $500.00. Counts 1, 2, and 3 DISMISSED ON ORAL MOTION OF THE GOVERNMENT."
Short narrative: Walter J. Messer, 51, of Englewood, OH, is charged with crimes related to his participation in the Capitol raid on January 6, 2021. He was seen both inside and outside the Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Kelly McFadden O'Brien
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of PA; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 4/6/22 to 90 days of incarceration, 12 months of supervised release, $500 restitution, $1,000 fine; Expressed support for QAnon
Short narrative: Kelly O'Brien, 49, a resident of Pennsylvania, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his role in the Capitol Raid. "A witness called the FBI after seeing videos on Kelly McFadden O'Brien's Facebook page reportedly showing her inside and nearby the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. In the videos, she narrates her path to the Capitol, reportedly saying: “We’re getting gassed and rubber bullets. We’re under Joe fake Biden Inaugural steps that he was supposed to be the fake president in. we’re probably about 20 feet to 40 feet from the Capitol doors. Some really brave patriots here. I’m right in the thick of it, following them up.” Law enforcement also identified O'Brien in security camera footage from inside the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, court documents indicate. In social media posts leading up to Jan. 6, 2021, O'Brien reportedly posted often about what she believed was a stolen election, a claim for which there is no basis. On Nov. 26, 2020, she allegedly wrote: "We are an Army of Patriots. You will know us when you see us. There will be no ambiguity. Prepare yourself.” On Dec. 12, 2020, she allegedly posted about being in Washington, D.C., and said she was walked back to her hotel by the far-right extremist group the Proud Boys. A week later, she reportedly posted: "CALLING ALL PATRIOTS! Be in Washington D.C. January 6th. This wasn’t organized by any group. DJT has invited us and it’s going to be 'wild.' " On Jan. 1, 2021, she made reference in a post to the "3 percent," which refers to a far-right extremist group named for the myth that only 3% of Colonists fought against the British during the America Revolution, court documents indicate, and in other posts she reportedly made references to QAnon. In a post on Jan. 7, 2021, O'Brien seemed to distance herself from those videos and posts that placed her among the Jan. 6, 2021, rioters, writing she “had to scrub my page, for obvious reasons,” according to court documents. Later, though, she reportedly wrote again: "No regrets" with a heart emoji." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Kim Michael Sorgente
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds;
Additional details: Wore 2 different MAGA hats
Short narrative: "Kim Michael Sorgente is allegedly seen in video footage, police body camera footage and photographs among the mob that stormed the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6. According to court documents, he was wearing a "Make America Great Again" hat and a shirt that read "Deus Vult," a Latin phrase used as a rallying cry during the Crusades that roughly translates to "God's Will" and that has now gained popularity among far-right extremists. Sorgente was also identified, prosecutors say, through his cellphone number. That number had been obtained when he was arrested for an incident in December 2020, and on Jan. 6, location records allegedly show it near and/or inside the Capitol building. In police body camera footage from that day, Sorgente can allegedly be seen yelling into a megaphone: “How dare you? How dare you, traitors? How dare you traitors?” from behind a line of rioters who were pushing a police barricade into officers. Sorgente continued to yell into the microphone as other rioters assaulted police, court documents indicate, including: “Why don’t you let us in? Let us in. It’s our house. It’s our house. You let us in, we’ll behave. If you keep fighting us and pepper-spraying us, we’re gonna get upset.” Sorgente is allegedly later seen on surveillance footage entering a tunnel that led into the Capitol, where a violent standoff between rioters and police occurred. At one point in the late afternoon, court documents indicate, Sorgente was pushing directly against law enforcement as they tried to expel rioters from the archway to the tunnel." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Tenney & Youngers
Charges: *18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; *18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Served in the US Marine Corp; "Sentenced 9/8/22 to 36 months of probation, $1,000 fine, $500 restitution."
Veteran status: Former active duty and reserve components
Short narrative: Darrell Alan Youngers of Texas traveled to Washington DC and unlawfully entered the US Capitol building with South Carolinian George Amos Tenney the III. Youngers walked around the building and laid hands on a police during an altercation. For his participation in the U.S. Capitol riot on January 6, 2021, he was charged with disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building, knowingly entering or remaining in a restricted building without lawful authority, disorderly conduct in a U.S. Capitol building, and parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Cory Ray Brannan
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of TX; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 9/23/22 to 30 days incarceration, 24 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Cory Ray Brannan, 24, a resident of Texas and alleged member of the Three Percenters, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his role in the Capitol Raid. "The criminal complaint against Cory Brannan, an employee at the Midland County Sheriff's Office in Texas, says he was identified as having been inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan.6 by the FBI using cellphone location data. Once agents went through his cellphone records, they found he’d been in touch with many other individuals alleged to have participated in the riot. Photos of Brannan online show him at the Capitol wearing a black hoodie, camouflage pants and a khaki vest with scissors and goggles. The vest had various patches, including one for the Three Percenters, an anti-government extremist group. There are multiple images that appear to show Brannan on the day of the riot, allegedly climbing into the Capitol through a window and walking around inside the building as well. Brannan was identified in photos by a captain of the Midland County Sheriff's Office in Texas where Brannan works as a jailer." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Tenney & Youngers
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; *18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Tenney is an administrator for "The PowerHouse Patriot" facebook page; "Sentenced 12/5/22 to Thirty-Six (36) Months of Incarceration on each count which shall run concurrently to each other followed by Thirty-Six (36) Months of Supervised Release as to each count which shall run concurrently to each other. Special Assessment in the amount of $100 imposed on each count for a total of $200. Restitution in the amount of $2,000 imposed."
Short narrative: George Amos Tenney III, 34, of Anderson, South Carolina traveled to Washington DC and entered the capitol building with Texan Darrell Alan Youngers. Tenney walked around the building before attempting to let more rioters into the Capitol and aggreesively interacting with and assualting Capitol security.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Anthony Sargent
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:1361, 2 - Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL; "Anthony Sargent Sentenced 12/15/23 to sixty (60) months of incarceration to run concurrently, thirty-six (36) months of supervised release to run concurrently, $2,980 in restitution and $220 special assessment."
Short narrative: Anthony Sargent is charged with engaging in physical violence, destruction of property and various acts of illegal entry and disorderly conduct. He was identified through the FBI BOLO list because of his knuckle tattoos. He can be seen in surveilance photos throwing what looks like a brick at the windows of the Capitol building. His social media shows a connection to the Proud Boys.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Adam Mark Weibling
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of TX; Attended with wife (not arrested); Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Adam Weibling Sentenced 4/12/23 to 24 Months Probation; $10 S/A; $500 restitution as to Count 4. Count(s) 1, 2, 3, were dismissed on Government's Oral Motion."
Short narrative: On January 19, 2021, a tipster notified the FBI that Adam Mark Weibling, 34, of Katy, Texas was one of the rioters that breached police lines and illegally entered the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. The tipster provided law enforcement with images from Weibling's social media accounts proving his presence in Washington on the day in question as well as a YouTube video of the events that show an individual matching Weibling's description participating. A second tipster also reached out to federal law enforcement about Weibling, providing his address and notifying them that he had travelled to Washington with his wife Brittany for the event; the second tipster directed the FBI to the same video that the first tipster did. In the video, the individual matching Weibling's description is shown talking to the officer attempting to hold him back from proceeding further into the U.S. Capitol building. Surveillance footage from within the building shows that Weibling then forced his way past the officer to linger about the Rotunda and Old Senate Chamber hallway. Review of flight records from America Airlines showed that Weibling did take a flight to Houston from Washington D.C. on January 7, and review of Weibling's social media activity found that the account linked to his phone number and address--where an affiant later observed Weibling physically--had engaged with posts by Mike Cernovich indicating that he and his wife would be in Washington D.C. on the day of the electoral ballot counts. Weibling was soon after arrested and charged with disorderly conduct in a restricted building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles, Government Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Kevin Douglas Creek
Charges: 18:751(a)(1) - Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Physical Violence on Capitol Grounds; 18:231(a)(3) - Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers;
Additional details: Resident of GA; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 5/2/22 to 27 months in prison, 12 months of supervised release, $2,000 restitution.
Short narrative: Kevin Douglas Creek, 46, from Alpharetta, Georgia, is charged with federal offenses after being captured on body cameras striking and kicking officers outside the United States Capitol Building during the riot on January 6, 2021. A complainant reported him to the FBI after describing his participation in the riot in the days afterward in January 2021. Subsequent review of financial and travel records then found that Creek indeed did travel to Washington D.C. on the days in question, checking into a hotel across the Potomac from the National Mall and bought things along the route from Washington to his Georgia home. Further, Creek was interviewed in May 2021 and confirmed the findings in the records and teh bodycam footage. A former marine, active from 1995 to 1999, creek was then arrested and charged by a bill of information.
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Release, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Gilbert Fonticoba
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3), 2 Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of FL; "Gilbert Fonticoba Found guilty at bench trial 10/6/23 of two felony charges for his actions during the Jan. 6, 2021, breach of the U.S. Capitol."
Short narrative: "Gilbert Fonticoba was arrested on Oct. 26 in Miami and charged in a felony indictment with six counts, including obstructing an official proceeding and civil disorder. He must appear at an arraignment in District Court in Washington, D.C., on Nov. 2. According to his LinkedIn page and multiple news outlets, Fonticoba has appeared at rallies for Trump in Florida and supports the Proud Boys." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Adam Johnson
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:641 - Theft of Government Property; 40:5104(e)(2) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 2/25/2022 to 75 days in jail, followed by a year of supervised release, 200 hours of community service, a $5,000 fine, and $500 in restitution.
Short narrative: On Jan. 6, 2021, Adam Johnson illegally entered the United States Capitol during the Capitol Riots and removed the Speaker of the House’s lectern from where it had been stored on the House side of the Capitol building. He is pictured carrying the lectern in a photo that became a very popular image online following the events. Social media users and law enforcement tipsters identified Johnson, a resident of Brandenton, Florida. Law enforcement then searched public government databases for an Adam Johnson in that area and found that the driver's license photo of the Adam Johnson of Brandenton, Florida did indeed match the description of the man in the widely-circulated photo. Johnson was then charged with theft of government property and several other counts.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles, Government Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Benjamen Burlew
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 18:113(a)(4) Assault in Special Maritime and Territorial Jurisdiction; 18:113(a)(5) Simple Assault within the Territorial Jurisdiction
Additional details: Former US Army serviceman; Resident of OK
Veteran status: Former active duty and reserve components
Short narrative: On October 27, 2021, Benjamen Scott Burlew, 45, was indicted on several charges related to his involvement in the U.S. Capitol riots on January 6, 2021. In video surveillance footage from that day, Burlew was seen assaulting a photographer for The Associated Press. The FBI says that Burlew, a former member of the U.S. Army, pushed and shoved the journalist, and tried to throw him over the wall of the U.S. Capitol's west lawn. He later lunged at the journalist and threw him over the wall. All further updates regarding Burlew's case are currently pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Paul Colbath
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of SC; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 4/6/22 to three years of probation, to include 30 days home detention, 60 hours community service, $500 restitution
Short narrative: In the days after the riot at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021, informants reached out to the FBI informing them that Paul Gray Colbath, 64, of South Carolina had been bragging about his participation in the events there. The FBI then conducted an interview with Colbath himself, in which he confirmed that he was indeed present in Washington D.C. on the day in question and did indeed enter the U.S. Capitol Building with the violent crowd. While inside, he witnessed vandalism and the usage of tear gas; he ushered another protestor, clearly affected by the tear gas, out of the commotion and into a nearby office. Colbath claims he left the building soon after. Footage provided by Colbath himself as well as closed circuit surveillance footage from within the building confirm all that he told the FBI; additionally, records from T-Mobil tracked the cell phone using the number associated with Colbath to the interior of the U.S. Capitol on the day in question. With all this information, Colbath was charged by the U.S. Attorney for the District of Columbia.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release, Local News Articles

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND State speech act
Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Dickinson
Charges: *18:231(a)(3) - Civil disorder; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of PA; "Defendant sentenced to TWENTY (20) months of incarceration; THIRTY-SIX (36) months of Supervised Release; Special Assessment of $100.00 and Restitution in the amount of $2000.00 ."
Short narrative: On October 29, 2021, Michael Dickinson was charged for his actions stemming from his January 6, 2021 activities at the US Capitol. Dickinson was alleged to have thrown a large coffee tumbler at law enforcement, striking one officer. Dickinson also allegedly threw a large bucket filled with liquid at law enforcement. He was identified by a tipster on January 9, 2021.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Kevin Louis Galetto
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of justice; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers or employees; *18:111(a)(1) and (b) Using a Dangerous or Deadly Weapon on Certain Officers; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Merritt Island, FL; "Kevin Galetto Sentenced 9/5/23 to 27 months in prison, 24 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $2,000 in restitution."
Short narrative: Kevin Louis Galetto, 61, was indicted on 9 charges for his involvement in a violent confrontation with a police officer during the Jan. 6, 2021 riot at the U.S. Capitol. That officer's body camera captured a “scuffle involving Galetto ́ in which the officer was knocked to the ground; the suspect's face can be seen pushed up against the officer's shield, according to the affidavit filed by FBI Special Agent David J. DiMarco. Four or five minutes after cameras captured Galetto entering the Capitol, police body camera video showed him pushing against officers' shields and eventually on one knee with a hand on the ground, according to the affidavit." (Los Angeles Times). Galetto pled guilty on 2/10/2023 to a charge of Obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder and Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers or employees. His sentencing is scheduled for August 8, 2023.
Source description: Court documents, Charging Documents, Local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Andrew Quentin Taake
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:111(a)(1)( and (b) (Felony) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers [2 counts]; 18:231 (a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1), (2), and (4) Entering or Remaining, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct, and Engaging in Physical VIolence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D)(E)(F) and (G) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, Impeding Passage through an Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings, Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of TX
Short narrative: "Andrew Taake assaulted law enforcement officers twice -- once with pepper spray and once with a metal whip, according to the FBI. Court documents show that Taake was identified to prosecutors by a match on the dating app Bumble. Those documents include screenshots taken from the app, which the FBI says show Taake being in Alexandria, Va., on Jan. 6 and admitting to spending half an hour inside the U.S. Capitol. Security camera footage confirms Taake was inside the Capitol carrying the metal whip, prosecutors say. The FBI says it served a search warrant on Verizon, and cellphone records show a phone associated with Taake’s number was likely inside the Capitol. Prosecutors also say they reviewed flight records showing Taake flew from Houston to Baltimore on Jan. 5 on Spirit Airlines and returned to Texas on Jan. 8." (NPR) He was sentenced to 74 months in prison.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents;

Name of case: United States of America v. Edward T. Spain, Jr.
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of OK; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 5/4/22 to 36 months of probation, including 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution.
Veteran status: Former active duty and reserve components
Short narrative: In the days leading up to January 6, 2021, Edward Thomas Spain, Jr, 55, posted messages on right-wing media site Parler warning that civil war was imminent and that Joe Biden's electoral college victory was a sign of America being a "banana republic." Then, on January 6, Spain was found to have illegally entered the U.S. Capitol building with the mob in Washington D.C. He took photos of himself at the event and posted them to social media; the posts were then found by the FBI, who connected the posts to a phone number belonging to Spain and to usage of a cell site servicing the interior of the U.S. Capitol Building on the day in question. Spain was later interviewed at his Oklahoma home, where he confirmed his presence at the riot and his entrance into the United States Capitol. Spain was then charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his participation in the Capitol riot.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles, Government Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. James Burton McGrew
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of AZ; served in the Marines; Evidence of QAnon connection is not well established; "Sentenced 1/20/23 to 78 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, a $5,000 fine and $2,000 restitution"
Short narrative: In the days and weeks after the riot at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021, the FBI received concerns from numerous people regarding James Burton McGrew, 39, of Arizona. The first tip, received by the FBI on January 7, 2021, notified them of McGrew's intent to travel to Washington D.C. and protest the "stolen vote" prior to the day as well as his belief in some elements of the Qanon conspiracy theory; the second, received on February 26, 2021, provided the FBI with photos of McGrew participating in the violent events and confronting MPD and Capitol Police officers. Law enforcement was able to identify McGrew through bodycam footage when the individual matching his description in the photos lifted his shirt and exposed a tattoo on his torso reading "King James." McGrew was known to have that exact tattoo in that exact area as it was shown in a booking photo from a previous arrest. Further footage shows McGrew repeatedly accosting law enforcement officers: he yelled "we're coming in, whether you like it or not" and "fight with us, not against us" at them directly; later, McGrew was seen within the rotunda lunging at an officer who attempted to forcefully repel the intruders; McGrew continued to disobey the officers' orders to retreat, screaming "You leave! This is our house!" and then striking and grabbing for the baton of an officer that attempted to push him back. With plenty of evidence to charge him on, law enforcement began a manhunt for McGrew that tracked him to a sober home he was living in in Carlsbad, California; McGrew was not there--having left for a hearing regarding another crime he committed in Mississippi--but law enforcement did find the clothing that was consistent with that worn by McGrew at the U.S. Capitol in the bodycam footage. Over the next several days, McGrew traveled westward from Mississippi to Arizona and even managed to cross into and out of Mexico; the FBI received a warrant to track McGrew's cell phone. McGrew was eventually found outside his half-sister's home in Glendale, Arizona and subsequently arrested by the FBI.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Andrew James Williams
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(C),(D),(E) Disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; 40:5104 (e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitiol building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Sanford, FL; Indicted by Bill of Information; released on $25,000 signature bond; Sentenced 2/9/22 to 24 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Andrew James Williams, a Sanford, Florida firefighter-paramedic was charged with Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitiol building following his participation in the Capitol riot. Williams was originally charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, and Disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds, but the charges were reduced following a supersceding Bill of Informtion and a plea deal. Williams pled guilty to Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitiol building. The case is still pending.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, News article, Local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Traci J. Sunstrum
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NY; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 2/24/22 to three years of probation, including 30 days of home detention, $500 restitution
Short narrative: Traci J. Sunstrum, 44, of New York was identified, arrested and charged for her actions on January 6 thanks to an anonymous tip referring them to her Facebook live stream of the event and Google location data that was obtained pursuant to a search warrant; the Google account registered to Sunstrum--tjgreenfrog@gmail.com--was found to have a mobile device using the account within the U.S. Capitol at the time in question. After the account was connected to Sunstrum, law enforcement obtained a known image of her from the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles and found upon comparison that it matched the photos believed to be of Sunstrum on January 6. Sunstrum was photographed--wearing a green jacket, stars-and-stripes-printed pants, and a hat with a symbol of the Qanon conspiracy theory--inside the U.S. Capitol, cursing at Capitol Police officers, telling other rioters to "hold the line," and "if I go to jail, I go to jail with pride!"
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Mattice & Mault
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings
Additional details: Resident of NY; "Sentenced 7/15/22 to 44 months in prison, followed by three years of supervised release, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: On January 6th, 2021 Cody Mattice and his friend James Phillip Mault entered the Capitol building in Washington DC after ripping down a barrier to give access to protesters and spraying a chemical agent at law enforcement officers. They were identified through pictures and videos taken by protesters that showed them outside of and inside the Capitol building. Mattice was charged with obstruction of an official proceeding, assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and an act of physical violent in the Capitol grounds or buildings.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Mattice & Mault
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings
Additional details: Resident of NY; enlisted in the US Army after the 1/6/20 assault; "Sentenced 7/15/22 to 44 months in prison, three years of supervised release, $2,000 restitution."; First active duty serviceman to be sentenced for Capitol offenses.
Short narrative: On January 6th, 2021 James Phillip Mault and his friend Cody Mattice entered the Capitol building in Washington DC after ripping down a barrier to give access to protesters and spraying a chemical agent at law enforcement officers. They were identified through pictures and videos taken by protesters that showed them outside of and inside the Capitol building. Mault was the first member of the armed forces to be arrested in connection with January 6th, having served in the United States National Guard. Mault was charged with obstruction of an official proceeding, assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and an act of physical violent in the Capitol grounds or buildings.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents

Name of case: Untied States of America v. Daniel Michael Morrissey
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of CO; "Sentenced 8/16/22 to 45 days of incarceration, three years of probation, $2,500 fine, $500 restitution." On appeal, sentence was reduced to probation only, no incarceration.
Short narrative: On November 8, 2021, Daniel Michael Morrissey, 39, was charged with numerous federal offenses for his actions at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. According to the Statement of Offense, Morrissey illegally entered the U.S. Capitol through the Rotunda door on the afternoon in question and proceeded to walk about areas of the interior, including Statutory Hall and Will Rogers Hallway. He protested outside the House Main Door before leaving the building through the Upper House Doors, having spent approximately 28 minutes inside the U.S. Capitol. Morrissey came to the attention of the FBI after a former co-worker of his reported that they had been shown photos and videos of him in the U.S. Capitol by another co-worker. Evidently, Morrisey sent these photos to the latter co-worker via text message, including a selfie that was sent in response to the direct question of whether or not he was inside the U.S. Capitol on that day.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Willard Jake Peart
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) and (2) Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of UT; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 5/2/22 to 36 months of probation, including 60 days of home detention, 240 hours of community service, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: On January 6th, 2021 Williard Jake Peart, 45, entered the Capitol in Washington DC in support of Donald Trump and paraded inside the building. Surveillance footage and video obtained from protesters showed Peart inside of the Capitol but confirmed that Peart did not participate in the destruction of the building or participate in any assault on law enforcement. Peart was charged with knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and parading, demonstration, or picketing in a Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Aaron Mostofsky
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; 18:641 - Theft of government property; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and remaining in a restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Brooklyn, NY; Sentenced 5/6/22 to eight months in prison, followed by 12 months of supervised release, including 200 hours of community service and $2,000 restitution.
Short narrative: Aaron Mostofsky, 34, of Brooklyn, NY, was charged with Civil Disorder, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and abetting, Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers, Theft of government property, Entering and remaining in a restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his participation in the Jan. 6 Capitol riot. In a video taken inside the Capitol, Mostofsky is seen wearing fur and a bullet proof vest, and wielding a Capitol police shield. Interactions between Mostofsky and another user confirmed that the photo was of him.
Source description: Charging documents, Court Documents, News articles, Databases

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND Supports organized political violence
Name of case: United States of America v. Barton Wade Shively
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) civil disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(3) Impeding ingress and egress in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings
Additional details: USMC 1985 -1989; Resident of PA; "Shively Sentenced 6/1/23 to 18 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release and a fine/restitution of $2,000."
Short narrative: On November 10th, 2021, Barton Wade Shively was charged via superseding indictment with 18:231(a)(3) civil disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(3) Impeding ingress and egress in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings. Shively, of Mechanicsburg, PA, can be seen in videos outside the Capitol during the Jan 6. riot including shoving a Capitol Police Officer, before being sprayed with Mace and retreating. According to a NYT article, Shively, a former member of the Marine Corps, is affiliated with Three Percenters. Plea and sentencing information is pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, News Articles, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Nichols & Harkrider
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) and (2) - Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1512(c)(2) and (2) - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly Weapon; 18:752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly Weapon; 40:5104(e)(1)(a)(i) - Unlawful Possession of a Dangerous Weapon on Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:651 - Theft of Government Property
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of TX; USMC Lance Corporal veteran 2008-2012, Deployed to Iraq and Afghanistan; "Alex Harkrider Sentenced 5/23/24 to term of Twenty-Four (24) months on Counts 1s, 2s, 6s and 8s, a term of Twelve (12) months on Count 4s, and a term of Six (6) months on Counts 9s and 11s, with all such terms to run concurrently. The Defendant is further sentenced to serve a Twenty-Four (24) month term of supervised release as to each of Counts 1s, 2s, 6s and 8s, and a Twelve (12) month term on Count 4s, with all such terms to run concurrently. In addition, the Defendant is ordered to pay restitution in the amount of $2, 000 and a special assessment of $100 for each of Counts 1s, 2s, 6s and 8s, $25 for Count 4s and $10 for each of Counts 9s and 11s, for a total of $445."
Short narrative: On February 12, 2021, in Washington D.C., Ryan Taylor Nichols, of Texas, age 30; and Alex Kirk Harkrider, of Texas, age 33; were charged with civil disorder and aiding and abetting; obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly weapon; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly weapon; unlawful possession of a dangerous weapon on Capitol grounds or buildings; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. Nichols was additionally charged with acts of violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings and assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon. Harkrider was additionally charged with theft of government property. The two men. both honorably discharged members of the Marine Corp., traveled to and entered the Capitol Building during the January 6 riots where they made violent threats and calls to action, carried a tomahawk, crowbar, and pepper spray. When entering the building, Nichols sprayed an officer with his pepper spray. Once inside, Harkrider stole a table leg. The two men were motivated by their rightist: anti-government ideology.
Source description: Charging documents, Court Documents, Local news articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Joshua Ryan Lollar
Charges: *18:111(a)(1) Assault, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers; *18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2),2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; *18:1751(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of Spring, TX; US Army infantryman 2002-2009, completed one combat deployted to Iraq, where he received the Purple Heart; history of "psychological issues" - currently being treated for PTSD; Supersceding indictment release 11/10/2021, pled guilty before the Supersceding Indictment; Sentenced 5/22/23 to 30 months in prison, 12 months of supervised release, and restitution of $2,000
Short narrative: Joshua Ryan Lollar, 39 of Spring, TX, was found guilty of Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and sentenced to 30 months incarceration for his involvement with the January 6 Capitol raid. Lollar was identified via a tip provided to the FBI and numerous posts and videos made on Facebook by Lollar which place him in the Capitol at the time of the riot and depict him in physical confrontation with a Capitol officer. Lollar is a U.S. Army infantryman, serving from 2002-2009. Lollar completed one combat deployment to Iraq, where he received the Purple Heart. Lollar has history of "psychological issues" and is currently being treated for PTSD.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, News articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Full legal name: Tipster provided photos from Instagram per news article, was also identified on Twitter thru OSINT
Name of case: United States of America v. Matthew Ryan Miller
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(d) Stepping, Climbing, Removing, or Injuring Property on the Capitol Grounds; *18:2 Aiding and Abetting;
Additional details: Resident of Cooksville, Maryland; Sentenced 5/23/22 to 33 months in prison, 24 months of supervised release, $2,000 restitution.
Short narrative: In 2021, in Washington D.C., Matthew Ryan Miller, 22, of Maryland was charged with numerous charged including Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Stepping, Climbing, Removing, or Injuring Property on the Capitol Grounds following his participation in the Capitol riot. Miller was identified via numerous photos posted to Instagram and taken by others. Miller was also captured in photos scaling the walls of the Capitol building. Additionally, according to the indictment, Miller shot a fire extinguisher at officers in the Capitol building.
