Name of case: United States of America v. Hughes & Hughes
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of official proceeding; 18:1361, 2 Destruction of Property; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly enter or remain in restricted building without authorization; 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly disrupt government business or official function; 40:5104(e)(2)(A) enter or remain in Capitol Building without authorization; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) Enter Capitol building with the intent to disrupt official business; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parade, demonstrate, or picket in a Capitol building;
Additional details: "Sentenced 11/22/22 to 38 months in prison, followed by three years of supervised release, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: Joshua Calvin Hughes and Jerod Wade Hughes climbed through a broken window into the Capitol on Jan. 6 and Jerod Hughes helped kick open a door to allow other rioters inside, the FBI said in charging documents. Two brothers from Montana were among the first to break into the U.S. Capitol while Congress was certifying the Electoral College vote, the FBI said in charging documents. The FBI declined to comment on whether they are in custody or to release their ages and hometowns.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Hughes & Hughes
Charges: *18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of official proceeding; *18:1361, 2 Destruction of Property; *18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly enter or remain in restricted building without authorization; *18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly disrupt government business or official function; 40:5104(e)(2)(A) enter or remain in Capitol Building without authorization; *40:5104(e)(2)(C) Enter Capitol building with the intent to disrupt official business; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parade, demonstrate, or picket in a Capitol building;
Additional details: Resident of MT; "Sentenced 1/6/23 to 46 months in prison, three years of supervised release, $2,000 in restitution."
Short narrative: Jerod Wade Hughes, 37 of Montana, and his brother Joshua Calvin Hughes climbed through a broken window into the Capitol on January 6. Jerod pled guilty to Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and was sentenced on 1/6/2023 to 46 months of Incarceration. "Prosecutors allege that Jerod Wade Hughes and his brother, Joshua Calvin Hughes, watched as other rioters broke windows outside the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, and that they then climbed inside. Jerod Wade Hughes allegedly then broke the lock on a door to allow more people inside. Both Hughes brothers were later seen in footage of the confrontation with Capitol Police officer Eugene Goodman, according to court documents, and joined with other rioters who followed Goodman and refused to follow orders to leave the building. Later, prosecutors say, they and other rioters entered the Senate Chamber, where they "sat in Senators’ chairs, opened Senators’ desks, and reviewed sensitive material stored therein.""(NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Nichols & Harkrider
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) and (2) - Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1512(c)(2) and (2) - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly Weapon; 18:752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly Weapon; 40:5104(e)(1)(a)(i) - Unlawful Possession of a Dangerous Weapon on Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Acts of Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon
Additional details: Resident of TX; USMC veteran; " Ryan Nichols Sentenced 5/2/24 to 63 months in prison and 36 months of supervised release. Judge Lamberth also ordered Nichols to pay a fine of $200,000, restitution in the amount of $2,000, and a special assessment of $200."
Short narrative: On February 12, 2021, in Washington D.C., Ryan Taylor Nichols, of Texas, age 30; and Alex Kirk Harkrider, of Texas, age 33; were charged with civil disorder and aiding and abetting; obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly weapon; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly weapon; unlawful possession of a dangerous weapon on Capitol grounds or buildings; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. Nichols was additionally charged with acts of violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings and assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon. Harkrider was additionally charged with theft of government property. The two men. both honorably discharged members of the Marine Corp., traveled to and entered the Capitol Building during the January 6 riots where they made violent threats and calls to action, carried a tomahawk, crowbar, and pepper spray. When entering the building, Nichols sprayed an officer with his pepper spray. Once inside, Harkrider stole a table leg. The two men were motivated by their rightist: anti-government ideology. His sentencing included, "63 months in prison and 36 months of supervised release. Judge Lamberth also ordered Nichols to pay a fine of $200,000, restitution in the amount of $2,000, and a special assessment of $200.", at the time this was the largest fine reported.
Source description: Charging documents, Court Documents, Local news articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Sean Michael McHugh
Charges: *18:111(a)(1), 2 - Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers, aiding and abetting; *18:231(a)(3) - Civil disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an official proceeding; *18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of CA; Sean McHugh was found guilty on 4/17/23, following a stipulated bench trial, of counts four and five of his superseding indictment; "Sean McHugh Sentenced 9/7/23 to 78 months in prison and 36 months of supervised release, $2,000 restitution and a $5,000 fine."
Short narrative: On November 10, 2021, Sean Michael McHugh, 34, from Auburn, California was charged in a superseding indictment with federal offenses that include assault on law enforcement with a deadly or dangerous weapon, obstruction of justice, and physical violence on Capitol grounds--among other charges--in connection with the U.S. Capitol riot on January 6, 2021. He was seen on Metropolitan Police Department body cameras assaulting U.S. Capitol Police officers, including pushing a large metal sign into them, scuffling with them over a barricade, and spraying them with an unknown, yellow chemical spray.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Release, News Articles, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Christopher Michael Alberts
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(1)(A)(i) Unlawful Possession of a Firearm on Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 22 DC Code 4504(a) Carrying a Pistol Without a License Outside Home or Place of Business; 22 DC Code 2506.01(b) Possession of a Large Capacity Ammunition Feeding Device
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Charged with DC Code and Federal charges; "Christopher Alberts Sentenced 7/19/23 to 84 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release and restitution of $2,000."
Short narrative: On November 10, 2021, the U.S. DoJ issued a second superseding indictment against Christopher Michael Alberts, 33, for carrying or having readily accessible a firearm and ammunition during the January 2021 U.S. Capitol protests. Alberts then tried to flee the police with the loaded weapon. He pled not guilty to all charges, was found guilty of nine charges (6 felonies), and was sentenced to 84 months in prison, 36 months supervised release, and $2000 resitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Releases; Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Thomas Webster
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct Within the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence Within the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
Additional details: USMC veteran and retired NYPD officer; "Sentenced 9/1/22 to 10 years in prison, three years of supervised release, $2,060 in restitution."
Veteran status: Former active duty and reserve components
Short narrative: On November 10, 2021, the US Department of Justice issued a superseding indictment against Thomas Webster, 54, for his role in the January 6 Capitol riots. Webster, a retired NYPD officer and former Marine, allegedly beat and pushed a Capitol police officer with a flagpole. He pled not guilty to the offense and stated that his actions were in self defense against the officer, who he claims provoked the dispute. Webster's trial began on April 26, 2022.
Source description: Charging Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Stephanie M. Hazelton
Charges: *18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and abetting; 18:231(a)(3) and 2 Civil Disorder and Aiding and abetting; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Member of NJ for Medical Freedom; Resident of Medford, NJ; Sentencing date set for February 1, 2023
Short narrative: Stephanie M. Hazelton, 49, A.K.A. Ayla Wolf, A.K.A. Ayla Wolfe, of Medford, NJ, was charged with Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and abetting; Civil Disorder and Aiding and abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings for her role in the January 6th Capitol Riot. Hazelton was seen on video directing members of a crowd of people barreling into police officers and pushing through the building’s West Terrace entrance in an effort to breach the Capitol building. She repeatedly said to others “we need more men” and “we gotta keep going". Hazelton initially pled not guilty, later accepting a plea deal and pleading guilty to Civil Disorder and Aiding and abetting. This case is currently pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Joseph Wayne Fischer
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and 2 Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Aiding and abetting; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Police officer with North Conwall PD. "North Cornwall Township said the officer has been suspended without pay, according to NBC affiliate WGAL in Lancaster. No Township official had any knowledge of this individual’s actions prior to his arrest," the township said in a statement. (NBC News)
Short narrative: Joseph Wayne Fischer, a Patrolman at North Cornwall Township Police Department in Pennsylvania, was arrested and charged for his role in the Capitol protests on January 6, 2021. Fischer is faces felony charges for rioting during the pro-Trump attack on the U.S. Capitol after he posted a video on Facebook charging a line of police officers. Fischer faces charges of civil disorder, assaulting a police officer, knowingly entering and remaining in a restricted building without lawful authority, obstruction of an official proceeding, disorderly conduct and demonstrating in a capitol Building. "Using the [Facebook] account SV Spindrift, the feds say, Fischer posted video of himself running at a line of officers while yelling “Charge!” Fischer wrote that the police line was four cops deep and that he “made it to level two.” (Huff Post). According to the criminal indictment, there was a physical encounter between Fischer and at least one police officer. This case is currently pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Wilmar Jeovanny Montano Alvarado
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(E) - Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;
Additional details: Arrested by FBI in TX 1/29/21
Short narrative: On November 11th, 2021, Wilmar Jeovanny Montano Alvarado was charged via 2nd superseding indictement with Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings. According to the Houston Chronicle: "Jeovanny Montano Alvarado, a 37-year-old Salvadoran native and Houston resident, called the FBI on Jan. 14 to voluntarily identify himself as one of the people featured on an FBI flyer with photos of people suspected in the violent Capitol mob...He told the federal officials he did not go inside the Capitol building and did not assault any officers. Investigators reviewed a YouTube video of footage from the riot that they believe showed evidence "contrary" to Alvarado's voluntary statements, according to the criminal complaint. The Houston man "participated in efforts by rioters to violently battle their way through a line of police officers guarding the West Terrace entrance to the Capitol Building," the complaint alleges. In the video, Alvarado turns and pushes toward the police line with his arm extended and his hand on a police officer's shield at one point, officials said. The footage shows that Alvarado appears to get struck in the back of the head by an object from the mob and then "easily" makes his way out of the crowd. Two days after the riot and before boarding his flight back to Houston, Alvarado on Jan. 8 described his experience in a Zoom interview with a Fox26 Houston reporter. He said he went to the Capitol to protest because he believed the election was fraudulent, according to the interview, but that he did not enter the building. The police presence was "almost non-existent," Alvarado told Fox26, describing how he walked onto the Capitol grounds after people moved barriers aside. "I turned around trying to get out and it was really impossible because people kept pushing me in," he told the reporter. "I found myself really close to the cops. I was with my hands up and I told them, 'I’m not part of this. I’m trying to get out.'" Alvarado, who owns Betty's Bakery and Restaurant, is charged with violent entry or disorderly conduct; entering a restricted building or grounds; civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers or employees; and obstruction of an official proceeding, according to a criminal complaint."
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Daniel Goodwyn
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorerly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: "Daniel Goodwyn Sentenced 6/8/23 to Sixty (60) Days of incarceration with credit for time served followed by One (1) Year of Supervised Release. Special Assessment of $25 imposed. Restitution of $500 imposed. Fine of $2,500 imposed."
Short narrative: Footage of the livestream filmed within the U.S. Capitol on January 6 by Anthime Gionet showed Daniel Goodwyn, 32, who was called out as "sfthoughtcriminal," within the building during the violent events that took place that day. Goodwyn stated his full, correct name into the camera and was shown confronting officers that told him to leave by calling them "oathbreakers." An associate of Goodwyn conversed with him over Instagram regarding his participation in the riot and recorded a post to Goodwyn's account stating that he entered the Capitol without causing any damage; screenshots of both, turned over to the FBI, were what alerted them to Goodwyn in the first place. Goodwyn is a member of the politically-violent extremist group known as the Proud Boys, which was known to be prevalent and active in the siege of the U.S. Capitol on January 6th. In the months leading up to it, Goodwyn made several declarations over social media that signaled his affiliation with them as well as his support for the objections to the results of the 2020 U.S. Presidential Election that catalyzed the gathering of protesters at the U.S. Capitol that day. After this information was collected, Goodwyn was arrested and charged.
Source description: Charging documents, Court Documents, Local News, Government Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Joseph Lino Padilla
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1), and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1512(c)(2),2 Obstruction of an official proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1), (b)(1)(A) Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2), (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4), (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in the Capitol grounds or building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings
Additional details: Resident of TN; QAnon follower; "Joseph Padilla Found guilty 5/3/23 of 10 charges, including eight felony counts and two misdemeanors, following a bench trial before U.S. District Judge John D. Bates."
Short narrative: On November 10, 2021, the US Department of Justice issued a superseding indictment against Joseph Lino Padilla, 40, for his role in the January 6 Capitol riots. Padilla, who tipsters claimed had recently become immersed in alt-right and QAnon mentalities, is accused of shoving and throwing a flagpole at Capitol police officers. Prior to the day's events, authorities claim that Padilla frequented the website "thedonald.win." Padilla pled not guilty to all charges on March 30, 2021. All further updates are currently pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Hentschel & Pryer
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of MO; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 9/30/22 to 45 days in a halfway house/residential reentry, 36 months of probation, $500 fine, and $500 restitution."
Short narrative: "Cara Hentschel allegedly wrote to a Facebook friend shortly after the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol, saying, “we storm peloskis [sic] office and took her beer. She drinks Corona,” according to messages the FBI obtained through a search warrant. The FBI’s criminal complaint, however, disputes this claim, stating that although surveillance footage shows Hentschel inside the Capitol for about a half-hour, the footage does not show Hentschel or her acquaintance, Mahailya Pryer, who is also charged, entering House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s office. Hentschel declined to answer the FBI’s questions in March and allegedly told a tipster who traveled to Washington, D.C., with them that “the FBI could not prove she committed any crimes if she refused to speak with them,” according to a criminal complaint. Hentschel was arrested Oct. 4 in Springfield, Mo." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Hentschel & Pryer
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of MO; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 9/30/22 to 45 days of incarceration, 36 months of probation, and $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Mahailya Pryer, 34, of Springfield, Missouri, travelled to Washington D.C. for the events of January 6th with Cara Maureen Hentschel and two other individuals. While the two identified individuals did not participate in the illegal riot at the U.S. Capitol Building, Pryer and Hentschel did. Photos of the two of them standing before the mob at the Capitol's threshold were posted to Hentschel's Facebook account afterwards and surveillance footage within the building caught the two people matching those in the photos walking about the Capitol interior. Hentschel was identified to the FBI by an anonymous tipster, which then led them to Pryer. Interviews with the two individuals who traveled with Hentschel and Pryer were conducted; the interviewees further identified Hentschel and Pryer in the photographs. Pryer herself declined to be asked questions. The two individuals encouraged their acquaintances to cooperate with law enforcement. Further interrogation of Hentschel's Facebook account revealed direct message conversations in which Pryer confirmed with conversants that they were inside the U.S. Capitol without proper authority. The two were arrested and charged based on this information.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release, News Articles

Video showed him inside the building for approximately five minutes before exiting to the outside terrace. Lollis was charged with entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Mick Chan
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of NJ; Indicted by a Bill of Information; According to charging documents, Chan called FBI to blame riot on "Antifa and Black Lives Matter"; "Mick Chan Found guilty 1/24/23 as to Counts 1, 2, 4. Verdict of not guilty as to Count 3."
Short narrative: "On Jan. 7, a tipster reached out to the FBI to report that a friend had breached the U.S. Capitol with other people, including Mick Chan. That tipster provided a screenshot to the FBI of a Facebook post from a friend in which Chan was tagged, and which seemed to indicate that Chan and the friend had gotten massages after the Jan. 6 riot, court documents indicate. The post reportedly read: "After all the tear gas and rubber bullets shot at us, this massage today was like heaven on earth!" On Jan. 8, Chan contacted the FBI and allegedly admitted to entering the Capitol on Jan. 6. According to court documents, Chan told the FBI that he "broke into, well, air quotes, broke into" the Capitol and clarified that he believed others had breached the building before him. Chan reportedly told the FBI that he did not engage in any confrontations, believed the crowd had been infiltrated by antifa and Black Lives Matter and that he had entered the building with "journalistic intent." Chan also allegedly said he had previously met with members of the Proud Boys. In security camera footage from inside the Capitol, he is seen giving the middle finger to the camera, court documents indicate." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Stephen K. Bannon
Charges: 2:192 Contempt of Congress-Testimony; 2:192 Contempt of Congress-Papers;
Additional details: Former White House strategist and Senior Counselor to former President Trump
Short narrative: Former Trump senior strategist Stephen K. Bannon, 67, was indicted on two counts of contempt of Congress for failing to comply with a subpoena issues by the US House Select Committee looking into the 1/6/21 riots. Bannon refused to appear for deposition and also failed to produce documents.
Source description: Charging Documents

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND Supports organized political violence
Name of case: United States of America v. Lisa Anne Homer
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of AZ
Short narrative: When a Proud Boys’ leader asked the crowd, “Do you want your house back?” on Jan. 6, 2021, near the U.S. Capitol, video footage allegedly shows Lisa Anne Homer standing next to him yelling, “Yes!” and then "taunting" police at the front of the protest lines, according to an FBI statement of facts. Homer added a camouflage helmet and googles to her tactical vest before entering the Capitol, where subpoenaed phone records indicate she remained for over an hour. Homer has posted a Proud Boys emblem to her social media, as well as photos taken at the Proud Boys’ Million MAGA March in Washington, D.C., in November 2020, according to the statement of facts. She was arrested on Nov. 26, 2021, in Colorado Springs, Colo. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Robert Chapman
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building; *18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building;
Additional details: Resident of NY; Located via Bumble; Sentenced 5/18/22 to 3 months of home detention, followed by 18 months of probation, $742 fine, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: On January 6th, 2021 Robert Chapman entered the Capitol building in Washington DC. Surveillance footage and videos taken by protesters showed Chapman parading in Statuary Hall within the Capitol. Chapman was charged with parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building, knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building. He was identified after bragging about his involvement at the Capitol on Bumble.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Moises Romero
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of FL; "Sentenced 7/22/22 to 12 months and 1 day imprisonment, 12 months supervised release, 60 hours community service, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: On January 6, 2021, Moises Romero was part of a group of protesters who forced their way into the U.S. Capitol building by pushing against a group of Capitol police officers and breaking through a temporary barrier. He then paraded around inside the U.S. Capitol building for approximately six minutes, taking photos and videos of himself with his phone. Romero was identified via an anonymous tip to the FBI, video footage from inside the Capitol, and an Instagram video. He was charged with civil disorder, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restrictive building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jason Douglas Owens
Charges: *18:231(a)(3) - Civil disorder [2 counts]; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers [2 counts]; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly or disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of TX; Evidence from crowd-sourced Sedition Hunters used as evidence in Statement of Facts; Confirmed via geolocating cell phone and a Liscense Plate Reader; "Jason Owens Sentenced to 24 months in prison, three years of supervised release, restitution of $2000, $100 special assessment, and a $2,000 fine."
Short narrative: On November 17, 2021, Jason Douglas Owens, 48, of Blanco, Texas was charged with multiple federal offenses for his activities at the United States Capitol on January 6, 2021. Owens was identified after his eldest son, Grady Douglas Owens, was identified thanks to analysis of images posted by SeditionHunters; after Grady was identified and investigated, it was found that Jason's mobile device, bearing the number that also appeared as the emergency contact on Grady's apartment lease, was present at the U.S. Capitol Building on the day in question as well. Witnesses identified Jason Douglas Owens with Grady in pictures from the riot, and review of footage from the body cameras worn by law enforcement officers showed that Jason Douglas Owens had assaulted two different Metropolitan Police officers at different locations around the Capitol Building exterior.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Sabol, et al.
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b), 2 Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder [2 counts]; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: Resident of Benton, Kentucky; "Clayton Mullins Sentenced 1/30/24 to Thirty (30) Months of incarceration, followed by Three (3) Years of Supervised Release with conditions. Special Assessment: $100.00; Restitution: $2000 (Architect of the Capitol) and $30,165.65 (to be paid joint and severally to the Metropolitan Police Department); Fine $49,764.00."
Short narrative: Clayton Ray Mullins, 52, of KY, was charged with Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Inflicting Bodily Injury and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder [2 counts]; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings following his participation in the Capitol riot. Mullins has been accused of assaulting at least two MPD officers during the Capitol riot–violently yanking an officer down the stairs of the Capitol entrance. Mullins has been charged with four co-offenders: Jeffrey P. Sabol, Peter Francis Stager, Michael John Lopatic, Sr., and Jack Wade Whitton.
Source description: Charging documents, Court Documents, News articles, Local news articles, Governmental reports and release, Other (Social media, Twitter)

Name of case: United States of America v. Sabol, et al.
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b), 2 Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; *18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: Resident of MI; "Logan Barnhart Sentenced 4/13/23 to 36 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, a fine of $3,688, and restitution of $2,000."
Short narrative: Logan James Barnhart, 40 of Michigan, was charged with alongside six other defendants for federal offenses for their roles in the Capitol raid. Barnhart pled guilty to Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and was sentenced to 36 months of incarceration. Barnhart assaulted" a Washington, D.C., Metropolitan Police officer with a baton, flagpole and crutch, though court documents indicate it's unclear who is accused of using which weapon. According to news reports, Barnhart was identified by the Sedition Hunters, a group of online amateur sleuths, as #CatSweat. When then-President Donald Trump tweeted preceding Jan. 6, 2021, that it would be a "historic day," Barnhart, a machine operator who has also modeled for the covers of romance novels, allegedly replied from his own Twitter account, "I'll be there," according to news reports." (NPR)
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Robert Wayne Dennis
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers [3 counts]; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: Resident of TX; " Found guilty 1/13/23 at bench trial of civil disorder, two counts of assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers, all felonies, and three misdemeanor charges, including: engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; and act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings."; "Robert Dennis Sentenced 4/13/23 to 36 months in prison for civil disorder, two counts of assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers, and the misdemeanor charges of of engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; and act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings, $2,000 restitution and serve 24 months of supervised release."
Short narrative: Robert Wayne Dennis, 61, a graphic artist from Texas, participated in the riot at the U.S. Capitol on January 6th by assaulting MPD officers attempting to hold a line on the stairs by the Upper West Terrace. Bodycam footage from MPD officers show the individual identified as Dennis approaching them, being pushed away after placing his hands on an officer, then grappling with an officer over their baton and throwing punches at them in a violent altercation that brought both to the ground. Afterwards, when the officer was able to regain their footing, they obtained Dennis's ID from his wallet to confirm his identity. The officer informed Dennis that a warrant would be put out for his arrest, but released him to seek medical attention for injuries sustained in the scuffle that could not be treated under the present circumstances.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles, Government Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Grady Douglas Owens
Charges: *18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; *18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon, Inflicting Bodily Injury; *18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon, Resulting in Significant Bodily Injury; *18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon, Resulting in Significant Bodily Injury; *40:5104(e)(2)(E) - Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder [3 counts]; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) and 2 Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon inflicting bodily injury and Aiding and abetting; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers [2 counts]; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) and (B) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly and dangerous weapon resulting in significant bodily injury; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) and (B) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds using and carrying a dangerous weapon resulting in significant bodily injury; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct inn a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) and (B) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds using and carrying a dangerous weapon resulting in significant bodily injury; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Evidence from crowd-sourced Sedition Hunters used as evidence in Statement of Facts; From Winter Park, Florida. Pled guilty on 11/10/2022 to 18:111(a)(1) and 40:5104(e)(2)(D). Sentencing set for 2/24/2023; "Grady Owens Sentenced 6/23/23 to 37 months in prison, two years of supervised release, restitution of $2000, $110 special assessment, and a $1,000 fine. Grady Owens also pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge of disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds and was sentenced to 6 months in prison concurrent to his 37-month sentence."
Short narrative: Grady Douglas Owens, 21, was chaged with Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; three counts of Civil disorder; Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon inflicting bodily injury and Aiding and abetting; two counts of Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly and dangerous weapon resulting in significant bodily injury; Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds using and carrying a dangerous weapon resulting in significant bodily injury; Disorderly and disruptive conduct inn a restricted building or grounds; Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds using and carrying a dangerous weapon resulting in significant bodily injury; Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; and Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building for his participation in the January 6th Capitol riot. Owens was caught on an officer's body camera participating in the riot, as well as assaulting an officer with a skateboard. Owens has pled not guilty. This case is currently pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Gregory Lamar Nix
Charges: *18:231(a)(3) - Civil disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon and inflicting bodily injury on certain officers; *18:1361 - Destruction of government property; *18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of AL; Sentenced to 42 months imprisonment, two years of supervised release, and $2,000 restitution.
Short narrative: On November 17, 2021, Gregory Lamar Nix, 52, of Cleveland, Alabama, was charged with multiple federal offenses stemming from his activities at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. The FBI began to look into Nix in July of that year when they found an individual matching Nix's drivers license photo on social media postings about the event and on the CCTV footage from within the U.S. Capitol building. Additional security footage show that individual identified as Nix outside the building, carrying a large white flagpole bearing a yellow "Don't Tread on Me" flag. At one point, Nix approached the East House Doors and attempted to use the flagpole to break inside. When U.S. Capitol Police officers arrived to stand guard in front of the doors, Nix got into a heated verbal exchange with one of them, and this confrontation culminated with Nix attacking the officer with the flagpole; this officer later reported to feeling a knot on his head near one of the spots where he was struck with the flagpole. Additionally, the FBI detected the cell phone number associated with NIx within the range of the cell service site within the U.S. Capitol Building on January 6, 2021. Phone records from this number show that Nix communicated with another individual in the leadup to the trip to Washington, D.C. to protest the election. In the messages, upon mention that the protest may get violent, Nix said "I have no problem with tar and feathering."
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND State speech act
Name of case: United States of America v. Sabol, et al.
Charges: *18:111(a)(1) and (b), 2 - Inflicting bodily injury on certain officers and aiding and abetting; 18:111(a)(1) and (b), 2 - Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; *18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder; *18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of MI; "Sentenced 2/10/23 to 51 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release and restitution of $32,165.65"
Short narrative: In a superseding indictment filed on November 17, 2021, Justin Jersey, 31, of Flint, Michigan was charged with federal offenses related to his actions at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. Jersey approached the USCP and MPD officers positioned near the Archway of the Lower West Terrace armed with a gnarled stick. After passing this stick off to another rioter, Jersey lunged at one of these MPD officers, grabbing him by the face and bringing him to the ground. Jersey tried to wrestle the officer's baton out of his grasp, but soon found another baton and used the weapon against other officers. As Jersey's attention turned elsewhere, the MPD officer he knocked to the ground was left open to attack by Jersey's co-defendants. The officer's helmet was knocked off, and he ultimately left the incident with a head lacerasion and several abrasions on his body. As his co-defendants were brutalizing the officer, Jersey picked up his helmet and took it for himself. Jersey came to the FBI's attention after he was recognized in photos from the riot that showed him wearing a distinctive blue University of Michigan sweatshirt and a brown jacket. Facebook messages between Jersey and those he traveled to Washington, D.C. with show that he was anticipating violence at the event. The helmet, along with an MPD badge, was found in Jersey's residence by law enforcement officers executing a search warrant later on.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Sabol, et al.
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) and (b), 2 Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon [2 counts]; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: From Conway, Arkansas; additionally sentenced to 36 months of supervised release and restitution of $2,000
Short narrative: Peter Francis Stager, 41, of Conway Arkansas, is charged with Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting, Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon, Civil Disorder, Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon, Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon, and Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, following his participation in the Captiol riot, and specifically the assault of an MPD officer using a flagpole which had the America flag on it. Stager and others took part in assaulting an MPD officer with various objects outside the US Capitol. Stager was charged with four co-offenders: Jeffrey Sabol, Michael John Lopatic, Sr., Clayton Ray Mullins, and Jack Wade Whitton.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documnts, Local news articles, News articles, Governmental reports and release

Name of case: United States of America v. Sabol, et al.
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b), 2 Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; *18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers [2 counts]; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder [2 counts]; *18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon [2 counts]; *18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building

Short narrative: Jack Wade Whitton Jr., 30, of Locust Grove, GA, was charged with Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder [2 counts]; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Dangerous or Deadly Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings following his participation in the Capitol riot. Name of case: United States of America v. Sabol, et al.
Charges: *18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder [2 counts]; 18:111(a)(1) and (b), 2 - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; *18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; *18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL; "Courson Defendant enters a plea of GUILTY to Count 10 of the third superseding indictment filed on 11/17/2021. CASE REFERRED TO THE PROBATION OFFICE for Presentence Investigation. Sentencing is set for 3/31/2023 at 10:00 AM in Courtroom 23A- In Person before Judge Rudolph Contreras. Speedy trial is excluded from 11/30/22 until 3/31/23 to allow the government to determine how to proceed on the remaining counts."; "Mason Courson Sentenced 6/16/23 to 57 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, and restitution of $2,000."
Short narrative: Mason Joel Courson has been charged with eight federal offenses, according to court documents, including participating in an assault of a police officer who was beaten with a baton, flagpole and crutch by a group of armed men. According to federal prosecutors, Courson also participated in a “heave-ho” effort to advance into the U.S. Capitol from the lower west terrace tunnel. After one officer was dragged by rioters down a set of stairs, Courson met him at the bottom and violently beat him with a police baton; Courson later took this baton home as a trophy from the event at the U.S. Capitol. Courson then climbed the steps and attacked another officer who was laying down at the top.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles, Government Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Sabol, et al.
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) and (b), 2 Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers [3 counts]; 18:2111 - Robbery in a Federal Enclave; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder [3 counts]; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon [2 counts]; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Held without a bond because he is a 'danger to the community and a risk of flight'; From Kettridge, Colorado; "Bench Trial as to JEFFREY P. SABOL held on 8/18/2023. The court finds the defendant GUILTY on counts 1sss, 8sss and 10sss of the indictment."; "Jeffrey Sabol Sentenced 3/21/24 to 63 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release and was ordered to pay $32,165.65 in restitution"
Short narrative: Jeffrey P. Sabol, 51, of Kittredge, CO, was charged with Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder [2 counts]; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings following his participation in the Capitol riot, and specifically the assualt of MPD officers. Sabol was identified via footage that shows Sabol and others grabbing an MPD officer, dragging him down the stairs, and assualting him with various objects outside the Capitol building. Sabol was aslo accused of assaulting a second MPD officer with Mullins and Whitton. Sabol was pulled over on January 11 for driving erratically and officers discovered that Sabol was covered in blood due to wounds that Sabol stated were self-inflicted and appear to be the result of a suicide attempt. At that time, Sabol stated that he had been "fighting tyranny" and admitted to being at the Capitol riot. Sabol then spent some time in a hospital, and was arrested several days later. Sabol is being charged with four other co-offenders: Peter Francis Stager, Michael John Lopatic, Sr. , Clayton Ray Mullins, and Jack Wade Whitton.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, Local news articles, News articles, Governmental reports and release

Name of case: United States of America v. Audrey Ann Southard-Rumsey
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Spring Hill, FL; additionally sentenced to 36 months supervised release and $2000 restitution
Short narrative: Audrey Ann Southard-Rumsey, 52, was arrested on 6/2/2021 and charged for her role in the January Capitol Protests. She was charged with assault on a federal officer or employee, obstruction of law enforcement during a civil disorder, obstruction of justice or congress, knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, knowing engaging in any act of physical violence against any person or property in any restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a U.S. Capitol building, parading, demonstrating or picketing in a U.S. Capitol building and engaging in an act of physical violence in the grounds or any of the U.S. Capitol buildings. According to a DOJ press release, Southard-Rumsey She entered the Capitol building through the east Rotunda door at approximately 2:26 p.m. She encountered a Capitol Police officer on the stairs leading to the building and tried to rip his shield out of his hands. She walked to the statuary hall connector area, stopped and stood in front of a U.S. Capitol Police (USCP) sergeant and several other USCP officers standing behind him and was seen of video yelling, “Tell Pelosi we are coming for that b****,” and “There’s a hundred thousand of us, what’s it going to be?” At some point during her interaction with the police sergeant, Southard-Rumsey obtained a flagpole, pressed against the sergeant’s chest and started pushing the sergeant, causing him to fall backward into the first set of doors leading to the House floor striking the back of his head on the base of the marble Lafayette statue. Southard-Rumsey was removed from the area by officers and made her way to the Rotunda. She joined a group of individuals who, seeking access to Speaker Pelosi’s office, pushed a group of police officers down a set of stairs. She then returned to the Rotunda. When officers attempted to clear the area of unauthorized individuals, she grabbed two officers’ batons and then grasped a metal stanchion with both hands, threatening the officers nearby. Southard-Rumsey was found guilty of seven felony charges and was sentenced to 72 months in prison, 36 months supervised release, and $2000 restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Release (DOJ), Local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Sabol, et al.
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder [2 counts]; 18:661 Theft in a Federal Enclave; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: From Lancaster, Pennsylvania; former Marine discharged on disability
Short narrative: Former marine, Michael John Lopatic Sr., 57, of Lancaster, PA, was charged with Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder [2 counts]; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct n a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings following his participation in the Capitol riot. Lopatic allegedly repeatedly punched a police officer in the head and ripped the body camera off another officer, disposing of it on his way back home after the riot. He also posted a 'call to arms' after the November election as well as posted pictures of two dead pheasants that he named Joe and Kamala. Lopatic was charged with four co-offenders: Jeffrey P. Sabol, Peter Francis Stager, Clayton Ray Mullins, and Jack Wade Whitton.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, News articles, Local news articles, Governmental reports and release

Name of case: United States of America v. Rodriguez, et al
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:371 Conspiracy; 18:641 Theft of Government Property; 18:1361 Destruction of Government Property; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1512(c)(1) Tampering with Documents or Proceedings; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon;
Additional details: Resident of Los Angeles, CA; Part of 'Patriots 45 MAGA Gang' Telegram chat
Short narrative: Charged along with co-conspirators Rodriguez and Badalian, Paul Belosic, 45, of Los Angeles, is charged in the indictment with felony offenses of conspiracy to commit an offense against the United States, obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting, tampering with documents or proceedings, and obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder. In addition to the felonies, Belosic is charged with several misdemeanor offenses, including theft of government property, destruction of government property, and entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds. The superseding indictment charging all three men was filed in November 2021. Belosic’s name was unsealed in the indictment on 8/17/23, and he remains at large.
Source description: Charging Documents

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND State speech act
Name of case: United States of America v. Sabol, et al.
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b), 2 - Inflicting bodily injury on certain officers and aiding and abetting; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of TN; Former county sheriff employee (Wiliamson County, GA) and deputy sheriff (Cherokee county, GA); Suspect was wearing attire with Three Percenters insignia on the day in question, but there has been no further indication that he is an official member of the organization; Sentenced 2/29/24 to a term of 70 months of imprisonment on Special Assessment: $610.00; Restitution: $32,165.65.
Short narrative: In a superseding indictment filed on November 17, 2021, Ronald Colton McAbee, 27, of Unionville, Tennessee, was charged with federal offenses related to his actions at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. According to the DOJ, McAbee, an off-duty sheriff's deputy who was on medical leave at the time, traveled from Tennessee to Washington, D.C. with a friend; the two had communicated to arrange the travel and the collection of weapons and other gear for the event. McAbee was able to procure some reinforced brass knuckle gloves and an outfit that brandished both his sheriff's patch and a Three Percenters emblem. After attending President Trump's rally at the Ellipse, McAbee proceeded to the U.S. Capitol Building with the mob. After using his phone to film the destruction of barricades on the West Plaza, McAbee went to the Archway of the Lower West Tunnel. There, he dragged a downed MPD officer deeper into the violent mob and then took swings at the other officer who stepped out to help his fallen cohort, striking him while wearing the reinforced brass knuckle gloves. McAbee then lifted up the downed officer, fell down a set of stairs with him, and landed on top of him. McAbee held him down for approximately 20 seconds while other rioters attacked him. After January 6, online sleuths gave the then-unidentified McAbee the moniker #ThreePercentSheriff, in reference to his attire's unique insignia. The FBI identified McAbee after they received a photo of him and the friend he traveled to Washington, D.C. with, showing him pridefully smiling while holding up a newspaper showing pictures of the insurrection.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Rodriguez, et al
Charges: 18:371 Conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1512(c)(1) Tampering with Documents or Proceedings; *18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; *18:641 Theft of Government Property; *18:1361 Destruction of Government Property; *18:1752(a)(1),(b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Fontana, CA; Part of 'Patriots 45 MAGA Gang' Telegram chat; "Daniel Rodriguez Sentenced 6/21/23 to 151 months in prison for conspiracy and obstruction of an official proceeding, obstruction of justice, and assaulting a law enforcement officer with a deadly or dangerous weapon. In addition to the prison term, U.S. District Court Judge Amy Berman Jackson ordered 36 months of supervised release, restitution of $2,000 to the Architect of the Capitol, and $96,927 to the Metropolitan Police Department for damages to the victim."
Short narrative: Daniel Joseph "DJ" Rodriguez, 38, of Fontana, California was arrested for his violent activities at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. In the months leading up to the attack, Rodriguez and several other California Trump supporters became members of a Telegram messaging group called PATRIOTS 45 MAGA Gang, which advocated for violent action against those who supported the results of the 2020 Presidential Election and the removal of those in power that refused to keep Donald Trump in power as the U.S. President; in the group, Rodriguez was reported to have written "Congress can Hang. I'll do it. Please let us get these people dear God." In preparation for the events of January 6, 2021, the group compiled weapons in anticipation of a fight, including a taser, pepper spray, and a baseball bat. The group then travelled from Los Angeles, California to Washington, D.C. and, after attending President Trump's speech at the Ellipse, made their way to the U.S. Capitol Building for the confrontation. There, Rodriguez and others participated in the "heave-ho" effort against Capitol Police and MPD officers in the tunnel near the lower west terrace; here, Rodriguez threw a flagpole at the line and discharged a fire extinguisher at officers. Then, Rodriguez was handed a taser by another rioter, and commited the act that made headlines around the country when he pulled Officer Michael Fanone from the police line and applied the stun weapon twice to the back of his neck. Later on, Rodriguez entered the Capitol Building and broke through a window to enter a hideaway office. Inside the building, Rodriguez stole emergency escape hoods. After the riot, Rodriguez returned to California and attempted to destroy evidence of his participation.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, National News, Government Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Philip James Weisbecker
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of CA; claimed to CBP that damage to the buiulding from from "Antifa"; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 6/27/22 to 24 months of probation with 30 days of intermittent incarceration on weekends, $2000 fine, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: Phillip James Weisbecker, 50, was part of the crowd that entered and paraded about the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. The FBI was notified of his participation by two anonymous tips, including photo evidence of Weisbecker in the U.S. Capitol. The FBI received records proving that Weisbecker had taken a plane to Washington, D.C. on January 5.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Nathan Wayne Entrekin
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(C)(i) - Disruption of Official Business; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of AZ; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 5/6/22 to 45 days in jail, 36 months of probation, including 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Nathan Wayne Entrekin was one of the many who paraded about the Capitol on January 6. While there, he was dressed as Captain Moroni, a character from the Book of Mormon. In photos of the defendant on the day of the event, he is carrying a wooden dowel with a piece of white cloth attached. The cloth appears to have the following text handwritten on it: IN MEMORY OF OUR GOD, OUR RELIGION, AND FREEDOM, AND OUR PEACE, OUR WIVES, AND OUR CHILDREN. ALMA 46:12. This is a message taken from the Book of Mormon, attributed to Captain Moroni.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Mark Kulas, Jr.
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: No complaint or affidavit located; Sentenced 4/26/22 to six months supervised probation, including 60 days home detention, $500 restitution
Short narrative: On January 6, 2021, Mark Kulas Jr. was present at President Trump's rally with his brother before heading over to the U.S. Capitol. He entered the Capitol building and paraded around the interior. No evidence has shown that Kulas participated in any violence or damaged the building in any way. He was charged with parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Fassell & Fassell
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL; USAF veteran; Wife also arrested; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced - 12/9/22 to 24 months probation, 7 days intermittent incarceration, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: A tipster informed the FBI that a relative had witnessed a coworker showing photos of himself and his wife in the U.S. Capitol Building during the January 6 riot. The couple was identified as Thomas, 67, and Marilyn, 58, Fassell of Largo, Florida. The FBI arranged a voluntary interview with the couple several weeks after the events. The couple admitted to having driven from Largo to Washington D.C. to participate in protests on January 6 and entering the building through a set of broken doors. The two claimed to have walked through several rooms and offices within the building for around forty minutes without any knowledge of the fact that it was illegal for them to do so. The FBI also gained consent to search Thomas's phone where several photos and videos timestamped on January 6 and GPS pinpointed to the inside of the U.S. Capitol building confirmed the claims. The pair were later charged with entering and remaining in a restricted building, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building, violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Fassell & Fassell
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
