Name of case: United States of America v. Thomas Patrick Hamner
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b), 2 - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:231(a)(3), 2 - Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of CO; Pleaded guilty 5/17/21 to Count 2 of the indictment (civil disorder); "Sentenced 9/23/22 on Count 2 to 30 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, $2,000 restitution; all other charges remain pending."
Short narrative: Thomas Hamner, 48, from Colorado was arrested for crimes related to the breach of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, which disrupted a joint session of the U.S. Congress that was in the process of ascertaining and counting the electoral votes related to the presidential election. Video of the events showed a man identified as Hamner wearing a helmet and a sweater that read "Guns Don't Kill People; Clintons Do." In these videos, he is shown grappling with Capitol police and MPD officers over one of the metal barricades set up at the Capitol; the footage also shows him trying to breach the defensive line of officers by pushing a large metal "Trump" sign into them. The FBI was able to identify and locate him via a Telegram account that showed a photo of the same individual at the Washington Monument; this photo then led them to obtain Verizon records that linked the account to a phone subscribed to Hamner's wife at the same address on Hamner's drivers license. He was arrested in Colorado Springs and then charged with engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, civil disorder, and assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers with a dangerous weapon (among other charges).
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United State of America v. Christian Matthew Manley
Charges: *18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; *18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assualting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of AL; "Manley Sentenced 4/25/23 to FIFTY (50) months of incarceration; THIRTY-SIX (36) months of Supervised Release; Special Assessment of $100.00 and Restitution in the amount of $2,000.00."
Short narrative: Christian Matthew Manley, 26, a discharged U.S. Marine formerly of Alabama and now of Alaska, was identified by an unnamed individual as one of the individuals who participated in the riot at the U.S. Capitol on January 6. The FBI obtained records indicating that the phone number associated with Manley was found to have used the cell site servicing the interior of the United States Capitol on January 6, 2021. CCTV footage of the individual identified as Manley show him inside the Lower West Terrace archway, spraying two cans of pepper spray at the officers trying to maintain the melee and then throwing both of the empty canisters at them. Later, Manley can be seen throwing a metal rod at officers and pushing his weight against a door blocking them. He was arrested in Alaska and charged by the U.S. Attorney for the District of Columbia.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release, National News

Name of case: United States of America v. Rodriguez, et al
Charges: 18:371 Conspiracy to commit an offense against the United States; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding; 18:1512(c)(1) *Tampering with documents or proceedings; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of CA; Part of 'Patriots 45 MAGA Gang' Telegram chat; "Badalian Found guilty 4/4/23 by Judge Amy Berman Jackson of conspiracy, obstruction of an official proceeding, and entering and remaining in a restricted building following a bench trial."; "Edward Badalian Sentenced 9/26/23 to 51 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $2,000 in restitution and fines."
Short narrative: On November 19, 2021, Edward Badalian, 27, was charged along with co-conspirator Daniel Rodriguez in a superseding indictment. He, Rodriguez, and others coordinated travel to and movement in Washington, D.C. in the Telegram group chat titled "PATRIOTS 45 MAGA Gang," where they advocated for violence against groups and individuals they described as liberal or communist, including political figures in high positions of power. Badalian specifically called for the violent removal of political figures who he described as "traitors" and replacing them with "able bodied patriots." The group used the communication channel to coordinate collection of resources for and travel to the events in the Nation's Capitol on January 6th with the intent to stop the certification of Joe Biden's election victory. Badalian is alleged to have collected weapons and tactical gear to bring to Washington D.C. on Jan. 6, 2021, including respirators, masks, snow goggles, knee pads, and baseball helmets. The gear was among the items used by supporters of former President Trump to storm past barricades to get into the Capitol. Badalian allegedly went on to boast about his part in the Capitol riot by appearing on the show “Infowars” under the pseudonym Turbo, alongside video provided by someone identified only as “Person One.”
Source description: Charging Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Philip Sean Grillo
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Glen Oaks, New York; "Philip Grillo Found guilty 12/5/23 at jury trial"
Short narrative: 2021, in Washington, DC, Philip Grillo, 46, of Glen Oaks, NY, Republican district leader climbed into the Capitol through a broken window and taken into custody on a felony charge. He's a state committee member for Assembly District 24 and calls himself the "Republican Messiah". He is also a member of the Catholic fraternal organization 'Knights of Columbus, St. Anne's Council". Grillo was charged with unlawful entry on restricted buildings or grounds, violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds, and obstruction of justice/Congress.
Source description: Local News Articles, Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Timothy J. Desjardins
Charges: 18:111(a) Assaulting a Federal Officer; 18:111(b) Assault on a Federal Officer; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of RI
Short narrative: Prosecutors allege that Timothy Desjardins arrived at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, carrying a backpack with three axes in it, assaulted police with a broken table leg, and later tried to breach chains near FBI headquarters. Desjardins' alleged assault of law enforcement took place during the infamous struggle in the tunnel of the lower west terrace, where he was allegedly seen in YouTube videos striking officers over and over again with “a significant amount of force.” Another tip from an FBI officer reported that Desjardins was caught the day after the riot in the early morning hours at FBI headquarters, trying to go over chains behind the building. When he was approached by officers, he reportedly showed his driver’s license, and officers noticed he had a couple of hatchets on the side of his backpack, which he claimed he was “good with." Desjardins was allowed to leave after it was determined there were no outstanding warrants for him. Court records state that Desjardins was later confirmed to be at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, by agents who compared the video from that day with both his driver’s license and mugshots from an arrest months earlier in which he allegedly fired a shot in a Providence Walgreens parking lot. Two weeks before his arrest on charges related to the Capitol riot, Desjardins was arrested in an armed standoff with police in Providence on unrelated charges. (NPR) Desjardins has since been sentenced by a Rhode Island judged (for his secondary crime) to 18 years in prison.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Daniel Charles Rhine
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted builidng or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of WA; additionally sentenced to 1 year supervised release, 60 hours community service, $7,376 fine and no restitution
Short narrative: On November 19, 2021, David Charles Rhine, 52, of Bremerton, Washington, was charged by the DOJ for his participation in the riot at the United States Capitol on January 6, 2021. Rhine, a CPA and former Navy submarine propulsion plant operator, initially came to the attention of the FBI after two tipsters independently notified federal law enforcement that Rhine was inside the Capitol during the insurrection. The FBI then identified Rhine's phone number, served a warrant upon Verizon, and confirmed that the phone bearing Rhine's number was indeed serviced by the cell site in and around the U.S. Capitol on the day in question. One of the tipsters engaged in a text conversation with Rhine and his wife regarding January 6th, and Rhine confirmed that he had been in the Capitol and had witnessed "ZERO violence." Screenshots of these text messages were given to the FBI. Security camera footage from within the U.S. Capitol Building shows a man believed by the tipsters to be Rhine marching throughout the interior carrying a blue flag emblazoned with white stars. In the footage, Rhine is stopped by U.S. Capitol Police officers. After they interrogated him and confiscated pepper spray and two knives, they put him in flex cuffs and escorted him to the area near the rotunda exit. After being helped out of the flex cuffs, Rhine left the building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Brandon Prenzlin
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parade, Demonstrate, or Picket in any of the Capitol Buildings
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 6/28/22 to 10 months of probation, $2500 fine, $500 restitution, 120 hours of community service."
Short narrative: Brandon Prezlin, 26, was charged with four federal offenses relating to entering the Capitol on Jan 6 2020 after being identified in CCTV and police body camera images taken inside the building. He pled guilty to the fourth count of Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building in exchange for all other charges being dropped.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND State speech act
Name of case: United States of America v. Rafael Valadez Jr.
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of CA; Sentenced to 30 days incarceration and $500 restitution
Short narrative: On November 23, 2021, Rafael Valadez Jr., 42, of Indio, California, was charged with multiple federal offenses for his activities at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. In late 2020, Valadez, Jr. posted messages on Facebook stating his belief that the 2020 presidential election was stolen and that a war was now merited. Later, he traveled to Washington, D.C. to protest the certification of the results, attending President Trump's "Stop the Steal" rally before proceeding on to the U.S. Capitol. He illegally entered the building through the Senate Wing Door and walked through areas of the interior, including the Crypt and the Rotunda; all the while, Valadez used his phone to record a video of the events which was later posted to Facebook. He exited the building through the East Rotunda Door after about 30 minutes spent inside. He had a photo taken of himself standing outside the building with rioters in the background, and later posted this photo to Facebook as well. A tipster later sent Valadez's Facebook posts to the FBI; they used this content, along with CCTV footage of him entering the U.S. Capitol Building, to identify Valdez.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Aaron Carico
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; Wore Navy hat but FBI claims no history of military service; Sentenced 3/11/22 to 24 months of probation, including 60 days of home detention; $500 restitution; $500 fine; 60 hours of community service
Short narrative: On November 29, 2021, Michael Aaron Carico, 33, was charged with numerous federal offenses for his participation in the riot at the United States Capitol building on January 6, 2021. A confidential human source who had also been present on the U.S. Capitol grounds on the day in question provided a photo and video to the FBI that showed Carico identifying himself by name to other rioters as he moved about the Capitol grounds with a camera and a stabilizer. The video features Carico relaying his Facebook and Instagram username to others, and content on these two accounts show the same individual identified as Carico in the confidential human source's video. Further, U.S. Capitol surveillance cameras captured Carico moving throughout the interior of the U.S. Capitol building. Additionally, the mobile device registered to Carico's Google account was found to have been inside the U.S. Capitol at the time in question. After a search warrant was obtained for Carico's Google account, more photos of him at sites outside the U.S. Capitol and around sites in D.C. were uncovered.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release, News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Paul Scott Westover
Charges: 40:5104 (e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building (misdemeanor)
Additional details: Sentenced 4/11/22 to 45 days in jail, $500 restitution; indicted via Information; Plead guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building, in violation of Title 40, United States Code, Section 5104(e)(2)(G). Sentenced 4/11/22 to 45 days in jail, $500 restitution
Short narrative: Paul Scott Westover, 52, of St. Louis, MO, was charged with Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building for his role in the January 6th riot. Westover was identified via numerous tips provided to the FBI as well as photographs taken inside the Capitol. Westover pled guilty, and was sentenced to 45 days in jail, $500 restitution.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, Local news article, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Marcos Gleffe
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of IL; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: A longtime friend of Marcos Gleffe's contacted the FBI after seeing a Facebook post from Gleffe that indicated he had been at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to a criminal complaint. The FBI was then able to trace Gleffe's cellphone location that day and confirmed that the device had been inside the building, court documents indicate. Gleffe is also allegedly in security camera footage inside the building, where he can be seen holding a flag that reads, "TRUMP 2020 MAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN." In a May 3, 2021, interview with the FBI, Gleffe reportedly admitted to being inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and said he decided to do so after he overheard people at the pro-Trump rally saying they were going to storm the building. He told the FBI he had made the "biggest mistake going through the door" and would take it back if he could, according to court documents. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Matthew Council
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil DIsorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Riverview, FL; Released on personal recognizance bond; Banned from Washington D.C.; "Matthew Council Sentencing held on 12/12/2022 as to MATTHEW COUNCIL. Defendant's motion for downward departure, granted. Counts 1s, 2s, 3s, 4s, 5s, 6s: Defendant sentenced to a term of Sixty (60) Months Probation, on each count, all counts to run concurrently, including 180 days of Home Incarceration with Location Monitoring. Special assessment of $100, as to each of Counts 1s and 2s; $25 as to each of Counts 3s and 4s, and $10, as to each of Counts 5s and 6s, for a total of $270. Restitution in the amount of $2000. Defendant shall complete 100 hours of community service as approved by the Probation Office."
Short narrative: Matthew Ross Council, 49, of Riverview, FL, was involved in the riot at the United States Capitol Building on January 6, 2021. At some point during the events of the day, Council was sprayed with a chemical irritant by law enforcement. After breaching the building through an emergency exit with several other rioters, Council charged a group Capitol police officers in an attempt to punch a hole in the defensive line for other rioters to move through. Once he collided with the officers, Council was arrested on the spot. He was charged on Jan. 7, 2021, with Civil DIsorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. While being apprehended inside the Capitol, Council pushed and pepper sprayed officers. Ross pled not guilty. Ross was released on personal recognizance bond, and was banned from Washington D.C.. He plead guilty to all charges in August of 2022 and was sentenced later that year.
Source description: Charging documents, Cours documents, Governmental reports and releases (DOJ), News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Howard Berton Adams
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Indicted by Bill of Information; "Howard Adams Sentenced 4/13/23 to eight months in prison for interfering with law enforcement officers during a civil disorder, 36 months of supervised release, restitution of $2,000, and a $2,000 fine."
Short narrative: On December 10, 2021, the U.S. DOJ issued a superseding indictment against Howard Berton Adams, 57, following his involvement in the January 2021 U.S. Capitol riots. Adams, whose presence at the Capitol was confirmed in images taken inside the building, pled not guilty to all counts. He remains on personal recognizance.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Bruno Joseph Cua
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers while engaged in the performance of official duties; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(A) Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Cua is believed to be the youngest suspect charged in the Capitol siege. (Insider.com); additionally sentenced to 36 months supervised release
Short narrative: Bruno Joseph Cua, 18, of GA, was charged with Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers while engaged in the performance of official duties; Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his role in the January 6th riot. Cua was identified through numerous photos and videos taken inside the Capitol as well as his social media accounts. He was filmed shoving a cop to be able to get into the Senate with a baton in his hand. Cua was found guilty of two felony charges and was sentenced to 12 months and one day in prison and 36 months of supervised release.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, News article, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Baquero & Valentin
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; *18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL; roommate also arrested; Sentenced 5/22/23 to 18 months in prison, 12 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay restitution of $2,000
Short narrative: Julio Baquero, 38 of Florida, pled guilty to Civil Disorder and was sentenced to 18 months incarceration. Baquero was charged with Louis Valentin. "Julio Baquero came to the attention of law enforcement through a tip to the FBI about a week after the events of Jan. 6, court documents indicate. Baquero allegedly traveled to Washington, D.C., with his friend and roommate Louis Valentin, and allegedly told law enforcment in an interview that he had entered the U.S. Capitol building during the insurrection. According to a federal filing, video footage from inside the Capitol shows Baquero entering the Capitol Rotunda and, in one instance, grabbing the hand of a police officer as law enforcement attempted to clear the building. At another point, Baquero is allegedly seen on camera shouding at officers, "You're a traitor!"" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local News Articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Daniel Gray
Charges: *18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Jacksonville, FL; additionally sentenced to 36 months supervised release and $2000 restitution; "Defendant sentenced to Thirty (30) months of incarceration on Count 3s to run concurrently to Count 2s, followed by Thirty-six (36) months of Supervised Release to run concurrently to Count 2s. Special Assessment of $200 and Restitution in the amount of $2,000 imposed."
Short narrative: On December 1, 2021, Daniel Paul Gray, 41, was charged with several crimes for his actions at the US Capitol on January 6, 2021, including physical altercations with law enforcement officers and stealing a police baton from an officer of the Metropolitan Police Department. He was identified after he posted a video to Instagram in which he boasted about his actions at the U.S. Capitol; several witnesses came forward to identify him afterward. Bodycam footage from MPD officers defending the building on the day in question showed the individual identified as Gray having to be pushed back by the line of officers several times before he injured one such officer by causing them to fall down a set of stairs. Gray was found guilty of two charges and was sentenced to 20 months in prison, 36 months supervised release, and $2000 restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Release, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Edward Francisco Rodriguez
Charges: *18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; *18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Identified by Reddit investigators as #SUITMACER
Short narrative: According to court documents, Edward Francisco Rodriguez, 26, of Brooklyn, NY was arrested for his participation in the January 6, 2021 protests and siege of the U.S. Rodriguez was charged with Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;for his role in the January 6th Capitol Riot. Rodriguez was among the crowd of protesters on the lower-level terrace of the west side of the U.S. Capitolwhere he was dressed in a dark colored suit carrying a white sign with the words “STOP THE STEAL” in red lettering. As depicted in publicly available video, Rodriguez pointed a canister at visibly marked law enforcement officers manning a barricade and sprayed them with a chemical irritant before retreating back into the crowd. The video circulated online, where social media users referred to the assailant as “#SuitMacer,” who was later identified as Rodriguez. "Reddit users dubbed Edward Francisco Rodriguez “#SUITMACER” based on a video in which he sprays a chemical irritant at law enforcement officers while dressed in a suit, federal prosecutors say. Court documents show that tipsters identified Rodriguez based on his Century 21 Real Estate profile. The FBI says two former co-workers were also able to confirm Rodriguez’s identity in the videos." (NPR). Rodriguez pled guilty to assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers, inflicting bodily injury. His case is still pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Release

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND State speech act
Name of case: United States of America v. Reed Knox Christensen
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil disorder; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers [3 COUNTS]; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings;
Additional details: Resident of OR; "Reed Christensen Jury Verdict of Guilty 9/18/23 on Counts 1s,2s-4s,5s,6s,7s,8s."; Sentenced to 46 months imprisonment, 36 months supervised release, and ordered to pay $2,000 restitution
Short narrative: On December 1, 2021, Reed Knox Christensen, 63, of Hillsboro, Oregon, was charged with numerous federal offenses for his activities at the U.S. Capitol Building on January 6, 2021. Footage taken on the day show an individual who was later identified as Christensen--thanks in-part to witness responses to the BOLO notice put out on him by law enforcement--was seen attempting to tear away the barricade of bike racks separating the crowd of rioters from the United States Capitol in the earlier part of the event. As he attempted to do so, law enforcement responded by spraying a chemical irritant in Christensen's face, later handing him a bottle of water to douse his eyes. Then, Christensen charged through the perimeter of bike racks and began attacking the officers, pushing and striking at them with his fists.
Source description: Governmental Reports and Release, Local News, Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. John Douglas Wright
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2),2 Obstruction of an official proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in the Capitol grounds or buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building; 18:1001 False statement to Federal agent
Additional details: Resident of OH; "Sentenced 3/6/23 to 49 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release and $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: John Douglas Wright, 54, a resident of Ohio was arrested for his involvement in the January 6th Captial Riots. "A person reported a tip to the FBI that Wright admitted to them that he was detained inside the Capitol rotunda during the Jan. 6 riot. Wright said he was sprayed with a chemical agent and forced to the ground. According to arrest reports, the claims are backed by photos and video evidence." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Knowlton & Montgomery
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and remaining in the gallery of congress; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of UT
Short narrative: On April 16, 2021, Brady Knowlton, age 40, of Utah; and Patrick Montgomery, age 48, of Colorado, were charged with entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building; entering and remaining in the Gallery of Congress; and obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting. Montgomery was additionally charged with assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; civil disorder; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; and an act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings. Knowlton and Montgomery both entered the Senate Chambers during the January 6 riot and at some point during the riot, Montgomery wrestled a Metropolitan Police Officer to the ground in a fight for the officer’s baton and kicked the officer in the chest. The two men were motivated by their rightist: anti-government ideology.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, News articles, Governmental reports and release

Name of case: United States of America v. Christopher Warnagiris
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disroderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(2)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Virginia; USMC major currently (October 2021) under review for possible discharge
Short narrative: "Major Christopher Warnagiris, 40, of Woodbridge, is charged with federal offenses that include assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder; and obstruction of justice, among other charges. According to court documents and security camera footage, Warnagiris violently entered the Capitol on Jan. 6, after pushing through a line of police officers guarding the East Rotunda doors. Once inside, Warnagiris positioned himself in the corner of the doorway, using his body to keep the door open and pull others inside. When a U.S. Capitol Police (USCP) officer tried to pull the doors shut, Warnagiris refused and continued pushing it open. Warnagiris can be seen pushing the officer in an effort to maintain his position in the open door in security camera footage. "- DOJ Warnagiris, whose 18-year tenure in the Marines includes deployments to Iraq and Afghanistan, faces a maximum possible sentence of 20 years in prison if convicted of the charges, which will be prosecuted in federal court in Washington.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Daniel Dink Phipps
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Physical Contact; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Indicted by Bill of Information first, now has an indictment
Short narrative: Daniel Phipps from Ft. Worth Texas, has been charged with unlawful entry and violent entry in connection to the January 6th Capitol protests.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 18:111(a) Assaulting a Federal Officer;
Additional details: Resident of SD
Short narrative: Federal prosecutors allege that James Haffner took part in the U.S. Capitol riot along with another man from the Seattle area named Ronald Loehrke. According to documents filed in federal court, Loehrke communicated in December 2020 with Ethan Nordean, a leader of the extremist group the Proud Boys who is facing conspiracy charges connected to the Jan. 6, 2021, attack. Nordean allegedly told Loehrke that he wanted Loehrke "on the front line" with him on Jan. 6, 2021. Loehrke allegedly agreed and said he was bringing three "Bad mother f******" with him to Washington, D.C. On the day of the attack, prosecutors say, Haffner and Loehrke marched with members and associates of the Proud Boys toward the Capitol. They then allegedly dismantled barriers protecting the outside of the Capitol building, and, at one point, Haffner allegedly used an aerosol spray against an officer with the U.S. Capitol Police guarding an outer door. Soon after, prosecutors say, Haffner, Loehrke and other rioters were able to breach the building through that door and can be seen in video footage taken inside the building. Haffner was arrested in Rapid City, S.D., on Dec. 1, 2021. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeremy Daniel Groseclose
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Released on a $20,000 bond; "Jeremy Groseclose Verdict of Guilty 11/21/23 as to Counts 1s, 2s, 5s and 6s of the Superseding Indictment. The Court RESERVES as to Counts 3s and 4s."
Short narrative: Jeremy Daniel Groseclose, 38, of VA, was charged with Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his participation in the January 6th riot. Groseclose's location and participation was confirmed via the Google estimated location of his cellphone during the riot and tipster accounts of his participation. Groseclose has pled not guilty and the case is currently pending. "Jeremy Groseclose Sentenced 10/2/24 to 40 months in prison, 24 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay a fine of $5,000".
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Baquero & Valentin
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL; roommate also arrested; The defendant is sentenced to twelve (12) months Probation on count 6. While on Probation, the defendant must serve a total of ten (10) days of intermittent confinement. The intermittent confinement shall be served for a consecutive term at a facility designated by the Bureau of Prisons. The defendant shall also pay a $10 Special Assessment, and Restitution in the amount of $500 as to count 6. Oral motion by the government to, "dismiss the remaining counts," HEARD and GRANTED. The Court ORDERS counts 3-5 are DISMISSED. Appeal rights given.
Short narrative: "Law enforcement was first alerted about Louis Valentin approximately one week after Jan. 6, according to court documents. Prosecutors say he had gone to Washington, D.C., with his friend and roommate Julio Baquero, and in a March 2021 interview, he allegedly acknowledged being inside the U.S. Capitol on the day of the insurrection. According to a federal filing, Valentin can be observed on camera footage entering the Capitol wearing a red hat and flag mask. While law enforcement asserts that Baquero physically and verbally confronted officers attempting to clear the Capitol, they make no similar claim about Valentin." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Knowlton & Montgomery
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and remaining in the gallery of congress; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of CO
Short narrative: On April 16, 2021, Brady Knowlton, age 40, of Utah; and Patrick Montgomery, age 48, of Colorado, were charged with entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building; entering and remaining in the Gallery of Congress; and obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting. Montgomery was additionally charged with assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; civil disorder; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; and an act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings. Knowlton and Montgomery both entered the Senate Chambers during the January 6 riot and at some point during the riot, Montgomery wrestled a Metropolitan Police Officer to the ground in a fight for the officer’s baton and kicked the officer in the chest. The two men were motivated by their rightist: anti-government ideology.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, News articles, Governmental reports and release

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND Supports organized political violence
Name of case: United States of America v. Timothy Earl O'Malley
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of FL; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Wore batting helmet and stated that "his biggest fear was Antifa throwing rocks" as they had "sacks of concrete rocks" according to FBI affadavit; Sentenced 4/12/22 to 24 months’ probation, including 20 hours community service, and $500 restitution
Short narrative: "Prosecutors allege that at least two people called the FBI to report that Timothy Earl O'Malley had been at the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol and that one of those tipsters said O'Malley has previously identified himself as a Proud Boy. In an interview with the FBI, O'Malley said that he drove to Washington, D.C., from Florida to attend the pro-Trump rally. According to court documents, O'Malley wore a red softball batting helmet with a "Trump is my president" bumper sticker on the side, because he said he had heard that antifa followers had sacks of rocks they were planning to throw. In his interview, O'Malley described the scene at the Capitol as "mayhem" and admitted to entering the building, where he can allegedly also be seen on security camera footage. The FBI also obtained videos from O'Malley's cellphone through a warrant. In one video, O'Malley allegedly yells, "WE FOUGHT OUR WAY, ALL THE WAY IN THERE. AND WE FOUGHT OUR WAY BACK OUT ... WE SWARMED THE CAPITOL, THOUGH. HOT DAMN."" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Ricky C. Willden
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of CA; "Sentenced 8/5/22 to two years in prison, three years of supervised release, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: Ricky Christopher Willden, 39, a resident of California was arrested for his involvement in the January 6th Captial Riots. "Publicly available videos show Ricky Christopher Willden cheering at the Capitol building on Jan. 6 near the east door around 2:30 in the afternoon, wearing a dark jacket, beanie cap and gloves, according to court documents. About10 minutes later, he can be seen raising his hand and spraying an unknown substance from a green can toward police officers standing guard. According to the FBI, Willden is a self-proclaimed member of the far right-extremist group The Proud Boys, whose members describe themselves as "Western Chauvinists."" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Klein & Klein
Charges: 18:371 Conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3), 2 Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1361, 2 Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds
Additional details: Resident of OR; Brother also arrested
Short narrative: On March 23rd, 2021, Jonathanpeter Klein and his brother Matthew Leland Klein, both self-proclaimed members of the Proud Boys, were indicted on charges of 18:371 Conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3), 2 Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1361, 2 Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; and 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds. Both pleaded not guilty to the charges, and their sentencing is pending. The Kleins came to the attention of law enforcement in fall 2020 when they attended Proud Boys rallies in Oregon. According to court records, Jonathanpeter Klein was seen at rallies in body armor and carrying a paintbull gun, and was photographed shooting the paintball gun at "an unknown target." On Jan. 6, federal prosecutors allege, Matthew and Jonathanpeter Klein joined with the mob and other members of the Proud Boys to breach the Capitol. Once inside, prosecutors said, Jonathanpeter Klein was seen engaging in a "celebratory exchange" with another Proud Boys member and displayed a Proud Boys hand signal. After the initial breach, the men allegedly exited the building and then "joined together to wrench open a secure door on the Capitol’s north side," allowing more rioters to enter the building "as part of a second or third wave of attacks."
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Ronald Loehrke
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of WA
Short narrative: Federal prosecutors allege that Ronald Loehrke took part in the U.S. Capitol riot along with another man from the Seattle area named James Haffner. According to documents filed in federal court, Loehrke communicated in December 2020 with Ethan Nordean, a leader of the extremist group the Proud Boys who is facing conspiracy charges connected to the Jan. 6, 2021, attack. Nordean allegedly told Loehrke that he wanted Loehrke "on the front line" with him on Jan. 6, 2021. Loehrke allegedly agreed and said he was bringing three "Bad mother f******" with him to Washington, D.C. On the day of the attack, prosecutors say, Loehrke and Haffner marched with members and associates of the Proud Boys toward the Capitol. They then allegedly dismantled barriers protecting the outside of the Capitol building. When a line of police protecting the outside of the Capitol stopped people from advancing farther, Loehrke allegedly said, "Don't back down, patriots! The whole f****** world is watching. Stand the f*** up today!" At one point, Haffner allegedly used an aerosol spray against an officer with the U.S. Capitol Police guarding an outer door. Soon after, prosecutors say, Haffner, Loehrke and other rioters were able to breach the building through that door and can be seen in video footage taken inside the building. Ronald Loehrke was arrested in Cumming, Ga., on Dec. 3, 2021. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United State of America v. Julio Chang
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL; Indicted by a Bill of Information; previously employed by Broward County Sheriff's Office (Statement of Facts) and USMC for 20 years deploted in Afghanistan
Short narrative: "An anonymous tipster contacted the FBI and said Julio Cesar Chang had posted photos from the Jan. 6 riot on Facebook, according to a statement of facts filed in federal court. Chang allegedly posted photos of himself wearing a pro-Trump hat by the U.S. Capitol, along with the caption: "The deplorables have taken back our country." In another post cited in court documents, Chang captioned a video from near the Washington Monument, "The beginning of our Second America Revolution." Prosecutors allege that celphone records and surveillance footage show that Chang breached the Capitol building during the riot and made it inside the Rotunda. Chang previously worked for the Broward County Sheriff's Office in Florida, the court documents state, and one of his former co-workers provided information to the FBI during its investigation into Chang. The Broward County Sheriff's Office confirmed to NPR that Chang worked there from 1991 to 2005 and said he retired at the rank of lieutenant. A spokesperson for the U.S. Marine Corps also confirmed that Chang served on active duty for nearly two decades, reaching the rank of gunnery sergeant. In 2003, he deployed to Afghanistan as part of Operation Enduring Freedom." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael G. McCormick
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of CA; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced - 12/20/2022 to 14 days incarceration, $1,000 fine, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: Michael G. McCormick, 51, of California was found to have flown on America Airlines from Santa Ana to Washington D.C. on January 5, 2021, to attend the events happening on the National Mall the next day. Phone records show that the mobile phone belonging to McCormick utilized the cell site servicing the U.S. Capitol for nearly three hours on Jan. 6, 2021. Additionally, surveillance footage shows McCormick entering the Senate wing and extensively filming a video on his cellphone. The FBI obtained photos and videos from McCormick’s phone that were taken during that time, including extended footage of his entry into the building and his walk through the Crypt and Hall of Columns. McCormick was arrested on November 18, 2021, in Orange, California, and he was subsequently charged by the U.S. Attorney for the District of Columbia.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Leo Christopher Kelly
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of Justice/Congress; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(A) Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) Disruption of Official Business; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: From Cedar Rapids, Iowa; "Leo Christopher Kelly Jury Verdict of Guilty on Counts 1 through 7 on 5/9/23."; "Leo Kelly Sentenced 8/18/23 to thirty (30) months of incarceration to run concurrently, thirty-six (36) months of supervised release to run concurrently, $190 special assessment, $5,000 fine and $2,000 fine."
Short narrative: In 2021, in Washington D.C., Leo Christopher Kelly, 35, of Cedar Rapids, IA, was charged with Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds without Lawful Authority, and Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds. Kelly was identified via a video of an interview with Kelly in which he describes his experience at the Capitol during the riots. Kelly also admits he was a part of the riots in other interviews.
Source description: Charging documents, Court Documents, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Jia Liu
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NY; INdicted by a Bill of Information; USMC reserves assigned to Direct Support Company, 6th Communication Battalion, Marine Forces Reserve.
Short narrative: Jia Liu, 26, corporal in the U.S. Marine Corps Reserve was arrested by federal agents and charged with four misdemeanor counts for his alleged participation in the Jan. 6 Capitol riot. Jia Liu, who lives in Queens, New York, became a Marine in 2014 and is a cyber network operator assigned to a communications battalion in Brooklyn. Liu was twice caught on security cameras entering the Capitol by climbing through an open window, according to a criminal complaint filed in Washington, D.C., federal court. He was also spotted on police body cam video during the Capitol siege—his identity was allegedly confirmed by a Marine Corps officer familiar with him—and Liu’s mobile device was located inside the building while the rampage was happening. In February 2022, Liu was accused of conspiring with a nurse (Steven Rodriguez) to defraud the USDHHS by selling fake Covid-19 vaccine cards to USMC reservists. Liu is being charged buy US District Court in Brooklyn, NY for the fraud.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Donald Hazard & Lucas Denney
Group affiliation: Three Percenters (III Percenters, 3%ers), Patriot Boys of North Texas (PBONT)
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; *18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of Justice/Congress; 18:1512(k) Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; *18:1752(a)(1) and (a)(1)(B) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds resulting in significant bodily injury; *18:1752(a)(2) and (a)(1)(B) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds resulting in significant bodily injury; *18:1752(a)(4) and (a)(1)(B) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) Disruption of Official Business; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of TX; Sentenced 5/19/23 to 57 months in prison for assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers, 36 months of supervised release and a restitution of $2,000
Short narrative: Donald Hazard, 43 of Texas, pled guilty to Assaulting, Resisting, Impeding and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers and was sentenced to 57 months incarceration for his role in the January 6 Capitol raid. He was charged with Lucas Denney, who invited Hazard to the Capitol with him. He walked up to a group of police officers with pepper spray but did not spray it. "On the day of the riot, Hazard allegedly wore a tan tactical vest, as well as a black helmet with the Confederate flag printed on it. Footage reportedly depicts Hazard grappling with officers as he fell down a set of stairs under a scaffolding erected on the west side of the U.S. Capitol. According to the FBI, Hazard fought with an officer, which resulted in both of them falling. The officer was knocked unconscious and sustained multiple injuries, court records indicate. Prior to Jan. 6, 2021, Hazard allegedly helped recruit members to a self-proclaimed militia group called the Patriot Boys of North Texas, where he served as sergeant of arms." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local News Articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Rondon & Mooney-Rondon
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:641, 2 Theft of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of NY; Son also arrested; Found guilty March 27, 2023 of obstruction of an official proceeding, and aiding and abetting the theft of government property and will be sentenced; "Maryann Mooney-Rondon Sentenced 12/5/23 to Five (5) years of Probation on Counts 1 and 3, to run concurrently. Special Assessment of $100 on Count 1 and $25 on Count 2 (totaling $125), a Fine of $7500 and Restitution in the amount of $3,657.51."
Short narrative: Rafael Rondon, 23, of NY, and his mother, Maryann Mooney-Rondon, 55, were charged with Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Theft of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; for their role in the January 6th Capitol riot. Both defendants were reported by tipsters and recorded via CCTV footage.Radael Rondon accepted plea deal, pleading guilty to Obstruction of an official proceeding. Maryann Mooney-Rondon was found guilty March 27, 2023 of obstruction of an official proceeding, and aiding and abetting the theft of government property. Both sentences are still pending.
