Name of case: United States of America v. Landon Bryce Mitchell
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) - Obstruction of An Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(A) - Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of TX; "Landon Mitchell Sentenced 4/20/23 to serve concurrent terms of incarceration of twenty-seven (27) months as to Count 1, twelve (12) months as to Counts 2 and 3, and six (6) months as to Counts 4, 5, and 6; the Defendant is further sentenced to serve concurrent terms of supervised release of thirty-six (36) months as to Count 1, and twelve (12) months as to Counts 2 and 3; he is ordered to pay a special assessment of $180.00 which consists of $100.00 as to Count 1, $25.00 as to Counts 2 and 3, and $10.00 as to Counts 4, 5, and 6; and $2,000.00 restitution payable to the Clerk of Court for the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia for its disbursement to the victim, Architect of the Capitol."
Short narrative: Luke Bender was arrested for participating in the January 6 riot at the United States Capitol in July 2021. After Bender was arrested and charged based on photos and videos of him at the event on social media, Bender admitted to having traveled to Washington D.C. and attended the riot with his friend and work colleague Landon Bryce Mitchell, 31. Indeed, the individual identified as Mitchell was also present with Bender in the footage from January 6, in which the two are shown entering the U.S. Capitol, going into the Senate Chamber, and rifling through papers on floor desks. Posts on the Facebook account belonging to Mitchell made after the day in question show that he was motivated by the belief that the 2020 Presidential Election was stolen. He was then arrested and charged by the U.S. Attorney for the District of Columbia.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Howard Charles Richardson
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: ; "Sentenced 8/26/22 to 46 months in prison, three years of probation, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: Howard Charles Richardson, 71, of Pennslyvania is alleged to have assaulted a law enforcment officer with a flagpole during the U.S. Capitol insurrection, which was captured on police body cameras. Cameras worn by at least four police officers captured Richardson taking a metal flagpole with a blue Trump flag on it and attacking the officers "unprovoked," a federal filing claimed. "Here it comes," Richardson is allegedly heard yelling before striking an officer three times. The FBI said that Richardson "only stopped swinging after the flagpole broke in his hands." Photos and videos of that act were later used to identify Richardson as the assailant. Richardson was also known to local police in his community due to a separate act in which he allegedly assaulted a motorcyclist outside his residence. In an interview with FBI agents after his arrest for that unrelated act, he acknowledged that he was at the Capitol on the day of the insurrection. He allegedly told the FBI that he had been tear gassed as rioters attempted to breach the perimeter of the Capitol and acknowledged that he was the individual in the body camera videos. "I'm not saying this is the best behavior I could have done here," he said. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Ezekiel Kurt Stecher
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; *18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; *40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; *18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of Justice/Congress;
Additional details: Resident of NJ
Short narrative: "Ezekiel Stecher, of Sewell in Mantua Township, [NJ] is charged with five crimes related to the Jan. 6 riot, including assault on a federal officer and violently entering the Capitol. He made his first appearance in federal court on Tuesday, in Camden...The FBI learned of Stecher’s alleged involvement in the Capitol attack from a video that was uploaded to an FBI tip line on Jan. 18, authorities said. Someone asks a man, “What is your name? Where are you from?” and he replies, “Zeke Stecher from New Jersey,” according to the complaint. The FBI searched New Jersey’s motor vehicle records and found an Ezekiel K. Stecher with an address in Sewell, and found his driver’s license photo looked like the man in the video, an agent wrote in the complaint. Agents then conducted an in-person interview with a local Sewell farmer who purchased produce from Stecher who said they’d known him for over 10 years. An agent showed the person still images from the video and the person identified Stecher as the man they know as “Zeke,” the FBI says in the complaint. In all, the FBI described three videos from the attack in which they say Stecher appears. In one, he allegedly appears against the wall of the lower west terrace of the Capitol, pushing the crowd forward, toward Washington D.C. police officers and into the doors of the U.S. Capitol. Stecher is also allegedly seen in a video in which riot shields are taken from officers and passed back by members of the crowd and Stecher is yelling in the direction of the police. In other videos, the FBI says, Stecher is seen multiple times pushing against police as the rioters squeeze and push through a narrow tunnel. At one point, he is sprayed with a chemical irritant but pushes forward, before eventually retreating from the building. He then pours water on his face." (NJ.com)
Source description: Charging Documents, Local news articles

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND Supports organized political violence AND State speech act
Name of case: United States of America v. Giddings, et. al.
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of PA
Short narrative: Court documents indicate that Freedom Vy was identified as a person involved in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot after law enforcement obtained and searched the phone records of Zachary Rehl, who is also charged and is the president of the Philadelphia chapter of the Proud Boys, a far-right group. Vy is charged with Brian Healion and Isaiah Giddings, who were all allegedly part of a Telegram message with Rehl and one other unidentified person who was not in Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6, 2021. The group members coordinated their travel from Philadelphia to D.C., including sharing contact information and blood types, and Giddings, Healion and Vy stayed together at The Darcy hotel in D.C. on Jan. 5, 2021, according to court records. On the morning of Jan. 6, 2021, Vy and Healion took a selfie together at the Washington Monument. They both flashed the "OK" hand sign, which is associated with the Proud Boys, according to court documents. The four men then allegedly entered the west side of the Capitol, near the Senate, and appear there in photos and videos. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND Supports organized political violence AND State speech act
Name of case: United States of America v. Giddings, et. al.
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of PA
Short narrative: Law enforcement allegedly identified Isaiah Giddings as a person who participated in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot after searching the phone records of another person charged, Zachary Rehl, who is the president of the Philadelphia chapter of the Proud Boys, a far-right group. Giddings is charged with two other men, Brian Healion and Freedom Vy, who were allegedly part of a Telegram message group with Rehl and another person who was not in Washington, D.C., on the day of the insurrection. The group coordinated travel from Philadelphia to D.C. ahead of Jan. 6, 2021, and Giddings, Healion and Vy stayed together at The Darcy hotel in D.C. on the night before the riot, according to court records. On the day of the riot, Giddings allegedly appeared in a photograph outside the U.S. Capitol with Rehl and others, all flashing the "OK" hand symbol, a gesture associated with the Proud Boys. The four men then allegedly entered the Capitol building, where the four of them appear in several photos and videos. In a reply to a text the next day asking how they were doing, Giddings allegedly wrote: “Yes we have everything and everyone all accounted for ... none of our Philly guys had any PB gear the entire event just plain trump supporters from beginning to end." According to news reports, the Proud Boys were directed not to wear their signature black and yellow on the day of the riot, aiming to blend in with other Trump supporters. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. John M. Cameron
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of WA; MAGA hat; "Sentenced 8/15/22 to 36 months of probation, including 30 days of intermittent confinement, $1,000 fine, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: On Jan. 6, 2021, John M. Cameron allegedly posted a video of himself in what appeared to be a Washington, D.C., metro train station, describing his experience at the U.S. Capitol: "Was it pretty? No. Did it make a statement? Yes." According to court documents, he also posted: “The least safe I felt was when walking back to catch train I was told to FU by a little anti fa BLMer on a Vespa who was traveling the opposite direction.” Cameron first came to the attention of the FBI when a tipster provided a link of Cameron’s Facebook account, which allegedly showed him attending President’s Trump “Stop the Steal” rally and his participation in the riot. According to court records, surveillance footage shows him wearing a baseball cap with white "Make America Great Again" lettering and a black hooded sweatshirt covered by a white T-shirt bearing the words "COUNT ALL LEGAL VOTES.” Cameron was also allegedly seen entering the Capitol through the Senate wing door and exiting 22 minutes later through a broken window. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Josiah Kenyon
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1361 Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of NV; "Josiah Kenyon Sentenced 4/11/23 to 72 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, and was ordered to pay $43,315.25 in restitution."
Short narrative: Josiah Kenyon, 34, a resident of Nevada allegedly stormed the U.S. Capitol building in costume. The criminal complaint details images of him dressed as Jack Skellington, from the film *The Nightmare before Christmas* -- with the addition of a red Make America Great Again hat. Court documents allege that Kenyon attempted to break a Capitol window with a flagstaff and assaulted law enforcement officers with several objects, including a broken table leg with a nail protruding from it. The FBI had asked for help identifying Kenyon from footage of the riot, and ultimately, it was the Jack Skellington costume that led several witnesses to say that they had seen him on the grounds of the Capitol; on the Washington, D.C., Metro; and at a motel in Springfield, Va., on or around Jan. 6, 2021, court documents indicate. According to court records, two more witnesses, including one relative, positively identified Kenyon from a photograph, and the criminal complaint alleges that FBI agents ultimately confirmed that his bank records and fare purchases at the Metro were consistent with his travel to the site of the Jan. 6, 2021, riot. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Evan Neumann
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:115(a)(1)(B) Influencing, Impeding, or Retaliating Against a Federal Official; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Fled to Belarus to avoid prosecution; Wore MAGA hat, gas mask, and scarf commemorating the Ukranian Orange Revolution; Expressed support for QAnon-like beliefs; Resident of CA
Short narrative: "Evan Neumann, prosecutors allege, is one of the rioters who engaged law enforcement in a prolonged struggle near a bike rack barricade in front of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6. Body camera footage allegedly shows Neumann wearing a red “Make America Great Again” hat and wearing a gas mask for some of the time, and yelling at one officer a common QAnon conspiracy theory that the officer is “defending the people who are going to kill your f**king children ... they are gonna kill your f**king children, they are gonna rape them, they are gonna imprison them, and you’re defending the people that are going to do this to your children.” According to court documents, Neumann refused orders by police to move back, and later, after a violent back and forth over the barricade along with other rioters, wrested it from the officers’ hands and used it as a battering ram to break the police line." NPR UPDATE: A US Capitol riot suspect who fled the United States has been granted refugee status in Belarus, according to Belarusian state-owned television BelTA. The California man, Evan Neumann, went to Europe after being charged in connection with the January 6, 2021, attack on the US Capitol. Neumann initially settled in Ukraine, he said in an interview in November, but he claims he traveled to Belarus on foot after noticing that Ukrainian authorities were following him.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Brent John Holdridge
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of CA; "Holdridge Sentenced 1/9/23 to 60 Days Incarceration, 36 months Probation, Restitution $500, Special Assessment $10."
Short narrative: In July 2021, the FBI found that the cell phone belonging to Brent John Holdridge, 56, was detected within and outside the U.S. Capitol on January 6th. Holdridge was previously in custody in California for a drug-related offense and a probation violation, and a booking photo from the Humboldt County Jail was used to connect Holdridge to the riot in Washington D.C. earlier in the year. Footage from the U.S. Capitol surveillance system was compared with the booking photo and Holdridge was identified as one of the individuals who paraded about the interior and exterior of the United States Capitol on January 6. Holdridge's probation officer identified him in the footage from the U.S. Capitol during an interview; in an interview with Holdridge himself, he confirmed that he was at the U.S. Capitol that day, but refused to confirm if he did in fact make it inside the restricted building. Based on the aforementioned evidence, Holdridge was arrested and charged.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Danean Kimberly Macandrew
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

Defendant sentenced as to Count(s) 1s, Three (3) Months incarceration followed by Twenty-four (24) Months of Supervised Release and a Special Assessment of $25.00. Count(s) 2s, Three (3) Months incarceration followed by Twenty-four (24) Months of Supervised Release to run concurrently with Count One (1) and a Special Assessment of $25.00. Count(s) 3s, Three (3) Months incarceration to run concurrently to Counts One (1) and (2) and a Special Assessment of $10.00. Count(s) 4s, Three (3) Months incarceration to run concurrently with Counts One (1), Two (2) and Three (3) and a Special Assessment of $10.00 for a total of $70.00."
Short narrative: Danean Kimberly Macandrew, of CA, was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following her participation in the Capitol riot. Macandrew was identified via cell phone location, a video Macandrew posted to her Gab account, and Capitol CCTV footage. The case is currently pending.
Source description: Charging Documents

Additional details: Resident of IL; Ligas pleaded Not Guilty to all charges
Short narrative: Lawrence Ligas was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his participation in the Capitol riot. Ligas was identified via a tip provided to the FBI about his name being in an NPR article, cell phone location inofrmation, and numerous photographs and surveillance footage. Name of case: United States of America v. Lawrence Dropkin Jr.
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of NJ; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Pled guilty 7/12/22; "Sentenced 10/7/22 to 30 days of incarceration, one year of supervised release, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Lawrence Dropkin Jr., 45, of NJ, was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his role in the January 6th Capitol riot. CCTV and screenshots of Facetime footage from a tipster confirms Dropkin's particiption in the riot. Dropkin pled guilty to the charges and was sentenced to 30 days of incarceration, one year of supervised release, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and release (DOJ), News article

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeremy K. Baouche
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of CT; Employed by a DOD contractor with securiry clearence and used a 'secure' computer to conduct pre-operational activities
Short narrative: Jeremy K. Baouche, of CT, was charged with Entering and remaining in a restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his participation in the Capitol riot. Baouche was identified via a tip provided to the FBI, cell phone location, and a video taken from inside the Capitol at the time of the riot. Baouche's employer provided his internet search history which included topics such as the inauguration, the U.S. Capitol building layout, guns, rifle scopes, lasers, Trump protests, FBI Capitol, and searches for jobs in the western U.S. (Statement of Facts). The case is still pending.
Source description: Charging Documents

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND Supports organized political violence
Name of case: United States of America v. James Robert Elliott
Charges: *18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and *(b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(a) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(a) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly and Dangerous Weapon; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of IL.; "James Elliott Sentenced 6/22/23 to 37 months in prison, 24 months of supervised release and restitution of $2,000 to the Architect of the Capitol."
Short narrative: On August 11, 2021, James Elliot was indicted for his role in the Capitol protests. Elliott was charged with civil disorder; assault of a federal officer; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; and carrying out an act of violence in the Capitol building or grounds. The charges primarily stemmed from Elliot's use of a flagpole as a weapon to restrain and hit Capitol law enforcement.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Article, Government Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Mark Andrew Mazza
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(1) Unlawful Possession of a Firearm on Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 22 DC Code 4504(a) Carrying a Pistol Without a License Outside Home or Place of Business;7 DC Code 2502.01 Possession of Unregistered Firearm; 7 DC Code 2506.01(a)(3) Possession of Unregistered Ammunition; 22 DC Code 3211, 3212(b) Second Degree Theft;
Additional details: Resident of Indiana; Has federal and DC/city charges; "Sentenced 10/21/22 to 60 months in prison, three years of supervised release, $2,150 in restitution."
Short narrative: Mark Mazza, 56, a resident of Indiana man, was arrested for carrying a loaded gun onto U.S. Capitol grounds and assaulting law enforcement officers during the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol. "A revolver loaded with both live shotgun shells and hollow-point rounds fell from an unknown suspect’s waistband as he scuffled with a police sergeant on Jan. 6, 2021, near the U.S. Capitol steps, according to court documents. Two days later, Mark Mazza reported to local police in Indiana that his gun, matching the serial number of the one dropped, had been stolen from a car while he spent hours inside a Cincinnati casino. When confronted during a police interview in March, Mazza claimed he reported it stolen because, “if Antifa found it, someone might get killed and my name is all over it.” Mazza then claimed the gun slipped from his holster in a tunnel entrance to the Capitol just after 3 p.m. Jan. 6, 2021, according to the court documents, but the police sergeant reported picking it up on the Capitol’s steps a half-hour before that. During the interview, Mazza denied assaulting any police officers during the riot, replying, “In fact … I helped two of them” and “I can barely make a fist because of my arthritis.” However, the court documents allege surveillance footage shows Mazza swinging a baton at officers in the tunnel just after he yelled, “This is our f**king house! We own this house!” According to the court documents, Mazza ended his interview by claiming he “may go down as a hero,” adding “if you do have to come back and take me, put me in a fed … I just want three squares and a nice clean room, someone takes care of my health care and I’m good.” Mazza was arrested Nov. 17, 2021, in Shelbyville, Ind." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeffrey William Hubbard
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of OR
Short narrative: Federal law enforcement identified Jeffrey Hubbard among the rioters inside the U.S. Capitol building, in part, through what court documents describe as his "distinct bald head." At one point, prosecutors say, footage shows Hubbard chanting "break it down" inside the Capitol. Local law enforcement allegedly spoke to Hubbard's mother around the time of the riot, and court documents state that she told officers that Hubbard was in Washington, D.C., for the pro-Trump rally. Subsequent searches of cellphone records allegedly corroborate the video footage and other evidence suggesting Hubbard breached the Capitol. Hubbard was arrested Dec. 8, 2021. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jonas Buxton
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Phone found to contain Three Percenter material; Resident of MO; Buxton Sentenced 12/2/22 to 18 months of probation, including 40 hours of community service, $500 fine, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Jonus Buxton, 26 of St. Charles, Missouri, pled guilty for Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The defendant wore tactical gear with a "Trump" patch in the center. After defendants began getting indicted, he quit his job and went into hiding. He was sentenced to 18 months of probation, including 40 hours of community service, $500 fine, $500 restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Oliveras
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NJ; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: Two days after the U.S. Capitol riot, at least three people contacted the FBI to alert them to a concerning Parler user operating under the account @Craftmetal. One wrote: "This individual has been talking about overthrowing the government for weeks in public chat rooms pushing disinformation and talking about hanging and executing people repetitively ... He claims to have been in the Capitol Building on the 6th of January and has posted multiple disturbing videos which would seem to substantiate this statement." The tipster including a screenshot of the Parler account, which appeared to show Michael Oliveras' name and phone number, which the FBI then verified and located as having been near the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, court records indicate. The FBI then reviewed Oliveras' Parler account, where they allegedly found video taken inside and around the Capitol on the day of the riot. In one video, Oliveras allegedly shows a pile of news media equipment strewn on the ground outside and says "“That’s what happens when the f***ing fake news shows up at a Patriot rally." In another video showing a mob of people inside the building, Oliveras allegedly says: “Where are the f***ing traitors? Drag them out by the f***ing hair!" (NPR) "Michael Oliveras Sentenced 10/3/24 to 60 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $2,000 in restitution"
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Johnson & Johnson
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder [felony]; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 1*8:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Son also charged; Resident of IA; Indicted by a Bill of Information; https://www.facebook.com/daryl.johnson.39904181/about_life_events; Sentenced 6/1/22 to 30 days in jail, one year of supervised release, $2,000 fine, $2,000 restitution
Short narrative: Daryl Johnson, father of Daniel Johnson, from Saint Ansgar, Iowa has been arrested and charged with several crimes in connection to the Capitol raid. He was inside the Capitol building during the protests with his son, who posted on Facebook claiming: "I was one of the first ones inside the capitol building.".
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Johnson & Johnson
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder [felony]; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 1*8:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Father also charged; Resident of IA; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 6/1/22 to 4 months in jail, one year of supervised release, $2,000 restitution.
Short narrative: Daniel Johnson, 29, has been arrested and charged for his role in the Capitol protests. He published several social media posts stating that he was at the Capitol on January 6 and he can be seen in numerous surveillance photos included in the affidavit.The affidavit against Johnson also states that the FBI received a tip from a witness that included a Facebook comment written by Johnson that said, "I was one of the first ones inside the capitol building."
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Matthew Jay Webler
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others

Short narrative: On December 3, 2021, Matthew Jay Webler was arrested on charges related to his actions on January 6, 2021 at the US Capitol. Webler documented his travel to and presence in the U.S. Capitol building on social media, and wore clothing with logos associated with the QAnon conspiracy theory group as he walked through the facilities.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Article, Government Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Thomas Paul Conover
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of TX; Sentenced 4/22/22 to 36 months’ probation, including 30 days at a residential reentry center, 60 hours of community service, $2,500 fine, $500 restitution
Short narrative: Thomas Paul Conover spent much of the day on Jan. 6, 2021, carrying a can of Coors Light beer, which he brought with him as he breached the U.S. Capitol building, federal prosecutors allege. During that time, court documents state, Conover also filmed videos of himself, including one in which he said, "I don't always storm the Capitol of the United States of America. But when I do, I prefer Coors Light." Prosecutors allege that Conover posted on Facebook about his activity on Jan. 6, stating, "GREETINGS FROM WASHINGTON DC" and "WE TOOK THE capitol [sic]." Surveillance and police bodycam footage also allegedly shows Conover inside the building during the riot. Later, court documents state, the FBI received a tip from someone who saw Conover's Facebook posts and turned over screenshots to law enforcement. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Pettit & Burress
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of OH; Partner also arrested; Indicted by a Bill of Information, sentenced to 18 months of probation, including 45 days of home detention, 60 hours of community service and $500 restitution
Short narrative: On December 27, 2021, Gabriel Burress, 22, and his partner Madison Pettit, 19, of Swanton, Ohio, were both indicted as co-defendants in a bill of information for their activities at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. Footage from CCTV and other recording devices within the U.S. Capitol Building showed the pair entering the Rotunda with the rest of the crowd and walking about the interior for about ten minutes before leaving. On their way out, Burress joined in a chant with the rest of the protestors, and Pettit later sent a text message disparaging the police officers on the scene by calling them "stupid ass Capitol police part of the swamp bad cops." The FBI became aware of the couple thanks to an online tip. Investigation linked their cell phone numbers to the U.S. Capitol's cellular service site on January 6th; their appearances in their social media and drivers license images also matched those that were captured in the footage from the event. This investigation culminated in an interview with the two where they confirmed their presence at the Capitol riot on the day in question.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Release, Local News Articles

Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; must remain in the eastern district of Missouri, which includes her home in Sullivan, for the immediate future. She is also forbidden from traveling to D.C., except ; Sentenced 4/11/22 to 30 days in jail, and one year of supervised release, including 80 hours of community service, and $500 in restitution.for her future court date.
Short narrative: Emily Hernandez, 21, of Sullivan, Missouri, woman seen inside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 has been arrested after she turned herself into the local FBI agents.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. William Merry
Charges: 18:641 Theft of Government Property; *18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly Conduct Which Impedes the Conduct of Government Business; *40:5104(e)(2) Disruptive Conduct in the Capitol Buildings
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 4/11/22 to 45 days in jail, nine months of supervised release, including 80 hours community service, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: "Merry is the uncle of Emily Hernandez, who was arrested in January, on charges related to the Capitol riot, according to the FBI, which received the information from tipsters. In a video inside the Capitol, the FBI reported Merry, with a red Trump cap and a red bandanna around his neck, can be seen holding a piece of the wooden sign that had previously been above a doorway to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's office. Hernandez also is seen in photos from that day holding a piece of the sign. (USA Today)"
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Dan Shaw
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of CA; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: Daniel Shaw was identified by law enforcement as having been involved in the Jan. 6, 2021, U.S. Capitol riot when another person charged, Kenneth Reda, allegedly mentioned that he had stayed in Shaw's hotel room while in Washington, D.C., and identified Shaw in security camera footage from inside the building. Law enforcement also obtained a search warrant from Verizon and allegedly confirmed that Shaw's cellphone pinged on a cell site that serves the area inside the Capitol on the day of the riot. According to court records, security camera footage from inside the building also appear to show Shaw's son, whose name has been redacted, with him. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Thomas Uberto
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;

Additional details: Resident of NY; MAGA hat; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Uberto Sentenced 2/6/23 to 10 days incarceration, restitution $500, Special assesment $10."
Short narrative: On January 11, 2022, Thomas Uberto was charged with several federal crimes through a bill of information for illegally entering the Capitol on January 6, 2021. He was identified after the phone and Google account belonging to him were detected within the U.S. Capitol building on the day in question; then, he was found entering the premises in security footage.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Avery Carter MacCracken
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of CO; Utilized data from Sedition Hunters; "Avery MacCracken Sentenced 5/17/24 to One (1) year and One (1) day; followed by a Thirty-Six (36) month term of Supervised Release. The Defendant is further ordered to pay a $100 Special Assessment and Restitution in the amount of $2,000."
Short narrative: Federal prosecutors allege that Avery MacCracken assaulted police officers guarding the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. MacCracken allegedly punched one officer "with his closed fist in the right cheek, causing a cut to the face under his right eye" and pushed and shoved another officer. Both incidents were allegedly captured by police body cameras. Court documents state that MacCracken is "considered a transient with no permanent place of residence" but is generally known in the Telluride, Colo., area. A tipster from Colorado recognized MacCracken in photos of the Capitol siege circulated by the online open-source investigative community known as the Sedition Hunters, prosecutors now allege. That tipster then contacted local law enforcement -- namely, San Miguel County Sheriff Bill Masters -- who reportedly recognized MacCracken as well as the outfit he wore on Jan. 6, 2021, court documents state. MacCracken was arrested on Dec. 11, 2021. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and releases (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Rhodes et. al.
Charges: *18:2384 Seditious Conspiracy; *18:1512(K) Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:372 Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; *18:1361 2, Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1512(c)(1) Tampering with Documents or Proceedings;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of FL; "Kenneth Harrelson Found guilty by jury on 11/29/22 of obstruction of an official proceeding, conspiracy to prevent an officer from discharging duties, and tampering with documents or proceedings." Sentenced on 5/26/2023 to 48 months incarceration; 24 months of supervised release
Short narrative: Kenneth Harrelson, 41 of Florida, was found guilty of Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; and Tampering with Documents or Proceedings for his involvement in January 6. He was sentenced to 48 months of incarceration and 24 months probation. He is an Army veteran and a member of the far-right militiant Oath Keepers organization. "The FBI says it obtained call records indicating that Meggs and Harrelson spoke by phone in December and on Jan. 4, two days before the attack on the Capitol. Investigators also obtained records from GoToMeeting, an online site used for video conference calls. The affidavit says an individual using a mobile device with the same IP address as Harrelson's phone organized a meeting titled "dc planning call" on Jan. 3, 2021. In addition to that, the same user organized some 30 meetings affiliated with the Oath Keepers between Sept. 30, 2020, and Jan. 3, 2021." He was indicted alone first, but he has now been added to the second superseding indictment including 9 other members of the oathkeepers.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local News Articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Rhodes et. al.
Group affiliation: Oath Keepers; Ohio State Regular Militia
Charges: *18:2384 Seditious Conspiracy; 18:1512(k) Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:372 Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; *18:1361 2, Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3) 2, Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of OH; Transgender female; Founder and Commanding Officer of Ohio State Regular Militia in 2019, "Jessica Watkins Found guilty by jury on 11/29/22 of obstruction of an official proceeding, interfering with law enforcement officers during a civil disorder, conspiracy to prevent an officer from discharging duties, and tampering with documents or proceedings."; Sentenced 5/26/23 as to Counts 2s and 3s of the 167 Superseding Indictment, the Defendant is sentenced to 102 months of incarceration followed by 36 months of supervised release. As to Count 4s of the 167 Superseding Indictment, the Defendant is sentenced to 72 months of incarceration followed by 36 months of supervised release. As to Count 6s of the 167 Superseding Indictment, the Defendant is sentenced to 60 months of incarceration followed by 36 months of supervised release. All terms of incarceration and supervised release shall run concurrently.
Short narrative: Jessica Marie Watkins, 38 of Champaign County, OH was found guilty of Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; Civil Disorder for her role in the January 6 Capitol raid. She was sentenced to 102 months incarceration. She was charged alongside other Oath Keepers defendants like Thomas Caldwell and Donovan Crowl. According to court documents, she is a member of the Ohio State Regular Militia, a dues-paying subset of the Oath Keepers. Watkins’ profile on the app Parler also alleges that she is a Commanding Officer of the Ohio State Regular Militia. Authorities said Watkins posted a video to her Parler account with the message: “Yeah. We stormed the Capitol today. Tear Gassed, the whole, 9. Pushed our way into the Rotunda. Made it into the Senate even. The news is lying (even Fox) about the Historical Events we created today.”...[Watkins was seen] wearing a helmet, reinforced vest and clothing with Oath Keeper paraphernalia on it.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND Supports organized political violence AND State speech act
Name of case: United States of America v. Caldwell, et al.
Charges: 18:1512(k) Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:372 Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; 18:1361 2, Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:231(a)(3) 2, Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting;
Additional details: Resident of FL; Identified through comparison of defendant's ear
Short narrative: James Beeks was allegedly part of a group of Oath Keepers members and affiliates that marched on the U.S Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Prosecutors say that he was already on the radar of law enforcement after a rioter who pleaded guilty identified him as one of the people who lined up with the Oath Keepers the day of the riot. The criminal complaint alleges that he was part of the group that entered into a formation — called a “stack” — in order to force its way into the Capitol. Court documents enumerate many records obtained that show Beeks traveled to Washington, D.C., on the day of the riot, including records from a personal finance app and a rental car agency, as well as cellphone records. Beeks was not wearing the typical camouflage favored by the far-right extremist group, according to court documents, but instead appears in images from that day in a black jacket with the word “Bad” on it in red letters, from Michael Jackson's 1987 world tour. It is that jacket that helped lead law enforcement to him; agents found photographs on Instagram of a person who appears to be Beeks wearing the jacket while posing in front of a sign for the musical play Jesus Christ Superstar. Beeks is an actor who performs as Judas — under the stage name James T. Justis — in the traveling production of the play, and the criminal complaint notes he was observed performing the role in both San Francisco and Los Angeles. In addition, he has also performed as a Michael Jackson impersonator. Prosecutors claim that Beeks changed his phone and phone number the day after an indictment naming co-conspirators was filed and registered his new phone under his stage name. After Beeks was charged, he appeared in court and claimed that the U.S. government had no authority over him — which a U.S. District judge called “gobbledygook.” The production of Jesus Christ Superstar has since replaced him in the role of Judas. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Short narrative: Thomas Caldwell, Donovan Crowl and Jessica Watkins are accused of coordinating the Oath Keepers militia in a criminal conspiracy. Thomas Caldwell, 65, a leader of the Oath Keepers, is accused of helping to organize at least eight rioters wearing military-stye gear who attacked the Capitol building on 1/6/21. He was arrested 1/19/21 in Virginia. He is charged with conspiracy amongst other crimes. The Complaint alleges that the individuals Caldwell coordinated moved "in an organized and practices fashion and force[d] their way to the ground of the crowd gathered around a door to the U.S. Capitol."

Charges: 18:2384 Seditious Conspiracy; 18:1512(K) Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:372 Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; 18:1512(c)(1) Tampering with Documents or Proceedings;
Additional details: Founder of the Oath Keepers; "Rhodes Found guilty by jury on 11/29/22 of seditious conspiracy, obstruction of an official proceeding, and tampering with documents and proceedings."
Short narrative: Shortly after the election in November 2020, prosecutors say, Rhodes and others began planning travel to Washingto D.C. and training for action there. As the crowd gathered outside the U.S. Capitol on 1/6/2021, about 2 p.m., federal prosecutors say Rhodes entered the restricted area of the Capitol grounds and directed his followers to meet him at the Capitol. Court records say two groups of Oath Keepers, many in paramilitary clothing bearing Oath Keepers patches and insignia, then formed military-style "stack" formations and invaded the Capitol.

Name of case: United States of America v. Rhodes et. al.
Charges: 18:2384 Seditious Conspiracy; 18:1512(K) Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:372 Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; 18:1512(c)(1) Tampering with Documents or Proceedings;
Additional details: Resident of GA; Added to Oath Keepers case late in August 2021
Short narrative: "Federal prosecutors allege that Brian Ulrich conspired with members of the extremist anti-government militia group known as the Oath Keepers to disrupt Congress on Jan. 6. Ulrich has been indicted along with several members of the group. According to the indictment, Ulrich goes by the moniker "Molon Labe" and allegedly participated in conversations on the encrypted messaging service Signal in a group message labeled "DC OP: Jan 6 21." On Dec. 31, Ulrich reportedly wrote the following message on the chat: "The more patriots the merrier 'gonna be wild." Later he allegedly wrote, "Someone can tell me if I'm crazy but I'm planning on having a backpack for regular use and then a separate backpack with my ammo load out with some basics that I can [just] switch too is [sic] s**t truly the fan blades. ..." According to court documents, Ulrich also asked another member on Signal: "Hey we told to bring guns and maybe stage them in VA ...?" On Jan. 4. Ulrich traveled with others to Washington, D.C., from Alabama and Georgia, and stayed at the Mayflower Hotel, court documents say. On the day of the riot, he headed for the U.S. Capitol in a golf cart along with others named in the indictment. He continued on foot and ultimately pushed his way inside through the Rotunda doors, and then, according to court documents, left the same way he came in." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Andrew Galloway
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of WY; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 10/12/22 to 30 days of incarceration."
Short narrative: “Yeah, that was us today; no that wasn’t Antifa,” Andrew James Galloway allegedly said on a TikTok video that was submitted to the FBI as a tip concerning his alleged participation in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol. The FBI later confirmed using cellphone records and footage take inside the building that Galloway entered the Capitol through a breached window and after about 10 minutes exited through another breached window, court documents indicate. According to court documents, the FBI interviewed Galloway at his home in Wyoming, where he allegedly confirmed the TikTok video but denied having entered the building. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents

Additional details: Resident of Long Beach, CA; Brother also arrested; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: Alexis Ivan Bustos-Ocampo and his brother Bryan Emmanuel Bustos, both of CA, were charged with Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; Parade, Demonstrate, or Picket in any of the Capitol Buildings following their participation in the Capitol riot. The Bustos brothers were identified via numerous photos and a video Bryan posted to his Instagram account which depict both himself and Alexis illegally inside the Capitol building.

Short narrative: On Jan. 6, 2021, Stephen Chase Randolph entered the capitol building along with 4 other defendants. He was charged with civil disorder, assaulting resisting, or impeding officers using a deadly or dangerous weapon and inflicting bodily injury, assaulting resisting, or impeding officers using a deadly or dangerous weapon , assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon, disorderly or disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly weapon, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a dangerous or deadly weapin resulting in significant bodily injury, disorderly conduct in the capitol grounds or building, acts of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building, and obstruction of an official proceeding. He entered a plea of not guilty, and was found guilty of civil disorder, assaulting an officer with a dangerous or deadly weapon, assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers, and misdemeanor charges of commiting an act of physical violence on capitol grounds and disorderly and disruptive conduct on capitol grounds. He was part of group that broke a barricade at the Capitol and pushed an officer, causing her to suffer a concussion. "Stephen Randolph Sentenced 9/19/24 to 8 years in prison, 36 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $2,000 in restitution."
Source description: Court Documents, Local News Articles, Charging Documents

Short narrative: James Tate Grant was charged with Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury; Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an official proceeding; Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building following his participation in the Capitol riot. Short narrative: Ryan Stephen Samsel, 37, of Bristol, Pennsylvania, was found guilty for his role in the Jan. 6th Capitol rios after helping dismantle barricades at the Capitol building and knocking over a U.S. Capitol Police Officer, who then suffered a concussion. Samsel was charged with one count of forcible assault/opposition or interference with a federal agent engaged in official duties, one count of committing or attempt to commit any act to obstruct, impede, or interfere with any firearm or law enforcement officer engaged in official duty, and one count of obstruction/impeding or attempt to, an official proceeding. He entered a plea of not guilty on 9/14/2021 and and was found guilty on 2/2/24 of civil disorder, assaulting an officer with a dangerous or deadly weapon, obstructing an official proceeding, assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers, and assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon. He sentencing was on June 13, 2023.

The sister said images taken from the Capitol complex on Jan. 6 appeared to show her brother James.

Name of case: United States of America v. Tim Levon Boughner
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of Justice/Congress; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;
Additional details: Resident of MI; Evidence used from Sedition Hunters
Short narrative: “I’m on my way to Washington DC. To make sure Biden’s doesn’t become president,” Tim Levon Boughner allegedly posted on social media on Jan. 5, 2021, the day that phone records reportedly indicate he traveled from Michigan to Washington, D.C. For weeks prior, Boughner wrote multiple social media entries questioning the legitimacy of the presidential election and calling Joe Biden “stupid,” according to court records. Boughner first came to the attention of the FBI in the spring of 2021 when FBI agents reviewed police body-worn camera footage that allegedly shows Boughner assaulting an officer with a chemical spray. Subsequently, the FBI issued a BOLO alert for the then-unidentified Boughner. In addition, the volunteer group Sedition Hunters assigned a moniker to the person who federal prosecutors say is Boughner: “#blackpufferwhitescarf." According to the FBI, Boughner was identified by a tattoo of a five-point star below a dragon on the inside of his left wrist. At the end of July 2021, a search warrant was issued to a Facebook account that matched Boughner. The subscriber data provided by Facebook allegedly confirmed he was indeed at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. On the day of the riot, he allegedly posted: “I grabbed a can from them and started spraying. I got it on video lol …That was wild. We made it to the senate floor till National guard started fight back.” (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and release (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Robert Gieswein
Group affiliation: Three Percenters (III Percenters, 3%ers); Woodland Wild Dogs
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3), 2 Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon [3 counts]; 18:1361, 2 Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon
Additional details: appears to have ties to the Proud Boys/Three Percenters/Oath Keepers; from Woodland, Colorado; "Gieswein Sentenced 6/23/23 to 48 months in prison for two counts of assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers, 36 months of supervised release, and restitution of $2,000 to the Architect of the Capitol."
Short narrative: Robert Gieswein, 24, of Woodland Park, CO was charged with Obstruction of an official proceeding; Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous easpon [3 counts]; Destruction of Government property; and Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon following his participation in the Capitol riot. Gieswein was identified via footage taken at the riot and can be clearly seen illegally entering the US capitol in paramilitary gear carrying a baseball bat and weilding an unidentified spray bottle which he used to spray at Capitol police officers. Gieswein appears to be affiliated with the domestic group the Three Percenters which is related to the Oath Keepers. Additionally, Gieswein runs a private paramilitary group in Colorado called the Woodland Wild Dogs. In an interview, Gieswein offers up anti-semitic conspiracy theories as part of his reasoning for his actions.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, News article

Name of case: United States of America v. Robertson & Fracker
Charges: 18:1512(c), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:231(a)(3) 2, Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of VA; USMC rifleman 2010-2014 and deployed to Afghanistan twice; joined VA National Guard (infantryman, 116th Infantry Brigade Combat Team, 29th Infantry Division); worked as a VA police officer in Rocky Mount, Va.' but was fired after arrest; After March 2022 guilty plea Fracker was "removed from the service component" of his National Guardman role., "Sentenced 8/16/22 to 12 months of probation, the first 59 days on home detention, 120 hours of community service, $2,000 restitution."
Veteran status: Former active duty and current reserve components
Short narrative: On January 29, 2021, in Washington D.C., Jacob Fracker, age 29; and Thomas Robertson, age 47; both of Rocky Mountain, Virginia, were charged with obstruction of an official proceeding, aiding and abetting, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, and violent entry and disorderly conduct in a capitol building. The two men, both members of the Rocky Mountain police department, entered the Capitol Building during the January 6 riot. Their actions were motivated by their rightist: anti-government beliefs.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental reports and release, Local news articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Robertson & Fracker
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction and Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3) 2, Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 18:1512(c)(1) Tampering with Document or Proceedings
Additional details: 2nd jury trial of Capitol cases; Resident of VA; Off duty Rocky Mountain VA police officer who was fired after arrest; US Army Reserve police officer; also served as a corporal in VA National Guard 2006-2009; free on a $15,000 unsecured release bond and are barred from either going to Washington or taking part in any demonstration or protest as their criminal case continues.; "RESENTENCED 9/5/24 to concurrent terms of 72 months as to Counts 3, 4 and 6. As to Count 2, the Defendant is sentenced to 60 months and 6 months on Count 5, to be served concurrently with the other term of imprisonment. The Defendant shall receive credit for time served. The Defendant is further sentenced to serve a concurrent term of 36 months as to Counts 2, 3, 4 and 6. The Defendant shall also pay $410 in special assessment and $2,000 in restitution."
Short narrative: On January 29, 2021, in Washington D.C., Jacob Fracker, age 29; and Thomas Robertson, age 47; both of Rocky Mountain, Virginia, were charged with obstruction of an official proceeding, aiding and abetting, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, and violent entry and disorderly conduct in a capitol building. The two men, both members of the Rocky Mountain police department, entered the Capitol Building during the January 6 riot. Their actions were motivated by their rightist: anti-government beliefs. THomas Robertson was the second Capitol defendant to have a jury trial. After a three-day trial, jurors deliberated a day and a half before convicting Robertson, now 49, on six counts. Found guilty 4/11/22 of a total of six charges, including five felonies: obstruction of an official proceeding, civil disorder, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds while carrying a dangerous weapon, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building while carrying a dangerous weapon, and tampering with a document or proceedings. Also found guilty of the misdemeanor offense of disorderly conduct in a Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental reports and release, Local news articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Niemela & Chiguer
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of MA; Girlfriend also arrested
Short narrative: Stefanie Nicole Chiguer came to the attention of the FBI when a witness identified her as the girlfriend of Kirstyn Niemela, who is also alleged to have entered the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, and is charged in relation to the riot. The witness identified Chiguer only as “Stefanie” but told the FBI she lived in Dracut, Mass. A driver’s license photo for Chiguer matches Facebook photos from Jan. 6, court documents say. Those photos allegedly show Chiguer wearing a sweatshirt that says “We the People ARE PISSED OFF,” which matched a sweatshirt worn by Niemela. Prosecutors claim Chiguer can also be seen in surveillance photos from inside the Capitol, and data from Verizon is allegedly consistent with Chiguer’s phone being inside the Capitol as well.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Niemela & Chiguer
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NH. Girlfriend also arrested; "Kirstyn Niemela Sentenced 6/8/23 to 12 months incarceration and to pay a $1,000 fine and $500 in restitution."
Short narrative: Kirstyn Niemela, 33 from NH, was charged with her girlfriend Stephanie Nicole Chiguar for her role in the January 6 Capitol raid. She was found guilty of all charges at trial and sentenced to 12 months incarceration. "Niemela claimed to be a member of the Proud Boys and that she had allegedly showed one witness a video of her breaking a window in the U.S. Capitol building on 1/6/21. A second witness, who said they were related to Niemela, as well as an anonymous text tipster, told the FBI that Niemela had also posted to Facebook near the Capitol. Prosecutors allege that other Facebook posts show “a woman believed to be Niemela” dressed in a sweatshirt reading “We the People ARE PISSED OFF,” as well as wearing sunglasses and an America flag cape. The FBI says a woman wearing the same outfit can be seen in surveillance footage from inside the Capitol. Court documents also allege that data from search warrants to Google and Facebook back up the assertion that Niemela entered the U.S. Capitol building." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Government Reports and Release, Local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Nicholas John Lattanzi
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: "Sentenced - 12/9/22 to 14 days incarceration, $500 fine, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: On January 10, 2022, Nicholas Lattanzi was indicted for his actions surrounding the January 6 Capitol breach. Lattanzi's TikTok account (@benshapiro.v2) was initially submitted to University of Delaware law enforcement in December 2020 when he made a post wearing a camouflagee jacket captioned "Who wants to commit war crimes in Bosnia with me?" University police referred this account to the regional FBI, who then continually monitored the social media account. Lattanzi posted on TikTok several times leading up to and during the January 6, 2021 raid on the Capitol; furthermore, footage from the security cameras of the U.S. Capitol building showed him entering and parading about the interior in defiance of law enforcement.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Tyler John Tew
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of ID; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "GUILTY Plea entered by TYLER JOHN TEW on 6/13/23 Counts 1, 2, 3 & 4."
Short narrative: Shortly after the U.S. Capitol riot, a tipster approached the FBI with the information that Tyler Tew had posted on Facebook that he was at the Capitol during the insurrection, court documents indicate. A search warrant served on Google showed that a mobile device associated with Tew was at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and surveillance camera footage inside the Capitol shows an individual that the bureau has identified as Tew entering the building through the Senate parliamentarian's door, according to court documents. Shortly after this footage, pepper balls were fired in his direction. Messages from his cellphone, obtained through a search warrant, reportedly showed Tew bragging that he "was inside" the Capitol and got "pepper sprayed in the face for my country." Two days after the riot, Tew allegedly wrote his spouse, "I stormed the capitol [sic] building FOR YOU!!!!" In the days following, Tew messaged multiple individuals and seemingly acknowledged that he had been inside the Capitol during the riot, according to a federal filing. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News article
