Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Additional details: Resident of AK; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 7/7/22 to 12 months of probation, 60 hours community service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: On January 21, 2022, Robert Thomas Snow, 78, was charged for his role in the January 6 protests. He was identified by the FBI after they found that his cell phone was connected to the cell site servicing the interior of the United States Capitol on the day in question. FBI agents confirmed as much when they interviewed Snow at his home in Heber Springs, Arkansas and he admitted to being in Washington D.C. and entering the U.S. Capitol Building on January 6, 2021. Footage from the closed circuit tv within the building captured an individual matching Snow's description entering the building illegally with the rest of the crowd, then walking about the Rotunda and other areas of the interior.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Billy Knutson
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NC who moved to SD in 2021; Indicted by a Bill of Information.; "Sentenced 8/26/22 to six months of incarceration, one year of supervised release, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: On January 24, 2022, Billy Knutson was indicted for his involvement in the US Capitol raid. He was seen on surveillance footage from inside the U.S. Capitol. Verification of social media posts confirmed that Knutson was in the videos, and that he was in the Capitol for several minutes, recording videos and taking photos on a cell phone before he left the building. He pled guilty and was sentenced for Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Blas Santillan
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of GA; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 9/23/22 to 45 days of incarceration, 36 months of probation, and $500 restitution."
Short narrative: In January 2021, Blas Santillian, 26, came to the attention of the FBI as one of the individuals who participated in the riot at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. A tipster who had known Santillian since high school gave his name to the FBI along with videos from Santillian's Snapchat story that show him--the image in the video matches that of Santillian's drivers license photo--in the rotunda of the U.S. Capitol building. The tipster's coworker who had also known Santillian since high school was connected with him on Snapchat and showed the video in the first place. Both were interviewed by the FBI, where they described what happened in the minutes of video footage showing Santillian in the building; the footage shows him walking about the interior and berating other protestors outside the entrance who did not enter the capitol building. capitol security footage shows much of the same. Based on all this, Santillian was charged by a bill of information on January 25, 2022.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Government Reports and Release, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Victoria White
Charges: 18:231(a)(3), 2 Civil disorder; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building or grounds
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of MN; "Victoria White sentenced to 10 days of incarceration on Count 1s, to be served on the weekends. Followed by two years of supervised release. $100 special assessment."
Short narrative: On January 26, 2022, Victoria Charity White, 40, of Rochester, Minnesota, was charged with several federal offenses for her actions at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. According to the case's documents, White attended the rally at the Ellipse and then proceeded on to the U.S. Capitol Building with the rest of the mob that converged on it. At the Lower West Terrace, White was recorded cheering on rioters fighting back against law enforcement officers in the tunnel. Then, White pushed further into the tunnel herself, where a law enforcement officer attempted to hold her back with a riot shield, but White tried to rip the shield away and fought back against the officer fending her off with a baton. Law enforcement apprehended her and then transported her to a police station away from the building, but she was released without formal charges later that night.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release, News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Nicholas James Brockhoff
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangous Weapon; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of KY; Used fire extinguisher as weapon; Identified with assisgance from OSINT hosted on jan6attack.com; "Brockhoff Sentenced 5/25/23 to 36 months in prison, 36 months supervised release, and $2,700 restitution."
Short narrative: On January 6, 2021, Nicholas James Brockhoff, 20, of Covington, Kentucky climbed to a vantage point above a line of MPD and Capitol Police officers on scaffolding in place for the inauguration of Joe Biden. He then proceeded to spray the officers with a fire extinguisher, disorienting them and obscuring their vision. After this, Brockhoff later went on to enter the Capitol Building through a broken window and obtain a stolen MPD helmet. Body camera footage showed that, when confronted by officers on the possession of their stolen property, Brockhoff identified himself by name. Later on, review of social media and other media sources found further images of Brockhoff in the helmet. The FBI reviewed records of vehicles known to be operated by Brockhoff and his family, finding that one had indeed been used to travel to Washington D.C. on the day in question; additionally, the FBI conducted an interview with an associate of Brockhoff, who identified him in photos of the January 6 riot. With all this, Brockhoff was arrested and charged by the U.S. Attorney for the District of Columbia.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Neefe & Smith
Charges: 18:1512(k) Conspiracy to Obstruct Official Proceeding; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; *18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) and 2 Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; *18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(3) and (b)(1)(A) Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) and 2 Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(E), 2 Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Shippensburg, PA; "Sentenced 9/23/22 to 41 months in prison, three years of supervised release, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative:
Marshall Neefe, 25 of PA, and friend Charles Bradford Smith were charged for their roles in the January 6 Capitol raid. Neefe pled guilty to Conspiracy to Obstruct Official Proceeding and a lesser offense as to 4s of Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Aiding and Abetting and was sentenced to 41 months incarceration.

"“Take off the 6th man! It’s the Big one!!! Trump is literally calling people to DC in a show of force,” Charles Bradford Smith, known as Brad Smith, allegedly wrote on Dec. 31, 2021, urging a friend on Facebook to travel with him to Washington, D.C. According to the FBI, Smith also told a friend, “If it’s big enough we should all just storm the buildings.” Three days before coming to D.C., Smith allegedly purchased a KA-BAR military-style knife. On Jan. 6, 2021, Smith is allegedly seen yelling and encouraging rioters to keep forcing a door to the U.S. Capitol closed so that police officers inside could not respond to the riots outside. “Well we literally chased them out into hiding…Pence cucked like we knew he would but that was an Unbelievable show of force and it did its job,” he allegedly wrote to a friend after the riot." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental reports and release (DOJ), Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Neefe & Smith
Charges: 18:1512(k) Conspiracy to Obstruct Official Proceeding; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; *18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) and 2 Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; *18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(3) and (b)(1)(A) Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) and 2 Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(E), 2 Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Newville, PA; "Sentenced 9/23/22 to 41 months in prison, three years of supervised release, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative:
Charles Bradford "Brad" Smith, 25 of PA, and friend Marshall Neefe were charged for their roles in the January 6 Capitol raid. Neefe pled guilty to Conspiracy to Obstruct Official Proceeding and Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Aiding and Abetting and was sentenced to 41 months incarceration.

"“I’m getting ready to storm D.C.,” wrote Marshall Neefe in a message to a friend on Nov. 4, 2020, the day after Election Day 2020, expressing his dissatisfaction with the election results, according to court documents. In the following weeks, Neefe engaged in multiple online conversations organizing travel to Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6, 2021. He wrote on Facebook in December: “Cause hot damn son I really wanna crack some commie skulls." According to the FBI, Neefe made a wooden club he called “the commie knocker” that he brought to Washington. On the Capitol grounds, footage shows Neefe participating in hoisting and pushing a large metal sign frame into a defensive line of police officers, court documents indicate. He is also allegedly seen entering the building and disregarding commands from law enforcement. “If i had it my way every cop who hurled a baton or maced [one] of us would be lined up and put down," he allegedly wrote later. Neefe faces 10 charges, including seven felonies." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental reports and release, Local news

Name of case: United States of America v. Matthew Thomas Krol
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: Executive officer of Genesee County Volunteer Militia; Resident of MI; "Matthew Krol Sentenced 12/15/23 to Fifty-One (51) Months of Incarceration (with credit for time served since arrest on 2/22/2022), followed by 36 Months of supervised release with conditions. Open Counts 1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7 and 8 are dismissed on the motion of the Government. Special Assessment: $100.00. Restitution: $2,000.00."
Short narrative: On January 26, 2022, government prosecutors filed a formal complaint against Matthew Thomas Krol, 63, for his role in the U.S. Capitol riots on January 6, 2021. Krol, a self-professed leader within the Genesee County Volunteer Militia, was seen numerous times on body-cam, CCTV, and cell phone video violently assaulting police officers with flagpoles, debris, and a stolen baton. Krol was later seen inside the Capitol buildling, mainly in the Rotunda and around the Senate wing. While no formal charges had been filed against him prior to this incident, Krol admitted to law enforcement that he is affiliated with the men accused of plotting to kidnap Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer, and that he has previously participated in riots in possession of a firearm. Krol entered a guilty plea on 8/14/23 to count 4: assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers with a dangerous weapon. Sentencing scheduled for 12/15/23. Tipsters called the FBI to identify Krol, open source videos were used to show his assault against officers, and geolocation of his phone was also used to place him at the scene.
Source description: Charging Documents, local news article; Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Westbury, James & Westbury
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of MN
Short narrative: Aaron James, 35, and father-son duo Robert Westbury, 62, and Isaac Westbury, 19, have been indicted for their role in the January 6th, 2021 Capitol protests. In addition to charges related to their illegal entry on restricted Capitol grounds, the younger Westbury and James face up to 20 years in prison for using a police shield to attack Capitol police officers. Last month, in an interview with the far-right website Red Voice Media, the older Westbury's wife, Rosemarie, called the arrest of her husband and sons an act of tyranny, and said the family went to the Capitol to exercise their First Amendment rights and support Trump. All three men have allegedly pled non-guilty to the charges.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Ariticles

Name of case: United States of America v. Aiden Henry Bilyard
Charges: *18:231(a)(3) - Civil disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a deadly and dangerous weapon; *18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly and dangerous weapon; *18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly and dangerous weapon; *18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building; *18:1361, 2 - Destruction of government property; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of NC; Attended USAF basic training but quit; "Bilyard Sentenced 3/17/23 to 40 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, and $3,500 in restitution."
Short narrative: Aiden Henry Bilyard, 19, was captured participating in the riot at the U.S. Capitol in bodycam footage, social media images, and open-source videos. In these pieces of media, Bilyard can be seen discharging a can of bear spray at officers, handing weapons to fellow rioters attempting to break through windows, and using a baseball bat to break through a window into the U.S. Capitol himself. In these pieces of media, Bilyard could be seen wearing a sweatshirt that read "Harvard," causing online third-parties posting photos of rioters in hopes of identifying them to dub Bilyard "#HarvardSweats". Bilyard was identified by the FBI after they found a 2020 booking photo that bore an exact resemblance to his appearance in the Capitol riot footage and the Facebook page belonging to his mother--in which his image is also featured. Bilyard was interviewed at Lackland Air Force Base, where he was undergoing basic training; he confirmed that he attended the riot at the U.S. Capitol, but cut the interview short when faced with the footage and images evidencing criminal activity on his part. The FBI also interviewed his mother, who identified her son in all the images and even took note of the bear spray can, saying that her son had brought it home afterward. With all this, Bilyard was charged with a litany of criminal offenses on January 26, 2022. He has since dropped out of Air Force basic training and returned home to Cary, North Carolina.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND Supports organized political violence AND State speech act
Name of case: United States of America v. James Russell Davis
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil disorder; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of VA; Charged with 18:231(a)(3) in superseding indictment at time of plea; DOJ describes him as a "self-proclaimed" member of the Proud Boys; "Defendant sentenced to two (2) months of Incarceration, followed by twenty-four (24) months of Supervised Release (with conditions). $100.00 Special Assessment and Restitution in the amount of $2,000.00. ALL Remaining Counts DISMISSED ON ORAL MOTION OF THE GOVERNMENT."
Short narrative: James Russell Davis, 45, of King George, VA, a former Marine and self-proclaimed Proud Boy, is charged with crimes related to his participation in the Capitol raid on January 6, 2021. He charged at police officers with a large stick.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Releases, Local News Articles

Other names/aliases: Sandra Suzanne Pomeroy, Sandy Pomeroy Weyer, Sandy Sue
Name of case: United States of America v. Sandra S. Weyer
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Particiapted in attacks on media stationed at Capitol; Wore 'Trump 2020' hoodie; Resident of PA; "Sandra Weyer found guilty 6/6/23 of five charges, including one felony count and four misdemeanor counts, following a bench trial."; "Sandra Weyer Sentenced 9/14/23 to 14 months incarceration followed by 1 year of Supervised Release to run concurrently with Counts 2-5; $100.00 S/A and $2,000 Restitution.; Count 2,. Defendant sentenced to 12 months incarceration followed by 1 year of Supervised Release to run concurrently with Counts 1, and 3-5; $25 S/A and $2,000 Restitution; Count 3, Defendant sentenced to 12 months incarceration followed by 1 year of Supervised Release to run concurrently with Counts 1,2 and 4-5; $25 S/A and $2,000 Restitution.; Count 4, Defendant sentenced to 6 months incarceration to run concurrently with Counts 1,2,3 and 5; $10 S/A and $2,000 Restitution.; Count 5, Defendant sentenced to 6 months incarceration to run concurrently with Counts 1-4; $10 S/A and $2,000 Restitution."
Short narrative: On February 2, 2022, Sandra S. Weyer, 58, was charged with multiple federal charges for her participation in the riot at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. During the events of the day, a reporter from the New York Times was assaulted and had her camera equipment stolen; she chased after the thief and passed by many other protestors in doing so. Weyer was one such protestor, who took a video of the pursuit on her cell phone and can be heard calling her a "traitor" and calling for her to be maced. Throughout the day, Weyer joined in several other provocative calls, chanting for a door to be broken down and for the protestors to "take our country back." She was identified by an anonymous FBI tip in the form of a reference to her Facebook account, in which she is dressed in a manner consistent with one of the protestors the New York Times reporter was shown to have passed in CCTV footage.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Dale Jeremiah Shalvey, et. al.
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting certain officers or employees; 18:1512(c)(2),2 Obstruction of an official proceeding; *18:661 Theft of personal Property within special Maritime and Territorial jurisdiction; *18:1001(a)(2) False statements [2 counts]; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(A) Entering and remaining on the Floor of Congress; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol building*
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Pleaded guilty on 10/3/22 to Count Two of the Superseding Indictment filed on February 2, 2022, Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Count Three of the Superseding Indictment filed on February 2, 2022, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; sentenced 5/11/23 to 41 months in prison, 24 months of supervised release, and a fine/restitution for $2,000, for assaulting, resisting, or impeding law enforcement officers and obstruction of an official proceeding. His wife, Tara Aileen Stottlemyer, 37, also of North Carolina, and Katharine Hallock Morrison, 38, of Dansville, New York, were each sentenced to eight months in prison, 24 months of supervised release, and a fine/restitution of $2,000 for obstruction of an official proceeding.
Short narrative: Dale Jeremiah "DJ" Shalvey, 36, Tara Aileen Slottlemyer (Tara Aileen Shalvey), 37, and Katharine "Kate" Hallock Morrison, 43, were all charged for their participation in the January 6th Capitol riot. Shalvey was charged with Civil disorder; Assaulting, resisting certain officers or employees; Obstruction of an official proceeding; Theft of personal Property within special Maritime and Territorial jurisdiction; False statements [2 counts]; Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; Entering and remaining on the Floor of Congress; Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol building for his role in the January 6th Capitol riot. Shalvey wore Army-green tactical clothing, including a helmet and gear, when he went to the Capitol. The FBI said he also took photos and videos, which include shots of his face and recording of himself yelling “(Expletive) yeah” as he roamed the hallways of the Capitol. He was turned in by a couple of people, including a classmate from his days in high school in Wheeling, West Virginia. One video taken in the Capitol shows Shalvey appearing to read a document that stated Senator Ted Cruz objected to the certification of the Arizona electoral votes. When a voice that the FBI believes was Shalvey’s said “He (Cruz) was going to sell us out all along,” another rioter said, “No that’s a good thing. That’s a good thing.” (USA Today) Shalvey accepted a plea deal, pleading guilty to Assaulting, resisting, impeding certain officers. Sentencing of this case is still pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental reports and release

Name of case: United States of America v. Dale Jeremiah Shalvey, et. al.
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(A) Entering and remaining on the Floor of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others

Short narrative: Dale Jeremiah "DJ" Shalvey, 36, Tara Aileen Slottlemyer (Tara Aileen Shalvey), 37, and Katharine "Kate" Hallock Morrison, 43, were all charged for their participation in the January 6th Capitol riot. Morrison was charged with Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; Entering and remaining on the Floor of Congress; Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building for her role in the Capitol riot. Morrison accepted a plea deal, pleading guilty to Obstruction of an official proceding. Sentencing for this case is currently pending.

Name of case: United States of America v. Dale Jeremiah Shalvey, et. al.
Charges: *18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; *18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; *18:661 - Theft in a Federal Enclave; *18:1001(a)(2) - False Statement or Representation to an Agency of the United States; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(A) - Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of NC; Pleaded guilty on 10/3/22 to Obstruction of an Official Proceeding
Short narrative: Dale Jeremiah "DJ" Shalvey, 36, Tara Aileen Slottlemyer (Tara Aileen Shalvey), 37, and Katharine "Kate" Hallock Morrison, 43, were all charged for their participation in the January 6th Capitol riot. Slottlemyer was charged with Obstruction of an official proceeding; Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; Entering and remaining on the Floor of Congress; Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building. Slottlemyer accepted a plea deal, pleading guilty to Obstruction of an official proceding. Sentencing for this case is currently pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Seymour & Seymour
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Hamilton, OH; Father also arrested; Charged via Information sheet; Sentenced 11/4/22 to 12 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: On February 3, 2022, Paul Lee Seymour, Jr., 33, and his father Paul Lee Seymour, Sr. of OH, were charged via complaint with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following their participation in the Capitol riot. The Seymours were identified via several anonymous tips provided to the FBI as well as numerous photos and video taken by Capitol police which depict both the Seymours illegally inside the Capitol building. He pled guilty to the parading charge and was sentenced 11/4/22 to 12 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution.

Name of case: United States of America v. Kenneth Scott Armstrong III
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

Armstrong is the owner of Ouroboros Farms in Half Moon Bay, a company specializing in "aquaponics," in which fish waste is used to grow plants in water.

Name of case: United States of America v. Joshua Lee Hernandez
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder; *18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and remaining in the gallery of Congress; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of TN; "Sentenced 2/2/23 to 24 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, and a $2,000 special assessment."
Short narrative: On February 9, 2022, Joshua Lee Hernandez, also known as “Ace Hernandez,” 28, of Memphis, Tennessee, was charged in an indictment filed in the District of Columbia with assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers, civil disorder, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, and related offenses. Hernandez entered the U.S. Capitol through the interior door of the East Rotunda with a group of other rioters, encouraging them to push against the Capitol Police officers guarding the area. During the melee that followed their breaching of the door, Hernandez wielded a flagpole and attacked one of the officers with it.
Source description: Charging Documents, Government Reports and Releases, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Peter J. Schwartz, et. al.
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon and aiding and abetting, 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon, 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon, 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in the Capitol grounds or buildings, 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building;
Additional details: Resident of CA; Participated in a J6-themed telegram group called "The California Patriots - DC Brigade"; Wore Infowars tshirt; "Jeffrey Brown Sentenced 4/28/23 to fifty-four (54) months of incarceration and thirty-six (46) months of supervised release."
Short narrative: On February 9, 2022, as part of a final superseding indictment, Jeffrey Scott Brown, 54, of California, was charged with multiple federal offenses for his participation in the riot at the United States Capitol Building on January 6, 2021. Brown was founded to have departed from LAX to Washington D.C. on January 5, 2021 and made a return trip on January 7, 2021; additionally, law enforcement discovered that he participated in a Telegram group chat known as "“The California Patriots- DC Brigade," which served as a communications channel for numerous California residents that traveled to Washington D.C. on the day of the Electoral College vote counting "willing to fight." Brown was caught on video spraying pepper spray at a line of Capitol Police and MPD officers in the lower west terrace of the U.S. Capitol Building. He was also pictured near the front of the line of protesters pushing against the defensive line of officers at the exterior Capitol entrance in the lower west terrace.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Peter J. Schwartz, et. al.
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon [3 counts], 18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder, 18:111(a)(1) and (b) and 2 Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon and aiding and abetting, 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting, 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon, 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon, 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon, 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in the Capitol grounds or buildings, 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building;
Additional details: Resident of PA; "Peter Schwartz Sentenced 5/5/23 to one hundred seventy (170) months of incarceration and thirty-six (36) months of supervised release as to Counts 1, 3, 4, 7, and 8 of the 63 Second Superseding Indictment. Defendant sentenced to sixty (60) months of incarceration and thirty-six (36) months of supervised release as to Count 2 of the 63 Second Superseding Indictment. Defendant sentenced to one hundred twenty (120) months of incarceration and thirty-six (36) months of supervised release as to Counts 9, 10, and 11 of the 63 Second Superseding Indictment. Defendant sentenced to six (6) months of incarceration as to Counts 12 and 13 of the 63 Second Superseding Indictment."
Short narrative: On February 9, 2022, as part of a final superseding indictment, Peter J. Schwartz, of Kentucky, was charged with Forcibly Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers or Employees; Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; and Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds. Schwartz was identified as participating in the Capitol riot via footage taken at the event. Schwartz was seen spraying pepper spray from a black canister at a line of Capitol Police and MPD officers on the west terrace of the U.S. Capitol Building. A tipster also called in to the FBI and reported that Schwartz is a felon who was released from prison due to the pandemic and is supposed to be residing at a rehabilitation facility. Numerous other tips came in identifying Schwartz after his image was released as part of a BOLO statement from the FBI. Schwartz had originally been arrested for his participation in the riot in February 2021.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental Reports and Release, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Schwartz, et al.
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder; *18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *18:1752(b)(1)(A) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *18:1752(a)(4), (b)(1)(A) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in the Capitol grounds or buildings; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings
Additional details: Resident of KY; "Pleaded guilty 8/24/22 to indictment. The charges include five felonies." "Defendant sentenced to 24 months of incarceration on Counts 2, 6, 9, 10, and 11 and six months of incarceration on Counts 12 and 13. All terms of incarceration shall run concurrently. Additionally, the Defendant is sentenced to concurrent 36 month terms of supervised release as to Counts 2, 6, 9, 10, and 11."
Short narrative: On February 9, 2022, Shelly Stallings, 42, of Morganfield, Kentucky, was charged with multiple federal offenses stemming from her participation in the riot at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. Stallings was named as an additional defendant in a superseding indictment that also included her husband, Peter Schwartz, and several others. According to court documents, Stallings and Schwartz traveled from Uniontown, Pennsylvania to Washington, D.C. to attend the "Stop the Steal" rally in protest of the 2020 Presidential Election results. Afterwards, the two made their way to the U.S. Capitol with the crowd to protest the certification of the election results. While there, the crowd engaged in a skirmish with law enforcement, and Stallings sprayed pepper spray at the officers on the Lower West Terrace. Later on, she made her way to the tunnel in that section of the Capitol and took part in the pushing effort against law enforcement officers attempting to hold the line.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Release, Local News Articles

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND Supports organized political violence AND State speech act
Name of case: United States of America v. Johnson, et al.
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) and 2 Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting [2 counts]; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) and 2 Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) and 2 Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) and 2 Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) and 2 Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: Resident of FL
Short narrative: According to an affidavit and criminal complaint, Alan Fischer III marched to the Capitol on 1/6/2022 with members of the Proud Boys. Once there, he moved to the vicinity of the terrace on the west side of the Capitol, where he joined others in pushing against law enforcement at the arched entrance to a passageway into the building. The group of rioters collectively pushed against officers, at times rocking together in a coordinated way, to gain entry to the interior of the building. He remained in this area for a period of more than 45 minutes. Later, according to the court documents, Fischer moved to the west front of the Capitol. Once there, he threw chairs, an orange traffic cone, and a pole towards officers.
Source description: Charging Documents; Local news articles; News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Kastner, et. al.
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of OH; Sentenced 1/20/23 to 24 months probation, $500 Restitution, $10 special assesment.
Short narrative: Luke Faulkner, 58 of Ohio, was charged with Jared Samuel Kastner and Kenneth Duncan Massie, also of OH, for their invovlement in the January 6 Capitol raid. Faulkner pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and was sentenced to 24 months probation. All three individuals were identified via cell phone location information and surveillance footage taken inside the Capitol building at the time of the riot. "Charging documents for Luke Faulkner and Jared Kastner say that a photo of Faulkner in front of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, appears in Google records belonging to Kastner. Agents believe Faulkner to be a frequent contact of Kastner and ran a search warrant on Faulkner's cellphone account, which showed the phone had pinged a cell site that includes the inside of the Capitol building during the riot. Surveillance footage also allegedly shows Kastner and Faulkner in the Crypt of the Capitol, among a crowd pushing through officers that were attempting to hold them back. In addition to the footage, multiple records obtained by law enforcement show that Kastner traveled to an apartment in North Beach, Md., in the first week of January 2021 from his home in Ohio and then back to Ohio, where he arrived at an address belonging to Faulkner, on Jan. 7, 2021." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Peter J. Schwartz, et al.
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) and 2 Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon and aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in the Capitol grounds or buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building;
Additional details: A court memo claimed that Maly has extensive criminal history and was once a member of a racist skinhead group in FL.; "Markus Maly sentenced 6/9/23 to 72 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release."
Short narrative: On February 9, 2022, Markus Maly, 47, of Fincastle, Virginia, was charged in a criminal complaint with assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury, civil disorder, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, and related offenses. Throughout the course of the events of January 6, 2021, Maly used a chemical agent on an MPD officer, passed a can of the same substance to another rioter--who was also charged as a defendant in this same case, participated in the "heave-ho" effort inside the Lower West Terrace tunnel, and stole a riot shield from an officer. After the riot, he was given the name #JohnSprayne by online sleuths seeking to identify him. He was identified after a tip from the DC Metropolitan Police led to the Facebook account of "Mark Maly," whose interactions online evidenced that the user participated in the riot. Further investigation matched photos of Maly at the riot with prior booking photos from an extensive criminal history, which included a case of battery against a law enforcement officer.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Releases, News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Adam Avery Honeycutt
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:1752(a) Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority;
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 5/11/22 to 90 days in jail, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Adam Honeycutt, 39, is charged with entering a restricted area without lawful authority as well as violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds. His home was raided, and agents found 4 guns as well as marijuana and drug paraphernalia. There were also 3 children in the house.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Reva Vincent
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; Resident of KY; "Sentenced 9/21/22 to 24 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $1,500 fine, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Reva Vincent, 57, was charged by information and ordered to attend an arraignment/plea agreement hearing on March 23, 2022. She has been charged with parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. Vincent was found to have driven to Washington, D.C. from her Kentucky farm with her husband and several others. She and her husband attended the rally at the ellipse on the morning of January 6, 2022, and later walked to the U.S. Capitol Building, where she used her cell phone to record herself entering through the Rotunda door while yelling things like "Stop the steal" and "This was built with our money, our money, not theirs, we own this Capitol." After being inside the Rotunda for approximately five minutes, Vincent left through the same door she entered through. Vincent was later found to have posted messages to her Facebook account in December 2020 that read "A LAST WARNING TO THE LEFT IN AMERICA Dear Leftist/Progressive, Your...life is in severe danger. That wasn’t a threat: It’s a fact."
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Nolan B. Cooke
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Acts during civil disorder; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Unlawful activities on Capitol grounds;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 6/10/22 to one year and a day in prison, 36 months of supervised release, $2,000 restitution
Short narrative: On January 21, 2021, Nolan Bernard Cooke was arrested for a series of charges that pertained to his activity at the January 6th, 2021 Capitol protests. He came to the attention of federal law enforcement after numerous tipsters who were connected with Cooke over social media saw his postings about the event on his Snapchat story. Further investigation found that Cooke had also posted evidence of his participation on his TikTok and Instagram accounts. The footage--which was apparently captured on a GoPro that Cooke wore around his neck that day--shows Cooke among the front line of rioters, grappling with U.S. Capitol Police officers and trying to break through a window into the Capitol Building with the end of a flagpole he was carrying. In an interview with the FBI, Cooke confirmed all of the above, saying he came to the Capitol to be heard and was at the front of the crowd pushing against the officers who were enforcing the restricted access to the Capitol Building and grounds. He was charged with acts during civil unrest in a bill of information issued on February 14, 2022.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Nicholas J. Lentz
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds;
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 5/10/22 to 36 months’ probation, including 30 days’ home detention, 100 hours of community service, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: On February 16, 2022, Nicholas Lentz, 42, a combat veteran of the U.S. Marine Corps and former police officer from North Miami Beach, Florida was charged for his role during the Capitol protests by a bill of information. Lentz was quickly identified by the FBI after two tipsters sent in photos and videos of him participating in the riot; one of these supplementary pieces of evidence was a fifty-two-second video clip posted to Lentz's Facebook account speaking in the Crypt, saying in-part "America has spoken. You can not stop millions of people. Cannot stop it." Lentz was later identified in the Miami Herald by former North Miami Beach Mayor Anthony DeFillipo. Lentz was interviewed by the FBI, in which he admitted to entering the United States Capitol but asserting that he did not partake in any violence. Additionally, surveillance footage from within the United States Capitol's interior confirms that Lentz paraded throughout the building for almost an hour. He was initially arrested on Feburary 19, 2021 in the Southern District of Florida and was later placed on personal recognizance bond.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Marcos Panayiotou
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry and disorderly conduct in a capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of FL/CA/NJ/PA; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Reported to be with USMC with 1st Maintenance Battalion in Camp Pendleton, CA, switched from active duty to reserves February 2020; "Sentenced 11/29/22 to 14 days of intermittent incarceration, 36 months of probation, $1,500 fine, $500 restitution."
Veteran status: Former active duty and current reserve components
Short narrative: On February 16, 2022, Marcos Panayiotou, 29, was charged for his role in the Capitol Protests. Investigators pulled his military records, and found drivers licenses for him from New Jersey and Florida, and learned he had been a member of the 1st Maintenance Battalion at Camp Pendleton in California until February 2020. He was released from active duty in May 2020 and enrolled as a Marine reservist. A tipster informed the FBI that he had moved to Philadelphia in October 2020. Anonymous tipsters provided the FBI with photographs showing Panayiotou parading through the U.S. Capitol Building's interior wearing a sweatshirt with the logo of his U.S. Marine Corps battalion on the back along with a hat that read "Make Politicians Afraid Again." The FBI officially identified Panayiotou after a complainant contacted him saying that she had been shown videos of him by his wife; after this, they obtained his driver's licenses, his military records, AT&T data showing that his phone had connected to a cell site servicing the Capitol interior on January 6th, and Capitol closed-circuit surveillance footage showing him walking freely throughout the U.S. Capitol in the clothing described above.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles, Government Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Juliano Gross
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of NJ; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced - 12/9/22 to 24 months probation, 45 days home confinement, 100 hours community service, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: On February 18, 2022, Juliano Gross, 27, of Kearny, New Jersey was charged for his actions in participating in the riot at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. He allegedly documented his own participation in the raid on the U.S. capitol on TikTok. Tipsters reported Gross's TikTok account to the FBI after it had been removed from the site. Gross admitted to the FBI that, after attending the rally at the Ellipse with his mother, he walked throughout the interior of the U.S. Capitol and Live Streamed the insurrection on TikTok in an effort to raise money. The FBI obtained the footage from the livestream largely thanks to citizen sleuths and other social media users that obtained it while it was posted on TikTok. Court documents state that Gross, in interviews with federal law enforcement, also confirmed the clothing he wore on January 6, 2021: a black peacoat, a red Trump-branded hat and an America flag mask. Prosecutors say that a person matching that description can be seen in surveillance footage from that day as well.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Article, News Article, Government Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Kenneth Rader
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of IA; Expressed support for QAnon; "Sentenced 9/29/22 to 90 days of incarceration, 36 months of probation, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: On February 18, 2022, Kenneth Bruce Rader, Jr., 53, of Sioux City, Iowa, was charged with illegally entering the U.S. Capitol Building during the riot that occurred there on January 6, 2021. He was identified by the FBI after one of his family members submitted a tip about him, pointing out his radicalization and social media postings that--among other things--threatened Vice President Mike Pence and President-elect Joe Biden. Further investigation of Rader's Facebook account indicated that he is an adherrent of the QAnon conspiracy theory and that, after Joe Biden was declared the winner of the 2020 Presidential Election, he wrote that his certification would lead to blood being spilled in the streets. During an interview, Rader told FBI agents in September 2021 that he had attended the Jan. 6, 2021 rally and walked to the Capitol grounds after hearing a "boom." He told agents he looked inside the Capitol, but never entered. However, security footage shows Rader, dressed in a blue "Trump 2020" hoodie, entering the Capitol at 2:14 p.m. through the Senate wing door that had already been broken by protesters. A screen shot from the video shows Rader standing near the door. The video shows Rader enter the building, stand near a broken window, speak with several unidentified men and then exit. In an interview with the FBI, two of Rader's relatives identified him as the person shown and in a photo taken outside the Capitol.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles, News Article, Government Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Heneghan & Kicinski
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of FL; "Sentenced 6/23/23 to Twenty (20) Days of incarceration followed by One (1) Year of Supervised Release; Special Assessment in the amount of $25 imposed; and Restitution in the amount of $500 imposed."
Short narrative: Carol O'Neal Kicinski, 64 of Florida, was charged with Jon Nicholas Heneghan and pled guilty to Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. She was sentenced to 20 days incarceration for her role in the January 6 Capitol raid. Heneghan and Kicinski, who are beleived to be in a relationship, were seen on CCTV footage both inside and around the Capitol building. Noteably, they were seen moving through the Rotunda and later as part of a larger group moving towards to House Chambers.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Vincent Gillespie
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of MA; "Vincent Gillespie Sentenced 4/14/23 to 68 months in prison for assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers; civil disorder; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, a fine of $25,000, restitution of $2,000, and to serve 36 months of supervised release."
Short narrative: Vincent Gillespie, 60, was among the rioters in the Lower West Terrace of the Capitol who engaged in pushing, shoving, yelling, and fighting with law enforcement officers. According to prosecutors, he took a police shield and used it to ram officers while shouting “traitor” and “treason." Gillespie also grabbed one of the officers. Court documents describe Gillespie as injured following the altercation, with photos of his bloodied face, but do not attribute his actions to any law enforcement injuries. Gillespie was charged with assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers, civil disorder, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds and related offenses. He was found guilty at trial on some of these charges. On the remainder a mistrial was declared and the government dropped the charges at sentencing.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeffrey Schaefer
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of DE; Sentenced 11/18/22 to 30 days of incarceration, $2,000 fine, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: On March 4, 2022, Jeffrey Schaefer, 35, was indicted for his role in the riot at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. He was first brought to attention of law enforcement by a tipster who took screenshots of his social media accounts. In one alleged post by Schaefer, he posted an image of what appears to be the inside of the U.S. Capitol, with the caption, "THE capitol HAS BEEN BREACHED... IT IS FILLING UP... THEY CAN'T STOP US." The FBI was able to link a Facebook photo of Schaefer with an image from a body camera worn by a police officer at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. The FBI also obtained video from inside the Capitol in which Schaefer is allegedly seen entering the building through a broken window on the Senate side. This video suggests that he was inside the Capitol for approximately 28 minutes, the FBI said.
Source description: Charging Documents; News Article; Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Joshua John Portlock
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of TN; "Joshua Portlock Sentenced 4/17/24 to Twenty (20) Months of Incarceration followed by a term of Twenty-Four (24) Months of Supervised Release (with conditions). Defendant further Ordered to pay $100 Special Assessment and Restitution of $2000."
Short narrative: "Wearing a black beanie stitched with a yellow wreath commonly associated with the Proud Boys and a white cowboy hat that referenced the Stop the Steal slogan, Joshua John Portlock allegedly shrugged when officers ordered him out of a tunnel into the U.S. Capitol building. In reply, Portlock allegedly gestured to the crowd surrounding him and said “I can’t with this." He then pleaded with officers to help a fellow rioter having a medical emergency and continued preventing police from closing doors into the Capitol building, according to the statement. Just a half-hour or so before that, FBI agents allege that Portlock pushed open metal barricades and used a large sheet of plywood to drive back a line of police officers in front of the Capitol. Portlock allegedly also joined a crowd of other protesters, chanting “heave-ho” and passing Capitol Police riot shields to other protesters in an attempt to push past officers blocking access to the tunnel into the Capitol. Portlock is a manager with Mitsubishi Motors, according to a LinkedIn page referenced in the FBI statement of facts. Court records show he was arrested on Nov. 3 in Smyrna, Tenn." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Other names/aliases: NaziGrayHat, SoggyKidInsider (IDs used by SeditionHunters and other private citizen investigators following January 6)
Name of case: United States of America v. Matthew Jason Beddingfield
Charges: *18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder; *18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; *18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a capitol building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of NC; In part identifed by Huffington Post, Ryan Reilly and others and video organized by Pro Publica and Sedition Hunters; Beddingfield Sentenced 7/11/23 To Thirty-Eight (38) Months Incarceration Followed By A Supervised Release Term Of Twenty-Four (24) Months With A Special Assessment Of $100.00 And Restitution In The Amount Of $2000.00.
Short narrative: On March 4, 2022, Matthew Beddingfield, 21, of Middlesex, North Carolina, was charged in an indictment filed in the District of Columbia with assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury, civil disorder, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, and related offenses, for his actions on January 6. While there, Beddingfield was caught on camera jumping barricades, beating law enforcement officers with a metal pole, and then parading about the interior of the U.S. Capitol Building illegally. After the riot, Beddingfield was the subject of online crowd-sourced policing efforts--including the efforts of Sedition Hunters--and was labeled with the hashtags #NaziGrayHat and #SoggyKidInsider. Eventually, the images of Beddingfield were connected to his December 2019 mugshot, taken in Johnston County, North Carolina. After Beddingfield was identified, it was discovered through the social media posts of his father--known only as J.B.--that he and Beddingfield had attended another rally in D.C. on November 14, 2020; Beddingfield's photos from the Facebook posts of this event matched Beddingfield's physical appearance on January 6th, and J.B. also had posts stating that "we" were at the Capitol.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Lucas Denney
Group affiliation: Three Percenters (III Percenters, 3%ers), Patriot Boys of North Texas (PBONT)
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; *18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; *18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; *18:1512(k) Conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding; *18:1752(a)(1) and (a)(1)(A) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds resulting in significant bodily injury; *18:1752(a)(2) and (a)(1)(A) Disorderly or disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds resulting in significant bodily injury; *18:1752(a)(4) and (a)(1)(A) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: Resident of TX; " Sentenced 9/28/22 to 52 months in prison, three years of supervised release, restitution to be determined at a later date by the Court."
Short narrative: Lucas Denney, 44 of Texas, pled guilty to Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and was sentenced to 52 months incarceration for his role in the January 6 Capitol raid. He tazed a police officer who had a heart attack while being tazed. He was a military police officer in an unknown branch. He "allegedly used social media and other means to recruit members to join his self-proclaimed militia group, the Patriot Boys of North Texas, as well as encourage them to travel to Washington, D.C. Court records indicate that Denney engaged in physical violence at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Denney can allegedly be seen wearing a mask with a Joker grin printed on it, as well as a hat with the Three Percenters symbol on it. According to the FBI, he grabbed and shoved a police officer, then attempted to grab a canister of crowd-control spray from a different officer. Denney was also allegedly seen later picking up a long metal pole from the ground and swinging it at an officer. Approximately 10 minutes later, he was seen grabbing a large tube and launching it toward a line of law enforcement officers, court records indicate. As the afternoon progressed, Denney was also allegedly seen carrying a baton and swinging his arm and fist at an officer. Denney has been detained, pending further proceedings." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Government Reports and Release, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Cantrell, Cantrell, & Cantrell
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of IN
Short narrative: Jared Paul Cantrell, Quentin G Cantrell, and Eric Cantrell, a group of cousins from Indiana, were identified through security images from inside the Capitol on Jan 6 2020 and by witness information provided to the FBI regarding Jared Paul Cantrell’s social media posts. They have been charged with four misdemeanor counts related to entering the Capitol. They were all arrested March 10 2022.

Name of case: United States of America v. Samuel Christopher Montoya
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(E) - Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of TX; Indicted by BIll of Information
Short narrative: Samuel Christopher Montoya, 35, from San Marcos, TX was arrested and charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building, Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building,Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings, and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his participation in the January 6, 2021 capitol riot. It has been reported that Montoya is a video editor with Infowars. On January 11 the FBI says it received a tip to the National Threat Operations Center from a family member of Montoya who said they had video proof Montoya was in the capitol. The FBI "says the video captures Montoya’s movements outside and then inside the Capitol Building until he arrives by the doors outside the Speaker’s Lobby, where it depicts the shooting of the woman publicly identified as Ashli Babbitt." (Fox 7 Austin). Montoya pled guilty on 11/7/2022 to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Source description: Charging documents, Court Documents, Local news article, Governmental reports and release (DOJ)

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND State speech act
Name of case: United States of America v. Samuel Lazar
Charges: 18:111(a) and (b) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; *18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder; *18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in physical violence in a restricited building or grounds using a deadly or dangerous weapon; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Ephrata, PA; sentenced to 30 months in prison and $2000 restitution
Short narrative: On March 7, 2022, Samuel Lazar, 35, of Ephrata, PA was charged with crimes in relation to his participation of the January 6, 2021 Capitol raid. He was seen dressed in "tactical gear, protectice goggles and comouflage face paint", and he approached police and discharged a chemical irritant at them while attempting to remove a bike rack. Lazar accepted a plea deal, pleading guilty to count one of the indictment and was sentenced to time served (30 months) and $2000 restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Loammi Yazdani-Isfehani, et. al.
Charges: *18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;

Short narrative: On February 18, 2022, Abigail Yazdani-Isfehani, along with her siblings Loammi and Loruhamah, was issued a complaint for entering a restricted area and protesting on Capitol grounds as a result of their presence at the January 6th riot at the United States Capitol. The siblings had traveled to DC from their Ohio home for the rally scheduled earlier in the day and were subsequently seen on CCTV and cell phone videos walking around the Capitol Rotunda and Statuary Hall. She pled guilty to the parading charge and was sentenced to 24 months of probation and community service.

Name of case: United States of America v. Myers & Gianos
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of PA; Sentenced 7/25/23 to Twenty-four (24) months of Probation. Special Assessment of $25 and Restitution in the amount of $500.
Short narrative: Michael Gianos, 33 of New Jersey, pled guilty to Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds for his role in the January 6 Capitol Riot. He was linked to another South Jersey suspect who was charged, Lawrence Stackhouse of Blackwood. A search of Stackhouse's cell phone uncovered incriminating text exchanges with both Gianos and a Philadelphia woman, 30-year-old Rachel Myers, who also was arrested and in this database.According to an uncontested statement filed with Gianos’ April 28 plea agreement, he texted and messaged the other suspects about the “stolen” 2020 election and his desire to block certification of Electoral College votes for incoming President Joe Biden.Gianos admitted guilt to a misdemeanor charge of entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents
