Name of case: United States of America v. Ballenger & Price
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Additional details: Resident of MD; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Cynthia Ballenger and Christopher Price Found guilty 3/21/23 on counts 1s-4s."; "Cynthia Ballenger Sentenced 9/29/23 to four (4) months incarceration to run concurrent with all other counts, followed by nine (9) months Supervised Release as to counts 1-2 to run concurrent, Special Assessments totaling $70, and Restitution in the amount of $500."; "Christopher Price Sentenced 9/29/23 to forty-five (45) days incarceration to run concurrent with all other counts, followed by nine (9) months Supervised Release as to counts 1-2 to run concurrent, Special Assessments totaling $70, and Restitution in the amount of $500."
Short narrative: On March 8, 2022, married couple Cynthia Catherine Ballenger and Christopher John Price of Emmitsburg, Maryland, were charged in a superseding information. The FBI first identified the pair after they received an anonymous tip indicating that the two had posted photos from the event on their Facebook accounts. Although photos had been removed, comments from posts on those accounts reflected the owners confirming their commenters' questions about whether or not they were at the U.S. Capitol rioting on January 6, 2021. The phone numbers and Google accounts attached to these accounts were found to be connected to mobile devices that were detected within the U.S. Capitol Building on the day in question. Further, CCTV footage from within the building featured images of two individuals whose physical descriptions matched those of the drivers license photos found for Ballenger and Price walking about the interior of the Capitol Building. Additionally, credit card account records from January 6, provided by PNC Bank, are consistent with purchases made at locations between their home in Maryland and their destination of Washington, D.C. The FBI interviewed a friend of the two, who identified them in the photos and provided the FBI with text messages and photos sent between him and Price; the photos show them at multiple Washington D.C. sites and the texts all but confirm their participation in the violent protest. Finally, the FBI interviewed Price and Bellenger themselves, who admitted to being in the city on the day in question, but denied that they were part of the crowd that caused damage or that they were there at that time.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Release, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Ballenger & Price
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Additional details: Resident of MD; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Cynthia Ballenger and Christopher Price Found guilty 3/21/23 on counts 1s-4s."; "Cynthia Ballenger Sentenced 9/29/23 to four (4) months incarceration to run concurrent with all other counts, followed by nine (9) months Supervised Release as to counts 1-2 to run concurrent, Special Assessments totaling $70, and Restitution in the amount of $500."
Short narrative: On March 8, 2022, married couple Cynthia Catherine Ballenger and Christopher John Price of Emmitsburg, Maryland, were charged in a superseding information. The FBI first identified the pair after they received an anonymous tip indicating that the two had posted photos from the event on their Facebook accounts. Although photos had been removed, comments from posts on those accounts reflected the owners confirming their commenters' questions about whether or not they were at the U.S. Capitol rioting on January 6, 2021. The phone numbers and Google accounts attached to these accounts were found to be connected to mobile devices that were detected within the U.S. Capitol Building on the day in question. Further, CCTV footage from within the building featured images of two individuals whose physical descriptions matched those of the drivers license photos found for Ballenger and Price walking about the interior of the Capitol Building. Additionally, credit card account records from January 6, provided by PNC Bank, are consistent with purchases made at locations between their home in Maryland and their destination of Washington, D.C. The FBI interviewed a friend of the two, who identified them in the photos and provided the FBI with text messages and photos sent between him and Price; the photos show them at multiple Washington D.C. sites and the texts all but confirm their participation in the violent protest. Finally, the FBI interviewed Price and Bellenger themselves, who admitted to being in the city on the day in question, but denied that they were part of the crowd that caused damage or that they were there at that time.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Release, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Myers & Gianos
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of PA
Short narrative: Rachel Myers, a 30-year-old who works at Delilah’s Gentlemen’s Club in Philadelphia, was charged along with Michael Gianos, who traveled to Washington with her for the Jan. 6 insurrection, the FBI says. According to the warrant, Myers stayed in a hotel with a man named Lawrence Stackhouse, of Blackwood, N.J. Stackhouse was arrested in March after several tips from coworkers who said it was “common knowledge” he was at the Capitol and had called out of work Jan. 5 and 6 to attend. In the days after the election of President Joe Biden, Myers and Gianos texted each other expressing the belief that the election had been stolen from Donald Trump and planning a trip to Washington to stop the certification process.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Nicholas Rodean
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:1361 Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) act of physical violence in the capitol grounds or building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; *405104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Charged by Bill of Information, then formally by indictment; "Found guilty 7/12/22 of the felony offense of destruction of government property, and six misdemeanor offenses, including entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a Capitol Building; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building; committing an act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds of Capitol Building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building."; "Sentenced 10/26/22 to five years of probation, including 240 days of home detention, ordered to pay $2,048 in restitution."
Short narrative: Nicholas Rodean, 26, was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Destruction of Government Property; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; and act of physical violence in the capitol grounds or building for his role in the January 6th Capitol riot. Rodean was photographed inside the Capitol during the riot and seen in footage interacting with Capitol Police Officer. Rodean was found guilty and sentenced to five years of probation, including 240 days of home detention, ordered to pay $2,048 in restitution. He was gound guilty for one felony and various misdemeanors.
Source description: News Articles, Charging Documents, Governmental reports and release

Name of case: United States of America v. Iraj Javid
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Virginia and employed by WMATA; "Javid Sentenced 2/3/23 to 24 months probation with special condition of home detention, $10 special assesment, $500 Restitution."
Short narrative: Iraj George Jarrid, 31, was charged on March 1, 2022 with a number of charges related to his involvement in the Janaury 6 riot at the United States Capitol. Jarrid could be seen most notably in the cell phone footage of the shooting that resulted in Ashli Babbit's death, as he was one of those who was standing next to her. Jarrid could otherwise be seen throughout the Capitol building, entering with a bare face and then putting on a facemask as he paraded about the Rotunda and the Speaker's Lobby. Afterward, Jarrid was identified by comparing a Virginia driver's license photo with the images of him on January 6. An IT specialist at the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority, Jarrid was further identified by three witnesses who were acquainted with him; also, his cell phone number was tracked to the interior of the U.S. Capitol building on the day in question.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Lloyd Casimiro Cruz Jr.
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of MO; additionally sentenced to 1 year supervised release and $500 restitution
Short narrative: Lloyd Casimiro Cruz Jr. was charged for his role in the January 6, 2021 raid on the US Capitol. Cruz initially told investigators he did not enter the Capitol building, but was nearby and attempted to aid people injured. During a subsequent voluntary interview he turned over video footage he had taken that day which showed him to be inside the Capitol.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Jolene Eicher
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Additional details: Resident of VA; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Defendant Is Sentenced 9/15/23 To Two (2) Months Incarceration Followed By Twelve (12) Months Of Supervised Release And A Special Assessment Of $25.00 ; On Count(s) 2s, Defendant Is Sentenced To Two (2) Months Incarceration Followed By Twelve (12) Months Of Supervised Release And A Special Assessment Of $25.00; On Count(s) 3s, Defendant Is Sentenced To Two (2) Months Incarceration And A Special Assessment Of $10.00; On Count(s) 4s, Defendant Is Sentenced To Two (2) Months Incarceration And A Special Assessment Of $10.00; said terms of incarceration and supervised release to run concurrent as to all counts."
Short narrative: Jolene Eicher, 30, has been arrested and charged for her connection to the January 6, 2021 Capitol protests. A previous classmate identified her from one of the pictures that was posted online after the protest. She was seen entering the U.S. Capitol Building through a broken window and then walking around the interior before exiting. She later boasted about her participation in the event in communications with others over social media. Eicher worked for a rescue squad in the Farmville, VA area but lost her job due to her involvement in the Capitol protest. She pled not guiilty and was found guilty on all four counts of her indictment.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Isaac Samuel Yoder
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Additional details: Resident of MO; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Yoder pleaded Not Guilty to all charges. Found Guilty on all charges in a Bench trial on 5/26/2023. Sentencing set for 8/25/2023 Counts 1ss, 2ss, 3ss and 4ss.; Defendant is hereby committed to the custody of the Bureau of Prisons for a term of Twelve (12) months on each of Counts One and Two and a term of Six (6) months on each of Counts Three and Four, with all such terms to run concurrently. Defendant is further sentenced to serve a Twelve (12) month term of supervised release as to each of Counts One and Two, with all such terms to run concurrently. In addition, the Defendant is ordered to pay a special assessment of $25 on each of Counts One and Two and $10 on each of Counts Three and Four for a total of $70, a fine of $1,000 and restitution in the amount of $500.
Short narrative: On March 11, 2022, Samuel Yoder, 31, was charged for his actions on January 6, 2021. On this day, the Missouri-based locksmith, while wearing a George Washington costume, illegally entered the Capitol building and told a Newsweek reporter, "Most of us out there are on the side of the aisle who are the gun owners … If we had collectively gone there to cause trouble there would have been piles of bodies. We could have leveled things." After a tipster told the FBI that an employee of Yoder's Missouri-based locksmith business, the FBI investigated. They found the pictures of Yoder on his drivers license and his business's website both matched the description of the colonial attire-clad individual captured in CCTV footage at the U.S. Capitol on January 6.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. John David Ross Gould
Charges: 18 U.S.C. § 1752(a)(1)- Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 18 U.S.C. § 1752(a)(2)- Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; 40 U.S.C. § 5104(e)(2)(A)- Entering or Remaining on the Floor of Congress; 40 U.S.C. § 5104(e)(2)(D)- Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40 U.S.C. § 5104(e)(2)(G)- Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of GA
Short narrative: John Gould was arrested and charged for his role in the January 2021 Capitol protests. He was discovered to be at the protest after his co-worker Jonathan Laurens , another defendant in this datset, was arrested.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Joshua Johnson
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(A) Entering and remaining on the floor of Congress; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Sherman, TX, formerly resident of Spokane WA; "Sentenced 7/6/23 to 24 months in prison, 24 months of supervised release, restitution of $2,000 to the Architect of the Capitol, and a $100 fine."
Short narrative: On March 11, 2022, Joshua Edward Johnson, 30, was indicted on a number of charges relating to their involvement in the January 6th attack on the United States Capitol. Johnson was seen through a number of cell phone and CCTV videos entering the building through a window near the Senate Chambers, and then could later be seen rifling through a desk in the Senate Chamber itself. Online, Johnson was dubbed #Metrojack by citizen sleuths spreading multiple photos of him from the riot across the internet in hopes of locating him. The FBI analyzed the photos and linked them to a previous booking photograph. In doing so, they identified him as a resident of Spokane, Washington, but soon discovered that he had since moved to an unknown location. Johnson was arrested in Spokane later that July for a domestic assault and was interviewed by the FBI while in custody. Johnson identified himself as the man in the #Metrojack photographs.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Christopher W. Ortiz
Charges: *18:1752(a) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Additional details: Resident of NY; "Sentenced 8/9/22 to 12 months’ probation, with the first 2 months to be served in home detention, 100 hours of community service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Christopher W. Ortiz, 27, was charged with Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority and Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds following his participation in the Capitol raid. Ortiz posted content to his instagram story that shows his illegal entry to the Capitol. Ortiz's identity was confirmed by a tipster. Ortiz pleaded giulty on March 24, 2022.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Riley D. Kasper
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of Green Bay, WI; "Riley D. Kasper, 24, of Pulaski, Wisconsin, pleaded guilty 9/15/23 in U.S. District Court in the District of Columbia to a felony offense of assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers or employees."; "Riley Kasper Sentenced 2/6/24 to thirty-seven (37) months of incarceration, two (2) years of supervised release, $2,000 restitution and $100 special assessment."
Short narrative: Riley D. Kasper was arrested and charged on March 15, 2022 for a number of trespassing and assault charges relating to his participation in the January 6 insurrection at the United States Capitol. Kasper could be observed in numerous CCTC, body-cam, and cell phone video from the West Terrace at the front of the riot line. At one point he could be seen pepper-spraying a number of Capitol Police officers before retreating from the riot line. Riley was wearing a full camouflage outfit for the day, along with multiple pieces of tactical equipment
Source description: Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Brian Raymond Jones & Patrick John King
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of WA
Short narrative: Brian Raymond Jones researched the marijuana laws in Washington, D.C., before traveling there to attend the pro-Trump rally on Jan. 6, 2021, according to an FBI statement of facts. After the rally, he allegedly marched to the U.S. Capitol and, with co-defendant Patrick King, then smoked marijuana inside the building, according to their middle school classmate who claimed to have seen photos on Facebook and tipped off the FBI in February of 2021. Investigators say surveillance footage shows Jones passing through the Senate Wing doors shortly after 2 p.m. and then walking through the rotunda. According to the FBI, Google records allegedly show Jones spent the evening of Jan. 6 searching phrases such as “Is it illegal to go into the Capitol” and “Unlawful entry charge,” among others. Court documents also allege that Facebook records show Jones told Facebook friends he deleted anything “political” from his account and was creating a second account for only close friends and family, as he grew anxious about getting arrested for allegedly entering the Capitol. He was arrested March 23, 2022, in Seattle. (NPR)
Source description: Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Brian Raymond Jones & Patrick John King
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of WA
Short narrative: Patrick John King told friends on Facebook that he “smoked weed n s***” while in the U.S. Capitol and “was part of rushing the riot police,” according to an FBI statement of facts. King also allegedly wrote to friends on Facebook that he “went to punk congress… let them know we ain’t f***ing around no more." Google records allegedly show King, similar to his co-defendant Brian Raymond Jones, spent the evening of Jan. 6, 2021, searching phrases like “Is it illegal to go into the Capitol,” “US Capitol facial recognition” and “Unlawful entry charge,” among others. A business owner near King’s home tipped off the FBI after one of King’s family members came into his business, in which a television was tuned to news coverage of the Jan. 6 riot. King’s relative allegedly told the business owner that King was “involved in that” and that he “went inside” the Capitol that day. King was arrested March 23, 2022, in Mount Vernon, Wash. (NPR)
Source description: Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Carson S. Lucard
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of PA; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 6/24/22 to 36 months’ probation with 21 days intermittent confinement (served in 3 intervals of 7 days each), 60 days home detention, and $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Carson S. Lucard was indicted on March 16, 2022 on a number of charges related to his involvement in the January 6th assault on the United States Capitol. Lucard had been seen on CCTV and cell phone footage breaching the Capitol building through a smashed withdow along with Brian Stenz, who was charged separately.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Lee Roche
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(A) Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of TN; "Michael Roche Found guilty at bench trial 3/10/23 on all six counts charged in the Indictment."; "Roche Sentenced 6/9/23 to 18 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, and $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: Michael Lee Roche was charged and arrested for 7 felony and misdemeanor counts related to his involvement in the January 2021 Capitol protest on April 13, 2021. He had his initial appearance in the Middle District of Tennessee the same day. He was released on conditions. Roche said his reason for being in the Capitol was praying and "inviting Jesus Christ" into the Capitol; he was seen in videos of the events (posted on Facebook and the New Yorker's YouTube channel) entering the U.S. Capitol, waking onto the floor of Congress, and praying over then-Vice President Pence's desk.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News, Government Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Nancy Barron
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of IN; "Nancy Barron Sentenced 5/2/24 to Thirty-Six (36) Months of Probation on Counts 1-4, to run concurrently. Defendant Ordered to Pay a Special Assessment of $70.00."
Short narrative: On March 17, 2022, Nancy Barron, 46, of Patriot, Indiana, was charged with numerous federal offenses for her role in the January 6th riot at the United States Capitol. Footage from the event shows the individual identified as Barron moving toward the Capitol with the group of rioters and later waving a flag on the platform outside the East Rotunda doors. Videos derived from Barron's Facebook account show her storming the doors, illegally entering the Capitol thereafter. Once inside the Capitol, Barron made a number of selfie-style videos where she talked about her movements within the biuldings; in these videos, she could be heard asking other rioters where Speaker of the House Nacy Pelosi's "stuff" was as well as saying "F**k Nancy Pelosi and f**k Chuck Schumer. Got to drag those c**ksuckers down.” Barron was seen walking through the Rotunda South area, into the Statuary Hall Connector,  then into the Main Door Hall, and then toward the East Stairs. The device that was registered to Barron's Gmail account was also detected inside the U.S. Capitol at this time. During a voluntary interview with the FBI, Barron falsely claimed that she was pushed into the U.S. Capitol by other rioters and then immediately tried to find an exit once inside.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Brian Glenn Bingham
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers or Employee of the United States in the Performance of their Official Duties; 18:231(a)(3) - Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) - Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL
Short narrative: Brian Glenn Bingham, 35, from Port Charlotte, Florida, is charged with federal offenses that include assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder; and violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds, among other charges. He allegedly pushed and grabbed an officer. He was arrested on June 23, 2021. He has ties to Florida and New Jersey.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental Reports and Release (DOJ), Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Shane Jason Woods
Charges: *18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:113(a)(4) - Assault in Special Maritime and Territorial Jurisdiction; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; *18:113(a)(5) - Simple Assault within the Territorial Jurisdiction;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of IL; "Shane Woods Sentenced 10/4/23 to 54 months in prison and 36 months of supervised release."
Short narrative: Shane Jason Woods, 43, resident of IL, was arrested and charged for his role in the January 2021 Capitol protests. He was charged with assault on a law enforcement officer, assault in special maritime and territorial jurisdiction, obstructing, impeding or interfering with law enforcement during civil disorder, being in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, violent entry or disorderly conduct and act of physical violence on grounds. According to court documents, Woods was at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6 in a large crowd of protesters who were congregated on the lower west terrace in the northwest corner of the building. After a U.S. Capitol Police (USCP) officer was one among several sprayed with bear mace, Woods can be seen in publicly available video running toward her. He then tripped the officer and pushed her to the ground. At approximately 4:50 p.m., Woods was part of a large crowd that made its way to a media staging area set up outside the U.S. Capitol grounds. As individuals stormed past metal barricades, media members were forced to flee the area before recovering all of their cameras and equipment. As depicted in several publicly posted videos and images, Woods gathered in the vicinity of the media staging area where several protestors were yelling and spitting at members of the news media near a pushed-over fence next to the staging area. Moments later, Woods climbed over the toppled fence and participated in the assault on the media equipment. Woods can be seen walking around the piled media equipment, as well as picking up and tossing some of it. He was also observed walking closely around a cameraman. As depicted in publicly available video, Woods then ran into and tackled the cameraman, causing him to fall and drop his camera. Woods was the first person to be arrested for assault on members of news media during the U.S. Capitol riot on January 6, 2021. Woods pled guilty on 9/9/2022 to Counts Two and Three of the Indictment, charging him with Striking, Beating, or Wounding in the Territorial Jurisdiction of the United States and Assaulting, Resiting, or Impeding Certain Officers. This case is currently pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jacob L. Zerkle
Charges: 18:111(a) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of AZ; Sentenced 2/22/24 to 24 months in prison and 36 months of supervised release
Short narrative: Jacob L. Zerkle, 50 of Arizona, pled guilty to Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; and Civil Disorder for his role in the January 6 Capitol Raid. Zerkle was seen in numerous Capitol Police officers body-cam footage assaulting officers and attempted to break through the riot line along the West Lawn. Zerkle confirmed to law enforcement upon arrest that it was him in the aformentioned footage, and admitting to physically interacting with officers. He punched one officer and pushed another.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Government reports and release, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Jake Maxwell
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers [2 counts]; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of GA
Short narrative: Jake Maxwell, 20, of Georgia, is charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers, civil disorder, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, and related offenses.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental press and release (DOJ)

Other names/aliases: Melanie Lanham (married name, changed in late 2022)
Name of case: United States of America v. Melanie Archer & Jordan Bonenberger
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of PA; Defendant surname changhed from Archer to Lanham as result of marriage; Sentenced to eighteen months of probation, special assessment of $10.00, restitution in the amount of $500.00, and 50 hours of community service.
Short narrative: On March 28, 2022, Melanie M. Archer and Jordan Bonenberger were charged together by a bill of information for joining in the riot at the United States Capitol Building on January 6, 2021. The pair were seen together on police body and surveillance camera footage parading about the interior of the building during the attack. FBI agents contacted a person who had known Archer for a long time and casually knew of Bonenberger. That person was able to identify the pair in multiple photos that were taken outside the Capitol and around Washington D.C. Prosecutors say that Archer and Bonenberger's appearences matched the clothing and likenesses of the images taken by closed circuit television inside the U.S. Capitol. In addition to the previously mentioned tipster, the FBI received information from others who knew Archer. According to those people, Archer told them she had been part of the event at the Capitol on January 6th.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles,

Name of case: United States of America v. John Franklin Lammons
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of TX; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: John Franklin Lammons was arrested and charged for his participation in the January 6th riot at the United States Capitol. Lammons, along with a friend, had traveled to the Capitol from Texas earlier in the week with the intention of participating in the planned demonstrations. As the crowd frenzied, Lammons made his way to the front of the crowd near the entrances for the Statuary Hall. Lammons conversed with police to secure the release of an injured rioted from behind the police line, and simmilarly brushed with police both in and outside the building. He was seperated from his friend for the majority of his actions, but later left the Capitol grounds with her.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Archer & Bonenberger
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of PA
Short narrative: Using police body camera and surveillance camera footage, FBI agents allegedly identified Jordan Bonenberger and Melanie Archer, who are both charged, as having been present during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol. Multiple tipsters were also able to identity Bonenberger in images taken outside the U.S. Capitol, court documents indicate, and one tipster noted that the person the FBI identified as Bonenberger outside the Capitol was wearing the same clothes as a person captured by surveillance footage inside the building. Bonenberger initially agreed to an interview with the FBI, but declined in person. After seeing Bonenberger in person, FBI agents say they were able to confirm a match between him and images from the riot. In court, attorneys refer to Bonenberger as a member of the military, which the U.S. Marine Corps confirmed to NPR. According to a USMC spokesperson: “The Marine Corps is aware of the situation, and we will fully cooperate with federal authorities as appropriate." The spokesperson added that Bonenberger is "pending administrative separation from the Marine Corps for unrelated misconduct" and that the "administrative separation process was started prior to the indictment.” Bonenberger is a corporal and has no service deployments, according to the Marines. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local News

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND Supports organized political violence
Name of case: United States of America v. Shawn Price
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil disorder; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of NJ; "Shawn Price Sentenced 4/3/23 to 12 months and one day in prison for interfering with law enforcement officers during a civil disorder, and $2,000 in restitution."
Short narrative: On March 30, 2022, Shawn Price, 27, of Rockaway, New Jersey, was charged with civil disorder, entering and remaining in a restricted building, and disorderly conduct for his actions on January 6, 2021. According to the statement of fact, Price is a member of the New Jersey Proud Boys chapter and has held a leadership position within the chapter. Price participated in the groups pushing against law enforcement and barricades to gain entry into the Capitol. When he came to Washington D.C. in January 202, Price brought goggles, milk, and other substances to neutralize the effects of pepper spray on his eyes.
Source description: Charging Documents, Government Reports and Release, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Hand & Robinson-Hand
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of GA; Sentenced on 1/13/2023 to 20 days incarceration; 6 months Probation; a $10 Special Assessment; Restitution of $500; 60 hours of community service; Husband also arrested
Short narrative: Mandy Robinson-Hand, 46 of Georgia, and her husband Charles pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for her role in the Capitol Raid. “We’re in the capitol (sic). Taking our house back … we’ve Been tear gassed etc.,” Mandy Robinson-Hand allegedly wrote in Facebook posts, which a tipster then submitted to the FBI. The FBI claims surveillance footage from the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, appears to show Robinson-Hand, formerly known as Mandy Robinson-Lanning, entering the building through the Senate wing door just before 2:30 p.m., holding her cellphone aloft. She and her husband, Charles Hand III, who is also charged, were then filmed walking hand in hand through the Capitol Visitors Center and the Crypt, court documents allege. According to an FBI statement, the video footage shows Robinson-Hand appearing to restrain her husband from advancing toward a scuffle involving police and protesters. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Hand & Robinson-Hand
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of GA; Sentenced on 1/13/2023 to 20 days incarceration; 6 months Probation; a $10 Special Assessment; Restitution of $500; 60 hours of community service; Wife also arrested
Short narrative: Charles Hand III, 35 of Georgia, and his wife Mandy pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for their involvement in the Capitol Raid. According the NPR, they went to the rally to “protest and stop the certification of what I personally believe to be an election stolen from the America people,” according to screenshots of his Facebook page included in an FBI statement of facts. His post also included the accusation that “Antifa sporting Trump gear were the ones who caused the chaos and who vandalized and attacked the Capitol Police," though there is no evidence suggesting antifa played any major role in the attack. According to court documents, video footage shows Hand breaking off a piece of metal fencing outside the U.S. Capitol and pocketing it in the early afternoon. More than an hour later, surveillance footage from inside the building allegedly captured Hand and his wife, Mandy Robinson-Hand, who is also charged in relation to the riot. Court documents indicate that surveillance footage shows Robinson-Hand restraining Hand at one point as he allegedly tried to move toward a scuffle between police and protesters. Hand and his wife were arrested March 11 in Butler, Ga. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local News

Name of case: Unietd States of America v. Narayana C. Rheiner
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of MD; Narayana Rheiner, 42, of Baltimore, was sentenced to 15 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $2,000 in restitution.
Short narrative: Narayana C. Rheiner, 40, of Baltimore, Maryland pled guilty to Civil Disorder in connection with his role in the January 6 riot at the United States Capitol. Rheiner could be seen in multiple body-camera and cell phone videos waving the rioters forward and engaging in physical altercations with Capitol Police along the riot line on the Western Terrace. While he was not charged with injuring a police officer, he was seen knocking into law enforcement with his left arm and then attempting to rip a riot shield out of the hands of one of the officers, sending the both of them tumbling to the ground in the process. Rheiner could later be seen entering the building through the northernmost entrance on the Western Terrace, telling officers inside to "stand down and go home." Rheiner was identified after a BOLO image was found to match his Maryland driver's license photo and an individual close to him identified him in media from the event.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. David Joseph Gietzen
Charges: 231(a)(3), and 2: Civil disorder and aiding and abetting; 111(a)(1): Assaulting, Resiting, or Impeding (3 counts); 1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(a): entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(a): engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 5104(e)(2)(f): act of physical violence in the capitol grounds or buildings
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of NC; "David Gietzen Sentenced 4/24/24 to Sixty (60) Months of Incarceration (all counts to run concurrently), followed by a term of Supervised Release of Thirty-Six (36) Months (with conditions) (all counts to run concurrently). Defendant further Ordered to pay Special Assessment of $100. No fine imposed. As to Counts 2-7: Defendant Sentenced to Seventy-Two (72) Months of Incarceration (all counts to run concurrently), followed by a term of Supervised Release of Thirty-Six (36) Months (with conditions) (all counts to run concurrently). Defendant further Ordered to pay Special Assessment of $100. No fine imposed. As to Count 8: Defendant Sentenced to Six (6) Months of Incarceration (all counts to run concurrently). Defendant further Ordered to pay Special Assessment of $10. No fine imposed. Total Special Assessment to be paid is $710.00."
Short narrative: On April 1, 2022, David Joseph Gietzen was indicted for his participation in the Capitol insurrection; he obstructed/interfered with a law enforcement officer, interfered/intimidated an employee of the United States, and used a pole as a deadly weapon to assault an employee of the United States, and remained in a restricted building while engaging in physical violence with a deadly weapon which was a pole.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and releases (DOJ), local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Jacob Garcia
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of TX; "Jacob Garcia Sentenced 1/26/23 to 24 months probation, $500 restitution, $10 special assesment."
Short narrative: On April 4, 2022, Jacob Elias Garcia, 27, was charged on a number of counts related to his involvement in the January 6th riot at the United States Capitol. Garcia posted about his plans to attend the demonstrations on Facebook prior to his travel to DC,and subsequently televised his expoits on the Capitol grounds through the same Facebook profile. He was seen breaching the Western Terrace entrances near the Senate Wing Door, and was later seen roaming the halls near the Rotunda. He was located after AT&T records indicated that a phone registered to Angela Kidd, Garcia's mother, was serviced by the cell site linked to the U.S. Capitol's interior; later, a Facebook and childhood friend of Garcia came forward as a witness and identified him in the images, blaming Garcia's acceptance of the Qanon conspiracy theory for his actions on the day in question.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Article, Government Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Miles & Lebrun
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of LA; "Matthew Lebrun Sentenced 1/23/24 to Twenty-Four (24) months of Probation. Special Assessment of $25 and Restitution in the amount of $500."
Short narrative: Steven Miles and Matthew LeBrun were both arrested and charged on April 7, 2022 for their actions during the January 6 insurrection at the United States Capitol.LeBrun could be seen around the West Terrace in multiple CCTC and cell phone videos from the day, before joining Miles to smash a window in the Senate Wing and enter the building. LeBrun could be seen wearing a tactical vest with a patch featuring the logo for the III% Militia group.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and release (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Miles & Lebrun
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1361 Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Zephyrhills, FL; sentenced to 24 months prison, 12 months supervised release, $2000 restitution
Short narrative: Steven Miles and Matthew LeBrun were both arrested and charged on April 7, 2022 for their actions during the January 6 insurrection at the United States Capitol. Steven Miles could be seen through numerous cctv and cell-phone videos along the West Terrace riot line both with and without LeBrun. The pair could later be seen smashing and breaching a window near the Senate Carriage Door before wandering the halls of the Senate Wing. Miles had also been observed in cell phone and body-camera footage shoving and hitting a Capitol Police officer. Miles is a member of the Proud Boys. Miles accepted a plea deal and was sentenced to 24 months prison, 12 months supervised release, $2000 restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and release (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeffrey Munger
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Additional details: Resident of IN; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 10/21/22 to 30 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Jeffrey Munger was charged via bill of information on April 11, 2022 for illegally entering the Capitol on January 6, 2021. Munger was identified using photo and video footage from inside the building as well as the location of a device associated with his Gmail account. An interview with Munger himself confirmed all of the FBI's findings, leading to his subsequent indictment.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release; Local News Article

Other names/aliases: rocknroll_gasstation (Instagram), your_greatest_rival (Instagram); AFO BOLO 244 (WFO); #lordlonghair (Twitter Crowd-Source Policing)
Name of case: United States of America v. Eric Gerwatowski
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of NY; Identified with aid from Sedition Hunters and Twitter; "entenced 3/9/23 to 24 months’ probation, 30 days home detention, $2,000 restitution, 60 hours of community service."
Short narrative: On April 12, 2022, Eric Gerwatowski, 31, was indicted for his actions during the Capitol riot. Gerwatowski allegedly re-opened doors that Capitol Police had just closed to prevent rioters from breaching the building, turned to the crowd and shouted, “Let’s go!” He allegedly directed rioters inside and entered the building himself. Gerwatowksi was identified based on his appearance in interviews and footage from the Capitol, civilian investigation efforts started by Sedition Hunters using the hashtag "#lordlonghair", tips to the FBI from personal associates, and the presence of a device associated with his cell phone number in the building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Matthew Montalvo
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL
Short narrative: "Matthew Montalvo is a real estate broker specializing in vacation home sales near Florida’s Disney World resort, according to his business website HomeSalesNearDisney.com, of which screenshots were included in an FBI statement of facts. On Jan. 6, 2021, Montalvo allegedly spent about 25 minutes walking around the U.S. Capitol’s second floor, according to the FBI statement, which includes photos from video surveillance footage that appear to show Montalvo carrying a tan backpack through the building. The FBI statement also alleges that Montalvo admitted to an FBI agent in December of 2021 that he went inside the Capitol that day. He was arrested April 26, 2022, in Kissimmee, Fla." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court docuemets

Name of case: United States of America v. Cale Douglas Clayton
Charges: *18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers [2 counts]; *18:661 Theft in a Federal Enclave; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of MO; "Cale Clayton Sentenced 7/11/23 to 30 months in prison, 24 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $2,000 in restitution to the Architect of the Capitol."
Short narrative: Cale Douglas Clayton, 41, of Drexel, Missouri was said to have rioted at the United States Capitol in an anonymous tip sent to the FBI on January 7, 2021. Two months later, Clayton was interviewed; while he admitted to attending Donald Trump's speech that morning, proceeding to the U.S. Capitol and being arrested as part of the riot, he claimed not to have been a hostile rioter that day; he claimed that he picked up an MPD officers baton and was attempting to return it to the officers when he was taken inside the building and arrested--he was later released without charges. However, footage from the bodycams worn by MPD officers that day show Clayton incessently taunting and shouting obscenities at the line of officers. Later in the videos, Clayton is shown grappling with officers on the Upper West Terrace, grabbing at their riot shields and picking up a discarded baton left on the ground. He was then apprehended by law enforcement and the baton was recovered. Based on this footage, Clayton was charged with a number of offenses by the United States Attorney for the District of Columbia.
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Release, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Roy Nelson Franklin
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of Justice/Congress and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of IL
Short narrative: Federal prosecutors say that Roy Franklin was one of the rioters that made his way to the Senate floor on the day of the riot at the U.S. Capitol. Court documents indicate that Franklin traveled to Washington, D.C., with his friend Thomas Adams Jr., who was charged in April of 2021. The criminal complaint references an article from *Insider,* published the day after the riot, that says Franklin tripped while at the bottom of the Capitol steps and fell onto an officer who he says “barely reacted.” The article reported that Franklin followed a group of people who were climbing scaffolding and entering the building through a window that was smashed. Once inside, Franklin allegedly followed people onto the floor of the Senate and observed “a shirtless man with an animal skin headdress and his face painted red, white, and blue stood at the speaker's chair, wielding a bullhorn, and flexing his biceps” who was presumably Jacob Chansley, also known as the QAnon Shaman. Months after the riot, agents say they tracked Franklin down at his house, executed a search warrant and seized gear that they claim can be seen in images of that day and in particular the footage from the Senate floor: a Trump 2020 Keep America Great flag, a plaid patterned shirt, a pair of Nike shoes and a baseball cap emblazoned with “United States of America” and a flag in the center. During the execution of the search warrant, an FBI agent alleges that he overheard a conversation between Franklin and his significant other. In the conversation, Franklin allegedly admitted that he was in the Capitol building. He also allegedly said, “You had to be there, the whole thing was fun.” (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND State speech act
Name of case: United States of America v. Seefried & Seefried
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building; 18:1752(a)(4) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with physical violence against property; 18:1361 Destruction of government property; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building
Additional details: Indicted by Bill of Information; Resident of DE; "Found guilty 6/15/22 of the felony offense of obstruction of an official proceeding, and four misdemeanor offenses, including entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a Capitol Building; disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building."; "Sentenced 10/24/22 to 24 months in prison, one year of supervised release, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: On April 7, 2021, in Washington D.C., Kevin Seefried, age 51, of Delaware; and Hunter Seefried, age 23, of Delaware, were charged with obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting that offense; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. Hunter Seefried was additionally charged with entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with physical violence against property; destruction of government property; and an act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building. The two men entered the Capitol building during the January 6 riot through a window that Hunter Seefried broke open with a wooden 2 x 4. Kevin Seefried was photographed holding a Confederate battle flag. The two men were motivated by their rightist: anti-government ideology.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Release (DOJ)

Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

Most noteably, Zoyganeles had posted (and later deleted) a video of himself inside the Capitol rotunda saying "Hey Nazi's, we're here, where are you?". Other posts seemed to be live-reactions to what he was seeing and doing within the Capitol. He was seen extensively on CCTV footage inside and outside the building.

Name of case: United States of America v. Ryals & Griffith
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of OK; Pleaded guilty 5/5/22; "Sentenced 10/18/22 to 9 months of incarceration, 36 months of supervised release, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: Jerry Ryals was charged with 18 U.S.C. § 231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his involvement in the January 6th Capitol insurrection Ryals plead guilty on 5/5/22 to the count of Civil Disorder (following a superseding information) and sentencing information is pending. ""We reclaimed our Capitol, just to be slandered by the media," Ryals wrote on Facebook after the riot, according to the FBI. "Things are headed in the direction of a Revolutionary war against the corruption of our government. "It is our responsibility to handle this at all costs. We are not animals, we are not barbarians, we are the heart of this country and the last ones to stand up for your freedom." Ryals, an apprentice electrician, traveled to Washington D.C. with his boss, Anthony Griffith, to attend the President's rally. The FBI said both men admitted going inside the Capitol. Several witnesses identified Ryals and Griffith." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Releases, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Raul Jarrin
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of TX; Jarrin Sentenced 6/23/23 to fourteen (14) days incarceration, Thirty-Six (36) months probation ,special assessment of $10 and restitution $500.
Short narrative: Raul Jarrin was charged on May 3, 2022 with a number of charges related to his participation in the January 6th riot at the United States Capitol. He was located after his cell phone was detected as having been connected to the cell site servicing the interior of the U.S. Capitol Building. In an interview with the FBI, Jarrin initially admitted to being in Washington, D.C. on the day in question but denied having entered the U.S. Capitol. But, in CCTV footage, Jarrin could be seen entering through one of the Eastern entrances that had been breached, and could subsequently be seen wandering around the halls near the door, taking photographs on his cell phone. Jarrin left shortly after he entered the building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Release

In addition, the defendant is ordered to pay a special assessment of $10 and restitution in the amount of $500."

Federal agents tracked Colton's phone inside the Capitol during the time of the riot, and both Colton and Kimberely signed photos of them confirming their presence in the Capitol. They were seen wandering in and out of the halls along with other rioters.

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND State speech act
Name of case: United States of America v. William Todd Wilson
Charges: 18:2384 Seditious conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of official proceeding
Additional details: Resident of NC; 3rd member of Oath Keepers to plead guilty to seditious conspiracy and agree to cooperate with the government's investigation
Short narrative: "William Todd Wilson is the third member of the Oath Keepers, an anti-government extremist group, to plead guilty to a charge of seditious conspiracy and agree to cooperate with the government's investigation into the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol. Wilson was a county-level leader of the Oath Keepers based in North Carolina, and he conspired with other members of the group to "oppose by force the lawful transfer of presidential power," according to a statement of offense Wilson signed and submitted in federal court as part of his guilty plea. In the days and weeks after the November 2020 presidential election, Wilson exchanged messages with other members of the Oath Keepers about how they believed Joe Biden had stolen the election and, as Oath Keepers leader Stewart Rhodes allegedly put it in one message, "we aren't getting through this without a civil war." On Jan. 5, 2021, Wilson drove from North Carolina to a hotel in Vienna, Va., which is near Washington, D.C., and brought with him an "AR-15-style rifle, a 9-millimeter pistol, approximately 200 rounds of ammunition, body armor, a camouflaged combat uniform, pepper spray, a large walking stick intended for use as a weapon, and a pocketknife," court documents state. Some members of the Oath Keepers allegedly remained at the hotel with a stash of weapons in order to act as a "Quick Reaction Force" that could bring arms into D.C. "in case of worst case scenarios," as Rhodes reportedly wrote in one message. On the day of the riot, Wilson breached the Capitol and helped force open doors to the building's rotunda, according to court documents. Prosecutors allege that at least 14 Oath Keepers breached the Capitol. Wilson left the building and later that evening gathered with Rhodes and other Oath Keepers at the Phoenix Park Hotel in Washington, D.C. At one point, court documents state, Rhodes called an unidentified person via speakerphone and "repeatedly implore[d] the individual to tell President Trump to call upon groups like the Oath Keepers to forcibly oppose the transfer of power." The person "denied Rhodes's request to speak directly with President Trump," according to court documents, which do not state what relationship that person may have had to Trump. Afterward, members of the group reportedly had dinner at an Olive Garden restaurant and discussed the possibility of taking further actions to fight the transfer of power. In the days after Jan. 6, Wilson deleted messages and information about the alleged plot and threw his cellphone into the Atlantic Ocean." (NPR)
Source description: Court documents, news articles, governmental reports and releases (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Justin Michael Smith
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1): Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1751(a)(2): Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G): Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of OH; 36 Months Probation; $10.00 Special Assessment; $500.00 Restitution.
Short narrative: On May 5, 2022, Justin Michael Smith was charged by a bill of information for his partcipation in the Capitol attack; witnesses claimed Smith drove to Washington D.C. alone, participated in the insurrection with photo evidence proving his whereabouts, and another witness claimed he bragged about participating in the insurrection during one of his group meetings. A confidential informant who does not know Smith personally provided law enforcement with a detailed collection of evidence against Smith including social media acounts, posts, screenshots of surveilance footage from the Capitol, and open-source video evidence.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Matthew Joseph Buckler
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of MD; "Sentenced 7/21/22 to 14 days of home detention, 24 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: On January 13, 2021, an anonymous tipster alerted federal law enforcement to Matthew Joseph Buckler of La Plata, Maryland by providing a video from his private Snapchat story, which showed an individual wearing a "Trump" hat chanting "USA!" within a large crowd. Additionally, Snapchat showed Matthew Buckler's "Bitmoji" figure at the United States Capitol on its map, relying on cell phone location data to pinpoint where users are sending images from. Further interviews with tipsters, acquaintances of Buckler's, and Buckler himself concluded that Matthew Joseph Buckler was indeed present at the United States Capitol during the riot on January 6th and that he was the individual chanting in the video provided by the first tipster. Security camera footage showing the individual matching Buckler's description entering the building through a broken window near the Senate Wing Door further confirmed his participation. He was then arrested and charged.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Logan Grover
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of CO; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: Logan Grover, from Erie, Colorado, has been charged and arrested for his role in the Capitol protests. "In the complaint, federal authorities claim Grover was present at the Capitol on Jan. 6. The FBI got at least two anonymous tips, one of which included a screenshot of a Facebook post, that Grover had flown to Washington D.C. with the intent of marching on the Capitol. Grover faces four federal charges: Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority, Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building, Violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds, and Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building." - CBS
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Shawn Bradley Witzemann
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Farmington, NM; Indicted by Bill of Information; "Sentenced to 24 months probation, Restitution $500, Special assesment $10, Government's oral motion to dismiss all remaining counts."
Short narrative: Shawn Bradley Witzemann, 38 was charged for knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; and parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building for his participation in the January 6, 2021 capitol riot. According to the FBI who received a tip in containing a Facebook page link with a video that was taken on January 6, 2021 from inside the Capitol building. The video was posted to the Facebook page of The Armenian Council for Truth in Journalism by an Instagram user with the username “@krampusnatch.” which read “moments ago... Shawn was inside the capitol building!” Using open source information, the FBI was able to determine that SHAWN BRADLEY WITZEMANN was the registered Instagram user of “@krampusnatch.” Witzemann admitted to the FBI during an interivew to being inside of the Capitol building on January 6, 2021 after he traveled to Washington, D.C. on or about January 4, 2021. Witzemann pleaded guilty to count 4 - Parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building and was sentenced to 7 days in jail, ordered to serve two years probation, 60 hours of community service and pay a $500 restitution fee. (St. Louis Record)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News, Databases
