Name of case: United States of America v. Thomas John Ballard
Charges: *18:231(a)(3) - Civil disorder [2 counts]; *18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; *18:111(a)(a) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; *18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of TX; Identified by a civilian using facial recognition website; Wore Infowars hat; "Thomas Ballard Sentenced 12/13/23 to Fifty-Four (54) months of incarceration with credit for time served and Three (3) years of supervised release. Defendant is further ordered to pay a special assessment of $100 and Restitution in the amount of $2,000"
Short narrative: On May 18, 2022, Thomas John Ballard, 35, was charged with multiple federal offenses for his activities at the United States Capitol on January 6, 2021. Ballard, who runs a motorcycle repair business and YouTube channel out of Arlington, Texas, was captured on camera attacking law enforcement officers on the Lower West Terrace of the U.S. Capitol building with multiple makeshift weapons, including a police baton, a tabletop, a white pole, a piece of metal scaffolding, a table leg, and pieces of a wooden plank. When Ballard made his way to the entrance of the Lower West Terrace tunnel and engaged in the combat there, he shined a strobing flashlight at officers in an attempt to blind them and then threw a cup of an unknown liquid at them.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Kyle Fitzsimons
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Using a dangerous weapon on certain officers; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers;18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
Additional details: Resident of Lebanon, ME, arrested 2/4/21 by FBI Maine; Spoke of 'Great Replacement; additionally sentenced to 3 years supervised release
Short narrative: Kyle Fitzsimons, 37, of Lebanon, Maine, was charged with Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Using a dangerous weapon on certain officers; Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildingsfor his role in thei January 6th riot. Fitzsimons was seen on officer body camera footage assaulting officers and charging the police line. Fitzsimons pled not guilty, but was found guilty "of seven felony charges: one count of obstruction of an official proceeding; four counts of assaulting, resisting, or impeding law enforcement officers, including two involving a dangerous weapon or bodily injury; one count of interfering with a law enforcement officer during a civil disorder, and one count of engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds. He also was found guilty of four misdemeanor charges including: entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building or grounds; and committing an act of violence in the Capitol Building or grounds" (DOJ). Fitzsimons was sentenced to 7 years and 3 months in prison and 3 years supervised release.
Source description: Charging documents, Court Documents, Government Press and Release (DOJ), News article

Name of case: United States of America v. Johnson, et al.
Charges: *18:231(a)(3) and 2 - Civil disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) and 2 - Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; *18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) and 2 - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) and 2 - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) and 2 - Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) and 2 - Disorderly conduct in the Capitol grounds or buildings
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of St. Petersburg, FL; additionally sentenced to 36 months of supervised release
Short narrative: On May 25, 2022, Zachary Johnson, 33, of St. Petersburg, FL was accused in a federal indictment of entering the U.S. Capitol grounds on 1/6/2021 and engaging in disorderly conduct. The indictment is light on details, but it states that Johnson, a member of Tampa's affiliate of the Proud Boys, traveled from Florida to Washington D.C. with a group of other members to protest the certification of the 2020 Presidential Election. Johnson and other Proud Boys members were among the first to arrive at the U.S. Capitol Building, charging through barricades and breaching the cordoned-off perimeter. Dressed in tactical gear and acting alongside other Proud Boys members, Johnson participated in the heave-ho effort against law enforcement in the Lower West Terrace tunnel, carried pepper spray and sprayed an officer with it, and is alleged to have carried a sledgehammer.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles, Local News Articles, Government Reports and Release

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND State speech act
Name of case: United States of America v. Ralph Joseph Celentano III
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of NY; "Ralph Celentano Found guilty 6/12/23 in the District of Columbia on Monday, June 12, 2023, of multiple felony and misdemeanor charges, including assaulting law enforcement officers, for his actions during the breach of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021."; "Ralph Celentano sentenced to seventy-eight (78) months of incarceration, 3 years of supervised release, and $285 special assessment.
Short narrative: On May 25, 2022, Ralph Joseph Celentano III, 54, of Broad Channel, NY, was charged with assaulting an officer and other offenses relating to his participation in the January 6th riot at the United States Capitol. Celentano was recorded on body-cam and cell phone video assaulting a number of officers with his hands and a flagpole along the riot line on the Western Terrace. On another instance Celentano is seen pushing an officer from behind over a ledge on the side of the terrace, causing the officer to fall a considerable distance. The FBI managed to identify him after they received information relating him to a BOLO image. He was then found in social media posts of the Jenny Albert Sea Turtle Foundation, and law enforcement interviewed people associated with Celentano through that organization; one of these witnesses then pointed out Celentano in the images from January 6th.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Release

Charges:
1752(a)(1): Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Ground; 1752(a)(2): Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 5104(e)(2)(G): Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in
a Capitol Building
Additional details: Son also arrested
Short narrative: "Bradley Bokoski and his son Matthew, who is also charged, were inside the U.S. Capitol for just five minutes, court records indicate, but in that time, Matthew Bokoski took numerous photos and videos, including at least one that showed his father. In an interview in June of 2021, investigators say Bokoski confirmed that he went inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Surveillance cameras also allegedly captured Bokoski entering through the Senate parliamentarian's door. Bokoski was arrested in May of 2022." (NPR)
Source description: Charging documents, local news articles

Charges:
1752(a)(1): Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Ground; 1752(a)(2): Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 5104(e)(2)(G): Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in
a Capitol Building
Additional details: Father also arrested
Short narrative: "Matthew Bokoski and his father, Bradley, who is also charged, were inside the U.S. Capitol for about five minutes, but their time there was well-documented, court documents show. Prosecutors say Bokoski took photos and videos, including one showing his outfit, which included a red and blue “Trump 2020” flag on his back and a red and blue hat with a pompom on top. One of Bokoski’s Facebook posts, which the FBI says it uncovered through a search warrant, allegedly read “...only thing I’m guilty of is trespassing on federal property if you want to get down to it. I kept my distance from police and even thanked them for being out and making sure things don’t get insane.” Prosecutors say Bokoski confirmed his presence in the Capitol in an interview and shared photos with investigators. Bokoski also said in the interview that the rally was effective because it shut down government, court documents show. Bokoski was arrested in May of 2022." (NPR)
Source description: Charging documents, local news articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Barry Bennet Ramey
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of FL; additionally sentenced to 36 months supervised release and $2000 restitution
Short narrative: Barry Bennet Ramey, 38, of Plantation, Florida was arrested and charged for his participation in the riot at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. A member of the Proud Boys, Ramey came into conflict with U.S. Capitol Police officers on the west side of the building; he was part of the mob pushing against the officers attempting to stop them from climbing the stairwell from the Lower West Terrace to the Upper West Terrace. It is here that Ramey sprayed officers in the eyes with an orange chemical agent, causing disorientation and pain. Though video footage of the incident was captured, the officers were not able to identify the perpetrator of the attack due to the impairment of their vision at the time. Ramey was identified using cell phone location data provided by AT&T--which showed that the phone belonging to Ramey had been using the cell site servicing the U.S. Capitol Building, testimony from the manager of Hilton Arlington Hotel, and identification from a former neighbor. Ramey was then arrested on charges of assaulting police, engaging in physical violence on Capitol grounds, entering a restricted building and civil disorder.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News articles, Government Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Yvonne St Cyr
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) 2, Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Boise, Idaho; "Yvonne St. Cyr Found guilty 3/10/23 by a jury of the six charges filed against her."
Short narrative: "The FBI announced Thursday that Yvonne Orbin St. Cyr of Boise was arrested on a warrant from Washington, D.C., charged with entering a restricted building and disruptive and disorderly conduct on restricted grounds. Both charges are misdemeanors, with respective penalties of up to one year and up to six months in prison." AP News
Source description: Charging Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Thaddis Derone Johnson Jr.
Charges: 1752(a)(1): Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Ground; 1752(a)(2): Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 5104(e)(2)(G): Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: "Sentenced - 12/19/2022 to 24 months probation, 60 days home confinement, 60 hours community service, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: "On Jan. 8, 2021, the FBI obtained information that Thaddis Derone Johnson Jr. was at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, according to court records. The FBI interviewed Johnson shortly after, but he told the FBI he traveled to Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6 at “the request of United States President Donald Trump,” but did not enter the Capitol. In September of 2021, however, a confidential human source provided open-source video that showed Johnson near a door of the building, wearing a red “Keep America Great” hat. In addition, CCTV footage showed Johnson enter the building through the Northwest Side door and walk through the Capitol, including the Senate parliamentarian’s office. In May of 2022, the FBI interviewed Johnson again, who this time admitted entering the building and confirmed that he was indeed the man depicted in the photos taken from inside the building." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Levi Gable
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parade, Demonstrate, or Picket in any of the Capitol Buildings
Additional details: Resident of OK
Short narrative: "Gable posted about his experiences on Facebook, which an acquaintance promptly forwarded to the FBI. Gable's post stated he was among the first to make it inside the Capitol. "Capitol Police backed away from their stations and allowed protestors to make our way to the building," Gable wrote in the post. They wanted to protest Vice President Pence's statement that he would not challenge the results of the 2020 election, he said. Although his comments said the protest was peaceful, his video showed people yelling and chanting, court records show. During an interview with Gable on Jan. 21, 2021, the FBI said he repeatedly denied entering the building. However, the FBI found multiple photos of Gable in surveillance footage." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Horvath later bragged about participating in the event on Facebook where an individual tipped off the police about her participation. She was sentenced 11/4/22 to 36 months of probation, including 90 days of home confinement and 14 days at a residential facility, $500 restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Christopher Ray Grider
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Cvil disorder;18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstrcution of an official proceeding; 18:1361 Destruction of government property; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of TX; "Grider Sentenced 5/23/23 in the District of Columbia today to 83 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, a $812 fine."
Short narrative: Federal prosecutors say they first learned about Christopher Grider's alleged involvement in the Capitol riot because he gave an interview to a local TV station in Texas. "The president asked people to come and show their support. I feel like it’s the least that we can do. It’s kind of why I came from central Texas all the way to D.C.,” Grider told KWTX. Grider said he witnessed the police shooting of Ashli Babbitt, who was killed by a Capitol Police officer while trying to climb through a broken window inside the Capitol. Prosecutors allege that Grider handed his helmet to another rioter, who used the helmet to break the glass window that Babbitt then tried to climb through. Grider also allegedly "attempted to push open the doors and then kick the doors in an attempt to breach the entrance leading to House Chamber where members of Congress were located." Grider was arrested in Austin, Texas, on Jan. 21, 2021, and was indicted on multiple charges, including destruction of government property, on Jan. 26, 2021. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local news

Name of case: United States of America v. Rodney Kenneth Milstreed
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:113(a)(4) Assault by Striking, Beating or Wounding; 18:113(a)(5) Simple Assault; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of MD; 60 months in prison, 24 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $2,000 in restitution.
Short narrative: "Federal prosecutors allege that, in the days after the 2020 election, Rodney Milstreed messaged a friend on Facebook warning that things could get "ugly" in the country, along with a photo of multiple military-style rifles, ammunition and a medical kit. On Nov. 25, 2020, court documents state, he posted on Facebook, "I pray every night. I hope we dont have to hurt anyone. THESE JUDGES BETTER DO THE RIGHT THING." On Jan. 6, 2021, Milstreed allegedly threw a flagpole "javelin-style" at a group of Capitol Police officers guarding the outside of the U.S. Capitol. Later that day, Milstreed can allegedly be seen on video trying to move bike racks that police had set up as a barricade around the building and taking a smoke grenade that was on the ground on the side of the rioters and throwing it toward police. Milstreed then allegedly pulled and shoved a photographer working for The Associated Press, who was covering that day's events. That evening, prosecutors say, he messaged a Facebook friend, "We f***** them federal cops up." Milstreed was arrested on May 24, 2022, in Brighton, Colo." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Geoffrey Samuel Shough
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of TX; Sentenced 3/22/23 to 6 months prison, 12 months of supervised release, and restitution of $2,000.
Short narrative:
Geoffrey Samuel Shough, 37 of Texas, pled guilty to civil disorder for his involvement in the January 6 Capitol raid. He was sentenced to 6 months incarceration. 

"Geoffrey Shough is one of many suspects who appeared on one of the open source platforms trying to identify people who might have committed crimes on Jan. 6, 2021. Shough was given the hashtag name of #TexasPleather. He wore a cognac-colored jacket that looked like leather and carried a Texas flag in images that prosecutors allege he appears in. On the day of the riot, court documents claim that Shough can be seen “forcibly” entering the U.S. Capitol and that he was one of the first people to breach a line of law enforcement officers trying to prevent the group from getting inside. On cellphone footage obtained by the FBI, agents claim that he can be heard saying he’s from Austin, Texas. Court documents indicate that Shough was ultimately identified by the FBI through two tipsters who led them to his ex-girlfriend: When agents interviewed her, she said they’d broken up the week before. She allegedly told the FBI that Shough owned a cognac-colored jacket, had said he was interested in attending the “Stop the Steal” rally while in Washington, D.C., and later said she was “fairly certain” that images shown to her were of him. In those images, Shough can allegedly be seen with a decal on his helmet that matches the logo of the Oath Keepers, a far-right extremist organization. Prosecutors also say that financial records show a payment to “Oath Keepers” in December of 2020."
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local news article

Adam Jackson was also seen pushing police officers with a riot shield to force his way into the Capitol.

Name of case: United States of America v. Rutledge, Bostic, & Bostic
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of VA; Sentenced 3/9/2023 to 36 months probation and a $10 assessment
Short narrative: Karegan Bostic of Virginia breached the Capitol with her sister and father and was found guilty for her involvement in the Capitol Riot. She pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and was sentenced to 36 months probation. Her father and sister, William Bostic and Meghan Rutledge, were previously arrested in October or 2021 for their involvment. Two people who knew the defedant's sister had seen her post photos to Facebook reported her to the FBI. Federal investigators also used surveillance footage to identify Rutledge among the mob inside the building, according to the statement of facts. Those investigators found evidence that their father had communciated by phone with others in a convoy to plan and pack for the January 6 Capitol Riot.

Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Miami, FL; former national chairman of the Proud Boys; additionally sentenced to 36 months supervised release; sentenced with terrorism enhancement
Short narrative: On June 6, 2022, Enrique Tarrio, 38, of Miami, Florida, was charged with seditious conspiracy, conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding; obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting, conspiracy to prevent an officer from discharging any duties, civil disorder and aiding and abetting, two counts of destruction of government property and aiding and abetting, and two counts assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers for his involvement in the January 6 insurrection. Tarrio, former national chairman of the Proud Boys, organized the "Ministry of Self Defense," a sub-group of the Proud Boys that coordinated and organized travel to DC, and participation in the Capitol riot. Tarrio himself was not physically present at the Capitol riots, but communicated with them and posted on social media away from the action. Tarrio was charged with Dominic Pezzola, Ethan Nordean, Charles Joseph Donohoe, Zachary Rehl, and Joseph Randall Biggs. The five men, all members of the Proud Boys, participated in a conspiracy to encourage other members of the Proud Boys to travel to the Capitol for the January 6 riots, enter the Capitol Building and cause damage while inside, and attempted to cover up their communications regarding their coordination.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release, News Articles, Local News Articles

Additional details: Resident of Kernersville, NC; Leader of Proud Boys NC and 4th degree member; Donohoe pled guilty to one of two counts of 18:111(a)(1); Donohoe is not included in the most recent supersceding indictment as he previously pled guilty; "Charles Donohoe Sentenced 12/19/23 to forty (40) months of Incarceration on Count 1s, to run concurrently with Count 6s, followed by thirty-six (36) months of Supervised Release (with conditions) on Count 1s to run concurrently with Count 6s. $100 Special Assessment on Count 1s and Restitution in the amount of $2000.00. Count 6s: Defendant sentenced to forty (40) months of Incarceration on Count 6s, to run concurrently with Count 1s, followed by thirty-six (36) months of Supervised Release (with conditions) on Count 6s to run concurrently with Count 1s. $100 Special Assessment on Count 6s and Restitution in the amount of $2000.00."
Short narrative: Charles Joseph Donohoe, 33, of Kernersville, NC, was charged with Conspiracy to obstruct official proceeding; Obstruction of an official proceeding and Aiding and abetting; Obstructin of law enforcement during civil disorder and Aiding and abetting; two counts of Destruction of government property and Aiding and abetting; and two counts of Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers. Donohoe was charged along with Enrique Tarrio, Ethan Nordean, Dominic Pezzola, Zachary Rehl, and Joseph Randall Biggs. The five men, all members of the Proud Boys, encouraged and coordinated other Proud Boys to travel to the Capitol for the January 6 riots, entered the Capitol Building and caused damage while inside, and attempted to cover up their communications regarding their coordination. Their actions were motivated by their rightist: anti-government ideology. Donohoe took a plea agreement, pleading guilty to Conspiract to obstruct official proceeding and one count of Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers. [Note: Dominic Pezzola was initially charged with Michael J. Greene and William Joseph Pepe (Case ID: 04162021_MJG_PROUDBOYCAP3 and 04162021_WJP_PROUDBOYCAP2, but Pezzola was removed from the case. Pezzola was named 3/7/22 in superseding indictment for the 4PROUDBOYS case, replacing 1:21-cr-52, and named again in the supersceding indictment from 6/6/2022. Charles Donahoe is not included in the supersceding indictment from 6/6/2022, as he pled guilty earlier in the proceedings)

Name of case: United States of America v. Kash Lee Kelly
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(A) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of IL; Sentenced 11/10/22 to 70 days of incarceration, 12 months of supervised release, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: On June 7, 2022, Kash Lee Kelly, a "Trump-loving former Chicago-area Latin Kings gangster" was indicted for knowlingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; violent entry and disorderly conduct on capitol grounds. He was indicted with 11 other members of the Latin Kings in 2017 for running a drug-dealing ring, although he avoided the racketeering charges brought against his peers. He was sentenced for the unrelated drug charges after the January 2021 protests. The charges are based on widely publicized photos, Kelly's social media, and a recorded interview in which Kelly admits to entering the Capitol. He was sentenced 11/10/22 to 60 days of incarceration, $500 in restitution.
Source description: Charging documents, News Article, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. David Walls-Kaufman
Charges: 1752(a)(1): Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 1752(a)(2): Disorderly and Disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 5104(e)(2)(D): disorderly conduct in a capitol building; 5104(e)(2)(G): parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a capitol building
Short narrative: "David Walls-Kaufman came to the attention of the FBI after he was named in a civil lawsuit related to the Jan. 6, 2021 attack on the Capitol, court documents show. Screenshots used to identify Walls-Kaufman in that suit, found by the Sedition Hunters, showed Walls-Kaufman in what the FBI calls a “scuffle” with law enforcement. Prosecutors say he wore a red, white and black motorcycle jacket, which they say can also be seen in a youtube screenshot of Walls-Kaufman discussing his work as a chiropractor. Court documents say Walls-Kaufman appeared on body-worn camera footage and surveillance video, which show him inside the Capitol. Prosecutors say they were also able to confirm Walls-Kaufman’s phone number and that his cell phone used cell sites inside the Capitol. Walls-Kaufman was arrested in June of 2022." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Leticia Vilhena Ferreira
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of IL; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 10/6/22 to 14 days of incarceration, three years of supervised release, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Leticia Vilhena Ferreira was arrested and charged for her role in the January 6th Capitol protests. Ferreira was observed on CCTV footage entering the Crypt of the Capitol building and partaking in the activities around that area. She had sent numerous texts, videos, and pictures from her mobile phone from within the Capitol building showing her movements and actions, and was later identified by law enforcement fromt those phone records. She is a Brazilian national who is living in the US. It is unknown if she also possesses US citizenship
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Cronin et al.
Charges: 18:1362 Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Charged with brother Kevin and father; "Dylan Cronin Sentenced 9/8/23 to sixty (60) days incarceration as to count 1 and eight (8) months incarceration as to count 7, to run concurrent. Defendant further sentenced to twelve (12) months Supervised Release on counts 1 and 7 to run concurrent, Restitution in the amount of $500, and Special Assessments totaling $50."
Short narrative: On June 8, 2022, Dylan R. Cronin was issued a complaint with his brother Kevin and father Kevin for their involvement in the capitol riot. The three entered the Capitol, and Dylan was seen breaking glass of the Senate door with a piece of wood. The brothers also were seen on CCV footage smoking cigarettes inside the Capitol. Dylan was a member of the US Army Reserves.

Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;

Name of case: United States of America v. Anthony Michael Mazzio Jr.
Charges: 40:5104 (e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of AL; "Sentenced 10/5/22 to 60 days of incarceration, three years of probation, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Anthony Michael Mazzio Jr. was arrested for his role in the January 6th riot at the United States Capitol. Mazzio could be seen on CCTV footage, and in numerous cell phone videos, entering the building near the Rotunda and lingering in the building for roughly an hour before leaving. Mazzio could be seen in these videos wearing a full camouflage outfit, complete with a black plate carrier across his chest and carried a gas mask with him.

Name of case: United States of America v. Caldwell, et al.
Group affiliation: Oath Keepers; Ohio State Regular Militia
Charges: 18:371 Conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; 18:1361, 2 Destruction of government property and aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds;
Additional details: Resident of Morrow, OH; Wife of Bennie Parker; Sentenced to 60 months probation
Short narrative: "Sandra Parker, 60, and Bennie Parker, 70, both of Morrow, according to federal documents, were charged with conspiracy, destruction of government property (and aiding and abetting), obstruction of an official proceeding (and aiding and abetting) and restricted buildings or grounds. Specifically, Sandra Parker, dressed in a uniform consisting of camouflaged-combat attire, and, operating as a group with several other similarly-attired members of the Oath Keepers Militia, breached the U.S. Capitol, directly or indirectly damaged property of the Capitol and obstructed Congress’s proceedings. Bennie Parker, similarly dressed in a uniform consisting of camouflaged-combat attire, assisted Sandra Parker and other members of the Oath Keepers Militia by staying in communication with members inside the Capitol while Bennie Parker remained on the grounds of the Capitol.” (Springfield News-Sun) Sandra and Bennie are married.
Source description: Charging documents, court documents, local news articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Caldwell, et al.
Group affiliation: Oath Keepers; Ohio State Regular Militia
Charges: 18:371 Conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; 18:1361, 2 Destruction of government property and aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds;
Additional details: Resident of Morrow, OH; Husband of Sandra Parker; Sentenced to 60 months probation
Short narrative: "Sandra Parker, 60, and Bennie Parker, 70, both of Morrow, according to federal documents, were charged with conspiracy, destruction of government property (and aiding and abetting), obstruction of an official proceeding (and aiding and abetting) and restricted buildings or grounds. Specifically, Sandra Parker, dressed in a uniform consisting of camouflaged-combat attire, and, operating as a group with several other similarly-attired members of the Oath Keepers Militia, breached the U.S. Capitol, directly or indirectly damaged property of the Capitol and obstructed Congress’s proceedings. Bennie Parker, similarly dressed in a uniform consisting of camouflaged-combat attire, assisted Sandra Parker and other members of the Oath Keepers Militia by staying in communication with members inside the Capitol while Bennie Parker remained on the grounds of the Capitol.” (Springfield News-Sun) Sandra and Bennie are married.
Source description: Charging documents, court documents, local news articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Short narrative: On June 22, 2022, Florida Oathkeeper William Isaacs, 22, was charged in the eighth and final superseding indictment for one set of Oathkeeper defendants; each face multiple counts for their participation in the January 2021 Capitol protests. Specifically, after attending President Trump's rally at the Ellipse, Isaacs was part of the "stack one" group that illegally entered the United States Capitol in a stack formation, struggling with U.S. Capitol Police officers to get through the door and trying to enter the Senate chamber by doing the same. Short narrative: On June 22, 2022, in a final superseding indictment, Laura Steele, a former policewoman from High Point, North Carolina, was charged for her activities with the Oathkeepers at the United States Capitol on January 6, 2021. Specifically, after attending President Trump's rally at the Ellipse, Steele was part of the "stack one" group that suited up in tactical gear and illegally entered the United States Capitol in a stack formation, struggling with U.S. Capitol Police officers to get through the door and trying to enter the Senate chamber by doing the same. Steele collaborated with her Oathkeeper brother Graydon Young, arranging for him to fly from Florida to North Carolina, and then travel to the nation's capital with her from there.

Short narrative: On June 22, 2022, Connie Meggs, wife of Florida Oathkeepers chapter leader Kelly Meggs, was charged in the eighth and final superseding indictment for one set of Oathkeeper defendants; each face multiple counts for their participation in the January 2021 Capitol protests. Specifically, Connie was identified as part of the coalition of Oathkeepers that attended President Trump's rally at the Ellipse, then donned paramilitary gear and forced their way inside the U.S. Capitol in a stack formation, referring to themselves in group communications as "stack one." Once inside, Meggs was part of the group that headed towards the House of Representatives half of the building in search fo Nancy Pelosi. In the days leading up to the insurrection, Meggs, her husband, and several other Florida Oathkeepers joined together in a convoy from the Sunshine State to Washington D.C.; Meggs and her husband brought firearms with them and dropped them off with the Oathkeepers' Quick-Reaction Force (QRF) teams stationed in Virginia.

Short narrative: In a superseding indictment issued on June 22, 2022, Arizona Oath Keeper, Edward Vallejo, 63, was charged with coordinating an armed backup team outside of D.C. on January 6, 2021. While other members of the far-right organization took action on the steps of the U.S. Capitol, Vallejo was one of two Oath Keepers tasked with preparing the militia’s “quick reaction force,” which was stocked with weapons, ammunition and equipment at the Ballston Comfort Inn just across the river from D.C. They intended to supply their compatriots with these materials should the need arise.

Name of case: United States of America v. Raechel Genco
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) and (2) Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; 40:5104(e)(2)(d) Impeding, disrupting or disturbing the orderly conduct of a session of Congress or either house of Congress, or the orderly conduct in that building of a hearing before, or any deliberations of a committee of Congress or either house of Congress;
Additional details:
"Sentenced 9/27/22 to 12 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution.
"
Short narrative: Raechel Genco, 37, was charged with knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority. She traveled from Pennsylvania to D.C. with Ryan Samsel, and she can be seen in pictures and videos from that day crossing police barricades with him. Samsel led rioters across one of the police barricades and engaged in an altercation with law enforcement officials. Police were tipped off to Raechel Genco after they served a warrant to her and Samsel's shared residence. Genco was charged with a superseding bill in an agreement to plea guilty to a misdemeanor disrupting or disorderly conduct charge.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release, News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Josiah Hueso
Charges: 1752(a)(1): Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Ground; 1752(a)(2): Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 5104(e)(2)(G): Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Josiah Hueso Sentenced 8/8/23 to Thirty-Six (36) Months' Probation; A $10.00 Special Assessment is imposed; Restitution in the amount of 500.00 imposed."
Short narrative: "“A huge group of us stormed inside … we were basically shouting at the cops,” says Josiah Hueso in CNN footage shot outside the U.S. Capitol riot on Jan. 6, 2021, according to an FBI statement of facts. A tipster who’d known Hueso for some time sent a link of the video to the FBI, adding that they’d heard Hueso “brag” about his involvement at the Capitol, according to the statement. The FBI claims surveillance footage shows Hueso entering the Senate side of the Capitol and heading into the parliamentarian office at one point. People were picking up items inside the office, Hueso later told the FBI, but he says he told them not to steal anything. He was arrested May 25, 2022, in San Diego." (NPR)
Source description: Charging documents, local news articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Hatchet Speed
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Remaining in a Restricted Building With Intent to Impede or Disrupt Official Functions; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct on the Capitol Grounds, Parading in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Purchased $50K worth of firearms following Jan 6; Indicted via Bill of Information; "Hatchet Speed found guilty 3/7/23 following a bench trial."; Expressed anti-Jewish/pro-Hitler beliefs and praise for Eric Rudolph, and Ted Kaczynski. Defendant sentenced to a term of Forty-Eight (48) Months of Incarceration on Count 1s, a term of Twelve (12) Months of Incarceration on Counts 2s and 3s, a term of Six (6) Months of Incarceration on Counts 4s and 5s, with all terms to run concurrently, and consecutively to 22-cr-165, from the United States District Court, for the Eastern District of Virginia, followed by a term of Thirty-Six (36) Months of Supervised Release on Count 1s, a term of Twelve (12) Months on Counts 2s and 3s, with all terms to run concurrently. Special Assessment of $100 imposed on Count 1s, $25 imposed on Counts 2s and 3s, $10 imposed on Counts 4s and 5s, for a total of $170. Restitution in the amount of $2,000. Fine in the amount of $10,000
Short narrative: Hatchet M. Speed, born Daniel Abraham Speed, is a Petty Officer First Class in the US Naval Reserves assigned to the Naval Warfare Space Field Activity. He also worked as a defense contractor conducting "advanced analysis for the DOD" and other federal agencies. Speed is charged with his connection to the January 6 riot at the US Capitol. IN conversations with an undercover FBI agent, Speed expressed anti-government, anti-semitic positions including opposition to BLM and anti-fascists, and plans to attack members of the ADL. He praised domestic terrorist Eric Rudolph and the so-called Unabomber, and spoke of browsing Telegram as a source of radicalization. He blamed antifascists for breaching the Capitol. He claimed to have been present at the Capitol with friends who were Proud Boys, and although it does not appear he was a 'patched' member, he at times claimed affiliation with the Proud Boys.
Source description: Charging Documents, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Robinson, et. al.
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of SC; husband, brother-in-law, and father-in-law also arrested; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Brittany Robinson Sentenced 8/2/23 to Thirty (30) days incarceration, no term of supervised release was imposed. Special Assessment of $10.00 and Restitution in the amount of $500.00."
Short narrative: On July 20, 2022, Brittany Nicole Robinson, 29, was charged in a bill of information for her involvement in the Capitol riot. Her husband and 3 other family members were charged with her as co-defendants, were some of the first to breach the line of police to gain access to the Capitol, and were in the group closest to the internal House door. Photos captured from Capitol surveillance footage and a Facebook post of a family gathering corroborate their identity and provide evidence of their involvement in some of the more notable moments of the riot at the U.S. Capitol. For example, one of the members of the family, Benjamin Scott Robinson, attempted to break through the internal House door in the moments before Ashli Babbit was shot and killed by law enforcement. The family departed the building soon afterwards.
Source description: Charging Documents,Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Release (DOJ), Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Robinson, et. al.
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of SC, children and daughter-in-law also arrested; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Linwood Robinson Sr. Sentenced 8/13/23 to Sixty (60) days incarceration, Special Assessment of $10.00 and Restitution in the amount of $500.00 was ordered."
Short narrative: On July 20, 2022 Linwood Alan Robinson I was charged in a bill of information for his involvement in the Capitol riot. He and 4 other family members, 3 of which were charged with him as co-defendants, were some of the first breach the line of police to gain access to the Capitol and were in the group closest to the internal House door. Photos captured from Capitol surveillance footage and a Facebook post of a family gathering corroborate their identity and provide evidence of their involvement in some of the more notable moments of the riot at the U.S. Capitol. For example, one of the members of the family, Benjamin Scott Robinson, attempted to break through the internal House door in the moments before Ashli Babbit was shot and killed by law enforcement. The family departed the building soon afterwards.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Release (DOJ), Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Tyler Earl Ethridge
Charges: 231(a)(3): Civil disorder; 1361: Destruction of government property; 1512(c)(2): obstruction of an official proceeding; 1752(a)(1): entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 1752(a)(2): disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building; 5104(e)(2)(G): parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a capitol building
Short narrative: On July 7, 2022, a complaint was issued against Tyler Earl Ethridge for his participation in the Capitol insurrection. Ethridge, a pastor, was seen removing gates that barricaded the protestors from the Capitol, he was seen climbing a media scaffolding urging other rioters to move forward. He also took videos inside the rotunda and posted them to his social media after the event.
Source description: Charging documents, press release, local news article

Rodriguez was pictured in and around the Capitol building on the day of the riot. He was pictured in front of a "Black Lives Matter sign" bending down with his knee on top of the neck of another protestor, mocking the death of George Floyd. He also gave himself up to the FBI by calling them in an attempt to "clear his name".
Source description: Charging documents, local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Landon Manwaring
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of UT; Mother also arrested; "Sentenced 11/28/22 to 30 days of incarceration, 35 months of probation, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: On August 10, 2022, Landon Manwaring, 32, was charged in a bill of information for his involvement in the Capitol raid. He was only charged with one offense: Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. Records show that Manwaring traveled to the Capitol with his mother to Washington, D.C. and attended an event on January 5, 2021 encouraging them to attend the rally the next day. After attending President Trump's rally at the ellipse, the two of them followed the other rallygoers to the Capitol, entered the building through the Senate Wing Door, and paraded about the building for about thirty minutes before leaving. Evidence shows that Manwaring saw damage, posed for photos, and took photos of other rioters but did not participate in the violence himself.
Source description: Charging Documents, Database, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release

Additional details: Resident of OH; Husband also arrested
Short narrative: On August 10, 2022, a complaint was issued against Donald and Shawndale Chilcoat for their participation in the capitol riot. The Chilcoat's were pictures, via themselves and via security footage, outside and inside the Capitol building. They also took pictures of themselves and others on the Senate floor. Shawndale Chilcoat posted multiple times on her Facebook explaining how her and her husband had gotten in the building, posted photos of them inside the building and on the Senate floor, and as well took and posted videos of other rioters in and outside the Capitol building.

Name of case: United States of America v. Benjamin Cole et. al.
Group affiliation: Three Percenters (III Percenters, 3%ers), Guardians of Freedom
Charges: 18:23l(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(l) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2)Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds
Additional details: Resident of FL; "Benjamin Cole Sentenced 10/3/23 to a term of Forty-Eight (48) Months of Probation, including Three (3) Months of Location Monitoring. The defendant must complete 40 hours of community service within 12 months. Special Assessment of $100. Restitution imposed in the amount of $2,000."
Short narrative: On August 16, 2022, a complaint was issued against Benjamin Cole, 38, of Leesburg, John Edward Crowley, 50, of Windermere, Brian Preller, 33, of Mount Dora, and Jonathan Rockholt, 38, of Palm Coast, and Tyler Bensch, 20, of Casselberry, Florida. All defendants are charged with the same felony charges of Civil Disorder and Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The first four defendants are also charged with Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The men all "self identify as part of “three percenters” (AKA “3%ers”, “III%ers”, or “Threepers”) based on their adherence to the sub-ideology or common belief known as Three Percenterism." These defendants "are also self-identified members of a Guardians of Freedom subgroup called B SQUAD" (DOJ Press Release).
Source description: Charging Documents, Government Releases and Reports, News articles

Other names/aliases: Mateo Q Capsel (FACEBOOK), Matthew Caspel, mateoqcapsel (TIKTOK)
Name of case: United States of America v. Mathew Capsel
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) and (4) Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; *18:111 Forcibly assaulted resisted, opposed, impeded intimidated, or interfered with any officer or employee of the US or of any agency in any branch of the US government while engaged in or on account of the performance of official duties; 18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Expressed support for QAnon; "Sentenced 12/16/22 to 18 months in prison, ordered to pay restitution in the amount of $2,000 and was ordered to complete 24 months of supervised release."
Short narrative: On January 6th, 2021, Mathew Capsel, partook in breaking and entering the Capitol building. From videos posted on social media, Capsel was shown fighting against National Guardsmen attempting to hold the line with riot shields until he was pepper sprayed. The FBI said that two witnesses, over the span of five days, came forward and identified Mathew Capsel (born in 1993) as a Capitol rioter, submitting screenshots of his “Mateo Q Capsel” Facebook profile. A Twitter profile with the name “Mathew Capsel” indicates that “Mateo Q” is a reference to QAnon.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release, News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Jonathan Copeland
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b)- Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon or Inflicting Bodily Injury; 18:231(a)(3)- Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1)- Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2)- Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4)- Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D)- Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G)- Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of OH; "Jonathan Copeland Convicted 5/8/24 of six felonies and two misdemeanor offenses in U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia following a bench trial"
Short narrative: On August 24, 2022, a complaint was issued against Jonathan Joseph Copeland, 28 of Ohio. "According to court documents, on Jan. 6, 2021, Copeland was among rioters who illegally entered the Capitol grounds, advancing past barricades. He failed to stay back despite commands from law enforcement officers. He moved to an area near the scaffolding and joined other rioters in pushing a large, metal sign into a line of law enforcement officers. He shoved the sign into officers attempting to secure the area. He then walked into the Senate Doors and moved through areas including the Crypt and Capitol Visitor Center" (DOJ Press Release)
Source description: Charging Documents, Government Releases and Reports, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Kellye Sorelle
Charges: 18:1512(k) Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1512(b)(2)(A)-(B) Obstruction of Justice–Tampering with Documents
Additional details: Resident of TX
Short narrative: "Kellye SoRelle has worked as an attorney for the far-right anti-government militia known as the Oath Keepers, though she does not represent any of the Oath Keepers currently facing criminal charges connected to the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol. Footage taken by a documentary filmmaker on Jan. 5, 2021, shows SoRelle at a meeting in a Washington, D.C., parking garage along with Stewart Rhodes, the founder and leader of the Oath Keepers, and Enrique Tarrio, then the leader of the far-right group the Proud Boys. Both Rhodes and Tarrio have been charged with seditious conspiracy. Federal prosecutors allege that SoRelle conspired to prevent the certification of the electoral college vote on Jan. 6 and entered restricted grounds outside the U.S. Capitol. Prosecutors also allege that on Jan. 7, 2021, SoRelle "did corruptly persuade and attempted to corruptly persuade" people to withhold or destroy documents or other records that were subject to a grand jury investigation. SoRelle was arrested on Sept. 1, 2022, in Junction, Texas." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Henos Woldemichael
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of VA
Short narrative: On September 19, 2022, Henos Woldenmichael was charged with Civil Disorder, Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building at the Capitol riot on January 6, 2021. Woldenmichael apparently barricaded a door to prevent police officers from getting through and took a selfie video stating, "see grandkids, this is what it’s all about. This is why you’re free. All these great patriots."
Source description: Court Documents, Press Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Roger Kent Baugh
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil disorders
Additional details: Resident of KY; "Sentenced 1/24/23 to 12 months and a day in prison, $2,000 restitution and 24 months of supervised release."
Short narrative: On September 20, 2022, Roger Kent Baugh, 51, was charged with civil disorders after he attended the Capitol riot on January 6, 2021 with a friend that he knew to be carrying a firearm. Baugh participated in a heave-ho effort against law enforcement officers with a group of other rioters in a tunnel area leading into the building.
Source description: Charging Documents,Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Release (DOJ), Local News Article

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND State speech act
Name of case: United States of America v. Joseph P. Leyden
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and *(b) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; *18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder; *18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Brother also arrested; "Joseph Leyden Sentenced 9/6/23 to six months in prison and 12 months of supervised release"
Short narrative: On September 21, 2022, Joseph and Daniel Leyden were indicted for their participation in the riot at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. Daniel was photographed and videoed with a group of protestors shoving and pushing police officers to the ground, using barricades as weapons to pin them to the ground. Daniel was also seen charging a police officer with other rioters. Joseph is videoed charging a Capitol police officer and knocking them to the ground, as well as participating with other rioters to knock police officers to the ground. The statement of facts states that "several" law enforcement officials were injured in this altercation, including one who was knocked unconscious.
Source description: Charging Documents, News Articles, Government Reports and Release, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Antonio Lamotta
Charges: 1752(a)(1)- Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 1752(a)(2)- Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 5104(e)(2)(D)- Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 5104(e)(2)(G)- Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of VA; "Antonio Lamotta Found GUILTY 3/21/24 at bench trial on counts 1s, 4s and 5s. COURT VERDICT of NOT GUILTY on counts 2s and 3s."
Short narrative: On August 8, 2022, a complaint was issued against Antonio LaMotta for his participation in the Capitol insurrection. LaMotta, who was previously arrested for bringing a car full of guns to a 2020 election vote re-counting, was pictured inside the captiol on security footage as well as in the rotunda. He was also pictured outside with other rioters. His lawyers originally tried to argue he was never inside the captiol, that was prior to pictures of him in the capitol were released. "Antonio Lamotta Sentenced 9/11/24 to six months in prison, 24 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $2,000 in restitution."
Source description: Charging documents, news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Mikhail Edward Slye
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds;18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;

Source description: Charging Documents, News Article, Press Release

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND Supports organized political violence AND State speech act
Name of case: United States of America v. Jeremy Bertino
Charges: 18:2384 Seditious Conspiracy; 18:922(g)(1) Unlawful Possession of Firearm
Additional details: Resident of SC; Required to cooperate in trial of other Proud Boys as part of plea agreement.
Short narrative: On October 6, 2022, Jeremy Bertino was indicted with Seditious conspiracy and unlawful possession of a firearm after he was found to be planning an attack of over one hundred Proud Boys with the "Ministry of Self Defense" for several months leading up to the attack on the Capitol building on January 6th. Bertino had previously served as the Vice President of his local Proud Boys chapter. Bertino was injured in a physical altercation in December 2020 so he did not attend the riot himself, but encouraged the group via social media while the attack was in progress.
Source description: Court Documents, Press Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Justin Dee Adams
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder;
Short narrative: "Justin Dee Adams, who owns a gun shop, was arrested after he was reportedly identified as an individual seen in body cam footage assaulting police and removing a makeshift barricade law enforcement was using to prevent rioters from entering the building." (KUTV News)
Source description: Court Documents, Governmental Press Release, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Darrell Neely
Charges: *18:231(a)(3), 2 Civil disorder; 18:641 - Theft of government property; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of DC; "Darrell Neely sentenced to an aggregate of 28 months in prison: 12 months (1 year) on each of Counts 2s, 3s, and 4s. Counts 2s and 3s shall run consecutively with each other; Count 4s shall run concurrently with Counts 2s and 3s; and 4months on each of Counts 5s and 6s. Counts 5s and 6s shall run concurrently with each other, and consecutively to Counts 2s and 3s, with credit for time served. Special Assessment of $25 on Counts 2s, 3s, 4s and $10 on Counts 5s and 6s (for a total of $95). Restitution $844.93."
Short narrative: Right-wing radio host, Darrell Neally was arrested and charged for his participation in the January 2021 Capitol protests. One of his charges includes stealing a baseball cap from a US Capitol police officer. It was also alleged that he stole china plates from inside the building as well. He came to the attention of the FBI after they received a tip identifying him by name; indeed, one of the men in open-source footage and closed circuit images from the riot at the U.S. Capitol matched the description of Neely pulled from internal law enforcement databases. Witnesses also claimed that Neely had, in meetings following the events, bragged about taking clothing belonging to U.S. Capitol police officers and some of the aforementioned items from inside the building. On his website, Neely claims to be a former military serviceman. Neely was charged with charges of civil disorder, theft of government property, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct inside a Capitol building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Cramer & Cramer
Charges: 1752(a)(1)- Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 1752(a)(2)- Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 5104(e)(2)(D)- Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 5104(e)(2)(G)- Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Brother also arrested; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Country Cramer sentenced to Four Years Probation; $500.00 Restitution."
Short narrative: On July 1, 2022, a complaint was issued against brothers Eric and Country Cramer for their participation in the Capitol insurrection. They were pictured outside the Capitol doors with a crowd pushing their way inside, they were also pictured inside the Capitol wandering the halls. Eric Cramer also posted on Facebook (and his daughter reposted on Twitter) that he had stolen a police baton and claimed it was his "trophy".
Source description: Charging documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Andrew Johnson
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL; Defendant has federal and state cases;
Short narrative: On October 21, 2022, Andrew Paul Johnson was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building on January 6, 2021. He broke in to the Capitol building during the riot through a broken window and was arrested for being out past the 12-hour curfew put in place by DC's mayor the night of the riot.

Name of case: United States of America v. David Rene Arredondo
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of TX; "David Arredondo Sentenced 8/8/24 to Thirty-Three (33) months as to each Counts 1s and 2s, Twelve (12) months as to each Counts 3s through 5s and Six (6) months as to each Counts 6s through 8s, with all terms to run concurrently. The Defendant is further sentenced to serve a Thirty-Six (36) month term of supervised release as to each of Counts 1s and 2s and Twelve (12) months as to each of Counts 3s through 5s, with all terms to run concurrently. In addition, the Defendant is ordered to pay restitution in the amount of $2,000 and a special assessment in the amount of $100 for each of Counts 1s and 2s, $25 for each of Counts 3s through 5s and $10 for Counts 6s through 8s, for a total of $305."
Short narrative: On October 24, 2022, David Rene Arredondo was charged after participating in the Capitol riot and assaulting a police officer who was trying to stop rioters from entering the building. Arredondo was identified through surveilance footage in the Capitol, as well as phone records that placed him in the Capitol for nearly 40 minutes on January 6, 2021.
Source description: Charging Documents, Press Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Joseph Howe
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; *18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; *18:1361 2, Destruction of Government Property; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Magnolia, KY; "Joseph Howe Sentenced 10/20/23 to 50 months in prison, 12 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $2,000 in restitution"
Short narrative: On January 6, 2021, Joseph Howe, 41, travelled from Kentucky to the Capitol to attend the Stop the Seal Rally. He wore a plate carrier vest and goggles. Howe entered the building through scaffolding and grabbed a riot shield out of the hands of a Capitol Police Officer. Howe deployed pepper spray against other police. Howe also deployed a fire extinguisher on an officer. Howe was arrested on October 28, 2022, pled guilty on August 1, 2023, to obstructing an official proceeding and assaulting, resisting, or impeding law enforcement officers. He was sentenced on October 20, 2023 to 50 months in prison, 12 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $2,000 in restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Release, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Chase Allen
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of physical violence on U.S. Capitol grounds
Additional details: Resident of MA; Sentenced to 36 months probation, 14 days intermittent confinement, and ordered to pay $500 restitution
Short narrative: Chase Kevin Allen, 26, from Seekonk, Massachucetts is charged with federal crimes for his connection in the Capitol raid on January 6, 2021. A video documentarian who traveled to Washington, D.C. to document President Trump's "Stop the Steal" rally, Allen returned to the U.S. Capitol Building later in the day after learning of the protestors gathering there. Although the record shows that he never entered the building with the rest of the rioters, Allen joined in attacking the expensive equipment left behind by members of the media, shouting at the members of the media to leave as he did so.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Wyatt & Therres
Charges: 18:111(a) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers or Employees; 18:231(a)(3) - Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) - Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) -Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;
Additional details: Resident of MD; Stepfather also arrested; "Therres Sentenced 4/24/23 to 40 months in prison. 36 months of supervised release and restitution of $2,000."
Short narrative: "Douglas Wyatt, 49, and his stepson, Jacob Michael Therres, 25, both of Fallston, Maryland, are charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers, and interfering with law enforcement officers during a civil disorder, both felonies, and five related misdemeanor offenses. They were arrested on Nov. 14, 2022...According to court documents, on the afternoon of Jan. 6, 2021, Wyatt was involved in multiple assaults of law enforcement officers with a chemical spray on the Lower West Terrace of the Capitol. He also shouted numerous obscenities at officers and helped pull away another rioter’s flag from an officer who attempted to grab it. Wyatt also handed a long, heavy plank to Therres, who used it to strike an officer in the head. The officer has experienced lingering medical effects from the blow to the head. Therres also sprayed a chemical irritant towards a line of officers." (DOJ press release)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Dale Huttle & Matthew Huttle
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct or disruptive conduct in the Capitol grounds or buildings; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in any of the Capitol buildings
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of IN; Uncle also arrested; "Matthew Huttle Sentenced 11/28/23 to a term of 6 months. The Defendant is further sentenced to serve a term of 12 months of supervised release, to pay a $25 special assessment and $500 in restitution."
Short narrative: On December 14, 2022, Matthew Huttle, 40, was charged with several federal offenses alongside his uncle Dale Huttle, 61, after participating in the Capitol riot on January 6, 2021. Dale Huttle struck two police officers with a flagpole as a metal barricade to keep rioters out of the Capitol building were knocked down. Dale was also seen trying to steal an officer's baton and shouting "Surrender!" about a half hour later. Although he was not linked to any violent acts, Matthew entered the Capitol building twice, illegally walking about the interior inside for less than twenty minutes before leaving out of a broken window.
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental reports and release, Court Documents, Local News Articles
