Name of case: United States of America v. Edward Kelley
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1361 Destruction of Government Property [2 COUNTS]; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(4), 2 Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:231(a)(3) 2, Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting;
Additional details: Resident of TN; 4th person to enter the Capitol via broken window
Short narrative: "According to court documents, a witness told the FBI they drove a man named Ed from Tennessee to Washington, D.C., on the day before the riot at the request of their pastor. The pair allegedly stayed in separate rooms of a hotel and then drove back to Tennessee on the day after the riot. Hotel and financial records belonging to Edward Kelley allegedly support that witness's claim. The FBI interviewed Kelley in June of 2021, during which he said he was near the Capitol but did not go inside. But prosecutors say video from the riot and other evidence allegedly show Kelley helping to throw a U.S. Capitol Police officer to the ground, pushing on a metal barricade against law enforcement, breaching a window with a piece of wood, and being confronted by Capitol Police Officer Eugene Goodman. Prosecutors estimate Kelley spent about 40 minutes inside the Capitol, including in the Senate gallery and the rotunda. He was arrested in May of 2022." (NPR)
Source description: Court docments, local news articles, governmental reports and releases (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Scott Miller
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:641 Theft of government property; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of MD; "Scott Miller Sentenced 4/19/24 to Sixty-Six (66) months of incarceration, followed by Thirty-Six (36) months of supervised release. Special assessment of $100. Restitution of $2000."
Short narrative: "Scott Miller, 36, of Smithsburg, Maryland, is charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers, civil disorder, theft of government property, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings, and an act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings. He was arrested this morning in Smithsburg, Maryland and is expected to make his initial appearance later today in the District of Columbia. According to court documents, on Jan. 6, 2021, Miller was among a mob illegally massed on the Lower West Terrace and in an Archway and tunnel that leads into the Capitol Building. At approximately 4:27 p.m., he entered the area near the tunnel. Law enforcement officers had formed a protective line with riot shields at the entrance to the tunnel in efforts to keep the rioters outside. Miller advanced until he was positioned immediately in front of the police line. He then swung and struck a police officer with a long wooden pole. At approximately 4:31 p.m., Miller was positioned on the steps of the Lower West Terrace, holding what appears to be a baton or stick. He threw the item towards the entrance to the tunnel, where a line of police officers was positioned. He then threw at least three other items, including a large audio speaker, at the line of police officers. At approximately 4:33 p.m., Miller again positioned himself immediately in front of the police line. He then swung a large pole or stick multiple times, striking a number of officers in the police line. Shortly thereafter, Miller grabbed a police riot shield which was being held by two police officers, and forcibly pulled the shield away from the officers. Miller took the shield into the crowd on the Lower West Terrace and handed it to another rioter." (DOJ press release)
Source description: Charging Documents

Additional details: Resident of MI; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Deborah Kuecken Sentenced 6/9/23 to 36 months (3 years) of Probation and ordered to pay $500 in restitution and a $10 special assessment. All remaining counts are DISMISSED on the Government's motion."
Short narrative: On October 21, 2022, Deborah Kuecken was charged with Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority, Knowingly Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds and Violently Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building on January 6th, 2021 along with her brother, Gary Francis Smith. The FBI obtained images of Kuecken from the Michigan Secretary of State and Facebook and compared them to images of her at the Capitol riot to positively identify her, along with a positive identification of her from the same images at the Capitol by Smith's son.

Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Sherman Oaks, CA; "Eric Christie Sentenced 12/1/23 to time served and thirty-six (36) months of supervised release."
Short narrative: On January 4, 2023, Eric Christie was indicted for Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon, and Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon at the Capitol riot on January 6, 2021 after yelling things like "it's a MAGA party" and "this is our capitol" into a bullhorn with a claw hammer tucked into his belt buckle outside of the building. According to an FBI interview with a friend days after the attack, Christie ran into him in DC, they went back to his hotel to watch President Trump's speech, and Christie joined the riot later in the day.
Source description: Court Documents, News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Deborah Anne Kuecken, Gary Francis Smith
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 40;5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of MI; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Gary F Smith Sentenced 6/9/23 to 36 months (3 years) of Probation and ordered to pay $500 in restitution and a $10 special assessment. All remaining counts are DISMISSED on the Government's motion."
Short narrative: On October 21, 2022, Gary Francis Smith was charged with Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority, Knowingly Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds and Violently Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building on January 6th, 2021 along with his sister, Deborah Kuecken. The FBI obtained records from Smith's phone that indicated he was at the Capitol at the time of the riot, and an image of him from his driver's license photo that helped positively identify him in a photo at the Capitol, along with a positive identification of him from the same images at the Capitol by his son.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Isaiah Farnsworth
Charges: 18:1361 Destruction of government property; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of CO; "Farnsworth Sentenced 9/8/23 to three months in prison and 36 months of supervised release for one felony count of destruction of government property."
Short narrative: On January 4, 2023, Isaiah Farnsworth, 44, of Broomfield, Colorado was charged for his actions at the United States Capitol on January 6, 2021. The FBI became aware of him after they received of tip that included a video of him boasting about his participation in the riot at a gathering. The FBI then looked into him and found images taken at the event on his Facebook page; also found there was a video dated January 6 in which a person believed to be Farnsworth can be heard saying "“We have a right to be at our house,” “We have a right to be on our lawn,” “We have a right to bring our grievances to the government,” and “Never, never be passive about such a powerful government any longer.” Other videos posted there further confirmed Farnsworth's presence at the U.S. Capitol on the day in question. Security footage from within the United States Capitol show the individual identified as Farnsworth entering the building and helping others to breach an interior door, breaking it. He then exited the U.S. Capitol through the same door he had entered through.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Zachariah John Sattler
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of MD; Defendant is hereby committed to the custody of the Bureau of Prisons for a term of thirty (30) days as to Count 4; Sentenced 7/27/23 to Twenty-Four (24) month term of probation, a special assessment of $10 and restitution in the amount of $500.
Short narrative: On December 9, 2022, Zachariah John Sattler was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building after attending the Capitol riot on January 6, 2021 and smoking marijuana in the Capitol building. Sattler reportedly vomitted and took a video of it, bragging that he "threw up on the Capitol."
Source description: Charging Document, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Gabriel Morgan Brown
Charges: 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence on U.S. Capitol grounds
Additional details: Resident of Bayville, NY; Participated in attacks on media stationed at Capitol; Sentenced To Twenty (20) Days Incarceration Followed By A Supervised Release Period Of One (1) Year With A Special Assessment Of $35.00 And Restitution In The Amount Of $500.00;
Short narrative: Gabriel Morgan Brown, 38, of Bayville, NY, was charged with destruction of property in special maritime and territorial jurisdiction and aiding and abetting; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; and act of violence on the U.S. Capitol grounds for his role in the January 6th riot. Brown filmed and posted his participation in the riot to his YouTube channel, GB0083. Brown was recorded destroying media equipment, and making statements advocating for the riot and against the media. Brown is described as a "Proud Boys supporter" in several media reports, but it is not clear that he was officially initiated into the organization.
Source description: Court Document, Local News Articles, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Frank R. Giustino
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of NY; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Frank Giustino Sentenced 11/21/23 to ninety (90) days incarceration, a $10 Special Assessment, and Restitution totaling $500 on count 4."
Short narrative: “Shooting tear gas at us at the capitol (sic). Real nice civil servants,” wrote Long Island-based massage therapist Frank Giustino. He allegedly posted that message to Facebook on Jan. 6, 2021, according to screenshots his former high school classmate sent to the FBI. An FBI affidavit claims Giustino also posted to the group-chatting platform Discord under the handle “President-Elect Frankie G” throughout the day, reiterating: “They’re firing tear gas at us.” The FBI claims surveillance footage shows Giustino passing through the U.S. Capitol’s crypt, rotunda and other areas throughout a 20-minute period on Jan. 6, 2021. He was arrested on Jan. 11, 2022, in Kings Park, N.Y. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Moss."
Short narrative: Joseph Irwin, resident of KY, has been arrested and charged for his role in the January 2021 Capitol protests. Irwin has been charged with unlawful entry and disorderly conduct in a restricted building and disorderly conduct and parading/demonstrating in the Capitol building.

Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;

Short narrative: Saul Llamas, 29, his girlfriend, Jordan Siemers, 25, and his best friend, Ryan Swoope, 28, were arrested and charged for their role in the January 6 Capitol Raid. Siemers pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and was sentenced to 12 months probation.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Llamas, Swoope, & Siemers
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of OH; "Saul Llamas Sentenced 9/11/23 to a term of Eighteen (18) Months of Probation, 120 hours of community service, Special Assessment of $10. Restitution imposed in the amount of $500. Fine imposed in the amount of $2,500."
Short narrative: Saul Llamas, 29, his girlfriend, Jordan Siemers, 25, and his best friend, Ryan Swoope, 28, were arrested and charged with Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Obstruction of Law Enforcement during Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following their participation in the Capitol riot. He pled guilty, and was sentenced on September 11, 2023, to 18 months of probation, 20 hours of community service, Special Assessment of $10, Restitution imposed in the amount of $500, and Fine imposed in the amount of $2,500.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Article, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Llamas, Swoope, & Siemers
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of OH; Sentenced on 1/9/2024 to 51 Months of Incarceration; 24 Months of Supervised Release; Special Assessment of $100; Restitution of $2,000
Short narrative: Saul Llamas, 29, his girlfriend, Jordan Siemers, 25, and his best friend, Ryan Swoope, 28, were arrested and charged for their invovelment in the January 6 Capitol Raid. Swoope pled guilty to Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and was sentenced to 51 months incarceration. He sprayed a Capitol police officer with an orange substance, causing the officer to cough and his eyes to water. The case was investigated by the FBI’s Cleveland and Washington Field Offices, which identified Swoope as BOLO (Be on the Lookout) Assault on Federal Officer (AFO) #486 on its seeking information photos. Valuable assistance was provided by the U.S. Capitol Police and the Metropolitan Police Department.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Article

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND Supports organized political violence

Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) and (a)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds resulting in significant bodily injury; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL
Short narrative: On January 19th, 2023 Kenneth J. Bonawitz was charged with several felonies relating to the January 6th riots. Bonawitz physically assaulted several police officers at the Capitol. He leaped and tackled two officers, grabbed an officer by their mask, elbowed an officer in the abdomen, and attempted to head butt another officer.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Victor Martinez
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of San Antonio, TX; "Victor Martinez Sentenced 7/18/23 to fourteen (14) days of incarceration, twelve (12) months of probation, $500 restitution and $10 special assessment."
Short narrative: On January 20, 2023, Victor Anthony Martinez was charged with several felonies related to his participation in the January 6th riot. Martinez was identified based on warrants served to his cellular service provider--which found that his cell phone was connected to the cell site servicing the interior of the U.S. Capitol Building at the time in question--as well as several photos and videos showing his presence in the building during the riot.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Bobby Wayne Russell
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; *18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder; *18:1752(a)(1)- Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2)- Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(F)- Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of AK; "Bobby Russell Sentenced 11/17/23 to twelve (12) months and one (1) day of incarceration and twenty four (24) months of supervised release. he first six (6) months of supervised release shall be served on home detention."
Short narrative: On January 25, 2023, an indictment was issued against Bobby Wayne Russell, 48 of Arkansas for his involvement in the Capitol raid. His presence is corroborated by cell phone data and video surveillance. Russell was among the rioters who grappled with police officers around a line of bike racks acting as barricades. He resisted the officers' efforts to get him to back away, and clung to the racks as he was pepper sprayed. Russell grabbed one of the officers by their jacket as he was knocked down, pulling the officer with him down a short flight of stairs. Later, Russell was seen pushing against the riot shields of other officers when he refused their order to move back, saying to the officers "There’s more of us than you guys, you’re gonna lose."
Source description: Charging Documents, Government Releases and Reports, News Articles, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Timothy Wayne Williams
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building; 18:641 Theft of Government Property
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of CO; Sentenced to 6 months imprisonment on two counts to run concurrently, along with $500 restitution.
Short narrative: On January 30, 2023, Timothy Wayne Williams, 39, of Trinidad, Colorado, was charged with numerous federal offenses for his activities at the United States Capitol on January 6, 2021. Evidently, Williams headed towards the U.S. Capitol Building after attending the "Stop the Steal" rally at the Ellipse, and he entered the building as part of the first wave of rioters through the Senate Wing Door. Inside, Williams illegally walked through numerous areas, including the Crypt, the Rotunda, the Speaker of the House's suite, and Statutory Hall. Williams took a selfie while there and also stole a black U.S. Capitol Police bag containing a helmet--which he kept with him as he walked through the building and as he exited.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;

Short narrative: "In subpoenaed Facebook messages sent a few weeks before Jan. 6, 2021, Dustin Sargent described plans to apprehend treasonous government employees and suggested that the penalty for treason is death. “They may publicly be hung,” he wrote in a Facebook message included in an FBI statement of facts. On Jan. 6, the FBI claims Sargent entered the U.S. Capitol on two separate occasions: once by climbing through a window on the west side and again through the east Rotunda doors. At those doors, Sargent was among rioters who sang the national anthem and then assaulted two officers trying to stop them from getting into the building, the FBI statement claims. Once he reached the House of Representatives Chamber, Sargent was filmed admonishing officers blocking their access. “You’re supposed to be with us!” Sargent said, according to the FBI statement. “This is our chance. If we don’t succeed, it’s over.”" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Tryon-Castro, et. al.
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:641, 2 Theft of government property, Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(1) and (a)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds resulting in significant bodily injury; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;
Additional details: Resident of VA
Short narrative: On January 13, 2023, Micaiah Joseph was charged with several felonies pertaining to the disorderly actions at the Capitol riot on January 6, 2021. He was wearing a “tricorn” hat with a red feather, a blue bandana or neck gaiter, a gas mask, a black long sleeve shirt or jacket, a black tactical vest, and black pants, and carried a black backpack. Joseph, along with other protesters, was seen attacking the police line and attempting to get into the capitol.

Weeks reportedly stole a can of pepper spray from a police officer and then tried to take possession of a sheild when the can was taken from him. He was caught on police body camera footage yelling "Why don’t we have f***ing police protecting the ballots? Why don’t we have this s*** when we have elections?"

Charges: 118:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding Passage through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;

Nichols was seen violently interacting with police on several occasions. After approaching the police line and working his way to the front, Nichols used a large circular shield to push and hit officers over the course of the riot.

Name of case: United States of America v. William Dunfee
Charges: 18:231 (a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(I) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5103(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of OH
Short narrative: On September 30, 2022, William "Bill" Dunfee was charged with two felonies and five misdemeanors after he attempted to take a baton from a police officer and helped break down a barricade in front of the Capitol on January 6th, 2022. He used a bullhorn to loudly address the crowd, stating things such as "we are taking our house". He was identified through phone records and his driver's license pictures.
Source description: Charging Documents, Press Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Todd Tilley
Charges: 1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 5104(e)(2)(D) disorderly conduct in a capitol building; 5104(e)(2)(G): parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a capitol building
Short narrative: On June 16, 2022, Todd Tilley of Maine was issued a complaint for his involvement in the Capitol raid. His presence at the Capitol, inside the Crypt, and near the Upper House door was confirmed by Capitol CCV and messages Tilley exchanged with his brother.
Source description: Charging Documents, local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Brandon Scott Cavanaugh
Charges: 1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building.
Short narrative: On August 16, 2022, a complaint was issued against Brandon Scott Cavanaugh for his participation in the Capitol riot. Cavanaugh, a previous employee for NASA, was seen inside the halls of the Capitol wandering around with other protestors while holding a "Trump" flag. He was also seen outside with the same flag along with other rioters.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Dusty Allan Higgins
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in Capitol Building;

Higgins was seen on camera illegally entering the Capitol and taking photos within the crypt. Higgins was later seen leaving the Capitol through a window.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. McGee & Harrison
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

Short narrative: Brian Scott McGee, 61 of Missouri and Jeremy Christian Harrison, 52 of Florida, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Both were sentenced to probation for their role in the January 6 Capitol Raid. The pair met online in advance of the Raid. McGee was an ex-National Guard member.

Name of case: United States of America v. Joseph Pavlik
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; *18:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Chicago, Illinois; Sentenced to 2 months prison, 6 months home confinement, 24 months supervised release, $6000 fine, and $2000 restitution; wore Three Percenters insignia at the U.S. Capitol, and was previously listed on an Oath Keepers' roster from 2009 to 2015.
Short narrative: On February 10, 2023 Joseph Pavlik was charged with several felonies relating to the January 6th riots. Pavlik belonged to B Group as identified by the FBI. Pavlik attended the riot wearing a black tactical vest, gas mask, black helmet, and carried some kind of chemical irritant. Pavlik was involved with the group of rioters who attempted to push their way through the police line securing the tunnel of the Lower West Terrace. Additionally, Pavlik was a part of the mob that physically assaulted law enforcement officers in the tunnel. Pavlik accepted a plea deal and was sentenced to 2 months prison, 6 months home confinement, 24 months supervised release, $6000 fine, and $2000 restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Karol J. Chwiesiuk
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; 40:5104(2)(2)(C)(i) Entering and remaining in a room designated for the use of a member of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of IL; Sister also arrested (Agnieszka Chwiesiuk); Member of Chicago Police Department-- badge # 7156; "Karol Chwiesiuk sentenced to a concurrent term of Probation for a period of Three (3) Years, to include 90 Days of home detention and location monitoring. Special assessment imposed in the total amount of $70.00. Defendant ordered to make Restitution in the amount of $500.00."
Short narrative: Karol J. Chwiesiuk, 29, from Chicago, Illinois and a member of the Chicago Police Department, was charged for his participation in the January 6, 2021 Capitol Raid. On June 2, 2021, the Chicago Police Department relieved him of his police powers. He was alledgedly inside the Capitol and bragged about his efforts through text messages to an associate. Photos sent between him and that associate show him taking selfies walking within the building, including the office of Senator Jeff Merkley. He was located after his mobile device was detected inside the building and around Washington, D.C. on the day in question.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Kaleb Dillard
Charges: *18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; *18:1361 Destruction of government property; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Mountain Brook, Alabama; Additionally sentenced to 12 months supervised release, $36,238.55 ressitution
Short narrative: On February 15, 2023, Kaleb Dillard, 27, was charged with multiple federal offenses for his participation in the Capitol riot. Dillard was pictured inside and outside the capitol along with other rioters. On one occasion he was recorded jumping an officer from behind and knocking him to the ground. On a seperate occasion he was seen shoving another officer in the chest. He was also reported to have entered the building by breaking open a window with a metal tool. Dillard was identified by the FBI after a witness identified him in photos from the event. Dillard also posted several photos and videos to his own social media, and had conversations with people confirming his participation and that he went to the Capitol "to strike fear into the politicians."
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release, News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Dillon Paul Homol
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Cocoa Beach, FL
Short narrative: Dillon Paul Homol, 22, from Cocoa Beach, FL was brought to the FBI's attention by two former classmates, who say they observed Homol livestreaming while entering the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6. The livestream allegedly showed Homol inside and around the Capitol, and featured him holding a red flag inscribed with "Make America Great Again." According to video obtained by federal investigators, Homol said, "They can't stop us all, come on we are going into the Capitol, can't stop us all." In another clip, Homol allegedly declared, "We're tired of it, the communist cops of Washington, D.C, we're storming the Capitol building. ... This is our country." According to an FBI special agent assigned to the case, Homol claimed he walked to the Capitol at President Trump's urging, and he believed that Trump was leading the crowd there. Homol also claimed the crowd forced him into the Capitol." (NPR). Homol has been charged with Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building, Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds, and impeding, disrupting, or disturbing the orderly conduct of a session of Congress or either House of Congress.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental reports and release (DOJ), Local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Robert William Degregoris
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; *18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds;
Additional details: Resident of VA
Short narrative: On January 23rd, 2023, Robert William Degregoris was charged with several felonies relating to his involvement in the January 6th raid. Degregoris was seen attempting to break through the police line in the "tunnel." He continuted to assault the capitol after being sprayed with Oleoresin Capsieum spray. He aided other rioters by helping move a ladder to toward the police line.
Source description: Charging Documents, Government reports and release

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND Supports organized political violence
Name of case: United States of America v. William Hendry Mellors
Charges: 231(a)(3): Civil disorder; 111(a)(1) and (b): Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon or Inflicting Bodily Injury; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (a)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds resulting in significant bodily injury; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 5104(e)(2)(F): Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; *5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;
Additional details: Use of bear spray makes it difficult to give exact number injured
Short narrative: "The FBI alleges that images from the Jan. 6, 2021, riot show William Hendry Mellors firing a canister of bear spray toward police officers on a staircase leading into the U.S. Capitol, according to court documents. “Took a nice beat down from Washington DC police tonight. Some tear gas and a riot baton. Broken ribs and some stitches needed,” Mellors later wrote on Parler as a caption for a close-up photo of what appears to be his own bloody ear, according to an FBI statement of facts. Mellors told FBI agents in April 2022 that he’d joined some “rabid” protesters at the Capitol on Jan. 6, also mentioning that a group of Proud Boys had asked him to “walk some ladies back to their hotel to protect them from Antifa” during the Trump rally in November 2020. He added that the Proud Boys “seemed like nice people.” When FBI agents interviewed Mellors a second time in May, he said he expected to be arrested and confirmed he brought two canisters of bear spray to Washington. He was arrested on July 18, 2022, in Houston" NPR
Source description: Charging documents, press release

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeffrey Michael Etter
Charges:
18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds
Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of VA; "Jeffrey Etter Sentenced 9/11/23 to Thirty-Six (36) Months of Probation. Special Assessment in the amount of $10 imposed. Restitution in the amount of $500 imposed. Fine in the amount of $5,000 imposed"
Short narrative: On February 24th, 2023 Jeffrey Michael Etter was arressted and charged with several felonies relating to the January 6th riots. Etter was seen on cameras yelling at officers and encouraging other rioters to enter the capitol. Etter and UNSUB were seen inside the Capitol building and stayed in the building for approximately 33 minutes.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. William Glynn Keen
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of KY; Sentenced 1/10/24 to Eighteen (18) months of probation. $10 Special Assessment and $500 Restitution.
Short narrative: William Glynn Keen, 41 of Kentucky, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his role in the January 6 Capitol Raid. Keen illegally entered the Capitol building and recorded himself and others while inside. Keen's footage was broadcasted on WDRB, a local news station. While he had no affiliation with a news outlet, he had a "Press" card taped to his coat.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. John O'Kelly
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;
Additional details: Resident of NY
Short narrative: On October 17, 2022, John O'Kelly was charged with Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers, Civil Disorder, Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds. and Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings after attempting to steal a baton from a police officer and breaking down a metal barricade at the attack on the Capitol building on January 6, 2021. He was identified through an online tip where he was identified from an open source photo ID software.
Source description: Court Documents, Press Release

Name of case: United States of America v. John Richter
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(l)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(I)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(A) Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building.
Additional details: Resident of FL ; "Joseph Irwin, 43, of Cecilia, Kentucky, and John Joseph Richter, 39, of Port Charlotte, Florida, were found guilty in U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia of multiple felony and misdemeanor offenses following a bench trial before U.S. District Court Judge Randolph D. Moss."
Short narrative: On March 2nd, 2023, John Richter was arrested and charged with several felonies relating to the January 6th riots. Richter was seen illegally entering the Capitol building with another individual named Joseph Irwin. While in the Capitol, Richter took pictures of rioters, the building, and himself sitting at the desks of senators. For the majority of Richter's time in the Captiol, he is seen holding a flag pole that he retreived earlier during the riot. He is seen exciting the Capitol building with this pole still in hand.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Rebecca Lavrenz
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor]
Additional details: Resident of Colorado Springs, CO; went to the Capitol with her son and grandson but they did not enter the building; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: On September 19, 2022, Rebecca Lavrenz was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building at the Capitol riot on January 6, 2021. CCTV footage shows Lavrenz entering the building with a crowd of rioters and observing many physical altercations, but she herself only stayed in the building for ten minutes. She admitted in a consensual interview with the FBI that she traveled to Washington DC with her son and grandson to attend the demonstration, but she was the only one to enter the building. This case is currently pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Mackrell
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of OH; Sentenced 3/18/24 to 27 months in prison, 12 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $2,000 in restitution
Short narrative: Michael Mackrell, 41 of Ohio, pled guilty to Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers and was sentenced to 27 months in prison for his role in the January 6 Capitol raid. According to legal documents, Mackrell was captured on video footage at the U.S. Capitol, where he wrapped his arm around the neck of an officer and threw them to the ground. Additional footage shows Mackrell assaulting four more officers in the same area. The assaults were captured on body-worn cameras from Metropolitan Police Department officers and CCTV footage. Mackrell entered a guilty plea on 3/9/2023, and was found guilty of assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers on 3/18/2024.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and release, Local News article

Name of case: United States of America v. Isaac Thomas, Christina Legros
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of MI; "Christina Legros sentenced 5/9/24 to Time Served. Six (6) months Supervised Release. $25.00 Special Assessment. $500.00 Restitution. During the riot, Legros and her boyfriend ignored police orders and continued through restricted areas to enter the capitol.

Farris was seen on video at the front of the mob on the North side of the Lower West Plaza, an area that was prohibited from the public. Farris told police "I bet your family is prou of you... You ain't shit. Ain't none of your shit." As other protestors were pulling the baracade, Farris shoved an officer in the back with two hands, which caused him to fall to the ground. The FBI identified him after a personal associate recognized him in a BOLO from the event and contacted law enforcement. Another witness confirmed that the image was indeed of Farris during an interview.

Name of case: United States of America v. Peter Joseph Harding

This was supported by other video and numerous photos which depict Harding inside the Capitol and attempting to light media equipment on fire. Additionally, Harding acknowledged his attempt to light media equipment on fire.

Name of case: United States of America v. Zvonimir Joseph Jurlina
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: x
Short narrative: "The charges brought against Zvonimir Jurlina center on events that happened in the late afternoon of Jan. 6 at the media staging area outside the northeast corner of the U.S. Capitol. An individual, identified by the FBI as Jurlina and seen in photographs posted on the FBI's website, participated in an assault on the area where the media had gathered. Jurlina allegedly incited "violent acts," along with others in the crowd, that forced members of the media to disperse and abandon their equipment. The photos show him allegedly kicking and stomping on equipment belonging to media outlets and assisting in an attempt to set fire to some of the equipment. In a 12-part video series Live Streamed on YouTube, Jurlina documents the incidents cited in the charging documents, including a moment where Jurlina says, “This is reporter Zykotik coming to you live. We are, haha. This is the real news media network. We have taken over. This is mother f**king America first."" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of PA; Sentenced 2/26/24 to nine months in prison and 36 months of supervised release
Short narrative: Cameron Edward Hess, 26 of Pennsylvania, pled guilty for his involvement in the January 6th riots at the US Capitol Building. Hess was identified through US Capitol CCTV video footage entering the Capitol building via the East rotunda doors. After being pushed out of the building by riot police, Hess later re-entered the Capitol building while law enforcement officials were attempting to direct the rioters out of the rotunda door. A photo captured later showed Hess assaulting police in an attempt to regain access to the Capitol building. During a confrontation with an Officer, Hess attempted to hold the door open as the officer worked to close it, however, the police were able to successfully push him out of the rotunda doors.
Source description: Court Documents, Government Reports and Release

On hiw own, Watson entered the building, walked about the interior, hung up a "Trump" flag with black tape in the crypt, and regrouped with Weston outside after calling him on the cell phone he was using to film video within the building.

Name of case: United States of America v. Jay Matthew Kenyon
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds;40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of VA
Short narrative: On March 2nd, 2023, Jay Matthew Kenyon was arrested for his involvement in the January 6th riots. Kenyon was seen on camera footage illegally entering the Capitol building. Once inside the Capitol, Kenyon and other rioters proceeded to the third floor and entered House Appropriations Committee office. There, officers instructed Kenyon and the other rioters to lay prone on the ground while Representatives were evacuated from the House floor. Once they were evacuated Kenyon was escorted to the second floor and placed into a group of rioters in the Capitol rotunda. Here, Kenyon was removed from the group because an officer saw him brandishing a knife. After confiscating the knife, he was escorted out of the Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jonathan Alan Rockholt
Group affiliation: Three Percenters (III Percenters, 3%ers), Guardians of Freedom
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder; 18:641, 2 Theft of government property
Additional details: Resident of FL; Rockholt Sentenced 7/7/23 to Five (5) Months of Incarceration, Twenty-Four (24) Months of Supervised Release, Five (5) Months of Home Detention. Special Assessment of $125. Restitution in the amount of $2,000.
Short narrative: On August 16, 2022, a complaint was issued against Benjamin Cole, 38, of Leesburg, John Edward Crowley, 50, of Windermere, Brian Preller, 33, of Mount Dora, and Jonathan Alan Rockholt, 38, of Palm Coast, and Tyler Bensch, 20, of Casselberry, Florida. All defendants are charged with the same felony charges of Civil Disorder and Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The first four defendants are also charged with Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The defendants engaged in confrontation with law enforcement, pushing them back and contributing to the breach of the Capitol. Rockholt was charged in his own lawsuit by a bill of information issued on March 30, 2023. Rockholt himself came armed with a knife and wearing a tactical vest and baseball helmet as protection. His theft of government property charge stems from his stealing a riot shield off of a law enforcement official. The men all self identify as part of the “Three Percenters” (AKA “3%ers”, “III%ers”, or “Threepers”). These defendants are specifically members of the "B Squad" a subgroup of the Guardians of Freedom.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Releases and Reports, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Larry Fife Giberson
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of NJ, student at Princeton University; given moniker "#DragThemOut" by Sedition Hunters; "Larry Giberson Sentenced 11/1/23 to Two (2) months of incarceration as to count 1. Defendant further sentenced to six (6) months of Supervised Release on Count 1 to be served as home detention, a $100 Special Assessment, and Restitution totaling $2,000."
Short narrative: On March 14th, 2023, Princeton University student Lary Fife Giberson was arrested for his involvement in the January 6th riots. Giberson was seen on video repeatedly engaging in violence against law enforcement officers guarding the Capitol near the Lower West Terrace's tunnel. Giberson and other rioters coordinated to forcefully enter the Captiol building by pushing against the police line, causing an officer to be crushed between a door and a shield held by a rioter. In an attempt to get more rioters into the tunnel, Giberson motioned more of the mob toward the "tunnel." As other rioters were assualting officers and dragging them out of the tunnel, Giberson yelled "DRAG THEM OUT" and cheered the the rioters on.
Source description: Court Documents, Government Reports and Release, Charging Documents,

Name of case: United States of America v. Mlynarek & Balhorn
Charges: *18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; *18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of MI; Sentenced 2/21/24 to a concurrent term of incarceration for One Hundred (100) Days. Defendant also sentenced to a concurrent term of supervised release for Twelve (12) Months on Counts 2 and 3. Special Assessment imposed in the total amount of $70.00. Defendant ordered to pay a fine in the amount of $1,000.00.
Short narrative: Kyle Mlynarek, 27, and Ronald Balhorn, 53, both from Michigan, were charged for their involvement in the January 6 Capitol Raid. Both Mlynarek and Balhorn were seen entering the Capitol building and actively pushing against a group of officers. They stayed in the Capitol building for approximately thirty minutes. Balhorn was seen on video carrying a wooden club or stick which he used to wrestle a police officer. Mlynarek pled guilty to four charges and Balhorn pled not guilty and was found guilty of three charges by a bench trial.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Document, Government reports and release

Name of case: United States of America v. Rachel Marie Powell
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding; 18:1361 Destruction of government property; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: "Rachel Powell Sentenced 10/17/23 to 57 months in prison and 36 months of supervised release ,more than $8,000 in restitution, fines, and fees."
Short narrative: Rachel Powell, 40, used a bullhorn during the Capitol riot to direct the crowd trying to gain control of the Capitol. Often referred to as “Bullhorn Lady” and “Pink Hat Lady,” Powell was seen on video giving very detailed instructions about the need to coordinate and the layout of the building. ln other photos, she was seen using a large pipe as a ramming device to breach windows to gain access. Powell was initially indicted on 3/3/21, but was then charged in a superseding indictment issued on 4/5/23. She plead not guilty to all counts, and was found guilty of all counts.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Mark Gabriel Sahady
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering or Remaining in Restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: US Army Reserve Captain 2004-(?), Deployed to Afghanistan; Vice President of Super Happy Fun America; organizer of the Boston 'Straight Pride' parade; Resident of Natick, Massachussets
Short narrative: Mark Sahady, the vice-president of Super Happy Fun America (formerly ResistMarxism), was arrested by the FBI on January 19th 2021. Sahady posted multiple times during late 2020 and early 2021 about travelling to Washington DC on January 6th, and was pictured on a chartered bus with members of SHFA on the night on January 5th. On January 6th he was seen entering the Capitol building. He has been charged with unlawful entry and disruption of government business alongside Suzanne Ianni. Ianni and Sahady are both associated with the group, Super Happy Fun America, and coordinated their arrival and participation in the Capitol riot. The case is currently pending. [NOTE: Sahady and Ianni were not charged togerher]
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. James McNamara
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers
Additional details: Resident of Illinois; "James McNamara, 61, of Chicago, was sentenced today by U.S. District Judge Amy Berman Jackson to 12 months in prison, 24 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $2,000 in restitution."
Short narrative: On April 7, 2023, James McNamara, 61, of Chicago, Illinois, was charged with assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers in a bill of information issued in regard to his conduct at the riot at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. McNamara was part of a group of rioters that pushed against law enforcement. McNamara was captured on video violently swinging his arms and lunging at law enforcement officers with a clenched fist. He also used a metal crowd control barricade as a weapon to hit against Capitol windows.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Article, Governmental Reports and Release, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Brennen Machacek
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(g) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of AR; "Machacek Sentenced 9/7/23 to Twelve (12) months of Probation, $10 Special Assessment and $500 Restitution."
Short narrative: On April 10, 2023, Brennen Machacek, 32, was charged with parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building following his participation in the Capitol riot. Machacek, a Marine Corps veteran, was referred to law enforcement by someone with whom he had served in the military and communicated with through a Facebook group chat. The FBI identified Machacek among the crowd of people walking throughout the Capitol interior on January 6, 2021 after comparing his appearance in the security camera footage with that in his driver's license photo and having the tipster who initially alerted the FBI to his participation confirm it.
Source description: Charging Document, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Tricia LaCount
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

LaCount was identified via footage, photographs, and several tips. The case is ongoing.

Name of case: United States of America v. Frederic Fiol
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

Fiol documented his involvment through messages and photos he took and then sent through Facebook Messenger to a friend.
Source description: Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Abate et. al.
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Expressed support for boogaloo/'Civil war 2'; Resident of IN; Active duty USMC stationed at Quantico; sentenced to four years probation and 279 hours of community service; "Micah Coomer Sentenced 9/12/23 to a term of Probation for a period of (4) Four Years. Special assessment of $10.00 imposed. Restitution ordered in the amount of $500.00"
Short narrative: On April 14, 2023, Micah Coomer was indicted for Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. He was an active duty marine and pled guilty to the charges. He posted pictures of himself at the Capitol on his Instagram, “mrcoomer08”, and he said on Facebook messages, “that everything in this country is corrupt. We honestly need a fresh restart. I’m waiting for the boogaloo," and that the boogaloo was "Civil War 2."
Source description: Court Document, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Joseph Pastucci, Jeanette Mangia
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(A) Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Short narrative: On April 26th, 2023, Joseph Pastucci and Jeanette Mangia were arrested for their involvement in the January 6th riots. Both Pastucci and Mangia were seen illegally entering the Capitol building on multiple occasions. Mangia first entered while wielding a bullhorn, and her husband, Pastucci, took photos of Mangia siting in House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's chair. When asked by Capitol officers to leave, the couple did not comply. Pastucci was pushed out of the Capitol building, resisting by clawing at a wooden table. Mangia, when asked to leave, dropped to the ground and repeatedely kicked at the officers as they tried to lift and carry her out. When finally removed from the building, Pastucci pushed an officer and Mangia kicked an officer in the groin.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Richard Cook, et. al.
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of IN
Short narrative: On March 15th, 2023, Arthur and Jessica Reyhers were arrested and charged with several felonies relating to the January 6th riots. The Reyhers repeatedly engaged in violent confrontations with law enforcement officers guarding the Capitol. Both of the Reyhers participated in collective pushes against police officers in the Lower West Terrace and tunnel areas in an attempt to gain access to the Capitol building. During these pushes, one police officer was pinned between a shield and a door, causing him to scream in pain. The Reyhers returned to the tunnel multiple times to participate in these collective pushes, contributing to the harm and suffering of the officer. Their active involvement in the riot highlights the severity and impact of the events that occurred on that day.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports an Releases

Grace joined other protesters at the tunnel on the Lower West Terrace collectively pushing the line of officers. As the officers began to push back and remove rioters from the tunnel, Grace remained nearby and watched the other rioters drag an officer out of the tunnel and attack him. Grace then resumed in pushing against the police line.

Name of case: United States of America v. Richard Cook, et. al.
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of FL ; "Richard Cook,found guilty 5/10/24 of civil disorder, a felony, and five misdemeanor offenses, including entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings, and act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings."
Short narrative: On March 7th, 2023 Richard Cook was charged with several felonies relating to the January 6th riots. Based on court records, Cook was one of the individuals who engaged in violent acts towards law enforcement officers safeguarding the Capitol during the events of January 6, 2021. He was involved in a confrontation with law enforcement officers in the Lower West Terrace and tunnel regions of the Capitol. Later, Cook entered the tunnel on the Lower West Terrace and joined a group of rioters who were coordinating pushes against police officers. They were yelling "HEAVE HO!" and "PUSH!" Cook entered the tunnel twice to contribute to the collective pushes against the police officers while attempting to gain access to the Capitol building. While Cook and other rioters were part pushing against the police line, one officer screamed in pain as he was pinned between a shield and a door due to the weight of the pushes. "Richard Cook Sentenced 8/28/24 to 18 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $2,000 in restitution"
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government reports and release, Local News article

Name of case: United States of America v. Richard Cook, et. al.
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of Gun Barrel City, TX
Short narrative: "According to court documents, on Jan. 6, 2021, Sarsfield was among rioters who repeatedly engaged in violence against law enforcement officers guarding the Capitol. Sarsfield participated in the confrontation with law enforcement officers in the Lower West Terrace and tunnel areas of the Capitol. He entered the tunnel on the Lower West Terrace at approximately 3:12 p.m., making his way into the mob of rioters who were coordinating pushes against police officers while yelling “HEAVE HO!” and “PUSH!” Sarsfield entered the tunnel three separate times to assist in the collective pushes against police officers as the rioters tried to gain access to the Capitol building. While Sarsfield joined in collective pushes, one police officer screamed in pain as the weight of the rioters’ pushes pinned him between a shield and a door. Sarsfield also assisted in passing stolen police shields into the tunnel." (DOJ Press Release)
Source description: Government reports and release; Charging documents
