Name of case: United States of America v. Christopher Maurer
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and 2 Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) and 2 Asaulting, Resisting, Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon [2 counts]; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Engaging in an Act of Physical Violence on Capitol Grounds or Buildings
Additional details: Resident of ME
Short narrative: On February 22nd, 2023, Christopher Maurer was arrested and charged with several felonies relating to the January 6th Riots. Maurer was seen entering the Capitol through the tunnel. Once reaching the police line, Maurer attempted to take an officer's shield and strike officers who were aiding another rioter expereincing a medical emergency. Later, Maurer entered the tunnel again, while screaming and making obscene gestures at the officers, he was sprayed with Oleoresin Capsicum by the same officers. Maurer was then seen picking up a long metal pipe/pole and swinging it at the front line of police officers before he left the tunnel area again.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government reports and release

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Daniele
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder
Additional details: Resident of NJ
Short narrative: On February 23rd, 2023 Michiel Daniele was arrested and charged with several felonies relating to the January 6th riots. Daniele was seen illegally entering the Capitol building during the riot. When questioned by the FBI, Daniele said he only went inside to find a restroom and that he was unsuccessful in finding one.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Nathan Donald Pelham
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: "Nathan Pelham Defendant received credit for time served and no imposition of supervised release; Special Assessment $10; Restitution $500. All remaining counts dismissed on Government's oral motion"
Short narrative: In 2023, Nathan Donald Pelham was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his participation in the Capitol riot. Pelham was identified via numerous photographs and text messages. The case is ongoing.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Macsen Rutledge
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Short narrative: In 2022, Macsen Rutledge was arrested and charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his participation in the Capitol riot. Rutledge was identified via photographs as being illegally inside the Capitol building during the January 6 riot. Rutledge was able to be identified in part due to his "bear-like hood" he is seen wearing in photos and videos.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jennifer Inzunza Vargas Geller
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of CA (former); Resident of Thailand (current); wife of Spencer Geller; NBC news reporter ex-boyfriend ended the relationship due to anti-immigrant beliefs, reading Mein Kampf and comments made "in reference to" Hitler.
Short narrative: On May 8th, 2023, Jennifer Inzunza Vargas Geller was charged for her involvement in the January 6th riots. Geller, also known as "Pink Beret," was seen illegally entering the Capitol building several times. She aided other rioters in destroying objects (bike rack and police equipment) on the Capitol grounds. Geller was also seen on cameras ushering other rioters into the building.
Source description: Charing Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Austin Brendlen Harris
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of CA, board-certified cardiothoracic anesthesiologist
Short narrative: On January 23rd, 2023 Austin Brendlen Harris was charged with several felonies relating to his involvement in the January 6th riots. Harris shared pictures on social media of him kneeling next to Ashli Babbitt, who was shot by capitol police protecting the politicians inside. Harris also got into several verbal altercations with police inside the capitol once he gained access inside.

Name of case: United States of America v. Nolf & Kepley
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds

Kepley pled guilty to one count of knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds and was sentenced to 5 months incarceration five months in prison, 1 year of supervised release, and $500 in restitution.

Name of case: United States of America v. Hostetter, et al.
Group affiliation: Three Percenters (III Percenters, 3%ers); American Phoenix Projec
Charges: 18:1512(k) - Conspiracy to obstruct official proceeding; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon;
Additional details: Former police chief of La Habra, CA; "Alan Hostetter Found guilty 7/13/23 of all four charges against him following a bench trial before U.S. District Judge Royce C. Lamberth."; "Alan Hostetter Sentenced 12/7/23 to One Hundred and Thirty-Five (135) months on Counts 1ss and 2ss and a term of One Hundred and Twenty (120) months on Counts 3ss and 4ss, with all such terms to run concurrently. The Defendant is further sentenced to serve a Thirty-Six (36) month term of supervised release as to each of Counts 1ss-4ss, with all such terms to run concurrently. In addition, the Defendant is ordered to pay restitution in the amount of $2, 000, a fine in the amount of $30,000 and a special assessment of $100 for each of Counts 1ss-4ss, for a total of $400."
Short narrative: On May 10, 2023, in a final superseding indictment, Alan Hostetter, 56, the former police chief of La Habra, California, was charged with several federal offenses for his activities at the United States Capitol on January 6, 2021. In the weeks after the 2020 Presidential Election and leading up to the certification of election results by U.S. Congress, Hostetter, who is the director of the anti-COVID regulation American Phoenix Project and a subscriber to the ideology of the Three Percenters, posted videos online expressing his outrage at the supposed tyranny of the deep state, advocating for the execution of high ranking public officials, and calling for Donald Trump to be inaugurated on January 20. In late December 2020, Hostetter and several other Californians associated with the American Phoenix Project began using the encrypted messaging app Telegram to coordinate plans to travel to Washington D.C. on January 6th and discuss what weapons to bring with them to the city. The members of the Telegram group chat--which had since been renamed "The California Patriots-D.C. Brigade"--traveled to the Nation's Capitol separately in the first few days of 2021. On January 6, Hostetter--who was armed with a hatchet in his backpack--and others attended President Trump's rally at the Ellipse before heading to the U.S. Capitol Building. Hostetter and Taylor pushed through a line of law enforcement officers on the Upper West Terrace, where Hostetter made a video of himself and proclaimed "The people have taken back their house." He remained in that area for hours until he was forced out by police.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Court Documents, Government Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Jon Lizak
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of NY; Sentenced to 36 months probation, supervised release, and restitution in the amount of $500.
Short narrative: On May 11, 2023, Jon Lizak, 21, of Cold Spring Harbor, New York, was charged with a federal offense for his activities on January 6, 2021. Lizak and several associates were captured on CCTV footage illegally entering the Capitol and walking through multiple restricted areas of the interior, including Nancy Pelosi's office, for about 35 minutes. Although Lizak himself was not seen engaging in any violent activities on the day in question, he did witness one of his associates--Joseph Brody--using a metal barricade as a weapon and destroying press equipment in a previously-cordoned-off area outside the U.S. Capitol Building. Lizak and his associates were found to be affiliated with America First, a group espousing the belief that the political and cultural changes occuring in America today need to be stopped. Evidence shows that the group had attended other Washington, D.C. rallies prior to this one and that they communicated in advance of traveling to our nation's capitol on January 6, 2021.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Odin Meacham
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grmmds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
Additional details: Resident of UT
Short narrative: On May 15th, 2023, Odin Meacham was arrested for his involvement in the January 6th riots. Meacham was seen on Capitol cameras attempting to take a bike rack the Capitol Officers were using to hold the line. He then charged toward a group of officers and hit the upper body of at least one officer. Later, Meacham then picked up a metal pole and threw it at another Officer, hitting an officer. After chanting at the rioters to "lean in" against the Officer held line, Meacham attempted to gain possession of an officer's baton.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. David Elizalde
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Active duty Navy Sailor stationed in VA; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "David Elizalde Sentenced 4/19/24 to Thirty (30) Days of Home Detention. Defendant further Ordered to pay $10.00 Special Assessment and $2,500.00 Fine."
Short narrative: On April 2nd, 2023, David Elizalde was arrested for his involvement in the January 6th riots. Elizalde was stationed on the USS Harry S. Truman in Norfolk Virginia. During the riots, Elizalde was seen on video illegally entering the Capitol building with a flag in hand. He then left the building after an officer told him to leave, but he stayed outside to observe the other rioters.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Both counts to run concurrently to each other. Special Assessment in the amount of $100 imposed for each count for a total of $200. Restitution in the amount of $2,000 imposed."; Resident of Lynnwood, WA
Short narrative: On October 18, 2022, Tucker Weston was charged with Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers, Civil disorder, Entering restricted building or grounds, and Violent entry or disorderly conduct after Weston participated in removing the metal barricade in front of the Capitol building and shoving police officers before entering on January 6th, 2021. Tucker Weston was sentenced to 24 months in prison.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Waynick & Waynick
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of TN; Son also arrested; "GUILTY 4/17/24 on Counts 1ss, 5ss, 7ss, 9ss, 11ss, 12ss, 13ss, and 14ss as to MARK WAYNICK"
Short narrative: Jerry McKane Waynick, along with his father, Mark Waynick, were arrested on February 17th in responce to their actions during the January 6th riot at the United States Capitol. Both Waynicks were observed on body-camera, CCTV, and cell phone video assaulting officers along the Western Front of the building. Jerry Waynick was specifically seen beating an officer with an orange traffic pilon. After breaching the police riot line, both Waynicks were seen on CCTV footage inside the Capitol building, specifically in both Senate and House wings, and in the Rotunda's Statuary hall.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and releases (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Joshua Hall
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752 (a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Sanford, NC; "Joshua Hall Sentenced 11/17/23 to Twelve (12) months of Probation, $25 Special Assessment, $200 Fine and Restitution in the amount of $500"
Short narrative: On January 6, 2021 Joshua Hall, 36, unlawfully entered the Capitol in Washington, D.C., and was charged with four different offenses: (1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, (2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, (3) Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds, (4) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. In an interview with an FBI agent, Hall said he was motivated to travel to Washington, D.C. with two other individuals to support former President Donald Trump and to “let their grievances be known”. After listening to his speech, Hall decided to march to the Capitol building and was seen climbing over a railing on the West stairs. In the Statement of Facts there are images of Joshua Hall in different parts of the Capitol. Hall denied taking part in any violence, theft, damage to property, or disorderly conduct, however, the FBI did find evidence of the defendant searching for violent weapons (ex: “collapsible baton”) near the date of the insurrection, so there is reason to believe he was carrying something that could be used to protect himself, but based on the documents the main tactic used to target the Capitol was blockading/unlawful assembly.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Daniel Charles Ball
Charges: 18:844(h) Using fire or explosive to commit any felony; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:2 Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(b)(1)(a) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:641 Theft of government property;
Additional details: Resident of FL, On probation, previous conviction of battery on an officer
Short narrative: On May 18th, 2023, Daniel Charles Ball was arrested for his involvement in the January 6th riots. During the riots, Ball was seen on camera throwing an explosive device into a crowd of capitol officers. Several officers reported injuries and hearing impairment that resulted from the explosion. Later, Ball broke off a piece of a Capitol window and used it to assault an officer. During the riot, Ball was already on probation from a previous crime where he was convicted of two counts of battery on an officer.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Tyler Bensch
Group affiliation: Three Percenters (III Percenters, 3%ers), Guardians of Freedom
Charges: 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 18:641, 2 - Theft of government property
Additional details: Resident of FL; Tyler Bensch Sentenced 7/7/23 to Twenty-Four (24) Months of Probation, home detention for Sixty (60) days, Sixty (60) hours of community service, Special Assessment of $50. Restitution in the amount of $500.
Short narrative: On May 19, 2023, Tyler Bensch, 20, of Casselberry, Florida, was charged with multiple federal offenses for his actions at the United States Capitol on January 6, 2021. Bensch participated in the riot as part of a squadron of “three percenters” (AKA “3%ers”, “III%ers”, or “Threepers”) self-identified as members of a Guardians of Freedom subgroup called B SQUAD." Tyler Bensch coordinated with the other members of this group in planning and preparing for travel to Washington, D.C., and then in carrying out their actions at the U.S. Capitol Building on the afternoon of January 6, 2021. Bensch came dressed in tactical gear and armed with a chemical irritant spray. While the other members of BSQUAD participated in the heave-ho effort inside the tunnel, Bensch waited outside. Once they exited the throng, Bensch helped to carry away a stolen riot shield with one of them; this piece of government property has yet to be recovered. Additionally, while there, Bensch sprayed a supposed member of "ANTIFA" with the chemical irritant spray despite the fact that they posed no threat to him. Bensch was identified by the FBI after a witness came forward and linked the individual captured in footage from the riot with Bensch's Snapchat account "yoitztylerrr," which then led to him being fully identified with photos of his garb at the event and other pictures on social media.
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Release, News Articles, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. James Breheny
Charges:
18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:2 Aiding and Abetting; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:1512(c)(1) Corruptly Alter,
Destroy, Mutilate, and Conceal a Record, Document, and Other Object, and Attempted to do so, With the Intent to Impair its Integrity and Availability for use in an Official Proceeding
Additional details: Bergen County coordinator of the NJ Oath Keepers and in direct contact with leader Stewart Rhodes prior to 1/6. Breheny organized a regional OK meeting in PA on 1/3; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: ""We weren't burning down the city. We wanted access to the capitol [sic] to watch the vote and have our voices heard. They put barricades up. It's our house not theirs,” wrote James Breheny on Facebook on Jan 6. Breheny, a member of the Oath Keepers, served as the coordinator of the Bergen County, N.J., chapter of the organization, according to court documents. On Jan. 3, Breheny is believed to have held a leadership meeting for the Oath Keepers of the Mid-Atlantic region in Quarryville, Pa., to prepare for the rally on Jan. 6, according to the FBI. “This will be the day we get our comms on point with multiple other patriot groups, share rally points etc. This one is important and I believe this is our last chance to organize before the show. This meeting will be for leaders only,” he wrote to the group. On Jan. 14, Breheny was interviewed by law enforcement about his involvement on Jan. 6, but further investigation revealed that he lied to the FBI on multiple occasions about his actions that day. Breheny stated to the officers that he was unwillingly pushed inside the building by the large group and did not engage in violence. Footage, however, shows Breheny in close proximity to ongoing violence involving assault on police officers with flagpoles and irritants, as well as communication between him and other members of the Oath Keepers on the platform Signal that read, “We breached the door Baby” and “Made it in Brother.” In addition, Breheny indicated on the same chat that he is deleting all his social media posts in order to avoid being caught. Breheny goes by the alias “Seamus Evers.”" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Renee Fatta
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in the Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Bridgeport, NY; Boyfriend also arrested; "Renee Fatta Sentenced 10/25/2023 to Twenty-Four (24) Months of Probation (with conditions). Defendant further Ordered to pay Restitution of $500, Special Assessment of $10, and Fine of $250."
Short narrative: In 2023, Renee Fatta was federally charged following her participation in the Capitol riot. Fatta was identified via a tip as well as CCTV footage and a photograph of Fatta inside the Capitol that she posted to Facebook. Fatta has admitted to being present and illegally entering the Capitol. Fatta's case is ongoing.
Source description: Charging Document, Court Document

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND State speech act
Name of case: United States of America v. Matthew DaSilva
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of TX; Navy veteran; Sentenced to 28 months imprisonment, 6 months supervised release
Short narrative: On May 31, 2023, a final superseding indictment charged Matthew DaSilva, 50, of Lavon, Texas with multiple federal offenses for his activities at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. According to court documents, after attending President Trump's rally at the Ellipse, DaSilva joined the mob at the U.S. Capitol Building, holding a flagpole and waving a large blue flag. Later, he joined in the heave-ho effort against law enforcement officers on the Lower West Terrace; in footage from a public video of the event as well as law enforcement bodycams, the individual identified as DaSilva made it to the front of the crowd, forcibly pushed against the officers' riot shields and even tried to rip one away from them. It is stated that he later swatted an officer's hand away and tried to deploy a canister of chemical irritant. A former Navy interpreter, DaSilva came to the attention of the FBI after they received tips from personal associates of DaSilva's, one of whom specifically recognized the distinctive Navy jacket, long hair, beard, and scarf he was wearing in photographs from January 6--in the time since the riot, DaSilva had ceased wearing these articles of clothing and cut his hair.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Raymund Joseph Cholod
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;
Additional details: Resident of Tallahassee, FL
Short narrative: "Raymund Joseph Cholod, 52, of Tallahassee, Florida, is charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a dangerous weapon, and disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a dangerous weapon...At approximately 2:45 p.m., Cholod pushed his arm and elbow into a police officer’s face and neck. Less than a minute later, he pushed against a police riot shield, then grabbed it, and attempted to pull it away from officers." (DOJ Press Release) Cholod was sentenced to 40 months in prison.
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Release

Moloney additionally assaulted officers and a member of the press amidst the riot. Moloney can be seen in photographs and videos taken during the riot. Moloney's case is ongoing.

Name of case: United States of America v. William Lance Wilkerson
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; *18:1752 (a)(2) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40: 5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in any of the Capitol Buildings;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Bedford, IN; "William Wilkerson Sentenced 11/20/23 to Twenty-Four (24) Months of Probation (with conditions). Defendant further ordered to pay Restitution of $500.00 and Special Assessment of $10.00."
Short narrative: William Lance Wilkerson, 39 of Indiana, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his involvement in the January 6 Capitol Raid. On January 10th, 2021 he shared a Facebook image stating “The Declaration of Independence Says We Have the Right to Overthrow the Government… The Declaration of Independence says that we not only have the right but we also have the duty to alter or abolish any government that does not secure our unalienable rights'' therefore, there is reason to believe Wilkerson was motivated by a socio-political purpose.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Article

Other names/aliases: Twisted Puffer; BlowfishAFO (both Sedition Hunters); 442-AFO (FBI); Bruce Moon; Adam Blest (both from statement of facts)
Name of case: United States of America v. Adam Ryan Obest
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers or Employees; 18:111(b) Using a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon to Assault, Resist, or Impede Officers or Employees; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:l752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A)Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Thurmont, MD; "Adam Ryan Obest  Found GUILTY at bench trial 8/2/24 as to counts one (1), three (3), and eight (8). Defendant was found NOT GUILTY as to the greater offenses of counts five (5), six (6), and seven (7) but GUILTY of lesser included offenses. Defendant was found NOT GUILTY as to counts two (2) and four (4)."
Short narrative: Adam Ryan Obest, 42, of Thurmont, Maryland, is charged with obstructing, impeding, or interfering with a law enforcement officer during a civil disorder, assaulting an officer with a deadly or dangerous weapon, act of physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon, and act of physical violence on Capitol grounds. Obest is seen on BWC video engaging law enforcement officers while holding a flagpole. Obest raised the flagpole above his head and brought the end of it down abruptly into the line of officers. Obest then engaged directly with an MPD Officer and attempted to take the officer’s baton out of their hands before eventually retreating into the crowd. In Facebook posts, Obest indicated he and his wife attended the Stop the Steal rally in Washington, D.C., and were in the vicinity of the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021. Multiple tipsters called the FBI providing identification of Obest through his social media posts.
Source description: Charging Documents; Government reports and releases; local news; Other

Name of case: United States of America v. Corinne Montoni
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil disorder
Additional details: "Corinne Montoni Sentenced 9/28/23 to 30 days in prison, 24 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $2,000 in restitution."
Short narrative: On June 9, 2023, Corinne Lee Montoni, 33, was charged with numerous federal offenses following her participation in the Capitol riot on January 6, 2021. The FBI was informed of Montoni's involvement after a complainant submitted an online tip which directed them to images taken from the perspective of one of the rioters inside the U.S. Capitol that were then posted to social media accounts belonging to her. This directed them to review Montoni's social media interactions in the leadup to January 6th, in which she made such incendiary remarks as "arrest these traitors," "Or were going to fucking WAARRRRR party," "If Pence betrays us, we riot," and "It’s either going to be a Trump victory party or the first real day of the revolution." After the riot, Montoni returned to social media to say "We want the TRAITOR POLITICIANS. This is not a civil war. This is a revolution." Footage taken within the building shows the individual identified as Montoni joining with other rioters to push against the police officers.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Richard Zachary Ackerman
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assault, Resist, Oppose, Impede, With a Person Engaged in Performance of Official Duties; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:641 Theft of Goverment Property
Additional details: Resident of Salem, NH; "Richard Ackerman Sentenced 8/1/24 to Time Served on Count 1, followed by twenty-four (24) months of Supervised Release (with conditions) on Count 1 to run concurrently with Count 2. $100 Special Assessment on Count 1 and total Restitution of $2,000. Count 2: Defendant sentenced to Time Served on Count 2, followed by twelve (12) months of Supervised Release (with conditions) on Count 2 to run concurrently with Count 1. $25 Special Assessment on Count 2 and total Restitution of $2,000."
Short narrative: On June 13, 2023, a criminal complaint was issued against Richard Zachary Ackerman, 22, of Salem, NH for theft of government property, obstructing law enforcement during civil disorder, resisting a person engaged in official duties, entering and remaining on restricted grounds, and disorderly and disruptive conduct on restricted grounds. On January 6, 2021, Ackerman was part of the crowd that attempted to break a police barricade in the Lower West Terrace of the U.S. Capitol Building. During the riot, Ackerman acquired a U.S. Capitol police helmet, something he termed a "war trophy." Ackerman later attached a New England 131 sticker to the helmet, a sticker referencing the small neo-Nazi group named the Nationalist Social Club 13.
Source description: Charging documents; court documents; local news articles; governmental reports and release;

Name of case: United States of America v. Daniel Bibonge Amsini
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752 (a)(2) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:641 Theft of Government Property
Additional details: "Daniel Amsini  Sentenced to Forty-Five (45) Days of Incarceration followed by Twelve (12) Months of Supervised Release (with conditions). Defendant further Ordered to pay $749.00 Restitution and $25.00 Special Assessment. No fine imposed."; Resident of Arlington, VA
Short narrative: Daniel Bibonge Amsini entered the U.S. Capitol building in Washington, D.C. on January 6, 2021 based on open source and social media images. He was charged with six different offenses: (1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; (2) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; (3) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; (4) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Capitol Building; (5) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; (6) Theft of Government Property. Amsini was seen entering multiple parts of the building while wearing a “Make America Great Again” hat. Based on screenshots from CCTV footage, he stole an ILC Dover Scape CBRN30 escape hood from the Senate Chambers and placed it in his string bag. This object is an advanced air-purifying escape respirator that provides protection from carbon monoxide, and chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear contaminants. Based on the Statement of Facts I would identify blockading/unlawful assembly as the tactic used to target this Federal building. His motive behind taking the air purifier from the Capitol and entering the building in the first place is not explicitly said. Daniel Amsini was sentenced to Forty-Five (45) Days of Incarceration followed by Twelve (12) Months of Supervised Release (with conditions). The defendant was further Ordered to pay $749.00 Restitution and $25.00 Special Assessment. No fine was imposed.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Cindy Young
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in the Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Bristol, NH; JURY VERDICT of GUILTY as to all counts on 8/9/24.
Short narrative: On June 21, 2023, a criminal complaint was issued againt Cindy Young of Bristol, NH for entering and remaining on restricted grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly or disruptive conduct in the Capitol grounds or building, and demonstrating in the Capitol Building. In preparation for the Capitol attack that occurred January 6, 2021, Young was transported to D.C. on a bus organized by the group "Super Happy Fun America," and she attended a "Stop the Steal" rally once there. During the Capitol attack, Young participated in calling for the Senate Chamber doors to be broken down while standing outside of the Chamber, later admitting that her goal was to have her voice heard inside the hearing room.
Source description: Charging documents; court documents; local news articles

Nelson later reintered the Capitol building for a second time, joining other protesters as they were pushing against the police line.

Name of case: United States of America v. Dragoo & Dragoo
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in the Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of St. Joseph, MO; Husband also arrested at Capitol; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Kimberly and Steven Dragoo Sentenced 4/19/24 to serve a term of Thirty-Six (36) Months Probation With A Condition Of Intermittent Confinement, And Ordered To Pay The Clerk Of Court for the U.S. District Court for the District Of Columbia, A Special Assessment In The Amount Of $10.00, Restitution To Be Disbursed To The Architect Of The Capitol In The Amount OF $500.00, And A Fine In The Amount Of $5000.00."
Short narrative: On June 12, 2023, a criminal complaint was issued against Kimberly Dragoo, 51, and Steven Dragoo, 62, both of St. Joseph, MO, for entering and remaining on restricted grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly or disruptive conduct in the Capitol grounds or building, and demonstrating in the Capitol Building. On January 6, 2021, the Dragoos, a married couple, attended a "Stop the Steal" rally, which the Dragoos became aware of through their Facebook group, before marching with other protestors to the Northwest side of the U.S. Capitol, later breaking off from the group to take pictures on a terrace outside the Senate Wing door. Kimberly Dragoo maintains that the police "let everyone go in and walk through" the Capitol and that where she was "everybody was happy."
Source description: Charging documents; court documents; local news articles;

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeremy Michael Rodgers
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon;
Additional details: Resident of Midland, MI
Short narrative: "Jeremy Rodgers, 28, of Midland, Michigan, is charged with felony offenses: assault on a federal officer with a deadly or dangerous weapon, civil disorder, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon, and act of physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon. Rodgers is also charged with misdemeanor offenses of disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, act of physical violence in a Capitol building or on Capitol grounds, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building...Rodgers was arrested in Orlando, Florida, and will make his initial appearance today in the Middle District of Florida...According to court documents, authorities identified a man, later determined to be Rodgers, from video and surveillance footage on Jan. 6, 2021, assaulting a law enforcement officer with a flagpole. Court documents state that on January 6th, Rodgers, carrying a blue flag attached to a wooden flagpole, approached a line of law enforcement officers guarding the entrance to the East Rotunda Door and then used his flagpole as a weapon, audibly striking a United States Capitol Police (USCP) Officer three times on the helmet. Court documents say that shortly after, Rodgers again struck down the flagpole twice more in the direction of the officers...Court records allege that Rodgers is believed to have attempted to use his flagpole to prevent officers from closing the East Rotunda Door and entered the Capitol building through that door at approximately 2:26 p.m. Once inside the building, court documents allege that Rodgers walked toward Statuary Hall and the House side of the building and was observed removing a railing blocking the path of the crowd behind him, stating, “come on in.” Court documents state that Rodgers then stood aside and shouted “USA, USA” while waving people toward the House Chambers...According to court documents, Rodgers then joined a crowd of rioters that pushed through a police line guarding the entrance to the House of Representatives Chambers and spent several minutes outside the entrance to the House Chamber. Afterward, Rodgers was involved in another scuffle with police, remained in the building, and paraded through the Rotunda waving his flag before finally exiting the building at approximately 2:56 p.m." (DOJ Press release)
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; News Articles;

Name of case: United States of Amerca v. Nathan Baer
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder, 18:1752(a)(1) - Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority, 18:1752(a)(2) -Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, 18:1752(a)(4) -Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds , 40:5104(e)(2)(D) -Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, 40:5104(e)(2)(F) -Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings.
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Asheville, NC; Sentenced 9/6/24 to Four (4) months of imprisonment, followed by 24 months of supervised release with conditions. Special Assessment: $100.00. Restitution: $2000.00. Remaining Counts: 2, 3, 4 and 5 are dismissed on the Motion of the Government.
Short narrative: "Nathan Baer, 43, of Asheville, North Carolina, is charged with the felony offense of obstruction of law enforcement during a civil disorder; and misdemeanor offenses of entering or remaining on restricted grounds without lawful authority to do so; disorderly or disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building...According to court documents, video footage taken from multiple sources on Jan 6., 2021, at the U.S. Capitol building show an individual, later identified as Defendant Baer, making his way into the lower west tunnel entrance at approximately 2:50 p.m. While inside this tunnel, court records say that Baer worked with other rioters to push his body back and forth in a concerted “heave-ho” movement against the line of officers." (DOJ press release)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of Amerca v. Jeffrey Reed
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder;
Additional details: Resident of Rosanky, TX
Short narrative: "Jeffrey David Reed, 48, of Rosanky, Texas, is charged with one count of civil disorder, a felony offense. Reed is also charged with various misdemeanor offenses, including entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly or disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly conduct in a capitol building; and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building...Reed was arrested in Rosanky, Texas, and made his initial appearance today in the Western District of Texas...According to court documents, video footage from Jan. 6, 2021, shows a man, later identified as Reed, taking down multiple barricades and passing through restricted areas secured by U.S. Capitol Police before heading into the U.S. Capitol building. Video footage depicts Reed physically moving the metal barricades in front of the U.S. Capitol Police line, impeding and interfering with law enforcement efforts to maintain a police line and keep rioters from crossing into restricted areas. At one point, a video taken from that day shows Reed yelling at police officers, stating, “you work for us.”" (DOJ Press release)
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; News Articles; Governmental Reports and Release;

Name of case: United States of America v. Christina Traugh
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752 (a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of PA; "Christina Traugh Sentenced 10/19/23 to eighteen (18) months of probation, with forty-five (45) days of home detention. Special assessment imposed of $10 and restitution owed in the amount of $500."
Short narrative: On June 29, 2023, Christina Traugh, 49, was charged with four different federal offenses for entering the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. During the investigation the FBI issued a search warrant for various Facebook accounts where she used the display name “Christina Austin”. On January 5, 2021 and the morning of the insurrection “Christina Austin” messaged Christy Taylor-Clark to make travel arrangements to Washington, D.C. In the Statement of Facts, you can view an image of Traugh, Taylor-Clark, and another individual/possible co-offender Matthew Clark. At 3:04 pm Traugh was captured on CCTV entering the East Rotunda door to the Capitol and occupying the inside of the Rotunda.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Terry Allen
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:231 Obstruction of Justice During Civil Disorder; 18:111(b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding a Federal Officer
Additional details: Resident of Spring Mills, PA
Short narrative: In 2023, Terry Allen was federally charged following his participation in storming the Capitol. Allen was identified via several witnesses coming froward and surveillance video from the Capitol. The footage shows Allen and other rioters assaulting law enforcement officers on the West Plaza. Allen is accused of “shoving officers before using his wooden flagpole as a lance to attack officers by driving it into them in a stabbing motion." One of the officers he assaulted is Sgt Aquilino Gonell, who suffered severe injuries. His case is ongoing. DC police (MPD) created a wanted poster for the subject, who was then identified by a member of the public who did not know him - that person provided info from Facebook and YouTube to law enforcement. A Pennsylvania State Trooper was interviewed and identified Allen from a previous encounter, as well as an unidentified person who had known Allen for over 10 years who also identified Allen and says he stockpiles guns, food, and propane.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Other

Name of case: United States of America v. Kahler & Kahler
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Great Falls, VA; Wife of Ralph Kahler;
Short narrative: Ralph Kahler, 61, and Suzanne Kahler, both of Great Falls, VA, are charged with entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. January 6, 2021, the Kahlers entered the Capitol through the Lower West Terrace and ascended to the Upper West Terrace, where they took photos and filmed. Once they reached the Crypt, they exited the Captiol, remaining inside for an approximate total of three minutes, remaining outside for an additonal 30 minutes.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents;

Name of case: United States of America v. Andrew Yavoich
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Sentenced to 6 months probation and $500 restitution
Short narrative: On July 6, 2023, Andrew Michael Yavoich, 40, was federally charged following his participation in the Capitol riot. Yavoich was identified via a confidential source. His involvement was further affirmed by surveillance footage showing an individual--matching the description of Andrew Yavoich when the FBI later went on to interview him--illegally entering the U.S. Capitol building and walking about the interior with a flag. Yavioch accepted a plea deal, pleading guilty to 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dropped and Yavoich was sentenced to 6 months probation and $500 restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Eric Glen Harrower
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of St. Louis, MO; "Eric Harrower Sentenced 4/9/24 to twelve (12) months Probation with conditions, a $10 Special Assessment, and Restitution in the amount of $500 on count 4."
Short narrative: Eric Harrower, #, of St. Louis, MO, is charged with entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. On January 6, 2021, after attending a Trump rally with Joshua Dressel, Harrower went to the Capitol and helped rioters climb up the northwest steps using a bike rack. After, Harrower joined the crowd in the Crypt.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Local News Articles;

Name of case: United States of America v. Chad Dustin Suenram
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752 (a)(2) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Wichita, KS
Short narrative: Chad Suenram. 43, of Wichita, KS, is charged with knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building. On January 6, 2021, Suenram participated in Capitol protests wearing a face mask painted with an America flag. Suenram was part of the crowd at the North Door and watched as other protesters attempted to break down that door. Suenram was identified through crowd-sourced policing.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Local News Articles;

Name of case: United States of America v. Scott Columbus
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering and Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752 (a)(2) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Wolcott, NY; Girlfried also arrested; sentenced to 3 years probation, 60 days home confinement, $500 fine
Short narrative: On January 6th, 2021 Scott Columbus (#) unlawfully entered the Capitol in Washington, D.C., and was charged with four different offenses: (1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority, (2) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, (3) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, (4) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. I would list the tactic used under blocking/unlawful assembly which targeted a non-military non-judicial Federal site. Columbus breached the Capitol building, entering the Parliamentarian doors with his girlfriend Renee Fatta. After leaving the office they advanced further into the Capitol building, holding hands, towards a police line positioned down the hallway from the Parliamentarian doors. Scott Columbus told an FBI agent that he drove himself and Fatta to former President Donald Trump’s rally and began following the crowd to the Capitol as the President began to speak, so there is reason to believe he was motivated by a socio-political purpose.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Duong & Miller
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in the Capitol Building

Short narrative: In 2023, Long Duong, 52, and Julie Miller, 49, were arrested and federally charged following their participation in the Capitol riot. Duong and Miller were identified via geolocation data. Capitol CCTV footage shows both Duong and Miller in the Captiol, and both Miller and Duong have shown agents photographs from inside the Capitol taken on their personal phones. Their case is ongoing.

Name of case: United States of America v. Brian Gerard Healion
Charges: 18:231(a)(3), 2 Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of PA; During Criminal Complaint was listed with 2 codefendants: Isaiah Giddings and Freedom VY. At the time of indictment, the defendant appears to have been seperated. 100 days in prison
Short narrative: The FBI zeroed in on Brian Healion as a person who entered the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, after the bureau obtained the phone records of another man charged, Zachary Rehl, who is the president of the Philadelphia chapter of the far-right group the Proud Boys, court documents indicate. Healion is charged alongside two others, Isaiah Giddings and Freedom Vy. They were allegedly part of a Telegram message with Rehl and one other unidentified person, who does not appear to be charged. The group members planned their travel together from Philadelphia to D.C., including sharing contact information and blood types, on the day before the riot. Giddings, Healion, and Vy then stayed together at The Darcy Hotel in D.C., court records say, on the night before the riot. On the morning of Jan. 6, 2021, Vy and Healion took a selfie together at the Washington Monument, each flashing the "OK" hand gesture, which is associated with the Proud Boys, court records indicate. The four men then allegedly entered the west side of the Capitol, near the Senate, where they can be seen in various photos and videos. (NPR) He was sentenced to 100 days in prison.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Stephen Roy Sexton
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1361 Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of SC;
Short narrative: Stephen Sexton, 38, of SC, is charged with obstruction of an official proceeding; destruction of government property; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; acts of physical violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. On January 6, 2001, Sexton entered the Capitol building through a broken window and carried a broken chair leg with him throughout the riot. Sexton told attorneys that "We need the militia," and that "The Civil War has begun."
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Local News Articles; News Articles;

Name of case: United States of America v. Taylor Franklin Taranto
Charges: DC Code 22:4504(a)(1) Carrying a Pistol without a License (Outside Home or Place of Business); DC Code 7:1506.01(b) Possession of a Large Capacity Ammunition Feeding Device; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering and Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident Pasco, WA; Defendant has city and federal charges
Short narrative: On January 6, 2021 Taylor Franklin Taranto (37) a former member of the Armed Services, unlawfully entered the Capitol in Washington, D.C., and was charged with four different offenses: (1) Knowingly Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority, (2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, (3) Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds, (4) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Taranto attended a rally in Washington, D.C. before traveling to the Capitol grounds and joining a large crowd of rioters gathered on the Upper West Terrace of the building. I would list the tactic used under blocking/unlawful assembly which targeted a non-military non-judicial Federal site. Taranto was seen picking up and throwing pieces of metal scaffolding that were stacked on the ground. When asked to leave by Metropolitan Police, Taranto and other rioters scuffled with officers. After he was forced to exit he continued to remain on Capitol grounds. Taranto appears to have a social media account, under the pseudonym “Eraci Taranot”, which he runs with his wife. On August 14, 2021 a civil suit was filed against Taranto and co-defendant David Walls-Kaufman. In the past Taylor Taranto made threats against House Speaker Kevin McCarthy and Maryland Democratic Republican Jamie Raskin, so there seems to be a socio-political motive behind storming the Capitol.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Article, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Stephen Alexander Ondulich
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: "Steven Ondulich sentenced 5/20/24  to thirty-six (36) months of probation to run concurrently and to include 45 days of Home Detention, Restitution of $500, fine of $1,000 and special assessment of $20."; Resident of MD;
Short narrative: "Stephen Ondulich first came to the attention of the FBI after a tipster reported he was inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to federal prosecutors. On social media, Ondulich allegedly wrote the following: “We took the capitol BACK from the communist scum that is the Democrats … Our cause is not destruction like BLM/Antifa … There was no violence … And yes. We did go into the democrats offices … and they are enemies of the people. And deserve to die a traitors death.” According to federal court records, Ondulich entered the Capitol from a door located in the Senate Wing, from the Northwest Terrace, carrying a flag." (NPR) Ondulich was sentenced to 36 months probation.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Local News Articles;

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Asbury
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Knoxville, TN
Short narrative: On June 27, 2023, a criminal complaint was issued against Michael Asbury, 43, of Knoxville, TN for civil disorder, entering and remaining on restricted grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, engaging in physical violence on restricted grounds, disorderly or disruptive conduct in the Capitol grounds or building, and acts of physical violence in the Capitol grounds. During the protest, Asbury was at the front of the crowd in the Lower West Terrace, directly disarming police officers and handing shields and a stun gun to members of the crowd behind him. Along with videos of the protest posted on his Facebook page, Asbury noted in a public comment that the protest was "about our constitution" and that people should be thanking the Capitol protesters. "Michael Asbury Sentenced 8/26/24 to four months imprisonment, 24 months of supervised release, the first four months of which are home detention, and ordered to pay $2,000 in restitution"
Source description: Charging documents; court documents; news articles; governmental reports and release;

Name of case: United States of America v. Devin McNulty
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231 Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752 (a)(2) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Biulding; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of Loudon, TN
Short narrative: "Devin McNulty, 27, of Loudon, Tennessee, is charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers, civil disorder, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, and an act of physical violence in a Capitol Building or on Capitol Grounds. He was arrested on June 13, 2023...According to court documents, on Jan. 6, 2021, McNulty was first seen among the crowd located on the west front of the Capitol building. From there, McNulty scaled the retaining wall to reach the upper west terrace of the U.S. Capitol. In surveillance footage, McNulty can be seen walking from the west side of the U.S. Capitol to the north side at 2:52 p.m. McNulty then followed the terrace around to the north door of U.S. Capitol, where a large group of rioters gathered and attempted to breach into the building...When McNulty approached the north door, he appeared to be affected by a chemical irritant, causing him to turn back to the crowd. As he did so, McNulty raised and pumped his fist into the air. Later, video footage shows an alarm coming from the Capitol building as well as loud music in the crowd. Eventually, some law enforcement officers moved between the rioters and the north door. One officer told the rioters, “Get back, everyone get back.” When the crowd demands that the officer let them into the Capitol building, the same officer responds, “I can’t do that.” McNulty is visible to the right of the officer...Later, additional law enforcement officers arrived to clear the terrace of the rioters. As that happened, McNulty stood in front of the line of officers and violently pushed against one officer’s riot shield multiple times over the course of several seconds. The officer, a member of the Prince George’s County Police Department, was interviewed about the incident after January 6. The officer claimed to distinctly remember the interaction with McNulty as aggressive and persistent. The officer explained that McNulty tried to gain control of their shields and that the officers had to exert increasingly more effort to counter McNulty’s force." (DOJ Press Release) He was sentenced to 12 months in prison.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Benjamin John Silva
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752 (a)(2) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building of Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding Passage through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
Additional details: Resident of Yacolt, WA; Sentenced 9/17/24 to four months in prison, 24 months of supervised release to include four months’ of home incarceration, and ordered to pay $2,000 in restitution
Short narrative: On January 6, 2021 Benjamin John Silva (36), unlawfully entered the Capitol in Washington, D.C., and was charged with five different offenses: (1) Civil Disorder, (2) Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, (3) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, (4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building of Grounds, (5) Impeding Passage through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings. In two separate videos on social media, Benjamin Silva yells “Push” and “Let’s go” as he enters the Lower West Terrace Tunnel according to federal prosecutors. The videos also appear to show Silva going all the way to the line of police officers guarding it and speaking to an officer, as well as pushing against their shields. Officers then sprayed a chemical irritant and Silva, with his head down, is seen leaving the tunnel. Due to his violent behavior, the two main tactics used to target this non-military non-judicial Federal site would be unarmed assault and blockading/unlawful assembly. His motive behind entering the Capitol is not explicitly stated.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Article, Governmental Reports and Release
