Name of case: United States of America v. Bierbrodt & Bierbrodt
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1754(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder;
Additional details: Resident of IL
Short narrative: "Federal prosecutors allege that Joseph Bierbrodt assaulted law enforcement officers on Jan. 6, 2021, alongside his brother William Bierbrodt, who is also charged. Surveillance footage allegedly shows Joseph Bierbrodt storm through an open door and assault two officers who are trying to guard the entrance. Federal court records say he was then pepper sprayed. According to the FBI statement of facts, Joseph Bierbrodt was a member of the Illinois Army National Guard." (NPR) FBI identified Joseph through the open source investigation of brother referred to as #CrowbarBeardGuy. Video was submitted to DoD for facial recognition, and a fellow Army National guard member was interviewed by the FBI to also confirm his identity.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Bierbrodt & Bierbrodt
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Physical violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorder Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:1361 Willfully injure or depredate any property of the United State; 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder
Additional details: Resident of FL
Short narrative: "William Bierbrodt, also known online as #CrowbarBeardGuy because of his very long beard, allegedly broke into the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Earlier in the day, federal court records state that Bierbrodt can be seen carrying a cane and on a scooter to help with mobility due to a foot injury. According to court documents, Bierbrodt used the cane to break a window next to the Senate Fire Door, then unlatched the locked door and let more rioters in. The door has been assessed to be worth over a thousand dollars. According to the FBI, Bierbrodt came to the Capitol with his brother Joseph Bierbrodt, who is also charged. William Bierbrodt allegedly wrote on Parler in December of 2020: “all the Obama cronies should be taken, stacked and shot in the head.”" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Article

Name of case: United States of Amerca v. Karthik Ramakrishnan
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Bluefield, VA; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Karthik Ramakrishnan Sentenced 12/14/23 to Six (6) months of Probation. $10 Special Assessment, $500 Fine and $500 Restitution. All remaining counts dismissed on government's oral motion."
Short narrative: "A little more than a year after the Jan. 6, 2021, riot, a business associate of Karthik Ramakrishnan contacted the FBI and told the bureau that Ramakrishnan had been in Washington, D.C., that day and had shown the associate photographs from the riot, federal court records state. When the tipster asked Ramakrishnan if he had entered the U.S. Capitol, he replied "I deny it." However, the FBI was allegedly able to identify Ramakrishnan in surveillance footage from inside the building that day. According to court records, Ramakrishnan walked around the building for 27 minutes" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Barber & Cramer
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: "Steven Barber Sentenced 5/15/24 to 2 years of probation, $20 special assessment and $500 restitution."; Resident of Tunkhannock, PA
Short narrative: Steven Boyd Barber and Esvetlana Cramer, a married couple, were arrested after a review of open source, body camera, and US Capitol surveillance videos for illegally entering the Capitol on January 6, 2021. Steven Barber took a plea deal and was sentenced on 5/15/24 to 2 years of probation, $20 special assessment and $500 restitution.
Source description: Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Azari & Azari
Charges: *18:111(b)(1) Use of a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of VA; son also arrested and charged separately (Farbod Azari)
Short narrative: On January 13, 2023, Farhad Azari was charged with several crimes for his violent actions at the Capitol riot on January 6, 2021. Azari threw a number of items at police officers, such as a water bottle, a flagpole, and an airhorn. He then entered the Capitol building through a broken window.
Source description: Court Documents, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Azari & Azari
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of VA; father also arrested and charged separately (Farhad Azari)
Short narrative: "The FBI was tipped off to the presence of Farbod Azari and his father, Farhad, at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, by a witness claiming to have seen photographs and videos of the two men at the riot. According to court records, another witness also left an anonymous tip saying they had been shown videos of the pair storming the building, as well as photos, including some of Azari's father, Farhad, sitting in Nancy Pelosi’s chair. Additional videos referenced in the court documents appear to show Azari spitting at officers, and pulling down fencing around the Capitol. As the crowd pushed towards the building, Azari allegedly picked up a blue and white flag emblazoned with the word “Trump,” and swung it at officers. When the barricades were finally broken, Azari was at the front of the group, motioning others to follow him, court records state. Both Azari and his father said that they had not been at the Capitol on Jan. 6, and that they had been at the son's house all day." (NPR)
Source description: Government reports and release; Charging documents; Court Documents;

Name of case: United States of America v. Jason Herold Curl
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Des Moines, IA; fiancee Deborah Sandoval (03092021_DS_SANDOVAL1) also arrested and informed FBI of Curl's involvement; "Jason Curl Sentenced 6/6/24 to Twenty-Four (24) months of probation as to each of counts 3 and 4, to run concurrently. Special Assessment of $10 on each count (for a total of $20). A Fine of $1000 and Restitution of $500."
Short narrative: Jason Herold Curl, 48, of Des Moines, IA, is federally charged following his participation in the Capitol riot. Curl was identified after his fiance, Deborah Sandoval, who also participated in the Capitol riot, informed the FBI of Curl's participation. He was then additionally identified via CCTV footage from the Capitol. His case is ongoing.
Source description: Charging Document, Court Document

Name of case: United States of America v. Daniel Donnelly Jr.
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; *18:641 Theft of government property;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of St. Louis, MO; Defendant changed name from Daniel Donnelly Jr. to Rally Runner on/around October 2023
Short narrative: Daniel Donnelly Jr (aka Rally Runner) of St. Louis, MO was arrested for felony civil disorder along with several misdemeanors for his involvement in the January 6th, 2021 insurrection. Donnelly posted a 26 minute video on Facebook, detailing his actions that day. Other open source video and Capitol CCTV show Donnelly at the front of a group of rioters in a Lower West Terrace tunnel entrance using a police riot shield to push back police. He is also seen removing items from a police bag. Donnelly was easily identified by his distinctive clothing and red face paint; he is also a well known Cardinal's baseball fan and publicly goes by the nickname "Rally Runner." DMV records indicate he has legally changed his name to Rally Runner. "Rally Runner Sentenced 8/15/24 to 10 months in prison, 24 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $3,000 in fines and restitution"
Source description: Charging Documents, Government reports and releases, local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Angelo Jude Pacheco
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752 (a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Kansas City, MO; sentenced to 24 months probation, 30 days house arrest, $500 restitution
Short narrative: In 2023, Angelo Jude Pacheco, 24, of MO, was charged with Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. He was only convicted of Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Pacheco was identified via an anonymous tip as well as Capitol surveillance footage. Pacheco's motivation is unclear at this time. Pacheco accepted a plea deal pleading guilty to charge 4 of the indictment and was sentenced to 24 months probation.
Source description: Charging Documents, Government reports and releases, local news article

Additional details: Resident of Palm Beach, FL

Name of case: United States of America v. Jacquelyn J. Starer
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:1362 2, Destruction of property in special maritime and territorial jurisdiction and aiding and abetting;
Additional details: Resident of MA; Works as a medical doctor
Short narrative: "Jacquelyn Starer, 68, of Ashland, Massachusetts, is charged by criminal complaint, filed in the District of Columbia, with civil disorder, a felony; assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; and engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds. She was arrested today in Ashland. She is expected to make her initial appearance later today in the District of Massachusetts. According to court documents, on Jan. 6, 2021, Starer illegally entered Capitol grounds. She went into the Capitol through the East Rotunda Doors. Video from body worn cameras worn by Metropolitan Police Department (MPD) officers shows Starer approach MPD officers and make contact with an MPD officer at approximately 2:59 p.m. Shortly thereafter, Starer struck an MPD Officer. At approximately 3:06pm, surveillance video shows Starer exited the U.S. Capitol from the East Rotunda Doors. Additional reviews of open-source video also show Starer, on January 6, 2021, exiting the east side of the U.S. Capitol Building." (DOJ press release)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Corey Horan
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Oceanside, CA;
Short narrative: Corey Horan, #, of Oceanside, CA, is charged with knowingly remaining on restricted grounds, disorderly conduct on restricted grounds, and parading in the Capitol building. On January 6, 2021, Horan entered the Capitol building through the Senate Wing door and filmed himself in the crowd. The FBI identified Horan initially through a search warrant served on Google for location data, corroborated by flight records and later, identification by a work colleage.
Source description: Charging Docments; Court Documents;

Name of case: United States of America v. Tyler Bradley Dykes
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Causing Significant Bodily Injury; 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Bluffton, SC; Attended Unite the Right in Charlottesville; former USMC; "Tyler Dykes Sentenced 7/19/24 To Fifty-Seven Months Incarceration As To Count 3 and 4 To Run Concurrent Followed By A Supervised Release Period (With Conditions) Of Thirty-Six (36) Months To Run Concurrent, $20.000.00 Fine, $2000.00 Restitution And A Special Assessment OF $200.00"
Short narrative: Tyler Dykes, 25, of Bluffton, SC, is charged with entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority, engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Causing Significant Bodily Injury, Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder, Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers, Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, an Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building, and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. On January 6, 2021, Dykes participated in tearing down barriers and overwhelming a line of police officers, during which he took a riot shield. Dykes later revealed he was at the Capitol for fun, wanting to make a statement. Dykes was identified with the aid of crowd-sourced policing. Dykes accepted a plea deal.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; News Articles; Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Christopher Brian Roe
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers [3]; *18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1361 Destruction of Government Property; *18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Raytown, MO; Sentenced 3/6/24 as to Count(s) 1: Seventy (70) Months incarceration followed by Twenty-four (24) Months term of Supervised Release and a Special Assessment of $100;
Short narrative: Christopher Roe, 39, of Raytown, MO, pled guilty to assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers; civil disorder for his role in the January 6 Capitol Raid. On January 6, 2021, Roe attended a "Stop the Steal" rally before heading to the Capitol carrying a pitchfork and a six inch dagger. As an officer pushed Roe near the exit of the east entrance, Roe told the officer "You are protecting traitors and treasonists" and grabbed at the officer's baton before leaving. Later, Roe rammed a bike rack into the North Door and successfully broke the door down. According to his Statement of Facts, he and other rioters caused $980 in damage and repair costs to the interior doors at the north entrance of the Capitol Building.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Adrian Christian Schmidt
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752 (a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Cincinnati, OH
Short narrative: On January 6, 2021 Adrian Christian Schmidt (25), unlawfully entered the Capitol in Washington, D.C., and was charged with five different offenses: (1) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder, (2) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, (3) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, (4) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, (5) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. He was allegedly part of a mob that pushed against police officers' riot shields on the lower west terrace therefore, there is reason to believe unarmed assault and blockading/unlawful assembly were the two main tactics used. Social media screenshots in the Statement of Facts show that Schmidt was planning to attend the January 6 rally in DC, so targeting this non-military non-judicial Federal site could’ve been for socio-political reasons.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Article, Governmental Reports and Release, Other

Name of case: United States of America v. Antony Vo
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: "Antony Vo Sentenced 4/10/24  to nine (9) months incarceration on counts 1s-2s to run concurrent with counts 2s-4s; six (6) months incarceration on count 3s to run consecutive to count 4s and concurrent with counts 1s-2s; three (3) months incarceration on count 4s to run consecutive to count 3s and concurrent with counts 1s-2s, followed by twelve (12) concurrent months of Supervised Release as to counts 1s-2s, Special Assessments totaling $70, and a $1000 Fine."; Resident of IN; Mother also present at Capitol riot
Short narrative: In 2021, Antony Vo, 28, was charged with knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and parading, demonstrating, or picking in a Capitol building. Vo participated in the Capitol riot alongside his mother, Annie Vo, although she was identified several years after Antony. Antony pleaded guilty to his charges and was found guilty of all 4 counts by a jury. He is awaiting sentencing. Vo was sentenced to 9 months in prison.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Clary & Clary
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor];
Additional details: Resident of Tennessee; wore red "Make America Great Again" baseball cap; mother of Xyan Claryl "Nico Clary Sentenced 6/18/24 to Three (3) Years Probation; Special Assessment in the amount of $25 imposed; Restitution in the amount of $500 imposed; and Fine in the amount of $1,800 imposed."
Short narrative: On August 8, 2023, Xyan Clary and Nico Clary were charged with a criminal complaint for alleged, "entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds disorderly conduct in a Capitol building or grounds, parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building" (Criminal Complaint). On January 6, 2021, Xyan and Nico climbed the Northwest Stairs and paused at the Upper West Terrace before heading to the Senate Wing Door and entering the Capitol (Statement of Facts). Xyan and Nico were in the Capitol for approximately five minutes before leaving (Statement of Facts). The two remained on Capitol grounds until members of the Metropolitan Police Department and the Unites State Capitol Police (USCP) removed them (Statement of Facts).
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Brett Alan Rotella
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;
Additional details: Resident of Kannapolis, North Carolina
Short narrative: "The FBI...arrested the North Carolina man that led the charge into the U.S. Capitol’s lower west terrace tunnel, resulting in an hours-long melee with police officers on Jan. 6. Video shows that Brett Rena Rotella was the first rioter to enter the tunnel, taking pepper ball shots from cops as he led fellow insurrectionists closer to the Capitol. Dozens of rioters poured in behind him, forcing officers to retreat as the mob chased them towards the building, according to an FBI affidavit. Rotella was given the nickname #SleevelessRedTattoos by online sleuths for his lack of warm-weather attire in the sub-40-degree January weather. He faces felony charges of obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder and assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers, among other misdemeanor charges..." (Daily Beast)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents; News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Ulises Wilkinson
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) Enter or Remain in the Gallery of Either House of Congress in Violation of Rules; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds or in any of the Capitol Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parade, Demonstrate, or Picket in any of the Capitol Buildings
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: "Ulises Wilkinson Sentenced 6/28/24 to 12 months (1 year) probation on Counts 4 and 5, to run concurrent. Special Assessment of $10 on each count (for a total of $20) and Restitution of $500."
Short narrative: In 2023, Ulises Wilkinson, 25, was charged with Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Enter or Remain in the Gallery of Either House of Congress in Violation of Rules; Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds or in any of the Capitol Buildings; and Parade, Demonstrate, or Picket in any of the Capitol Buildings following his participation in the Capitol riot. Wilkinson was identified via a confidential human source as well as numerous images and vides taken from inside the Capitol. After being identified, Wilkinson agreed to a phone interview with agents where he acknowledged his participation in the riot. Additionally, a remorseful note was found in Wilkinson's phone stating he "regretted it since the moment I stepped foot inside" (affidavit). Wilkinson's case is ongoing.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Zachariah Boulton
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in the Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident Georgia; "Zachariah Boulton Sentenced 2/6/24 to Twenty-Four (24) months of Probation on Count 1. A Special Assessment of $25, Fine of $500 and Restitution of $500."
Short narrative: On June 13, 2023, a criminal complaint was issued against Zachariah Boulton, 35, from Georgia for entering and remaining on restricted grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct on restricted grounds, and demonstrating on Capitol grounds. On January 6, 2021, Boulton entered the Capitol Rotunda from the Upper West Terrace Door. Boulton posted videos of his involvement in the January 6 United States Capitol attack on his TIktok account, greeneyedveteran, documenting his experience before the attack and while in the Rotunda.
Source description: Charging documents; court documents;

Name of case: United States of America v. Douglas Harrington
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; *18:1752(a)(4) Knowingly engaging in any act of physical violence against any person or property in any restricted building or grounds;
Additional details: Resident of Bedford, WY; "Douglas Harrington found guilty 7/31/24 at bench trial"
Short narrative: On January 6, 2021 Douglas Harrington (#), unlawfully entered the Capitol in Washington, D.C., and was charged with seven different offenses: (1) Civil Disorder, (2) Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers or Employees, (3) Using a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon to Assault, Resist, or Impede Officers or Employees, (4) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, (5) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, (6) Knowingly engaging in any act of physical violence against any person or property in any restricted building or grounds, (7) Obstruction of an Official Proceeding. “At the U.S. Capitol, Douglas Harrington wore a cowboy hat, goggles, a gas mask, and held a flagpole with a metal ball at the end, according to federal prosecutors. Video footage allegedly shows Harrington attempting to strike law enforcement with the flagpole.” According to federal court records, Harrington told an intimate partner that he helped cause the riot because the government devils don't get it, therefore, there is reason to believe he targeted this non-military non-judicial Federal site, for socio-political reasons. Due to his aggressive behavior there is reason to believe the two main tactics used were blockading/unlawful assembly and other weapons.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Bradley
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings [misdemeanor]; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Forsyth, Georgia; Michael Bradley Found guilty 8/28/24 at bench trial
Short narrative: "Michael Bradley, 49, of Forsyth, Georgia, is charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with felony offenses of civil disorder and assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers. In addition to the felonies, Bradley is charged with several misdemeanor offenses, including knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; and act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings" (DOJ). On January 6, 2021, Bradley attended the attack on the U.S. Capitol in Washington D.C.. He was located on the video footage moving towards a tunnel on the Lower West Terrace of the Capitol Building. Bradley watched as others beat and assaulted an officer on the ground and approached the tunnel two different times with the intent of assaulting officers with his baton. He swung and attempted to hit MPD officers two separate times.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Joseph Cattani
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) and 18:1752(a)(2) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Picketing, and Demonstrating in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor]
Additional details: Resident of Colgate, Wisconsin
Short narrative: On September 9, 2023, Joseph Cattani received an official criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia District Court. In the criminal complaint, Cattani allegedly committed "civil disorder and assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers, both felony offenses. In addition to the felonies, Cattani is charged with several misdemeanor offenses, including entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and parading, picketing, and demonstrating in a Capitol building" (Department of Justice). On November 1, 2021, in an interview with law enforcement Catanni said, "he was pushed inside the Capitol Building" and that "once inside, he approached someone who appeared to work in the Capitol Building to find out how to get out [and] the individual escorted him to a foyer and [he] crawled through a broken window to exit" (United States v. Joseph Cattani, Statement of Facts). Yet, on January 6, 2021, surveillance video captures Cattani "at the Rotunda doors to the Capitol building as he uses his right hand to grab the face shield of the U.S. Capitol Police (UCSP) officer [and] pull[ed] the face shield up and down as the officer's head twists and turns," "entering the Capitol through the Routunda Doors," and "travel[ing] to other areas of the Capitol building" (Department of Justice).
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Luke Hoffman
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of Covington, KY;
Short narrative: Luke Hoffman, 39, of Covington, KY, is charged with civil disorder; assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers with a dangerous weapon; entering restricted grounds with a deadly weapon; disorderly conduct in restricted grounds with a deadly weapon; engaging in physical violence on restricted grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; and an act of physical violence on Capitol grounds. On January 6, 2021, at the West Plaza, Hoffman took bike racks away from officers, attempted to take a baton, and sprayed a chemical irritant at police. While in the tunnel of the Lower West Terrace, Hoffman allowed other rioters to stand on his shoulders as they attacked officers with objects including a flagpole. FBI agents identified Hoffman through a social media post made on Parler by Kari Hoffman, his wife, who wrote "I'm so proud of my husband! He stood up for America today!! Were you a part of today, too?" "Luke Hoffman Sentenced 9/13/24 to 20 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $2,000 in restitution".

Name of case: United States of America v. Nhi Ngoc Mai Le
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

Name of case: United States of America v. James Ray Epps Sr
Charges: 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds
Additional details: Resident of Queen Creek, AZ
Short narrative: James Ray Epps, Sr, was arrested for disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds due to his actions that were extensively caught on video on January 6th. Epps was shown on other defedant's livestreams, other videos, and was interviewed by media during an impromptu rally on Jan 5th and at the Capitol on Jan 6th. After the FBI posted his image on January 6th as a "person of interest", Epps called the FBI to identify himself and was voluntarily interviewed. In that and subsequent interviews, he admitted to disorderly conduct.
Source description: Charging Document, Court Document, Local news

Name of case: United States of America v. Adams
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a capitol building or grounds 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building

Short narrative: Dustin and Karla Adams of Hillsdale, of Michigan, allegedly can be seen entering the U.S. Capitol through Facebook and video surveillance on January 6. According to the Statement of Facts, Dustin and Karla entered the U.S. Capitol building through the Senate Wing Door. After a few minutes, Karla and Dustin existed in the same way they entered. The married couple are charged with Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly conduct in a capitol building or grounds; Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. Both defendants pled not guilty, and the case is still pending.

Name of case: United States of America v. Matthew Schmitz
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752 (a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Lindenhurst, NY
Short narrative: On January 6, 2021 Matthew Schmitz, (#) unlawfully entered the Capitol in Washington, D.C., and was charged with four different offenses: (1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, (2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, (3) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, (4) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Video footage and security camera images obtained by the FBI showed Schmitz participating in the riot. After tear gas was deployed in a Capitol hallway Schmitz exited through a window next to the Senate Wing Door. The Statement of Facts doesn’t explicitly state his motive behind entering this non-military non-judicial Federal site, but there is reason to believe the tactic used was blockading/unlawful assembly.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Cody Lee Tippett
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752 (a)(2) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: "Cody Tippett Sentenced 4/4/24 to a term of 30 days as to Count 3. The Defendant is further sentenced to serve a 3 year term of Probation as to Count 4, to pay a $20 special assessment ($10 as to each Count) and to pay $500 in restitution."; Resident of Grove City, OH
Short narrative: Cody Tippett, 32, of Grove City, OH, is charged with entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building or grounds, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building. Tippett traveled with Dustin Martin to the D.C. area, and during the protest on January 6, 2021, Tippett remained in the Lower West Terrace, later moving to the Upper West Terrace, where he was sprayed with pepper spray and forced to leave. Tippett was sentenced to 30 days in prison followed by probation.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; News Articles;

Name of case: United States of America v. Steven Cook
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings [misdemeanor]; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Bethesda, Maryland
Short narrative: On September 27, 2023, Steven Cook of Bethesda, Maryland, was indicted for two felony charges: "assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers," and "obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder" (Department of Justice). He was also indicted with several misdemeanors including: "entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, and engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds" (Department of Justice). According to the "United States v. Steven Cook" charging documents, various body-worn cameras illustrated Cook pushing and hitting police officers after the police line securing the West Plaza of the U.S. Capitol broke. Various body-worn cameras also show Cook "pushing into the police line" in the Lower West Terrance door of the U.S. Capitol ("United States v. Steven Cook," ¶ 15, pg.10). He was sentenced to 28 months in prison.
Source description: Charging Documents; Governmental Reports and Release; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Peter Willey & Ethan Mauck
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Troutville, Virginia; history of previous misdemeanor convictions
Short narrative: Peter Willey, 37, of Roanoke, Virginia, and Ethan Mauck, 31, of Troutville, Virginia, are charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with a felony offense of obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder. In addition to the felony, Willey and Mauck are charged with misdemeanor offenses of entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building or grounds. Willey and other rioters began to move a large sign on wheels with a metal frame towards the police line and barricade, using it as a battering ram against the law enforcement officers attempting to hold the line. As the large sign passed over Willey’s head, Willey placed his hands on the billboard’s frame and pushed it toward the police line. As the officers gained control of the large metal sign, Willey is seen blocking his face with his arms and running away from an officer who deployed pepper spray at the rioters, including Willey.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Marroquin
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of Justice/Congress and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(A) Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Condut in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Nederland, TX;
Short narrative: "The day after the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol, a tip was submitted to the FBI showing a screenshot of an Instagram story. It showed a man in a red Trump hat, wearing a black hoodie with an orange Q on it. The photo also included an emoji of eyes and the caption, “If you know, you know…” The tipster did, in fact, know, and identified the man to the FBI as Michael Marroquin, according to federal court documents. Marroquin had posted several times on Facebook about plans to attend former President Trump's rally in Washington, D.C., and also allegedly posted after the riot as well, saying he was there and claiming Antifa were among the crowd. In August of 2021, the FBI received a package containing a Verizon phone and the message: “THERE IS PHOTO, VIDEO AND OTHER EVIDENCE ON THIS DEVICE THAT IMPLICATES THE OWNER AS A PARTICIPENT [sic] IN THE JANUARY 6, 2021 CAPITOL RIOT." On the phone, there were multiple recordings that Marroquin allegedly took inside the Capitol that day, including one looking through a broken door at the faces of law enforcement with their weapons drawn. In an interview with the FBI, Marroquin admitted to entering the building, court records state. He also said he fell asleep on a train on the way back to his hotel. When he woke up, his cell phone was gone and he had not seen it since." (NPR)
Source description: Court Documents; Local News Articles; Governmental Reports and Release;

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND State speech act
Name of case: United States of America v. Peter Michael Krill, Jr.
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder
Additional details: Resident of Sewell, NJ; additionally sentenced to 12 months supervised release, $2000 restitution
Short narrative: On September 28, 2023, Peter M. Krill, Jr., 55, of Sewell, New Jersey, was charged with a federal offense in a bill of information, stemming from his activities at the United States Capitol on January 6, 2021. Peter M. Krill was part of a mob of rioters who pushed into police officers who were attempting to establish a perimeter. He removed a metal bike rack, allowing other rioters to proceed past the police. Krill was unarmed but wearing a combat-style helmet and goggles. He was reportedly one of the last individuals to exit the Rotunda after repeatedly ignoring law enforcement orders to vacate.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Anna Lichnowski
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Condut in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Brick Township, NJ
Short narrative: Anna Lichnowski was identified as a member of the crowd that illegally entered the Capitol after tipsters called the FBI, saying she posted pictures on Facebook and was telling people she had been inside. FBI interviewed a detective with the Brick Township Police Department. The detective knew Lichnowski as a personal acquaintance from growing up together. FBI also identified her through her hotel receipt through Booking.com, surveilliance, and open source video footage of the day. Case is ongoing.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Israel Mark Matson
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G): Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Ogden, Utah; "Defendant sentenced to twelve (12) months of Probation (with conditions). $10 Special Assessment and Restitution in the amount of $500.00."
Short narrative: On October 4, 2023, Israel Mark Matson, 25, of Ogden, Utah was charged in a bill of information for his involvement in the January 6, 2021 insurrection. According to the statement of facts "Law enforcement investigated Matson based on information and photographs of him inside and outside the U.S. Capitol" (Statement of Facts 2). He entered the building and illegally walked about the interior with the rest of the mob for about thirty-two minutes. After law enforcement identified him, they set up an interview with Matson where he confirmed that he was the individual in several of the photos picked out from the day in question. He was charged with 40:5104(e)(2)(G): Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; News Articles

Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1361 Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly andDisruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Wepon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: Resident of CA

Braun was identified after an his Uber driver tipped him off to the FBI, saying that he bragged about his participation in the riot while in the car.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Ryan Wilson
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:111(b)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon); 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;
Additional details: Resident of Athena, Oregon
Short narrative: Ryan Wilson, 40, of Athena, Oregon, is charged with felony offenses of obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder and assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon. Wilson is also charged with several misdemeanors, including knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building or grounds, and act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings. On January 6, 2021, video footage depicts Wilson throwing a water bottle toward the police line during riots in the Lower West Terrace Tunnel of the United States Capitol. Wilson then grabs a pipe from another rioter and rams it toward the police "repeatedly and forcefully" (FBI). After a policeman sprays Wilson with OC spray, Wilson throws the pipe toward the police line and then exits the tunnel.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Marcus Clint Martin
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Melbourne, FL;
Short narrative: Marcus Martin, 32, of Melbourne, FL, is charged with obstructing law enforcement during civil disorder, assaulting an officer, knowingly remaining on restricted grounds, disorderly conduct on restricted grounds, and engaging in violence on restricted grounds. On January 6, 2021, Martin moved metal barricades away from the Capitol building and repeatedly yelled "Whose house? Our house" at the crowd. After attempting to administer first aid to another rioter, Martin grabbed at and shoved an officer away before being pepper sprayed. After identification from a confidential human source, the FBI corroborated Martin's presence at the Capitol through multiple social media videos and by accessing DMV records. Martin was sentenced to 32 months in prison.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Local News Articles;

Name of case: United States of America v. Paul Thomas Brinson
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a capitol building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Additional details: Resident of Flower Mound, TX
Short narrative: On October 10, 2023, Paul Thomas Brinson was arrested for entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly conduct in a capitol building or ground; Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. Through video surveillance and Brinson's Facebook posts, he can be seen entering the Capitol Building on January 2, 2021. He admitted to using barricades and bike racks as ladders to enter the Capitol. He entered through the Senate Wing door and spent 45 minutes in the building. He then exits the Capitol Building through the East Front House Door.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Valdez & Valdez
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Aurora, Colorado
Short narrative: Daniel Jay Valdez, 59, and his son, Payton John Valdezare, 30, of Aurora, Colorado, are charged with knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. Through text messages, Facebook posts, and surveillance video, the pair attended the riots on the Capitol on January 6, 2023 because Daniel believed that "President Trump was going to tell everything about who in politics was sex trafficking children" (Statement of Facts). Daniel and Payton were inside the Capitol building for around nine minutes, entering and exiting through a broken window next to the Senate Wing Door. Pictures of Payton holding a law enforcement riot shield and a beverage can be seen inside the Capitol.
Source description: Charging Documents, News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Joshua Curtis Coker
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752 (a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: 36 months probation; Resident of Oregon, OH
Short narrative: On January 6, 2021, Joshua Curtis Coker (45), unlawfully entered the Capitol in Washington, D.C., and was charged with five different offenses: (1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, (2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, (3) Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress, (4) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, (5) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Facial recognition software returned images of Coker walking to, and entering the Capitol. The motive behind the defendant's intention to enter the Capitol is not explicitly stated, however, the tactic used to target this non-military non-judicial Federal site is blockading/unlawful assembly. Coker was sentenced to 36 months probation.
Source description: Charging Docments; Court Documents; Local News Article

Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40: 5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building [misdemeanor];

(Department of Justice). Lee was indicted for civil disorder, assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings (Department of Justice). Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; News Articles; Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Rockne Earles
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Chama, New Mexico
Short narrative: "Rockne Gerard Earles, 62, of Chama, New Mexico, formerly of Oriska, North Dakota, is charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers, civil disorder, both felonies, and the misdemeanor charges of entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building" (DOJ). Earles allegedly participated in the Capitol Riots on January 6, 2021, in the West Front of the U.S. Capitol, according to posts on his Facebook page, surveillance video footage, and cellphone records. In the surveillance footage, Earles grabs and throws an officer to the ground with force. Eales then proceeds to assault the officer with two other rioters, resulting in injuries to the officer.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Benjamin Cohen
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
Additional details: Resident of Westport, CT
Short narrative: On January 6, 2021 Benjamin Cohen (21), unlawfully entered the Capitol in Washington, D.C., and was charged with six different offenses: (1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Officers, (2) Civil Disorder, (3) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, (4) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, (5) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds, (6) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings. Between approximately 2:28 p.m. and 2:30 p.m. Coker is seen assaulting U.S. Capitol Police and Metropolitan Police Department Officers on the West Plaza of the Capitol. Cohen’s father told FBI investigators that Benjamin attended the political rally taking place that day alongside his mother. Since he was there in support of then-President Donald Trump there is reason to believe Benjamin joined the march to the Capitol building for socio-political reasons. “For almost two hours, Benjamin Cohen joined other rioters in their efforts to push a line of police officers, both on the West Plaza and in the Lower West Terrace tunnel. At one point, open-source video and police body-worn camera footage allegedly show Cohen and others breaching the police line where Cohen is seen making physical contact by pushing and shoving officers with his hands. In the tunnel, he allegedly joined others in a “heave-ho” effort, as they coordinated to push the officers (NPR).” During the time of the insurrection, the two main tactics used by Cohen to target this non-military non-judicial Federal site, were unarmed assault and blockading/unlawful assembly.
Source description: Charging Docments; Court Documents; News Article; Local News Article; Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. William Frederocl Beals, II
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:641 Theft of Government Property; 18:1001 Knowingly Make False statements Within the Jurisdiction of the Branches of Government
Additional details: Resident of Georgia
Short narrative: William Frederick Beals, II, 52, of Ringgold, Georgia, is charged in a criminal complaint with knowingly making false statements within the jurisdiction of the branches of government, a felony offense. In addition to the felony, Beals is also charged with knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building or grounds, parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building; and theft of government property. Beals was arrested on Aug. 24, 2023, in Adairsville, Georgia, and made his initial appearance in the Eastern District of Tennessee.William Beals was discovered as being part of the Capitol protests after the doj was investigating another rioter through their text messages. Beals admitted in the text that he had a riot shield confiscated by the police and stated that he hew it was easy to get in to the Capitol. Investigation revealed Beals traveled from his then-home in Tennessee on or about January 5, 2021, to Washington, DC. He attended the pre-“Stop The Steal” Rally activities at the Black Lives Matter Plaza to protest the certification of the Electoral College for the 2020 Presidential elections. Beals also is facing 3 previous charges from Catoosa County.Court documents we obtained say William Beals was accused of battery, child cruelty, and trespassing in September of 2022.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Ryan Keith Yates
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor];
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Holiday, Florida; "Ryan Yates Sentenced 6/12/24 to a term of Six (6) Months of Incarceration, followed by a term of Twenty-Four (24) Months of Supervised Release. As a condition of his supervised release, the defendant is sentenced to Three (3) Months of Home Detention. Special Assessment of $100. Restitution imposed in the amount of $2,000."
Short narrative: On October 25, 2023, Ryan Keith Yates of Holiday, Florida, was indicted for civil disorder, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building ("United States v. Ryan Keith Yates," Indictment). On January 6, 2021, Ryan Keith Yates allegedly entered the U.S. Capitol, in Washington, D.C., and joined other rioters as they "rushed from the outside to get into the Rotunda" ("United States v. Ryan Keith Yates," Statement of Facts, ¶ 13, pg. 7). Yates then "worked his way to the front of the group, and, along with a handful of other rioters, was able to push against police to get inside the Rotunda" ("United States v. Ryan Keith Yates" Statement of Facts, ¶ 13, pg. 7). Afterward, Yates was escorted from the Capitol by the police ("United States v. Ryan Keith Yates" Statement of Facts, ¶ 13, pg. 7).
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Governmental Reports and Release;

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND State speech act
Name of case: United States of America v. Elliot Patrick Williams
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in Capitol building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Spokane, Washington; Sentenced on April 18, 2024 to 30 days incarceration on Count 2 of the information; additionally sentenced to one year of supervised release and $500 restitution.
Short narrative: On October 26, 2023, Elliot Patrick Williams, 21, was indicted for four federal offenses relating to the January 6 Capitol riots. An online tipster that recognized Williams in the CCTV footage from the event and notified the FBI. The footage showed this individual illegally entering the Capitol building and moving throughout the interior, including around the outside of Nancy Pelosi's office. He exited the building once and then re-entered again before being one of the final protestors to be removed from the Rotunda by police. In a voluntary interview, Williams admitted that he had traveled to Washington, D.C. to attend President Trump's rally at the Ellipse, entered the Capitol twice, and saw other rioters doused with pepper spray and carried out on stretchers. While inside, he tried to break open a cabinet in an attempt to find tissues to deal with the pepper spray in the air. Additionally, he told law enforcement and a friend he texted afterwards that he was part of a mob that participated in a heave-ho effort trying to push futher into the building; this throng of people was eventually repelled.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Bowling
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly enter or remain in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority to do; 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly and with intent to impede or disrupt the orderly conduct of government business; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of AL; "Dylan and Marisa Bowling Sentenced 7/19/24 to twenty-four (24) months of probation as to counts 3 and 4 with each to run concurrently. The first 30 days of Defendant DYLAN BOWLING'S (2) term of probation are to be served on home detention. Counts 1 and 2 as to both Defendants dismissed by USA's oral motion. Both Defendants to pay $20 special assessment and $500 restitution."
Short narrative: On January 6, 2021, Dylan and Marissa Lee Bowling allegedly were seen on CCTV entering the Capitol through a broken window and exit the Capitol through the same window 21 minutes later. Both deny entering the building. Marissa Bowling was arrested November 1, 2023. The case is ongoing.
Source description: Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States v. Howard Freelove
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor]; 40:5014(e)(2)(G) Parading, Picketing, and Demonstrating in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor];
Additional details: Resident of Chula Vista, California; wore a red "TRUMP" baseball cap
Short narrative: On October 30, 2023, Howard Raymond Freelove, was charged with allegedly "knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a capitol building, and parading, picketing, and demonstrating in a Capitol building. On January 6, 2021, after attending the "Stop the Steal' rally, Freelove entered the Capitol, through the Rotunda Doors, when they (the Rotunda Doors) "were breached by a large crowd of rioters" (Statement of Facts). Freelove lingered in the Rotunda, entered the Statuary Hall, returned to the Rotunda, and then exited the Capitol.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents

Charges: 18:1752(a)(1): Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2): Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly Conduct a Capitol Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G): Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;

On January 6, 2021, "numerous photographs and screenshots from videos...show[s] Mahoney in and around the Capitol Building" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). CCTV also showed Mahoney inside the Capitol. (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts).
