Name of case: United States of America v. Jared Miller
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder
Additional details: Resident of Chesapeake, VA; served as "sharpshooter" trainer for Constitutional Defense League
Short narrative: "Jared Miller, 37, of Chesapeake, Virginia, is charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with felony offenses of civil disorder and assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers. In addition to the felonies, Miller is charged with multiple misdemeanor offenses, including knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; obstruct, or impede passage through or within, the grounds or any of the Capitol buildings; and violent entry and disorderly conduct. Miller was arrested on Aug. 23, 2023, in Chesapeake, Virginia and made his initial appearance in the Eastern District of Virginia...According to court documents, Miller attended a rally in Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6, 2021, and afterward walked to the United States Capitol building, where he entered the restricted grounds on the west side. Miller then joined a mob that had broken through multiple barriers and police lines. Soon, the mob, including Miller, became increasingly hostile towards United States capitol Police (USCP) officers, pushing officers back to the base of the Inaugural stage...At approximately 1:12 p.m., several units of Metropolitan Police Department (MPD) officers arrived at the West Plaza to assist USCP officers in crowd control. Miller and other rioters were held back behind bike rack barriers as MPD and USCP set up a line to prevent rioters from advancing. At about 1:16 p.m., the north side of the police line was breached by rioters. Closed-circuit television (CCTV) captured Miller joining this breach, first as he pushed an unidentified MDP officer and then he shoved an officer as the officer attempted to rejoin the police line...At 1:21 p.m., Miller is seen on body-worn cameras dragging a bike rack away from the northern side of the police lines. Miller then re-engaged with police, striking both USCP and MPD officers and driving barricades back into the police lines. Miller then grabbed an adjacent barricade and ripped it from unidentified MPD and USCP officers, who were pulled away with the barrier before regaining control. Miller is also captured on BWC as he reached over the barriers to hit officers before walking away from that portion of the police line...Miller eventually walked to the center of the West Plaza police line and is captured on body-worn camera footage tossing a water bottle at MPD officers. Miller remained on the restricted grounds, eventually making his way to the Lower West Terrace after the West Plaza police line was overrun at about 1:36 p.m." (DOJ)
Source description: Charging Document, Court Document

Name of case: United State of America v. Bryan Roger Bishop
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly and Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disroderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Marathon, FL; Accepted a plea deal pleading guilty to 18:111(a)(1)
Short narrative: Bryan Roger Bishop, 51, of Marathon, FL, was charted with in relation to the January 6th Capitol Riot. Bishop was seen in video participating in a riot and spraying two officers with a chemical substance. Bishop was identified via CCTV and body camera footage, as well as a BOLO, Sedition Hunters, and a witness. Bishop accepted a plea deal pleading guilty to 18:111(a)(1). This case is currently pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Release (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Joshua Parmenter
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor];
Additional details: Resident of Lancaster, Ohio
Short narrative: On November 15, 2023, Joshua Parmenter was indicted on four counts relating to the January 6 Capitol raid. In an interview with the FBI, Parmenter "advised that he traveled alone from Lancaster, Ohio to Washington D.C...to show his support for President Donald J. Trump and to protest against the election" (Charging Documents). Open-source videos and photos show Parmenter near the West Plaza of the Capitol and CCTV footage shows him entering the U.S. Capitol building through the Senate Wing Doors (Charging Documents).
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Siaka Tonia Massaquoi
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor];
Additional details: Resident of Moreno Valley, California
Short narrative: "Siaka Tonia Massaquoi is an L.A.-based actor and conservative activist who's had roles in television shows like S.W.A.T. and Lethal Weapon. According to court documents, Massaquoi traveled from California to Washington, D.C., on Jan. 5, 2021, and was present at the Capitol riot the following day. Surveillance videos, along with Massaquoi's own live stream, showed him entering the building through the Senate wing door at approximately 3:38 pm, and exiting two minutes later. He was arrested on Nov. 30, 2023." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents;

Name of case: United States of America v. Barber & Cramer
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: "Esvetlana Cramer Sentenced 5/15/24 to 2 years of probation, $20 special assessment and $500 restitution."; Resident of Harveys Lake, PA
Short narrative: Steven Boyd Barber and Esvetlana Cramer, a married couple, were arrested after a review of open source, body camera, and US Capitol surveillance videos for illegally entering the Capitol on January 6, 2021. Esvetlana Cramer took a plea deal and was sentenced 5/15/24 to 2 years of probation, $20 special assessment and $500 restitution.
Source description: Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Tonya Jean Bishop
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752 (a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Marathon, FL; Wife of Bryan Bishop; "Tonya Bishop Sentenced 7/11/24 to twenty-four (24) months of probation, $500 of restitution and $20 special assessment."
Short narrative: On January 6, 2021 Tonya Bishop aka Tonya Allison-Oberst (47), unlawfully entered the Capitol in Washington, D.C., and was charged with four different offenses: (1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, (2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, (3) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, (4) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. On August 7, 2023 she was arrested alongside her husband Bryan. There is reason to believe Bishop targeted this non-military non-judicial Federal site, for socio-political reasons due to an alleged call she had with her son on 01/04/2021 stating “On the 6th, Trump has called The Patriots together, a bunch of us are headed over there.” After reading the Statement of Facts the main tactic used seems to be blockading/unlawful assembly. Bishop was sentenced to 24 months probation
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Ryan Joseph Orlando
Charges: 18:641 Theft of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(A) Enter or remain on the floor of a House of Congress without authorization; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;

Name of case: United States of America v. Brent Meldrum
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Lynn, MA
Short narrative: "In the days leading up to Jan. 6, 2021, Brent Meldrum retweeted posts saying that “Its paramount that all Americans storm DC,” and imploring people to “Occupy The Capitol,” according to court documents. Meldrum was subsequently seen on security footage inside the Capitol building on Jan. 6, entering at 3:06 pm and being removed by Capitol Police around 3:33 pm. Meldrum was identified by federal agents after an anonymous tipster recognized him in a TikTok video exiting the Capitol building. When agents interviewed him in December, 2021, he refused to talk about the events of Jan. 6. He was arrested on Dec. 4, 2023." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents;

Name of case: United States of America v. Lawrence Silas Billiter
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Picketing, and Demonstrating in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor]
Additional details: Resident of Flint, Michigan (DOJ); Resident of Minot, North Dakota (United States of America v. Lawrence Silas Billiter, Statement of Facts)
Short narrative: On November 8, 2023, Lawrence Silas Billiter, was charged in the District of Columbia for allegedly "assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers and civil disorder. In addition to the felonies, Billiter [was] charged with several misdemeanor offenses, including entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a capitol building, act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings, and parading, picketing and demonstrating in a Capitol building" (DOJ). On January 6, 2021, after attending a Trump rally at the Ellipse, Billiter made his way to the Capitol (United States of America v. Lawrence Silas Billiter, Statement of Facts). A body-worn camera shows Billiter "throw a metal pole at a USCP officer" (United States of America v. Lawrence Silas Billiter, Statement of Facts). Then after some time, "Billiter and a group of rioters entered the U.S. Capitol through the Senate Parliamentarian door" (United States of America v. Lawrence Silas Billiter, Statement of Facts). "After Billiter exited the Capitol building a second time, he remained on Capitol grounds, and close to the building...before law enforcement pushed rioter en masse from the upper terraces near the building" (United States of America v. Lawrence Silas Billiter, Statement of Facts). Billiter was "among the last group of individuals on the U.S. Capitol steps as law enforcement attempted to push back the crowd" (United States of America v. Lawrence Silas Billiter, Statement of Facts).
Source description: Government Reports and Release; Charging Documents; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Tyler Roberts
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct on a Capitol Building [misdemeanor]
Additional details: Resident of Knoxville, Tennessee; During the investigation of Ronald Colton McAbee's actions during the January 6th riots, McAbee's telephone was seized and text messages showed that McAbee was texting Roberts and that the two traveled together from Tennessee to Washington D.C. and back (United States v. Michael Tyler Roberts, Statement of Facts).
Short narrative: On October 23, 2023, Michael Tyler Roberts of Knoxville, Tennessee, received a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia. Roberts allegedly committed "a felony offense of civil disorder and misdemeanor offenses of entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building" (Department of Justice). On January 6, 2021, images reveal Roberts emerging from rioters attempting to enter the Capitol through the "tunnel" leading to the Lower West Terrace Exterior Door (United States v. Michael Tyler Roberts, Statement of Facts). Surveillance footage near the tunnel shows Roberts "swiftly mov[ing] over and on top of other rioters in order to get to the police line," and "visibly grappling with the officers and grabbing hold of their hands and arms" (United States v. Michael Tyler Roberts, Statement of Facts).
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Richard Markey
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752 (a)(2) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of Wolcott, CT
Short narrative: Richard Markey, 38, of Wolcott, CT, is charged with assaulting a federal officer with a deadly or dangerous weapon; obstruction of law authority; disorderly or disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly or disruptive conduct in a Capitol building or grounds; obstructing or impeding passage within or through a Capitol building or grounds, and violent conduct in a Capitol building or grounds. Part of the rioters in the Lower West Terrace on January 6, 2021, Markey struck three officers in the face with a baton and, later, a wooden pole.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; News Articles;

Name of case: United States of America v. Spencer Offman
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in Any Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor];
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Novi, Michigan; "Spencer Offman Sentenced 7/12/24 on Count 1 to Thirty (30) days incarceration followed by Six (6) months of Supervised Release. $25 Special Assessment fee imposed. $500 Restitution imposed."
Short narrative: On December 1, 2023, Spencer Offman was charged for allegedly (1) knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority (2) disorderly or disruptive conduct in any restricted building or grounds (3) disorderly or disruptive conduct in a Capitol building (4) parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. On January 6, 2021, still images show Offman moving barricades at the Capitol. Also, "a review of the Capitol Police CCTV footage from the Senate Wing Door identified Offman entering the Capitol through one of the broken windows...[he was inside for less than ten minutes] Offman remained in view of the camera of the Senate Wing and did not go into any other rooms" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts).
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Davis & Bishop
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752 (a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Picketing, and Demonstrating in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor];
Additional details: Resident of Greene County, North Carolina; some sources refer to her as "Tonya" and the Statement of Facts refer to her as "Tanya"; Traveled to Capitol with male co-offender
Short narrative: On December 4, 2023, Curtis Davis and Tanya Bishop of Snow Hill, North Carolina were "charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with felony offenses of civil disorder and assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers. In addition to the felonies, the couple is charged with various misdemeanor offenses, including entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; and parading, picketing, and demonstrating in a Capitol building" (DOJ Press Release). MPD body-worn camera footage shows Davis "assaulting officers by punching towards an MPD officer," and another video shows him "pushing MPD officers inside the Capitol" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). In regards to Bishop, "the FBI was able to "locate more than ten videos in which also appear to show Bishop...inside the Capitol building and interacting with Davis. The videos also show Bishop interacting with law enforcement for an extended period of time" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). A YouTube video also showed "Davis aggressively yelling at officers and being held back by Bishop. The video then shows Davis fighting with law enforcement officers, including throwing punches towards officers and appearing to make contact with at least one punch against an MPD officer" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). Surveillance footage shows Davis and Bishop entering the Rotunda inside the U.S. Capitol Building, where Davis is captured shoving and punching law enforcement (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). It also captured Bishop placing her hands on and pushing police officers who were attempting to disperse rioters from the Rotunda (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). Both continued to "forcibly resisted, impeded, and interfered with MPD police officers attempting to remove rioters from the Rotunda before fleeting the area" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts ).
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Daniel Edwin Wilson
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Lousiville, Kentucky
Short narrative: In 2023, Daniel Edwin Wilson, 47, was charged with Obstruction of Justice/Congress; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in Capitol Building following his participation in the Capitol riot. Wilson was identified as being a part of the group "Coalition of the Unknown" (COTU) as well as the "Gray Ghost Militia." Wilson had been planning with his group to disrupt the joint session of Congress on Jan. 6 for some time. Since being identified, Wilson has denied entering the Capitol despite CCTV footage that places him there. "Daniel Wilson Sentenced 8/28/24 to five years – or 60 months – imprisonment, 36 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $2,000 in restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Phillip Marion Crawford
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Buildings or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
Additional details: Resident of Douglasville, GA
Short narrative: Phillip Crawford, 47, of Douglasville, GA, is charged with forcibly assaulting, resisting, or opposing law enforcement officers; obstructing, impeding, or interfering with law enforcement during a civil disorder; knowingly entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly or disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; and knowingly engaging in an act of violence in a restricted area or grounds. On January 6, 2021, Crawford was in the front of the crowd in the Lower West Terrace, punching at and attempting to pull out officers in the lineup. During the protest, he also threw a gas mask at officers.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Local News Articles; Governmental Report and Release;

Name of case: United States of America v. Kyle Andrew Campbell
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;
Additional details: Resident of Columbus, Ohio
Short narrative: On December 12, 2023, Kyle Andrew Campbell was "charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with felony offenses of assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers and civil disorder. In addition to the felonies, Campbell is charged with several misdemeanor offenses, including entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, act of physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly or disruptive conduct in the Capitol grounds or building, and acts of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building" (DOJ Press Release). On January 6, 2021, Campbell was captured, in United States Capitol video footage, "amongst rioters who were attempting to overwhelm officers by breaching a police barricade on the Lower West Terrace of the Capitol" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). Photos also reveal Campbell "moving past snow fencing erected by U.S. Capitol Police as part of the Restricted Perimeter around the U.S. Capitol."
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Joseph Vaglica
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Source description: Charging Documents; Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Francis Biondo
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct on capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Colonial Heights, Virginia
Short narrative: On October 16, 2023, Francis Gregory Biondo was charged in a criminal complaint in the District of Columbia for allegedly "entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct on capitol grounds, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building" (Charging Documents). On January 6, 2021, Biondo "marched to the Capitol, holding a large America flag" (Charging Documents). Open source and surveillance video "also consistently shows Biondo in the presence of...Jeffery Etter, who has been separately prosecuted" (Charging Documents). Video footage also shows Biondo entering the US Capitol...through the Senate Wing Door with Etter. While inside of the Capitol, Biondo entered the Crypt" and remained for some time before exiting through a broken window with Etter (Charging Documents).
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Anthony Mastanduno
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds WIht a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Rutherford County, NC
Short narrative: "Anthony Mastanduno, 60, formerly of Farmingdale, New York and now a resident of Rutherford County, North Carolina, is charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with civil disorder and assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon, both felony offenses. In addition to the felonies, Mastanduno is charged with several misdemeanors, including knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building...According to court documents, Closed Circuit Television (CCTV) footage from Jan. 6, 2021 shows a man, later identified as Mastanduno, unlawfully entering the U.S. Capitol building through the Senate Wing Door while wearing a camouflage jacket, backpack, and a red baseball cap with a patch on the bill and “Trump 2020 Keep America Great!” embroidered in white thread. Mastanduno entered the building approximately four minutes after it was first breached. Mastanduno was also observed in the area near the Memorial Door and at the front of a line of rioters who overwhelmed officers in the Crypt at about 2:23 p.m...Mastanduno later traveled outside the Capitol building, engaging with fellow rioters and participating in coordinated attacks on uniformed Metropolitan Police Department (MPD) Officers defending the Lower West Terrace tunnel. Court documents allege that videos and still images taken by others in the crowd showed Mastanduno at around 4:30 p.m. as he threw an object toward officers, utilized a telescoping baton to strike at officers in the tunnel, and pushed into the tunnel with a stolen police shield." (DOJ) He was sentenced to 57 months in prison.
Source description: Charging Document, Court Document, Local news

Name of case: United States of America v. Kyle Travis Colton
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a capitol building or grounds 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Short narrative: In 2023, Kyle Travis Colton was federally charged following his participation in the Capitol riot. Colton was identified via a tip, photos, texts, and surveillance footage. His case is ongoing.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Lobianco & Vournas
Charges: 18:231(a)(3)(Civil Disorder); 18:1512(c)(2), 2 (Obstruction of an Official Proceeding); 18:111(a)(1) and (b)(Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon, Inflicting Bodily Injury); 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A)(Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon); 18:1752(a)(1) (Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds); 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) (Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon); 18:1752(a)(2) (Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds); 18:1752(a)(4) and b(1)(A) (Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon); 40:5104(e)(2)(D) (Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building); 40:5104(e)(2)(G) (Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building);
Additional details: N/A
Short narrative: Leonard Lobianco, a.k.a. "Riddler," 52, of North Port, Florida, is named in the indictment and was arrested on Jan. 4, 2024 for their involvement in the capitol riot. According to the Indictment, " on Jan. 6, 2021, the men committed and attempted to commit an act aimed at impeding law enforcement officers from performing their official duties during a civil disorder event. In addition, defendant Vournas is alleged to have used a chemical irritant to assault law enforcement officers on the Capitol grounds and allegedly brought the weapon inside the Capitol building" (Indictment). Lobianco is charged with civil disorder, a felony, and misdemeanor offenses of entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles, Governmental Reports & Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Lobianco & Vournas
Charges: 18:231(a)(3)(Civil Disorder); 18:1512(c)(2), 2 (Obstruction of an Official Proceeding); 18:111(a)(1) and (b)(Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon, Inflicting Bodily Injury); 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A)(Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon); 18:1752(a)(1) (Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds); 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) (Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon); 18:1752(a)(2) (Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds); 18:1752(a)(4) and b(1)(A) (Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon); 40:5104(e)(2)(D) (Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building); 40:5104(e)(2)(G) (Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building);
Additional details: N/A
Short narrative: Tom Vournas, a.k.a. "El Greco," 62, of Bradenton, Florida, is named in the indictment and was arrested on Jan. 4, 2024 for his involvement in the capitol riot. According to the Indictment, " on Jan. 6, 2021, the men committed and attempted to commit an act aimed at impeding law enforcement officers from performing their official duties during a civil disorder event. In addition, defendant Vournas is alleged to have used a chemical irritant to assault law enforcement officers on the Capitol grounds and allegedly brought the weapon inside the Capitol building" (Indictment). Vournas is charged with felony offenses of civil disorder; obstruction of an official proceeding; assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or ground with a deadly or dangerous weapon and engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon. Vournas is also charged with misdemeanor offenses of disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, acts of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles, Governmental Reports & Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Messer & Borgerding
Charges: 18:231(a)(1) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds [Misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds [Misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building [Misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building [Misdemeanor]
Additional details: Resident of OH; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: Therese Borgerding, 58, of Piqua, OH, is charged with crimes related to her participation in the Capitol raid on January 6, 2021. She was seen both inside and outside the Capitol building. She posted on Facebook-- "YES I was inside the Capitol Building for a long time. You don't know The Truth what really happened" and was seen on the steps of the Capitol with a "Q" sign.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Daniel Tocci
Charges: 18:1361 Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Additional details: Resident of Amherst, MA
Short narrative: On November 28, 2023, Daniel Tocci was charged in a criminal complaint for destruction of Government Property, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a capitol building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. Tocci can be seen through pictures and videos recovered by the FBI attending a rally in Washington D.C. before making his way to the Capitol Building on January 6, 2021. Tocci went up the stairs to the Capitol's Upper West Terrace. He then entered the Capitol building through the Senate Wing Door. Tocci then exited the Capitol Building through a window. He then reached into a broken window coming from outside and removed a piece of the shutter from the window.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Records; Local News article

Name of case: United States of America v. Elliot Resnick
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder;
Additional details: Resident of NY, Chief Editor of The Jewish Press
Short narrative: On March 16th, 2023, Elliot Resnick was arrested for his involvement in the January 6th riots. Resnick was seen illegally gathering with a mob on the East Plaza of the Capitol. When that police line failed, Resnick, among many others, rushed up the Central East Steps toward the East Rotunda Doors. During this rush, Resnick motioned at other rioters to join them on the stairs. Resnick grabbed and held the arm of an officer who was deploying a chemical irratant as an attempt to prevent the rioters from entering the Capitol. "Elliott Resnick Sentenced 9/19/24 to four months in prison, four months of home detention, 24 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $10,539 in fines and restitution."
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Government Reports an Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Gene DiGiovanni Jr.
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds
Additional details: Resident of Derby, CT; "Gene DiGiovanni Sentenced 4/24/24 to a term of ten (10) days. The Defendant is further sentenced to twelve (12) months of Supervised Release, a $25 Special Assessment, and Restitution in the amount of $500."
Short narrative: Gene DiGiovanni, Jr., 42, of Derby, CT, is charged with entering and remaining in a restricted building; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. "In the fall of 2022, online sleuths first identified Gene DiGiovanni, Jr., as allegedly having been at the U.S. Capitol riot on Jan. 6, 2021, and alerted a Connecticut NBC affiliate to their findings. The TV station then interviewed DiGiovanni, who told them, "I was there, I went inside there, and, you know, I didn’t damage or break anything. Obviously you got the pictures to prove it.” DiGiovanni can allegedly be seen on surveillance footage from inside the Capitol as well. He is an alderman in Derby, Conn., though was not in that position at the time of the riot, according to the NBC station." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Document; Court Documents; Local News Articles; News Articles;

Name of case: United States of America v. Purkel & Purkel
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a capitol building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of Covington, Louisiana; father also arrested; "Colby Purkel Sentenced 8/1/24 to 21 days in prison, 12 months of supervised release, 100 hours of community service, and ordered to pay $2,000 in restitution"
Short narrative: "According to court documents, on Jan. 6, 2021, Willard and Colby Purkel went to the east side of the Capitol building and joined a crowd of rioters who forcibly entered the Capitol through the East Rotunda doors. At approximately 3:07 p.m., a group of rioters were attempting to enter the Capitol through these doors while another group was attempting to exit. Law enforcement authorities attempted to shut the doors to prevent the rioters’ entry. Willard and Colby Purkel are accused of attempting to enter the Capitol by pushing against the authorities who then sought to close the doors. At about 3:21 p.m., the East Rotunda doors were again opened as police tried to remove rioters from the building. As the doors were opened, the Purkels pushed their way into the building, streaming into the lobby outside the Rotunda. The Purkels then joined protestors to push against police officers attempting to prevent their entry into the Rotunda. Ultimately, the two men forced their way into the Rotunda" (DOJ). The Purkels are being charged with Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly conduct in a capitol building or grounds and demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building.
Source description: Charging documents, Government reports and release

Name of case: United States of America v. Donald Pearston
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct on capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in Capitol Building;

Short narrative: On September 13, 2023, Donald Pearston was charged for allegedly "entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct on capitol grounds, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building" (Charging Documents). On January 6, 2023, Pearston claimed "he flew to Washington DC on January 5, 2021 to attend the Trump Rally" (Charging Documents). "A review of capitol video reveals that Pearston went into the Captoil Building two times...[and] stayed in the Rotunda area until being pushed out of the Capitol by the police" (Charging Documents). Pearston was sentenced to 10 days in prison, followed by probation.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Christopher H. Keniley

Keniley of Greenfield Ma., was charged in a criminal complaint in the District of Columbia for entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a capitol building or grounds and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. Name of case: United States of America v. David Mitchell Bates
Charges: 18:1752 (a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18: 1752(a)(1) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in any of the Capitol Buildings [misdemeanor];
Additional details: In the "Statement of Facts," there is a picture of BATES and he "is displaying a hand sign commonly associated with the Proud Boys with his right hand"; The FBI interviewed a member of the West Virginia Chapter of the Proud Boys who identified Bates as another known Proud Boys member from the West Virginia Chapter; Resident of West Virginia
Short narrative: On January 6. 2021, the U.S. Capitol Police Closed Circuit Television (CCTV) recorded David Mitchell Bates "entering the Brumidi Corridor from the Upper West Terrace of the U.S. Capitol Grounds at approximately 2:45 p.m. and exiting the Brumidi Corridor onto the Upper West Terrace of the U.S. Capitol Grounds at 2:49 p.m." (Charging Documents; "Statement of Facts") After leaving the Brumidi Corridor, an open-source video recorded Bates "on the west side of the U.S. Capitol (Charging Documents; "Statement of Facts"). On January 3, 2024, Bates was indicted with four misdemeanors: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds, and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in any of the Capitol Buildings (Charging Document; Information).
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents

On January 6, 2021,
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Martin James Cudo
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor];
Additional details: Resident of Lakeville, Minnesota; traveled to Washington D.C. with mother and stepfather to attend the "Stop the Steal" rally
Short narrative: On January 3, 2024, Martin James Cudo, 43, was indicted with five misdemeanors: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding, Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building (Charging Documents; Indictment). On January 6, 2021, after attending the "Stop the Steal" rally with his mother and stepfather, Cudo "walked with the crowd to the Capitol Building" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). Open-source footage shows Cudo around the Senate Wing Door, entering the Capitol's Upper West and Northwest Terrace, Northwest Courtyard, and the Brumidi Corridor (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). CCTV captured Cudo "[entering] various offices adjacent to the [Parliamentarian] fire door" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). "After leaving the Capitol interior, Cudo remained in the Upper West and Northwest Terrace until "a line of law enforcement officers removed him and other rioters" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). Eventually, Cudo exited the Capitol Grounds.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Local News Article

Other names/aliases: CashHypnotic (Twitter); God Hypnotic (Skype); Godhypnotic; Cashgodhypnotic; Cash Hypnotic

Short narrative: In 2024, Paul Caloia was federally charged following his participation in the Capitol riot. Caloia was identified via Twitter (username "CashHypnotic") and Skype (username "God Hypnotic") as well as CCTV footage at the Capitol. His case is ongoing.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Matthew Brackley
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Waldoboro, ME; Republican Senate candidate (2022); "Matthew Brackley sentenced 5/14/24 to 15 months in prison, 24 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $3,000 in fines and restitution"
Short narrative: Matthew Brackley, 39, of Waldoboro, ME, is charged with assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers and civil disorder; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a capitol building; act of physical violence in the capitol grounds or buildings; and parading, picketing, and demonstrating in a capitol building. On January 6, 2021, Brackley attended a Stop the Steal rally before heading to the Captiol, where he helped tear apart a tarp and was part of the group that overwhelmed officers in the Crypt.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents: News Articles; Local News Articles; Governmental Reports and Release;

Name of case: United States of America v. Frank Dahlquist
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1),(2), and (4): Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:111(a)(1): Forcibly assaulting, resisting, opposing, or impeding a person designated in section 1114; 18:231(a)(3): Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 40:5104(e)(2) (D) and (G): Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds;
Additional details: Resident of Helena, Montana
Short narrative: Frank Dahlquist, 45, of Helena, Montana is charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia for his involvement in the January 6, 2021 insurrection. According to the press release, "His actions and the actions of others disrupted a joint session of the U.S. Congress convened to ascertain and count the electoral votes related to the 2020 presidential election" (Press Release 1). Frank Dahlquist is charged with 18:1752(a)(1),(2), and (4): Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:111(a)(1): Forcibly assaulting, resisting, opposing, or impeding a person designated in section 1114; 18:231(a)(3): Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 40:5104(e)(2) (D) and (G): Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds;
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Additional details: "Angel Villanueva Sentenced 3/20/24  to a term of Twenty-Four (24) Months of Probation on each of Counts 1 and 2, to run concurrently, including 4 months of Home Detention. The defendant must complete 60 hours of community service within 12 months. Special Assessment of $10 imposed as to each count, for a total amount of $20. Restitution in the amount of $500."
Short narrative: On January 5, 2024, Angel Villanueva was charged with 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly or disruptive conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for their actions during the January 6, 2021, Capitol demonstration. Villanueva was identified through Capitol photo and video footage. They were sentenced to 24 months probation.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. David Evan Smither
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Lexington, KY; "David Smither Sentenced 5/15/24 to twelve (12) months of probation on counts 3 and 4 to run concurrently. $20 Special Assessment. $725 Fine. $500 Restitution."
Short narrative: On 6 December 2023, a complaint was filed against David Evan Smither, age unknown, of Lexington, KY for allegedly entering and remaining in the Capitol Building on 6 January 2020 during the United States joint session to certify Electoral votes. Smither was reported, according to the complaint, to have entered the Senate Wing Corridor of the Capitol Building. The complaint states that he entered "by climbing through a smashed window and stepping over furniture." He allegedly entered, photographed several officers, walked towards the Crypt, and then returned to the Senate Corridor and left about 13 minutes after entering.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents;

Name of case: United States of America v. Mario Gonzalez
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in Any Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor];
Additional details: Resident of Las Vegas, Nevada; Statement of Facts mentions "the rioter was flagged as being associated with three other rioters"; wore "TRUMP" beanie and "TRUMP" hooded sweatshirt with an America flag;
Short narrative: On January 5, 2024, Mario Salvador Gonzalez, was "charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with felony offenses of obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder and assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers. In addition to the felonies, Gonzalez is charged with misdemeanor offenses of knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds" (DOJ Press Release). On January 6, 2021, Gonzalez, "entered onto restricted Capitol Grounds near the Peace Monument circle. While on Capitol Grounds, Mario Gonzalez joined the mob that gathered on the Lower West Terrace of the Capitol. Specifically, Mario Gonzalez approached and entered the northern scaffolding around the inauguration stage where police were attempting to prevent the rioters from gaining access to the steps leading to the Upper West Terrace" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). "Mario Gonzalez then came out of the scaffolding carrying a fire extinguisher and proceeded to spray the fire extinguisher in the direction of the police line that held the crowd at bay. Shortly after he sprayed the fire extinguisher at the police line, the police deployed a chemical riot control agent in the direction of Mario Gonzalez. Once the riot control agent made contact with Mario Gonzalez, he dropped the fire extinguisher and retreated back into the crowd" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts).
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. David Kennedy Homol
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2): Obstruction of Justice/Congress; 18:111(a)(1): Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3): Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1): Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2): Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F): Act of Physical Violence on Capitol Grounds;
Additional details: Resident of Umatilla, Florida; Died by suicide while awaiting trial.
Short narrative: David Kennedy Homol, 55, of Umatilla, Florida is charged in a criminal complaint for violating 18:1512(c)(2): Obstruction of Justice/Congress; 18:111(a)(1): Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3):Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1): Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2): Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F): Act of Physical Violence on Capitol Grounds; According to the press release, "At approximately 2:12 p.m., the defendant was captured swinging his flagpole multiple times at police officers as they battled rioters on the south end of the West Plaza. Court documents say that the defendant's assaults on police officers are visible on body-worn camera footage from that area and time" (Press Release).
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Jonathan Bonney
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in Capitol Building
Additional details: Former resident of CO, current Resident of WI; "Jonathan Bonney Sentenced 7/12/24 to twelve (12) months of probation as to all counts, each to run concurrently. Special assessment of $70. $500 restitution."
Short narrative: On April 27th, 2023, Jonathan Bonney was arrested due to his connection to the January 6th riots. Bonney was seen illegally entering the Capitol building with other rioters. After walking around the Capitol building for approximately 12 minutes, Bonney exited the building through the same door he entered.
Source description: Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Shawn Schaefer
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly, and With Intent to Impede or Disrupt the Orderly Conduct of Government Business [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) Entering or Remaining in a Room of the Capitol Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor];
Additional details: Resident of Placentia, California; attended the "Stop the Steal" rally at the Ellipse; wore a blue Trump face mask
Short narrative: On January 9, 2024, Shawn Schaefer was charged for allegedly (1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority (2) Knowingly, and With Intent to Impede or Disrupt the Orderly Conduct of Government Business (3) Entering or Remaining in a Room of the Capitol Building or Grounds and (4) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building (Charging Document; Arrest Warrant). On January 6, 2021, after attending the "Stop the Steal" rally at the Ellipse, Schaefer entered the U.S. Capitol via the Senate Fire Door and then entered the Parlimentarian's Office (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). Schaefer was in the Capitol for "less than two minutes" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts).
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Benjamin Michael Shuler
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers or Employees; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Knowingly engaging in any act of physical violence against any person or property in any restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings
Additional details: Resident of Grove City, OH
Short narrative: In 2024, Benjamin Michael Shuler, 26, of OH, was federally charged following his participation in the Capitol riot. Shuler was identified via photgraphs, surveillance footage, and an interview with someone who knows Shuler personally. Amidst the riot, Shuler was seen actively resisting the police line–pushing and shoving both shields and officers themselves. Shuler's case is ongoing.
Source description: Charging Document, Court Document

Name of case: United States of America v. Billy Joe Gober
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers [2 counts]; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
Additional details: Resident of Smithville, Texas
Short narrative: "Billy Joe Gober, 65, of Smithville, Texas, is charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with felony offenses of civil disorder and assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers. Gober is charged with several misdemeanor offenses as well, including, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings" (DOJ). On January 6, 2021, Gober is seen through video surveillance and social media posts on the south side of the Capitol's Lower West Terrance. Gober charged and struck a police officer. He then proceeded to the police line and attempted to pull the barricade away from another officer. After a section of the police line collapsed, Gober can be seen charging at another officer and grabbing their baton to try to take it away from him, pulling the officer into the crowd of rioters. Gober then grabbed the officer and placed his arm around him until the officer was pulled away from Gober's grip by another officer. Gober made statements to the crown urging them to break through the police line protecting the U.S. Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. David Michael Gary
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor];
Additional details: Resident of California
Short narrative: On January 16, 2024, David Michael Gary (AKA BOLO #74) allegedly "knowingly enter[ed] or remain[ed] in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority to do so, knowingly, and with intent to impede or disrupt the orderly conduct of Government business, willfully and knowingly utter[ed] loud, threatening, or abusive language, or engage in disorderly or disruptive conduct, at the Capitol, and parad[ed], demonstrat[ed], or picket[ed] at the Capitol (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). On January 6, 2021, Gary "is visible [on U.S. Capitol Police surveillance cameras] in a crowd of rioters attempting to push through a group of U.S., Capitol Police officers assembled at the Senate Wing Door" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). Gary and the crowd then broke through the line of officers and forced their entry into the building (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). After entering, "Gary remained in the corridor just inside the Senate Wing Doors for several minutes, yelling and gesticulating at the assembled Capitol Police officers" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). Gary is captured in several locations in the Capitol before returning to the Senate Wing and exiting through a broken window (Charging Document; Statement of Facts).
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Dustin Martin
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:231(a)(3); 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752 (a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Grove City, OH
Short narrative: On January 6, 2021 Dustin Martin (29), a biracial man from Ohio, unlawfully entered the Capitol in Washington, D.C., and was charged with five different offenses: (1) Obstruction of an Official Proceeding, (2) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, (3) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, (4)Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds, (5) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Martin stated he was traveling to Washington D.C. to support former President Trump and for the certification of the electoral college vote. According to open source footage at the rally in support of Trump at the ellipse you can visually see Martin react to him saying “we are going to walk down to the Capitol ''. Therefore, there is reason to believe he targeted this non-military non-judicial Federal site for a socio-political purpose, using unarmed assault and possibly blockading/unlawful assembly as his two main tactics. During the investigation the FBI received a search warrant for his Facebook account where they found a significant amount of content related to the 2020 Presidential Election. Specifically, several messages and images about the election being stolen. The day of the insurrection Martin was also seen pushing against a line of officers hence the unarmed assault tactic.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Andy Steven Oliva-Lopez
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1),(2), and (4) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct and Act of Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Violence in a Capitol Building or Grounds [misdemeanor];
Additional details: Resident of Milwaukie, Oregon; was a suspect on the FBL "Be on the Look Out" ("BOLO");
Short narrative: On January 18, 2024, Andy Steven Oliva-Lopez was "charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with felony offenses of civil disorder and assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers. In addition to the felonies, Oliva-Lopez is charged with misdemeanor offenses of disorderly and disruptive conduct and act of physical violence in a restricted building or grounds and act of violence in a Capitol building or grounds" (DOJ Press Release). On January 6, 2021, Oliva-Lopez allegedly assembled on the West Front of the Capitol with a crowd of violent rioters (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). Minutes later, Oliva-Lopez "deployed a yellow/orange-colored chemical aerosol multiple times at individual MPD officers[;] the spray struck at least one officer...in the face shield" (Charging Document; Statement of Facts). Afterward, Oliva-Lopez climbed past "the temporary scaffolding erected for the Inauguration."
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Christopher Taylor
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in Any Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor];
Additional details: Resident of Pennsylvania; had a TRUMP flag around his neck
Short narrative: On January 18, 2024, Christopher Taylor was charged for allegedly (1) knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority (2) disorderly or disruptive conduct in any restricted building or grounds (3) disorderly or disruptive conduct in a Capitol building (4) parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. On January 6, 2021, a CCTV video shows Taylor entering the Capitol building through the Senate Wing Door and entering an office space before exiting through the Memorial Door on the east side of the Capitol (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts).
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Middendorf & LaGesse
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building of Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Picketing, and Demonstrating in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor]; 18:1361 and 2: Destruction of Government Property;
Additional details: Resident of McLeansboro, Illinois; associate of Theodore Middendorf; was holding a "Gadsden" flag; was wearing a matching shirt with Middendorf saying "FUCK ANTIFA"; called MPD "fucking traitors" and "fucking communist scum" and other insults for several minutes
Short narrative: On January 18, 2024, Justin LaGesse and Theodore Middendorf, of McLeansboro, Illinois, were "charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with felony destruction of property. In addition to the felony, LaGesse and Middendorf are charged with misdemeanor offenses of entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building, and parading, picketing, and demonstrating in a Capitol building" (DOJ Press Release). On January 6, 2021, LaGeese entered the U.S. Capitol Building through a broken window "next to the Senate Wing Door" with a Gadsden and America flag, then helps Middendorf through the same window (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). They then entered the Crypt and "continued south into the House of Representatives side of the U.S. Capitol" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). They passed the House Wind Door emergency exit and "continued south through the Hall of Columns" before leaving the Capitol through the South Door (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). They then approached MPD officers and LaGesse verbally insulted them while Middendorf stood nearby (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). Afterward, as they approached a group of rioters attempting to breach the North Doors, they "used their flagpoles to strike the window numerous times and damaged the window in several places" (Charging Document; Statement of Facts). Middendorf proceeded to strike another window with his flagpole once. The damage from both men amounted to $41,315.25.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Governmental Reports and Releases

Additional details: Resident of Crown Point, Indiana
Short narrative: In 2023, Gregory Mijares, AGE, was charged with Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; and Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds following his participation in the Capitol riot. Mijares was located via video evidence, a tip provided to the FBI, and several photographs. Mijares was interviewed by agents and acknowledged traveling to DC to take part in the rally. The case is ongoing.

Name of case: United States of America v. David Brian Howard
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor];
Additional details: Resident of Frisco, Texas; attended the former President's "Stop the Steal" rally at the Ellipse
Short narrative: On January 25, 2024, David Brian Howard, was indicted for (1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, (2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, (3) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds, and (4) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building (Charging Document; Information). On January 6, 2021, after attending the "Stop the Steal' rally, Howard was captured on CCTV surveillance footage "within restricted grounds on the Upper West Terrace of the U.S. Capitol" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). Afterwards, surveillance also shows Howard "entering the Capitol building through the Senate Wing Doors...walked south down the corridor...[then] exit[ed] the Capitol through the Senate Wing Doors" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). He entered through the Senate Wing Doors a second time, walked down the corridor again, and entered the Crypt of the Capitol (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). He finally retracted his steps and exited from the Senate Wing Doors (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts).
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Robert Colello
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: 12 months probation
Short narrative: Robert Colello, 24, of Woodland Park, Colorado is charged in a bill of information for his involvement in the January 6, 2021 insurrection. According to the news article by The Denver Post, "A 24-year-old Colorado man faces federal charges after investigators allege he assaulted and threatened police officers defending the U.S. Capitol and also climbed through a broken window to enter the building during the Jan. 6 riot that disrupted the certification of the 2020 election" (Schmelzer 1). Robert Colello is charged with 18:1752(a)(1): Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2): Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building: or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G): Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in: a Capitol Building. He was sentenced to twelve months probation.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; News Articles;

Name of case: United States of America v. Theo Hanson
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of Justice/Congress; 18:231 Obstruction of Law Enorcement During Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Nampa, Idaho
Short narrative: On 28 November 2023, a Criminal Complaint was filed against Theo Hanson, 54, of Nampa, ID. The complaint includes one felony charge and three misdemeanors. According to the criminal complaint, Hanson gained entry to the Capitol Building and progressed toward the Crypt. Law enforcement had begun trying to close security doors, and Hanson is seen allegedly standing under a door waving his arms to keep it open. Once Hanson made his way to the East Rotunda, he allegedly repeatedly prevented East Rotunda doors from being shut by law enforcement by using his body as an obstruction.
Source description: Charging Documents; Governmental reports and releases;

Name of case: United States of America v. Dean Robert Harshman
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) Obstructing or Impeding an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Waynesville, OH;
Short narrative: Dean Harshman, 36, of Waynesville, OH, is charged with obstructing an official proceeding, knowingly remaining on restricted grounds, disorderly conduct on restricted grounds, and parading in a Capitol building. On January 6, 2021, Harshman took part in the protests in the Crypt and entered the Capitol building through a broken Senate door. After obtaining photos of Harshman from an anonymous tipster, FBI agents conducted interviews with two of Harshman's frequent associates, who both positively identified Harshman as the subject of those photographs. Subsequent investigation led to Harshman's identification on CCTV footage and the obtainment of cell phone records.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Local News Articles; Governmental Reports and Release;
