Name of case: United States of America v. Adam Kovsky
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds;
Additional details: Resident of MI
Short narrative: "Federal prosecutors allege that Adam Kovsky entered the U.S. Capitol building through a broken window next to the Senate Wing Doors at approximately 3:26 pm on Jan. 6, 2021. It's unclear from court filings how long Kovsky spent inside, but he was later seen in a social media post holding pieces of broken wood that were allegedly taken from furniture inside the building. Kovsky was accompanied that day by sisters Jenna and Laura McGrath, who have also been indicted for the participation in the riot. Kovsky was arrested on Dec. 21, 2023."
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents;

Name of case: United States of America v. Waynick & Waynick
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers [2 counts]; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of TN; Father also arrested; "GUILTY 4/17/24 on Counts 1ss, 2ss, 3ss, 4ss, 6ss, 8ss, 10ss, 12ss, 13ss, and 14ss as to JERRY MCKANE WAYNICK"
Short narrative: Jerry McKane Waynick, along with his father, Mark Waynick, were arrested on February 17th in responce to their actions during the January 6th riot at the United States Capitol. Both Waynicks were observed on body-camera, CCTV, and cell phone video assaulting officers along the Western Front of the building. Jerry Waynick was specifically seen beating an officer with an orange traffic pilon. After breaching the police riot line, both Waynicks were seen on CCTV footage inside the Capitol building, specifically in both Senate and House wings, and in the Rotunda's Statuary hall.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and releases (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Thomas Pooler Jr.
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G): Unlawful Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: "Thomas Pooler Sentenced 3/20/24 to a term of Twelve (12) Months of Probation on each of Counts 1 and 2, to run concurrently. The defendant must complete 60 hours of community service within 10 months. Special Assessment of $10 imposed as to each count, for a total amount of $20. Fine in the amount of $1,000. Restitution in the amount of $500."; Resident of Pinellas County, Florida
Short narrative: Thomas Pooler Jr, of Pinellas County, FL is charged in a bill of information for his involvement in the January 6, 2021 insurrection. According to the bill of information, "willfully and knowingly engaged in disorderly and disruptive conduct within the United States Capitol Grounds and in any of the Capitol Buildings with the intent to impede, disrupt, and disturb the orderly conduct of a session of Congress and either House of Congress, and the orderly conduct in that building of a hearing before or any deliberation of, a committee of Congress or either House of Congress" (Bill of Information 1). Thomas Pooler Jr is charged with 40:5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G): Unlawful Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Other;

They allegedly spent 11 minutes inside the building" (Seidel 1). Name of case: United States of America v. David Scott Kuntz
Group affiliation: Grey Ghost Partisan Kentucky Rangers; Three Percenters (III Percenters, 3%ers);
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of Justice/Congress;
Additional details: Resident of Elizabeth, IN
Short narrative: "In November 2020, David Kuntz messaged a group on Facebook about the presidential election, "we must start showing the world we will not stand for anymore sh** its time to take action and stop watching," according to court documents. As described by prosecutors, Kuntz referred to himself as "Reaper" in his social media chats. The next month, in a private social media channel, Kuntz allegedly wrote “[L]et’s go train and remove the Democratic party it is a must.” After Donald Trump posted on Twitter that there would be a "wild" protest in Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6, 2021, Kuntz allegedly wrote to the group, "January the 6th will be the target date for D.C. this goes to all groups that can help to defend those that can not defend themselves," and in another message, he allegedly wrote that he was "going armed." According to court documents, Kuntz later told federal investigators that he belonged to the "Three Percenter" militia movement along with a militia called the "Grey Ghost Partisan Kentucky Rangers." During the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, Kuntz allegedly entered the restricted area around the Capitol building near a door that was breached and yelled, "f*** the police." Prosecutors do not allege that he entered the Capitol building. Kuntz was arrested on Mar. 7, 2024, in New Albany, Ind." (NPR) Kuntz is charged with "18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of Justice/Congress.
Source description: Charging Documents;

Name of case: United States of America v. Jonathan Andrew Humphreys
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor];
Additional details: Resident of San Diego, California; during an FBI search multiple loaded unregistered handguns were found in Humphrey's vehicle and residence; Humphrey stated that he checked a firearm on his flight from San Diego to Baltimore-Washington International Airport (BWI) but denied carrying a firearm inside the Capitol building
Short narrative: On February 12, Jonathan Andrew Humphreys, of San Diego, was indicted for entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a capitol building, parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. On January 6, 2021, Humphreys "entered the Capitol Building through a broken window next to the Senate Wing Doors on the ground floor of the building" and entered various areas of the Capitol, including the Rotunda, Hallway H227, Hallway H230, and the Speaker's Suite (Statement of Facts). Recordings also show Humphreys smoking a cigarette in the Rotunda before approaching a line of officers and pushing "against the officers with his back" (Statement of Facts).
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. John Anthony Schubert III
Charges: 18: 111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers;
Additional details: Resident of Bradenton, Florida; Mother and father also arrested; "John Anthony Schubert III Sentenced 7/11/24 to 18 months incarceration, 24 months supervised release, $2000.00 Restitution, $100 Special Assessment."
Short narrative: On September 29, 2023, John Anthony Schubert III was charged in a criminal complaint for allegedly "civil disorder...assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers...knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in any of the Capitol buildings (DOJ). On January 6, 2021, Schubert III aided in breaching a police barricade at Peace Circle and encouraged other rioters to breach the police barricades (Charging Documents). He pushed and punched different law enforcement officers (Charging Documents). Later Schubert III entered the Capitol through a broken window next to the Senate Wing before helping his parents enter through the same window (Charging Documents). CCV video then shows Schubert III in various locations throughout the Capitol (Charging Documents). Schubert III was wearing a red Trump visor. He was sentenced to 18 months in prison.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Government Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Matthew Honigford
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers;
Additional details: Resident of Delphos, Ohio
Short narrative: On November 17, 2023, Matthew Honigford was charged in a criminal complaint in the District of Columbia for allegedly "assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers and one count of civil disorder. In addition to the felonies, Honigford is charged with several misdemeanor offenses, including entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building or grounds (DOJ). On January 6, 2021, D.C. Metropolitan Police Department body-worn camera footage recorded Honigford pushing the flagpole he was holding into the chest area of an officer (Charging Document). Later Honigford is also recorded touching or attempting to touch two officers with his hands. Afterward, Honigford joins rioters to push against metal barriers and "used his body to push the barriers against the law enforcement line...kicked the metal barrier toward" an officer (Charging Document). Once the barrier was broken through Honigford "instructed other rioters to 'pull it down' and carried one of the barriers into the crowd away from law enforcement" (Charging Document). Honigford was wearing a red, white, and blue "USA" hat and carrying a flagpole with the America flag attached. "Matthew Honigford Sentenced 8/19/24 to 19 months in prison, 24 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $2,000 in restitution"
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Government Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Gerard Fournier
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in Any Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Portland, Maine
Short narrative: On January 19, 2024, Michael Gerard Fournier, was charged for allegedly (1) knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority (2) disorderly or disruptive conduct in any restricted building or grounds (3) disorderly or disruptive conduct in a Capitol building (4) parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. On January 6, 2021, Fournier "first approached the U.S. Capitol from the east at the intersection of East Capitol Street and First Street NE" (Charging Document; Statment of Facts). An open-source video captured Fournier "on the East Plaza of the U.S. Capitol below the stairs to the Rotunda doors among a large crowd...Shortly thereafter Fournier proceeded to climb the steps to the Rotunda doors" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). Security cameras then caught Fournier entering the Capitol through the Rotunda doors. Once inside, "Fournier walked west towards the Rotunda...entered the Rotunda through the east door and moved around to different locations in the Rotunda for...several minutes" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). Fournier then interacted with another rioter who was carrying a painting. He took the painting from the rioter, walked away from the Rotunda doors, and returned moments later without the painting (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). Before leaving the Capitol, through the Rotunda door, Fournier "turned around, placed both his hands on U.S. Capitol Police officer, and appeared to exchange words with the officer" (Charging Document; Statement of Facts). After exiting the building, "Fournier made his way around the to the west side of the U.S. Capitol where he remained on the Upper West Terrace for at least an hour" (Charging Document; Statement of Facts). Fournier is captured around various police lines outside the Capitol before leaving U.S. Capitol grounds.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents

Mozingo was identified through Capitol photo and video footage.

Name of case: United States of America v. Valdez & Valdez
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: "Daniel Valdez Sentenced 6/18/24 to thirty-six (36) months of probation, Restitution of $500 and $20 special assessment"; Resident of Aurora, Colorado
Short narrative: Daniel Jay Valdez, 59, and his son, Payton John Valdezare, 30, of Aurora, Colorado, are charged with knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. Through text messages, Facebook posts, and surveillance video, the pair attended the riots on the Capitol on January 6, 2023 because Daniel believed that "President Trump was going to tell everything about who in politics was sex trafficking children" (Statement of Facts). Daniel and Payton were inside the Capitol building for around nine minutes, entering and exiting through a broken window next to the Senate Wing Door. Pictures of Payton holding a law enforcement riot shield and a beverage can be seen inside the Capitol. Daniel Valdez was sentenced to 36 months of probation.
Source description: Charging Documents, News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Patrick Woehl
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;

Short narrative: Patrick Woehl of Citrus Heights, is charged in a criminal complaint in federal court in Washington, D.C. in connection with the January 6, 2021 insurrection. According to the statement of facts, "By reviewing CCV footage from the Capitol, I observed Woehl entering the Capitol building through the Senate Wing Doors at approximately 2:24 PM on January 6, 2021" (Statement of Facts 3). Patrick Woehl is charged with 18:1752(a)(1): Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2): Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G): Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building." "Patrick Woehl Sentenced 9/23/24 to six (6) months of incarceration, $500 restitution, $70 special assessment."
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Holmes was sentenced to 12 months of probation.
Source description: Charging Documents;

Name of case: United States of America v. Curtis Logan Tate
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers [3 counts]
Additional details: resident of Clarksville, IN; "Curtis Tate Sentenced 79/24 to 63 months as to each of Counts One through Three, with all counts to be served concurrently. The Defendant is further sentenced to serve a 36-month term of supervised release as to each of Counts One through Three to be served concurrently. It is further ordered that the Defendant pay a $300 special assessment ($100 per count) and restitution in the amount of $3,176."
Short narrative: "Curtis Logan Tate, 32, of Jeffersonville, Indiana, is charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with civil disorder, assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a deadly or dangerous weapon, and destruction of government property. In addition to the felonies, Tate is charged with several misdemeanor offenses, including entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in the Capitol grounds or buildings, and engaging in an act of physical violence in the grounds or any of the Capitol buildings...Tate was arrested on Aug. 24, 2023, by the FBI in Wilmington, North Carolina, and will make his initial appearance in the Eastern District of North Carolina...According to court documents, on Jan. 6, 2021, Tate attended a rally in Washington, D.C., and afterward made his way toward the U.S. Capitol building. A review of open-source video, body- worn camera footage, and closed-circuit video showed Tate present at various locations in Washington, D.C., and in the restricted area of the U.S. Capitol grounds, including in the Lower West Terrace tunnel...At approximately 2:05 p.m., Tate is seen in body-worn camera videos from Metropolitan Police Department Officers (MPD) near the Lower West Terrace as he used a metal baton to strike an MPD officer in the hand. In response, an MPD officer sprayed Tate with pepper spray and can be heard warning another officer that Tate was wielding a baton. Tate later uploaded a video to a social media site depicting himself near the Lower West Terrace holding a metal baton, which appears to be the same baton used to strike the MPD officer, with the caption: “POST 1ST MACING.” During the video, Tate yelled, “We’re tearing this motherfucker down!”...At approximately 2:43 p.m., Tate was outside the entrance to the Lower West Terrace tunnel. He arrived minutes after the area was first breached and entered the tunnel closely behind the initial group of rioters. Tate is later seen on Capitol CCTV footage inside the tunnel holding his cell phone above his head, consistent with using the phone to record video. At about 2:57 p.m., Tate is shown inside the tunnel brandishing the metal baton above his head and charging towards the line of police officers protecting the entrance to the Capitol building. Tate then repeatedly struck a U.S. Capitol Police (USCP) officer in the helmet with the metal baton. In response, a USCP officer pepper sprayed Tate, and he retreated....Later, at about 4:28 p.m., Tate is seen on publicly available video throwing a black speaker box and breaking a window located to the left of the tunnel entrance. Tate then threw a black speaker box and a shoe at police officers protecting the entrance to the tunnel. The speaker box and shoe struck MPD officers. Shortly after the above assaults, Tate is shown in publicly available video receiving a broken table leg with a protruding screw through a broken window in the Capitol building. The window was the same window damaged by Tate earlier with the speaker box and now was completely broken as a result of damage caused by Tate and others...Tate is shown in multiple publicly available videos and photographs taken by a photojournalist, navigating through the crowd and carrying the broken table leg toward the entrance to the tunnel. At approximately 4:34 p.m., Tate is shown in publicly available video throwing the broken table leg at police officers who were protecting the tunnel entrance...Later, at approximately 4:38 p.m., Tate is shown in publicly available video assisting others carry a piece of lumber toward the entrance to the tunnel, and, at about 5:01 p.m., Tate is shown in multiple publicly available videos throwing a floor lamp at police officers near the tunnel...Tate later gave an interview to a media outlet, in which he stated, “I would never hurt an officer. I come from a military background. I’m very respectful of our military and police… I know I didn’t hurt anybody… I’m not speaking here bold as brass, because you never know what can happen…but I’ve never, ever once hurt, or put my hands on an officer… I never did it. So, I’m not going to live the rest of my life in fear.”" (DOJ)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States v. Lin Marie Carey
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of Justice/Congress; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor]; 40:5014(e)(2)(G) Parading, Picketing, and Demonstrating in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor];
Additional details: Resident of Naples, Florida
Short narrative: On February 20, 2024, Lin Marie Carey was charged with alleged "obstruction of an official proceeding...knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, parading, picketing, and demonstrating in a Capitol building" (DOJ Press Release). On January 6, 2021, after attending the "Stop the Steal" rally, Carey entered the Capitol through the East side doors and filmed as she walked through the Capitol, chanting phrases like, "This is our house," "We overtook the Capitol," "We will not allow the Chinese to overtake the United States of America" (Statement of Facts). Carey "posted a live video from inside the Rotunda on her Facebook page" and wrote, "a long post on Facebook describing, in part, her actions inside the U.S. Capitol building" (Statement of Facts). While looking for the restrooms, Carey and another female rioter were directed outside through the Parliamentary doors.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Gregory C. Yetman
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;
Additional details: Resident of Helmetta, New Jersey
Short narrative: Gregory C. Yetman, 47, a former Army National Guard police officer of Helmetta New Jersey, was arrested and "charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with felony offenses of assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers and obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder. In addition to the felonies, Yetman is charged with misdemeanor offenses of entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, and an act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings" (DOJ). According to Facebook posts and other photos taken at the January 6th Riot, the FBI identified Yetman at the riots near the Lower West Terrace Door. Yetman allegedly picked up an MK-46H spray canister and assaulted Officers by spraying the canister consisting of a chemical irritant multiple times onto a group of officers who fighting off swarming rioters. Yetman was sentenced to 30 months in prison.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Kenneth Giusini
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1): Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2): Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G): Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:231(a)(3): Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder;
Additional details: Resident of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania
Short narrative: Kenneth Giusini, 67, of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania is charged in a criminal complaint for his involvement in the January 6, 2021 insurrection. According to the Statement of Facts, "Footage from the Capitol’s security cameras show that Giusini entered the Capitol through the north door at approximately 3:10 p.m. on January 6, 2021" (Statement of Facts 6). Kenneth Giusini is charged with 18:1752(a)(1): Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2): Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G): Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:231(a)(3): Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder;
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; News Articles;

Name of case: United States of America v. Nicholas L. Kennedy
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:1512(c)(1) Tampering with Records, Documents, or Objects
Additional details: Resident of MO
Short narrative: "Few details have been released about Nicholas Kennedy's role in the insurrection at the U.S. Capitol. Kennedy, also known as "Nick," was arrested on July 28 and made his first appearance in federal court on Aug. 5." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Stephen Baker
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Washington, DC
Short narrative: "Stephen Baker recorded live footage under the alias “Stephen Ignoramus” during the protests at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. Some media outlets have used his footage in news reports. Once inside, Baker is allegedly heard on tape saying: “All right, what’s up, y’all? How you guys doin’? Super-intense. Welcome, I am Stephen. I’m a livestreamer and a musician. We’re having fun, huh? Repent and believe in Jesus.” Baker also makes multiple references to members from the far-right groups The Red Elephants and Oath Keepers, identifying some of them by name, during his livestream. According to court documents, the FBI identified a profile page of a Washington, D.C., music store featuring Baker, on which he describes himself as a “multi-instrumentalist, composer, and business owner who studied music at Western Michigan University, before moving to the D.C. area.” The profile further states that Baker operates a recording/rehearsal studio in Hyattsville, Md., and that he has performed at venues including the 9:30 Club, the Howard Theatre, the Black Cat and Rock & Roll Hotel. Baker is also seen on video saying, “I was inside for like an hour, dude. I was one of like the last 10 people in there. ... I’m on Instagram and YouTube. I’m Stephen Ignoramus. I don’t matter though — this s*** is history.” A witness who was interviewed by the FBI stated that they’ve known Baker for about 10 years and were alarmed by the content of those videos, which included, according to the witness, the “advancement of conspiracy theories and mockery of minority groups.” (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents;

Name of case: United States of America v. Thomas Paul Osborne
Charges: 18:231(a)(3): Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1): Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2): Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Lakeland, Florida
Short narrative: Thomas Paul Osborne, 40, of Lakeland, Florida is charged in an indictment filed on 02/21/2024 for his involvement in the January 6, 2021 insurrection. According to the press release, "His actions and the actions of others disrupted a joint session of the U.S. Congress convened to ascertain and count the electoral votes related to the 2020 presidential election" (Press Release 1). Thomas Paul Osborne is charged with 18:231(a)(3): Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1): Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2): Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building;
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; News Articles; Governmental Reports and Release;

Name of case: United States of America v. Cleophus Dulaney
Charges: 18:111(a)(1): Assaulting, Reisistng, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3): Obstruction of Law Enforcement during Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1): Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2): Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4): Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(F): Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;
Additional details: Resident of Columbus, Ohio
Short narrative: Cleophus Dulaney, 63, of Columbus, Ohio is charged in a criminal complaint for his involvement in the January 6,2021 insurrection. According to The Columbus Dispatch news article, "In court documents, prosecutors allege that Dulaney, who was at the front of a crowd of rioters trying to stop the electoral college certification of President Joe Biden, became confrontational with Capitol police officers as the rioters approached a barricade made out of bike racks" (Meighan 5). Cleophus Dulaney is charged with 18:111(a)(1): Assaulting, Reisistng, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3): Obstruction of Law Enforcement during Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1): Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2): Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4): Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(F): Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;

Name of case: United States of America v. Joseph Julius Lapoint, et. al.
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL
Short narrative: "According to court documents, a tipster informed the FBI that their relative, Joseph Lapoint, had entered the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and posted a photo of himself on social media, standing on a window ledge inside one of the offices. The tipster also referenced videos that show him with his girlfriend or fiancé, Nicole Joyner. On Jan. 6, 2022, court documents state, Lapoint posted a video of himself and Joyner on his TikTok account with the text “HAD A BLAST one year ago” and “me and babe stormed the Capitol with the rest of America.” Lapoint first appeared in federal court on March 12, 2024" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents;

Sylvester was identified via her cell phone, images taken inside the Capitol, and surveillance footage. Kymberly Sylvester Sentenced 6/13/24 to concurrent terms of twelve (12) months of Probation.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents

Name of case: United States v. Miles Brandon Adkins
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor]; 40:5014(e)(2)(G) Parading, Picketing, and Demonstrating in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor];
Additional details: Resident of Stephens City, Virginia; allegedly said he was in touch with a member of the Oath Keepers on January 6, 2021, and previously traveled to Washington D.C. "to act as an escort for persons associated with the Oath Keepers" (Statement of Facts).; "Miles Adkins Sentenced 7/1/24 to a term of Twenty-Four (24) Months of Probation on each of Counts 1 and 2, to run concurrently. As a condition of probation, the defendant must serve a total of 12 days of intermittent confinement. The intermittent confinement shall be served on consecutive weekends. Special Assessment of $10 imposed on each count, for a total amount of $20. Restitution in the amount of $500.00. Fine in the amount of $1,000."
Short narrative: On February 27, 2024, Miles Brandon Adkins was charged with allegedly "knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a capitol building, and parading, picketing, and demonstrating in a Capitol building. On January 6, 2021, after attending the "Stop the Steal" rally, Adkins " approached the Capitol from the West Front and made his way up the Northwest stairs to the Upper West Terrace after police lines were breached" and entered the Capitol through the Senate Wing Door (Statement of Facts). After spending time in the Capitol, Adkins "returned to the Senate Wing Door lobby, waived rioters who were outside into the building", then helped an individual enter the U.S. Capitol through a broken window next to the Senate Door (Statement of Facts). After spending more time in the Capitol, Adkins left through the Memorial Door.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; News Articles

Name of case: United States v. Matthew James Melsen
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civli Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings [misdemeanor] 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings [misdemeanor];
Additional details: Resident of Wheat Ridge, Colorado; wore a black "Keep America Great" baseball cap;
Short narrative: On February 27, 2024, " Matthew James Melsen, 34, of Wheat Ridge, Colorado, is charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with felony offenses of civil disorder and assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers. In addition to the felonies, Melsen is charged with several misdemeanor offenses, including entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings, and act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings" (DOJ). On January 6, 2021, Melsen, "arrived at the bike racks separating the crowd from the U.S. Capitol and the police officers on the West Plaza," and suddenly, "he reached over the bike rack and pushed a Metropolitan Police Department Officer" (Statement of Facts). He pushed the officer again then another officer sprayed Melsen with OC spray. Afterward, "he climbed up onto the Inaugural Stage...through the dense crowd to the mouth of an entrance to the U.S. Capitol building located on the Lower West Terrance" (Statement of Facts). There he grabbed officers' batons to prevent the officers from using them on rioters.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Curtis Pulaski
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Grand Rapids, Michigan;
Short narrative: On 20 December 2023, a Criminal Complaint was filed against Curtis Pulaski, 29, of Grand Rapids, Michigan. According to the complaint, Pulaski is alleged to have entered the Capitol building to "live stream and collect video of the Trump rally for his YouTube channel." He moved around, entered offices, and took pictures of documents on desks. He left the Capitol but re-entered shortly afterwards where he saw people barricading doors. Upon exiting again and seeing the chaos, frightened he woud be trampled, Pulaski jumped off a Capitol building wall. According to the complaint, Pulaski "fell a significant distance and suffered severe injuries as a result of the fall."
Source description: Charging Documents; News article;

Short narrative: Dominic Box was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his participation in the Capitol riot. The case is ongoing.

Name of case: United Staes of America v. Matthew Brent Carver
Charges: 18:111(a) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Building or Grounds
Additional details: Resident of Vanceburg, Kentucky
Short narrative: "Body-worn camera footage of two police officers on the Upper West Terrace of the Capitol allegedly show Matthew Carver shouting at officers, then appearing to to push one and grab his baton, struggling with it for several seconds, according to court documents. In January, 2023, FBI agents interviewed Carver at his home and showed him photos from outside the Capitol. He confirmed it was him and, when asked to explain why he had his hands on an officer’s baton, Carver stated that officers were being aggressive towards a woman in the crowd. He also allegedly stated that he believed the 2020 presidential election was clearly stolen. He was arrested on Jan. 30, 2024." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents;

Name of case: United States of America v. Troy Allen Koen
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:1361 Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5014(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
Additional details: Resident of Brownsburg, Indiana
Short narrative: On November 2, 2023, Troy Allen Koen, was charged in a criminal complaint in the District of Columbia "with felony offenses of assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers, destruction of government property, and obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder. In addition to the felonies, Koen [was] charged with several misdemeanor offenses, including knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building without lawful authority, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or groups, obstruction or impeding passage through or with the grounds or any of the Capitol buildings, and an act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings" (DOJ). On January 6, 2021, Koen aided other rioters as they removed police barricades, and video footage shows Koen "jab[bing] the flagpole into to glass" leading to the glass door shattering (Charging Documents). Then Koen used the flagpole to "repeatedly assault officers by jabbing the flagpoles into the officer line" (Charging Documents). Koen wore a black top with white lettering saying 'STOP THE STEAL,' and a video recording showed him holding a 'TRUMP 2020' flag and a Confederate flag (Charging Documents).
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Government Reports and Release

Short narrative: On February 29, 2024, Mark Christian Wroblewski was charged with 18:1752(a)(1): Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2): Knowingly, and with intent to impede or disrupt the orderly conduct of Government business; 40:5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G): Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:231(a)(3): Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder for his actions during the January 6, 2021, Capitol demonstration. Wroblewski was identified through Capitol photo and video footage.
Source description: Charging Documents;

Name of case: United States of America v. Patrick Duffy
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Cleveland Heights, OH
Short narrative: "Court documents allege that on Jan. 6, 2021, Patrick Duffy of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, made his way from the White House Ellipse down Pennsylvania Avenue toward the U.S. Capitol building at approximately 1 pm. Open-source video showed Duffy in the crowd walking directly behind right-wing provocateur Alex Jones during that time. As protestors reached the east side of the Capitol building, Duffy joined a group that took a riot shield from a police officer and pushed through an entrance guarded by police. He entered the building at around 2:45 pm, making his way through the Rotunda and a hallway outside the Old Senate Chambers. He was arrested on Mar. 6, 2024, in Cleveland, Ohio." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents;

Name of case: United States of America v. Kayla Reifschneider
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of Justice/Congress; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
Additional details: Resident of Los Angeles, CA; Telegram group "PATRIOTS45 MAGA Gang" member
Short narrative: in 2024, Kayla Reifschneider, 25, of CA, was federally charged following her participation in the Capitol riot. Reifschneider was identified via her membership in a Telegram group called "PATRIOTS45 MAGA Gang". She is also visible in surveillance footage and other video footage captured that day. The DOJ press release notes that she is seen in one video spitting in the direction of the media then yelling "mother f—! F— you! That's spit, b—'! Get f— COVID!" (DOJ Press Release). Her case is ongoing.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Ivan Todd
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Gainesville, FL
Short narrative: "Security camera footage from U.S. Capitol grounds on Jan. 6, 2021 showed Ivan Todd entering the building through the Parliamentarian Door at around 2:56 pm, according to court documents. Federal investigators also obtained GPS records showing that a mobile device associated with Todd's email address was present at the Capitol that afternoon. He exited the building after four minutes inside, leaving through the same door he used to enter. Todd was arrested Mar. 7, 2024, in Gainesville, Fla." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents;

Charges: 8:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder, 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
Additional details: Resident of Adairsville, Georgia
Short narrative: "Jacob Davis, 31, of Adairsville, Georgia is charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with felony offenses of assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers with deadly or dangerous weapon and obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder. In addition to the felonies, Davis is charged with misdemeanor offenses of disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings." (DOJ) Davis attended the "Stop the Steal" rally at Ellipse and then made his way toward the Lower West Terrace tunnel of the Capitol Building. According to video footage, Davis pushed his way through hundreds of rioters to get to the front of the riot. He then went up the northwest steps of the Capitol and continued into the mouth of the LWt Tunnel, where he picked up a Police Officer's shield to press into the tunnel against the police. He passed it off to participate in a "heave-ho" effort with other rioters to exert maximum force against the police line. After exiting the tunnel, he found a long wooden board and hurled it at the officers inside the tunnel, with the board landing on the officers' heads.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Philip Anderson
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority[misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of Justice/Congress;
Additional details: Resident of Mesquite, Texas
Short narrative: "Philip Anderson, 28, of Mesquite, Texas, is charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with felony offenses of civil disorder and obstruction of an official proceeding. In addition to the felonies, Anderson is charged with misdemeanor offenses of entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building" (DOJ). On January 6, 2021, Philip Anderson attended the "Stop the Steal" rally at the National Mall and then proceeded towards the U.S. Capitol to participate in the breach of the U.S. Capitol. Open-source video footage captured Anderson speaking into a microphone saying, "We're occupying the Capitol. Let's go!" He stood on a statute at the Peace Circle and then headed closer to the U.S. Capitol building. He scaled the northwest staircase that leads to the Upper West Terrace of the U.S. Capitol building. He entered the Capitol building through the Senate Wing Door. After coming in contact with several police officers upon his entrance, Anderson exited the Capitol Building through the Senate Wing Door. Anderson then gave numerous speeches to the rioters in support of the riot. He also participated in the heave-ho motion to break through the police at the Lower West Terrace.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Hatcher, Mackie, Mackie
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor];
Additional details: Resident of Weatherford, Texas: brother of Nathan Mackie; wore a dark blue Trump hat; attended the "Stop the Steal" rally
Short narrative: On March 11, 2024, Daniel Hatcher, Brandon Mackie, and Nathan Mackie were indicted for entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in any of the Capitol buildings. On January 6, 2021, the three men walked to the Capitol after attending the "Stop the Steal" rally and Hatcher "attempted to climb a wall leading the Northwest Terrace of the building," but the three men ended up "ascending the stairs leading to the Upper Northwest Terrance of the Capitol building" (Statement of Facts). Then the men entered the Capitol building through a broken window and exited through the Senate Wing Door two minutes later (Statement of Facts).
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Timothy Tedesco
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: "Timothy Tedesco Sentenced 7/12/24 To Thirty-Six (36) Months Probation (With Conditions) On Each Count To Run Concurrent; $20.00 Special Assessment, Restitution In The Amount of $500.00 And A Fine Of $10,000.00"\
Short narrative: Timothy Tedesco of Corpus Christi, Texas is charged in a criminal complaint in connection with the January 6, 2021 insurrection. According to the statement of facts, "Open-source video shows TEDESCO before the breach of the barricades on the east front of the U.S. Capitol, listening to an audio broadcast of the electoral vote counting, and then cheering with the crowd when a U.S. lawmaker objected to the counting of the electoral votes from Arizona" (Statement of Facts 4). Timothy Tedesco is charged with 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2): Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G): Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building." Tedesco was sentenced to 36 months probation.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Other

Name of case: United States v. Sarty & Sarty
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Engage in an act of Physical Violence in the Grounds of any of the Capitol Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Marietta, Georgia
Short narrative: On January 19, 2024, "Cepane Sarty, 38, of Marietta, Georgia, and Seth Sarty, 45, of Rockmart, Georgia, [were] charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with a felony offense of assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers. In addition to the felonies, both men are charged with misdemeanor offenses of knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, engaging in an act of physical violence in the grounds or any of the Capitol buildings; and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building" (DOJ). On January 6, 2021, Cepane and Seth entered the Capitol through the Senate Wing Door. CCTV shows the two entering various areas of the Capitol, including the office suite of the Speaker of the House and the Rotunda where they encountered Capitol police officers. In the Rotunda, they began fighting with the police, assaulting officers, and preventing the officers from clearing the Rotunda. Cepane and Seth left the Capitol Building after the police deployed a chemical riot control agent (Statement of Facts).
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Charles Tyler Himber
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Slidell, Louisiana
Short narrative: Charles Tyler Himber, 30, of Slidell, Louisiana is charged in a criminal complaint filed on 01/16/2024 for his involvement in the January 6, 2021 insurrection. According to the press release, "His actions and the actions of others disrupted a joint session of the U.S. Congress convened to ascertain and count the electoral votes related to the 2020 presidential election" (Press Release 1). Charles Tyler Himber is charged with 18:231(a)(3): Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1): Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2): Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G): Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; News Articles; Governmental Reports and Release;

Name of case: United States of America v. James Weeks
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1361 and 2 Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds of Buildings;
Additional details: Resident of Sodus, New York; a possible connection to Troy Week; held a "Stop the Steal" while on Capitol grounds; Sentenced 10/4/24 to 27 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $2,774.00 in restitution and a $5,000 fine
Short narrative: On January 26, 2024, James Weeks of Sodus, New York was "charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with felony charges of civil disorder and assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers. In addition to the felonies, Weeks is charged with several misdemeanor offenses, including destruction of government property and aiding and abetting, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, and impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings" (DOJ Press Release). On January 6, 2021, open-source, CCTV, and BWC video show Weeks entering the Capitol through the Lower West Terrace tunnel. Afterwards "Weeks moved through the crowd to the very front where several police officers were defending the entrance to the U.S. Capitol...[,]reached through the shattered window of one of the doors inside the tunnel toward the police...[,] reached through the door frame, [and allegedly] pointed and gestured yelling 'I'm gonna shove it up your ass! I’m gonna shove that up your ass, you fat fuck! I’m gonna fuck you up'"(Statement of Facts). Then, Weeks "moved around the door frame and closer to the police. He then reached out and struck a nearby Metropolitan Police Department (“MPD”) officer" (Statement of Facts). Afterward, "Weeks was sprayed with OC spray by officers. He then made his way back out of the tunnel" (Statement of Facts). "After leaving the tunnel...Weeks made his way to the Senate Wing Door in the Northwest Courtyard of the U.S. Capitol building. When other rioters kicked in a barricaded window, Weeks "approached the window and shook what appears to be a can of pepper spray in the hole in the window several times. He then banged the can against the edge of the hole several times...Weeks then took the white stick or pole he had in his hand and began to strike the window with it" (Statement of Facts).
Source description: Charging Documents; Cout Documents; Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. John Banuelos
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40: 5104(e)(1)(A)(i) Unlawful Possession of a Firearm on Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40: 5104(e)(1)(A)(ii) Unlawful Discharge of a Firearm on Capitol Grounds or Buildings;40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Summit, IL
Short narrative: "According to court documents, shortly after 2:30 pm on Jan. 6, 2021, John Banuelos climbed a scaffolding outside the U.S. Capitol building, pulled a gun out of his waistband and fired two shots into the sky. Banuelos was seen in open-source video and body-worn camera footage throughout the afternoon on Capitol grounds wearing a red puffy jacket, black boots and knee pads, and a white "Trump 2020" cowboy hat. At various points, he was seen kicking metal barricades, pushing against police officers and showing off the gun tucked into his pants, prosecutors allege. Federal investigators first became aware of Banuelos' actions that afternoon in 2021; he was arrested on Mar. 8, 2024, in Summit, Ill." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents;

Name of case: United States of America v. Joshua Scott Borum
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of IN; sentenced 9/6/24 to a term of Twenty-Four (24) Months of Probation on each of Counts 3 and 4, to run concurrently. Special Assessment of $10 imposed as to each count, for a total of $20. Fine in the amount of $2,000. Restitution in the amount of $500.
Short narrative: On March 18, 2024, Joshua Scott Borum was charged with 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; for his actions during the January 6, 2021, Capitol demonstration. Borum was identified through Capitol photo and video footage.
Source description: Charging Documents;

Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of Charleston, SC

He also allegedly picked up a can of chemical spray from the ground and sprayed it directly at officers. Perrou was arrested on Mar. 21, 2024, in Charleston, SC." (NPR)

Name of case: United States v. Johnson, Johnson
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752 (a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in the Capitol Building or Grounds; 40: 5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building or Grounds
Additional details: Resident of Vero Beach, Florida; wife of Johnson Joshua Johnson; wore red Trump cap and American flag scarf
Short narrative: On February 16, 2024, Whitney Johnson, and her husband, Andrew Joshua Johnson, of Vero Beach, Florida, were charged for their actions during the January 6, 2021, U.S. Capitol Breach. Whitney Johnson was charged with alleged, "civil disorder and assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers... entering or remaining in restricted buildings or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly or disruptive conduct in the Capitol building or grounds, act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building or grounds." (DOJ Press Release). On January 6, 2021, after attending the "Stop the Steal" rally Whitney Johnson entered the Capitol through the Rotunda Doors. While an officer was trying to clear Whitney from the Rotunda, she "yelled expletives at the officer and hit [the officer] with an open hand." She exited through the Rotunda Doors shortly after.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States v. Johnson, Johnson
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752 (a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in the Capitol Building or Grounds; 40: 5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building or Grounds
Additional details: Resident of Vero Beach, Florida; husband of Whitney Johnson; wore a red Trump hat and a black backpack with distinctive firearms-related patches; was caught on USCP surveillance footage carrying white zip ties when entering the Capitol
Short narrative: On February 16, 2024, Andrew Joshua Johnson, and his wife, Whitney Johnson, of Vero Beach, Florida, were charged for their actions during the January 6, 2021, U.S. Capitol Breach. Andrew Joshua Johnson was charged with alleged "civil disorder... entering or remaining in restricted buildings or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, entering and remaining in certain rooms in the Capitol building, disorderly or disruptive conduct in the Capitol building or grounds, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building or grounds" (DOJ Press Release). On January 6, 2021, after attending the "Stop the Steal" rally Johnson entered the Capitol through the Routunda Doors and made his way to the Gallery Stairs where he "appeared to exchange some words" with a USCP Officer (Statement of Facts). As the police attempted to form a police line and move rioters away from the Rotunda, Johnson, and other rioters, "physically pushed back against the police line" (Statement of Facts). Body-worn camera footage shows Johnson "physically resisting as multiple police officers attempt to push him [Johnson] forward" (Statement of Facts). Another physical altercation with officers led to a USCP officer physically restraining Johnson. While this occurred, Johnson continuously used offensive language with the officers and at one point called them "Nazi Stormtroopers" (Statement of Facts). He continued to struggle with the police before being escorted out of the Rotunda.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Ian MacBride
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:641 Theft of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Douglassville, PA
Short narrative: In 2024, Ian MacBride, 41, of PA, was federally charged following his participation in the Capitol riot. MacBride was identified via an anonymous tip as well as Facebook posts, Instagram posts, and surveillance footage. MacBride additionally stole a Capitol police sign that reads "Area Closed". MacBride's case is ongoing.
Source description: Charging Documents; Governmental Reports and Release

Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1361 Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly or disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Knowingly engaging in any act of physical violence against any person or property in any restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly or disruptive conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Engaging in an act of physical violence in the Grounds or any of the Capitol Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Norwalk, California
Short narrative: Michael Haltom, 43, of Norwalk, California is charged in a criminal complaint for violating 18:1752(a)(1): Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2): Disorderly or disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(4): Knowingly engaging in any act of physical violence against any person or property in any restricted building or grounds; 18:231(a)(3): Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2): Obstruction of Justice/Congress; 18:1361: Destruction of Government Property; 40:5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly or disruptive conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F): Engaging in an act of physical violence in the Grounds or any of the Capitol Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G): Parading Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; According to the press release, "His actions and the actions of others disrupted a joint session of the U.S. Congress convened to certify the Electoral College vote related to the 2020 presidential election" (Press Release).

Name of case: United States of America v. Paul Orta Jr.
Charges: 18:1752 (a)(1) Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction or Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder;
Additional details: Resident of Blue Earth, Minnesota (DOJ); Resident of Rio Hondo, Texas (Statement of Facts) On January 5, 2012, officers from the Prince George's County Police Department executed a traffic stop of a bus covered in Trump 2020 graffiti and Orta was among the individuals on the bus (United States of America v. Paul Orta Jr., Statement of Facts). The same bus was stopped again by the Metropolitan Police Department (MPD) and Orta was aboard (United States of America v. Paul Orta Jr., Statement of Facts). This time "law enforcement discovered a 9mm pistol, four loaded 9mm magazines, a .22 caliber rifle, 275 rounds of .22 caliber ammunition, and a 110 round .22 caliber drum magazine" (United States of America v. Paul Orta Jr., Statement of Facts). With both stops Orta was searched and released.
Short narrative: On November 13, 2023, Paul Orta Jr. of Blue Earth, Minnesota was charged with allegedly "obstruct[ing] law enforcement during civil disorder. In addition to the felony, Orta [was] charged with misdemeanor offenses of entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds and disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds" (DOJ). On January 6, 2021, open-source videos and body-worn camera footage from MPD officers showed Orta "tossing a section of black metal barricade onto the ground and beckoning to the remaining crowd beyond the perimeter to move forward" (United States of America v. Paul Orta Jr., Statement of Facts). Orta continued moving forward with the crowd and even "pulled metal bike racks, that barricaded officers from the crowd, away from the law enforcement" (United States of America v. Paul Orta Jr., Statement of Facts). While with the crowd, Orta "threw an unknown dark colored object towards the police line on the West Side of the Capitol," and when law enforcement formed a police line "Orta joined other members of the crowd from advancing further toward the Capitol building" (United States of America v. Paul Orta Jr., Statement of Facts). "Paul Orta sentenced 10/7/24 to Six (6) months incarceration. Followed by Twelve (12) months Supervised Release. $100 Special Assessment imposed. $2000 in restitution"
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Charles Anthony Espinosa
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:1752(b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon;
Additional details: Resident of NH
Short narrative: "The FBI reviewed many social media posts showing Charles Espinosa on January 6, 2021, known by the Instagram username “Charlie_alpha_echo,” court documents state. One video tagging that account showed Espinosa on the steps of the Capitol, speaking to the crowd through a megaphone held by another rioter, saying, “I think this should be happening in every single major city in the country.” Espinosa’s previous employer provided his attendance records to the FBI, showing he requested paid time off for January 6 and 7, 2021. In the leave request comments section for January 7, Espinosa allegedly submitted: “Stop the steal!” The FBI further reviewed other unrestricted, public social media posts that allegedly contained pictures of him with what appeared to be a large knife concealed in the rear waistband of his pants. Court documents state that he entered the Capitol building around 2:14 pm and exited 45 minutes later. He was arrested Mar. 26, 2024 in Derry, NH." (NRP)
Source description: Charging Documents;

Short narrative: Sandra Lee Hodges, 59, of NC, was federally charged after her participation in the Capitol riot. Hodges was identified via her hotel key card which was discovered while cleaning up after Jan 6. Hodges then agreed to an interview with FBI agents during which she admitted to entering the Capitol claiming she was "sucked into the building" with the crowd. Hodges can also be seen in Capitol surveillance footage and video footage taken by another rioter. Her case is ongoing.

Name of case: United States of America v. Kyle Douglas McMahan
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly, and with intent to impede or disrupt the orderly conduct of Government business; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers
Additional details: Resident of Watauga, Texas; Sentenced 9/10/24 to 19 months in prison, 12 months of supervised release, 100 hours of community service, and ordered to pay $2,000 in restitution
Short narrative: Kyle Douglas McMahan, 41, of Watauga, Texas, is charged in a criminal complaint for his involvement in the January 6th Capitol Riot. According to the statement of facts, "While being pushed back by one officer, MCMAHAN attempted to swat at another officer. Eventually, MCMAHAN grabbed the fingers of one of the officers, appearing to crush them in his hand as captured by a photographer and body camera footage" (Statement of Facts 9). McMahan is charged with 18:231(a)(3): Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1): Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2): Knowingly, and with intent to impede or disrupt the orderly conduct of Government business; 40:5104(e)(2)(G): Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 18:111(a)(1): Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers (Physical Contact)."

Name of case: United States of America v. Edward Amyot, Domonic Jakubowski
Charges: 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds;
Additional details: Sentenced to 24 months probation; Resident of MI:
Short narrative: According to federal investigators, Edward Amyot and an acquaintance -- Dominic Jakubowski -- arrived at the Capitol building a little before 1 pm on Jan. 6, 2021. In social media posts, Amyot is seen pushing past police tape and fencing on the West Lawn of the grounds. Later, open source video allegedly showed Amyot among a crowd pushing a large metal sign into a line of police on the steps of the Capitol. According to court documents, Amyot deleted much of his social media presence following the riot. He was arrested in Detroit, Mich., on Nov. 2, 2023. (NPR) "Jakubowski and Amyot Sentenced 8/30/24 to twenty-four (24) months of probation as to Count 1 with the first 60 days to be served on home detention, Special Assessment of $25, Restitution of $500, and $5,000 fine."
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Edward Amyot, Domonic Jakubowski
Charges: 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds;
Additional details: Sentenced to 24 months probation; Shown in Statement of Facts weight black and white 'Siege/skull' mask possibly signaling as an accelerationist ; Resident of MI:
Short narrative: "According to federal investigators, Dominic Jakubowski and an acquaintance -- Edward Amyot -- arrived at the Capitol building a little before 1 pm on Jan. 6, 2021. As they made their way to the building, Jakubowski allegedly ripped away a line of police tape and pulled aside fencing. Throughout the afternoon, he posted updates on Snapchat; in one, Jakubowski can be seen in a black and white skeleton mask; in another, he's heard saying "We stormed the Capitol...let's go!"; in another, the words "I did this" are written over an image of crowds surrounding the Capitol building. Later, open source video showed Jakubowski among a crowd pushing a large metal sign into a line of police on the steps of the Capitol. He was arrested in Detroit, Mich., on Nov. 2, 2023" (NPR) "Jakubowski and Amyot Sentenced 8/30/24 to twenty-four (24) months of probation as to Count 1 with the first 60 days to be served on home detention, Special Assessment of $25, Restitution of $500, and $5,000 fine."
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Article
