Name of case: United States v. Daniel Harrington
Charges: 18:641 Theft of Government Property [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building [misdemeanor]; 40: 5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor];
Additional details: Resident of Independence, Kentucky; attended the "Stop the Steal" rally
Short narrative: On January 17, 2024, Daniel Harrington was charged in a criminal complaint in the District of Columbia for alleged theft of government property, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, entering and remaining in certain rooms in the Capitol building, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. On January 6, 2021, Harrington entered the Capitol through the Senate Wing Door. Video surveillance captured Harrington in the Senators' Spouse's Lounge, the Rotunda, the hallway with the suite of offices of the Speaker of the House, the Statuary Hall, and the Speaker's suite (Statement of Facts). In the hallway, Harrington "took what appears to be a stapler and a tape dispenser from on top of the desk...and put them in his pockets...grabbed a pair of what appears to be scissors that [were] on top of the desk and pocketed that as well...then opened a drawer in the desk and removed what appears to be coasters...[then] he threw one at a rioter coming down the hall toward him and took one" (Statement of Facts). Afterward, he remained in the Capitol and roamed around before leaving. "Daniel Harrington sentenced to Forty-Five (45) days of Incarceration on Count 1, no term of Supervised Release to follow. Defendant sentenced to Six (6) months of Probation on Count Six (6). Counts 1 and 6 to run consecutive. A Special Assessment fee of $35 ($25 on Count 1 and $10 on Count 6) and Restitution in the amount of $500 as to both counts. Count(s) 2, 3, 4 & 5 are hereby Dismissed on Oral Motion by the Government."
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jason Howland
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in Any Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Clinton Township, Michigan; had a Twitter account with the username @Jason_Howland but this username is not associated with the current version of @Jason_Howland on X and "the Wayback Machine" was used to find his old tweets;
Short narrative: On January 23, 2024, Jason James Howland was "charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with a felony offense of obstruction of an official proceeding. In addition to the felony charge, Howland is charged with several misdemeanor offenses, including entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building" (DOJ Press Release). On January 6, 2021, Howland was captured on an open-source video on YouTube "turning to yell to the people behind him 'Let's Go!'...immediately after yelling 'Let's Go!' Howland twice waves his arm forward in the direction of the U.S. Capitol police officers guarding the northwest scaffolding [and] the crowd immediately begins to push forward, overtaking the officers (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). Howland is again captured "with a group of rioters moving up the stairs in the direction of the Upper West Terrace" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). Howland entered the Capitol through the Senate Wing Door and proceeded to the Capitol's Crypt. Once inside, "Howland eventually moves to the area of the Memorial Door...then moves south in the direction of the House Wing Door" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). Later, Howland is observed in the Crypt again "and eventually moves in the direction of a hallway to the south of the Crypt Lobby" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). Then, Howland "enters the Capitol Rotunda...enters the East Foyer...[reenters] the Rotunda...[and later] he returns to the East Foyer area" (). While in the Rotunda, Howland is "observed on camera interacting with law enforcement officers who were attempting to clear rioters out of the Rotunda" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). Then, after leaving the U.S. Capitol Building, Howland remained on the U.S. Capitol grounds.
Source description: Charging Documents; Cout Documents; Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Joshua Kaleb Youngerman
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:2 Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Condut in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(d) Stepping & Climbing on Any Erection or Architectural Feature on Capitol Grounds
Additional details: Resident of Imperial Beach, CA;
Short narrative: Joshua Kaleb Youngerman, 23, of Imperial Beach, CA, is federally charged with entering on restricted grounds, disruptive conduct on restricted grounds, disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds, parading on Capitol grounds, and stepping and climbing on any architectural feature on Capitol grounds. On January 6, 2021, Youngerman was inside the Capitol building carrying a flag that reads "Black Voices for Trump," and been identified as being part of the Telegram group “The California Patriot - DC Brigade." Youngerman admits he was present but states he didn't actually enter the Capitol despite CCTV evidence to the contrary. His case is ongoing.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Local News Articles;

Name of case: United States of America v. Matthew Valentin, et. al.
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of Stroudsburg, PA; Brother also arrested
Short narrative: According to federal investigators, Matthew Valentin and his brother Andrew spent hours on the grounds of the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, as the riot unfolded. He was seen in open-source video footage wearing a grey hoodie, camouflage pants and a grey hat; both brothers wore a black vest. Around 2:14 pm that afternoon, the Valentin brothers were seen climbing to the top of a metal tower erected outside the building for the upcoming inauguration. Fifteen minutes later, they were seen pushing a bike rack barricade into a line of police officers. Matthew Valentin was later seen grabbing an officer's baton and spraying a chemical irritant into police lines. He was arrested on Feb. 12, 2024, in Wilkes-Barre, Pa. (NPR) e video throwing a folding chair at a group of police. He was arrested on Feb. 11, 2024, in Allentown, Pa.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents;

Name of case: United States of America v. Davis & Bishop
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752 (a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Picketing, and Demonstrating in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor];
Additional details: Resident of Ayden, North Carolina; Traveled to Capitol with female co-offender
Short narrative: On December 4, 2023, Curtis Davis and Tanya Bishop of Snow Hill, North Carolina were "charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with felony offenses of civil disorder and assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers. In addition to the felonies, the couple is charged with various misdemeanor offenses, including entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; and parading, picketing, and demonstrating in a Capitol building" (DOJ Press Release). MPD body-worn camera footage shows Davis "assaulting officers by punching towards an MPD officer," and another video shows him "pushing MPD officers inside the Capitol" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). In regards to Bishop, "the FBI was able to "locate more than ten videos in which also appear to show Bishop...inside the Capitol building and interacting with Davis. The videos also show Bishop interacting with law enforcement for an extended period of time" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). A YouTube video also showed "Davis aggressively yelling at officers and being held back by Bishop. The video then shows Davis fighting with law enforcement officers, including throwing punches towards officers and appearing to make contact with at least one punch against an MPD officer" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). Surveillance footage shows Davis and Bishop entering the Rotunda inside the U.S. Capitol Building, where Davis is captured shoving and punching law enforcement (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). It also captured Bishop placing her hands on and pushing police officers who were attempting to disperse rioters from the Rotunda (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). Both continued to "forcibly resisted, impeded, and interfered with MPD police officers attempting to remove rioters from the Rotunda before fleeting the area" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts ).
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. David Paul Daniel
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752 (a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Willfully and Knowingly Engaging in an Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Mint Hill, North Carolina; Made his initial appearance in the Western District of North Carolina but the criminal complaint was made in the District of Columbia;
Short narrative: On November 30, 2023, David Paul Daniel was charged in a criminal complaint in the District of Columbia for allegedly "assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers and civil disorder...entering and remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; willfully and knowingly engaging in an act of physical violence in the grounds or any of the Capitol building; and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building" (DOJ). On January 6, 2021, "a review of U.S. Capitol Closed Circuit Video (CCV) shows that...Daniel assaulted U.S. Capitol police officers that were attempting to keep the mob out" (Charging Documents). To push against a police barricade, Daniel joined another rioter to push against the barricade and the officers attempting to hold it (Charging Documents). After the barricade was breached, Daniel "spent several moments walking around the perimeter of the area just inside the Senate Wing Door" (Charging Documents).
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Government Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Zeis & Schulze
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restriced Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 40:5104 (e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Monument, Colorado; Attended the "Stop the Steal" Rally before arriving at the Capitol; Was considered the leader of the group that traveled to Washington D.C. to attend President Trump's speech at the rally mentioned prior.
Short narrative: On November 13, 2023, Eric D. Zeis, along with Justin R. Schulze, were charged in the District of Columbia for allegedly "obstruct[ing] law enforcement during civil disorder. In addition to the felony, the two [were] charged with several misdemeanor offenses, including disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building" (DOJ). On January 6, 2021, Zeis and Schulze "joined a large group that forced officers from the United States Capitol Police (USCP) to retreat to the East Rotunda doors" (United States of America v. Eric Zeis, Statement of Facts). After entering the Capitol, Zeis and Schulze "made their way to varying parts of the Capitol" (United States of America v. Eric Zeis, Statement of Facts). After making their way to the Statuary Hall Connector, "they emersed themselves in a larger group confronting officers guarding the U.S. House of Representatives chambers...Zeis and Schulze eventually retraced their steps back throughout the Capitol stopping in the Routhnda. Zeis is seen, in an open-source video, joining a group who collectively pushed officers...after shoving forward, Zeis turned around and called 'Justin'...Schulze then joined the group pushing against the officers;" then, Zeis and Schulze exited the Capitol through the Rotunda Door (United States of America v. Eric Zeis, Statement of Facts).
Source description: News Article; Government Reports and Release; Charging Documents; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Zeis & Schulze
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restriced Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 40:5104 (e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Colorado Springs, Colorado; Attended the "Stop the Steal" Rally before arriving at the Capitol
Short narrative: On November 13, 2023, Justin R. Schulze, along with Eric D. Zeis, were charged in the District of Columbia for allegedly "obstruct[ing] law enforcement during civil disorder. In addition to the felony, the two [were] charged with several misdemeanor offenses, including disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building" (DOJ). On January 6, 2021, Schulze and Zeis "joined a large group that forced officers from the United States Capitol Police (USCP) to retreat to the East Rotunda doors" (United States of America v. Justin Schulze, Statement of Facts). After entering the Capitol, Schulze and Zeis "made their way to varying parts of the Capitol" (United States of America v. Justin Schulze, Statement of Facts). After making their way to the Statuary Hall Connector, "they emersed themselves in a larger group confronting officers guarding the U.S. House of Representatives chambers...Schulze and Zeis eventually retraced their steps back throughout the Capitol stopping in the Routhnda. Zeis is seen, in an open-source video, joining a group who collectively pushed officers...after shoving forward, Zeis turned around and called 'Justin'...Schulze then joined the group pushing against the officers;" then, Schulze and Zeis exited the Capitol through the Rotunda Door (United States of America v. Justin Schulze, Statement of Facts).
Source description: News Article; Government Reports and Release; Charging Documents; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Allan Jennings
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1361 Destruction of Government Property;
Additional details: Resident of TN
Short narrative: "In November of 2021, a tipster wrote a letter to the FBI saying that Allan Jennings had posted on Facebook shortly after Jan. 6, 2021, and indicated that he had been at the riot and was home safe, but a little "banged up," according to federal court records. In January of 2022, the FBI interviewed Jennings, who allegedly admitted to being at the riot that day. Metropolitan Police Department body-worn camera footage inside the Tunnel leading to the U.S. Capitol allegedly shows Jennings pulling an implement from his pocket which an officer identified as a “knife with a glass-breaking end” and shattered a door near the Tunnel’s entrance, allowing the rioters to push further into the Tunnel." (NPR) "Allan Jennings Sentenced 10/4/24 to 12 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, and ordered to pay $3,825 in restitution and fines".
Source description: Charging Document, Court Document

Name of case: United States of America v. Scott Alan O'Brien

Additional details: Resident of Ponder, TX; "Scott O'Brien Sentenced 6/11/24 to a term of Twenty-Four (24) Months of Probation on each of Counts 1 and 2, to run concurrently. Special Assessment of $10 imposed as to each count, for a total of $20. Fine in the amount of $1,000. Restitution in the amount of $500. The defendant must complete 60 hours of community service within 10 months."
Short narrative: On April 25, 2024, Scott Alan O'Brien of Ponder, Texas was charged with 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; for their actions during the January 6, 2021, Capitol demonstration.

Name of case: United States of America v. Cameron C. Clapp
Charges: 18:1752(a)(l) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Los Angeles, California
Short narrative: Cameron C. Clapp, 38, of Los Angeles, California is charged in a criminal complaint for his involvement in the January 6, 2021 insurrection. According to the news article, "Clapp traveled from California to Washington, D.C., to join thousands of Donald Trump supporters protesting against Congress certifying Joe Biden’s 2020 electoral win. He allegedly joined the mob at the Capitol that day, apparently entering the building at around 3:34 p.m., more than an hour after the initial violent breach of the building that forced lawmakers and staff to either flee the building or shelter in place for hours" (Kandel 2). Cameron C. Clapp is charged with 18:1752(a)(l): Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2): Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G): Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; News Articles;

Name of case: United States of America v. Lee Stutts
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers [2 counts]; 8:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 140:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
Additional details: Resident of Terrell, North Carolina; blockading as an additional criminal method; was on FBI Office of Public Affairs "Seeking Information" List; FBI posted Stutts on "Be on the Lookout"(BOLO") and Stutts was referred to as "57-AFO"; Attended the "Stop the Steal" Rally before arriving at the Capitol
Short narrative: On September 26, 2023, Lee Stutts of Terrell, North Carolina was charged in the District of Columbia for allegedly "assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers with a deadly or dangerous weapon and obstruction of law enforcement during a civil disorder. In addition to the felonies, Stutts is charged with misdemeanor offenses of entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, and engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds" (DOJ). On January 6, 2021, after attending the "Stop the Steal" rally on the Ellipse Stutts "joined other rioters on the west plaza" where he "wav[ed] other rioters on as he made a beeline for the line of United States Capitol Police (USCP) officers blocking the way to the southwest steps of the Capitol" (United States of America v. Lee Stutts, Statement of Facts). Court documents mention Stutts "wrapp[ing] his arms around," "shov[ing]," and assaulting officers on various occasions (United States of America v. Lee Stutts, Statement of Facts). During this time Stutts also attempted to break the police line on the west plaza and joined other rioters as they "began to move a large sign on wheels with a metal frame towards the police line and barricade" (United States of America v. Lee Stutts, Statement of Facts). After the police took the sign from the rioters Stutts threw a water bottle toward the police line. The police line was eventually broken and the rioters, including Stutts, overtook the west plaza (United States of America v. Lee Stutts, Statement of Facts).
Source description: Government Reports and Release; Charging Documents; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Mitchell Bosch
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assault, Resist, Oppose, Impede, Intimidate, or Interfere with an Officer or Employee of the United States; 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly and With Intent to Impede or Disrupt the Orderly Conduct of Government Business or Official Functions; 18:1752(a)(4) Knowingly Engage in Any Act of Physical Violence Against Any Person or Property in Any Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Engage in an Act of Physical Violence in the Grounds or any of the Capitol Buildings
Additional details: January 2022, Bosch was also arrested at an anti-vax protest at the Museum of Natural History.
Short narrative: Mitchell Bosch, 44, of Brooklyn, New York is charged in a criminal complaint for his involvement in this January 6, 2021 insurrection. According to the press release, "His actions and the actions of others disrupted a joint session of the U.S. Congress convened to ascertain and count the electoral votes related to the 2020 presidential election" (Press Release 1). Mitchell Bosch is charged with 18:111(a)(1) Assault, Resist, Oppose, Impede, Intimidate, or Interfere with an Officer or Employee of the United States; 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly and With Intent to Impede or Disrupt the Orderly Conduct of Government Business or Official Functions; 18:1752(a)(4) Knowingly Engage in Any Act of Physical Violence Against Any Person or Property in Any Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Engage in an Act of Physical Violence in the Grounds or any of the Capitol Buildings. His case is ongoing.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; News Articles; Governmental Reports and Release;

Name of case: United States of America v. Dustin Ray Williams
Charges: 18:231 Civil Disorder; 18:11(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Violent Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Violent Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds
Additional details: Resident of Brady, TX
Short narrative: Dustin Ray Williams, 32, of Brady, TX was arrested for obstructing law enforcement, violent conduct, disorderly conduct, and knowingly entering restricted grounds or buildng. This arrest happened after a tip was sent to the FBI about Dustin posting videos on Facebook describing his activites on January 6. His Facebook videos showed him wearing identifiable clothing including a bright orange t-shirt with the name and phone number of a concrete company in Fort Collins, CO. The FBI reached out to the business, and the owner confirmed Mr. Williams' identity. Several videos and posts from Mr. Williams' Facebook account were used in charging.
Source description: Charging Documents, Government reports and releases, local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Charles Walters
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:1361 Destruction of Government Property
Additional details: Resident of Sparta, Wisconsin
Short narrative: On September 25, 2023, Charles R. Walters received an official criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia. In the criminal complaint, Walters allegedly committed a felony by injuring or depredating U.S. property, which amounted to $1,170.72 ("United States v. Charles Walters, Statement of Facts, ¶ 26, pg. 16 ). He also allegedly committed several misdemeanors "including entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds, disorderly or disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, and disorderly or disruptive conduct in the Capitol grounds or buildings, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building (Department of Justice). On January 6, 2021, Walters "kick[ed] [a] railing [at the West Fron of the Capitol building] until it fold[ed] forward" and the sections he damaged were valued at $1,170.72 ("United States v. Charles Walters, Statement of Facts, ¶ 14, pg. 4). Different closed circuit video (CCV) shows Walters in and around the Capitol building until, amongst a crowd, he is directed away from the Capitol building but law enforcement ("United States v. Charles Walters, Statement of Facts").
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. William Lewis
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; *18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; *18:1361 Destruction of Government Property [misdemeanor]; *18:1752(a)(1)(2) Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds[misdemeanor]; *18:1752(a)(1)(4) Acts of Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Engaging in an Act of Violence on Capitol Grounds [misdemeanor];
Additional details: Resident of Burbank, Illinois; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: On November 7, 2023, William (AKA Bill/Billy) Lewis was "charged in a criminal complaint in the District of Columbia with felony offenses of assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers and civil disorder. In addition to the felonies, Lewis is charged with several misdemeanor offenses, including the destruction of government property, knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority, and willfully and knowingly engaging in an act of physical violence on the grounds of any of the Capitol buildings " (Governmental Repors and Release; DOJ Press Release). On January 6, 2021, Lewis was captured, on three separate occasions, spraying law enforcement officers with wasp and hornet spray (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). On the first occasion, Lewis sprayed five MPD officers, on the second occasion he sprayed two officers, and on the third occasion, Lewis sprayed an officer and threw the canister toward officers. Afterward, Lewis used a baton to break "at least three glass panes of a window located immediately to the right of the Lower West Terrance tunnel;" the cost of repairing these panes was $1761 (Charging Document; Statement of Facts).
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Lowell Gates
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Violent Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds
Additional details: Resident of Mechanicsburg, PA; works as attorney and real estate developer
Short narrative: Lowell Gates, 63, of Mechanicsburg, Pennsylvania, is charged with assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers using a dangerous weapon and obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder. Gates traveled to Washington, D.C. on January 6, 2021 with a group of friends. Gates was seen on body camera footage throwing an object at a group of law enforcement officers, and he then attacked the officers with a flagpole. The FBI received several tips that #BrownJacketJabber was Lowell, and obtained his driver's license photo from Pennsylvania DMV. Open source videos were used to identify Lowell's crimes.
Source description: Charging Documents, Government reports and releases, local news article, other

Charges: 18:111(a)(l) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:23l(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:17S2(a)(l) - Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:17S2(a)(2) - Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building or Grounds;

Short narrative: On May 09, 2024, James Link Behymer (61) and Donald Lee Moss (62) of Indiana were indicted with 18:111(a)(l) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:23l(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:17S2(a)(l) - Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:17S2(a)(2) - Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building or Grounds, for their actions during the January 6, 2021 Capitol demonstration. At the Capitol the pair were seen assaulting and shoving police officers. Moss and Behymer were identified through Capitol picture and video.
Source description: Charging Documents;

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Ortt
Charges: 18:111(a)(1), 2 Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4), 2 Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds and Aiding and Abetting; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of Mount Airy, MD; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: "Federal investigators allege that Nicholas Juston Ortt assaulted police officers on the West Plaza of the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021. Open source video showed Ortt struggling against a line of officers at that location, eventually becoming the first protestor to break through. Body-worn camera footage showed Ortt continuing to grapple with officers after breaking through the line until he was forced back into the crowd. By that point, a large group of protestors had followed Ortt through the breach, headed for the Lower West Terrace and the U.S. Capitol building itself. Ortt was arrested on Mar. 8, 2024, in Howard County, Md." (NPR) "Nicholas Ortt Sentenced 9/24/24 to two years in prison. He was also ordered to serve three years of probation and pay $2,000 in restitution."
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Barbara Balmaseda
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) (Disorderly or disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds); 40:5104(e)(2)(D) (Disorderly or disruptive conduct in a Capitol building); 40:5104(e)(2)(G) (Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building)
Additional details: Resident of Miami Lakes, Florida; Former Marco Rubio intern; Miami Young Republican Board Member; Proud Boy associate; Former organizer for DeSantis 2018 campaign; Former campaign manager for Florida State Senator Ileana Garcia
Short narrative: On 13 December 2023, a Criminal Complaint was filed against Barbara Yazmin Balmaseda, 23, of Miami Lakes, FL. Balmaseda had been in frequent contact with Proud Boys member Gabriel Garcia in the days leading up to the Capitol Siege. Balmaseda met up with Garcia on 6 January 2021, and at the Capitol, they climbed equipment on the Upper West Terrace previously set for the upcoming Inauguration. Balmaseda, with Garcia, enter the Capitol minutes after rioters initially breached this entrance point. According to the complaint, Balmaseda and Garcia traveled to the Crypt, OAP corridor, and the Rotunda. Balmaseda confronted law enforcement blocking areas of the Capitol, and Balmaseda, Garcica, and other rioters continued through police lines.
Source description: Charging Documents; News article; Local News Article;

Short narrative: On 28 November 2023, Brandon Keith Heffner, 38, of Harford County, MD, was charged with a felony offense of obstructing law enforcement during civil disorder and several misdemeanor charges. An FBI Confidential Human Source (CHS-1) confirmed Heffner was in the photograph blocking a door at the Lower West Terrace.

Name of case: United States of America v. Dana Jean Bell
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers
Additional details: Resident of Princeton, Texas; was a suspect on the FBL "Be on the Look Out" ("BOLO"); was carrying an America flag and was carrying a cell phone with folio-style cover that was rose in color and consisted of an America flag backdrop and images of former President Donald Trump;
Short narrative: On December 6, 2023, Dana Jean Bell was "charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with felony offenses of assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers and obstruction of law enforcement during a civil disorder. In addition to the felonies, Bell is charged with multiple misdemeanor offenses, including knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in the Capitol grounds or buildings; parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building" (DOJ Press Release). On January 6, 2021, "Bell is seen assaulting a member of the press (a local news anchor from Fox 5)...Bell appears to move forward and reach out in an aggressive manner and attempts to push or grab at the news anchor. Eventually, Bell appears to make her way to the United States Capitol Buiding itself. She pushes with the mob to the Rotunda Doors...[and] then successfully enters the Capitol" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). Then "other images and footage...show Bell near the Speaker's Lobby...then the House Chamber" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). At the House Chambers "in the video from which the below screenshots are taken, Bell appears to aggressively yell toward various officers, showing them her middle finger" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). Bell is seen "in a number of Metropolitan Police Department (MPD) officers' body-worn camera where she continually acts aggressively, uttering threatening or insulting language very close to officers' faces" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). "Bell is also heard telling officers 'Do not touch me.' while appearing to actively resist and/or push back against officers as she is being forced to exit the Capitol...During this confrontation...Bell grabs an officer's baton with her right hand. Then Bell is seen in other body-worn camera footage actively resisting and/or pushing against an officer while speaking aggressively towards him" (Charging Documents; Statement of Facts). After spending 30 minutes in the Capitol, Bell exits the building.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Documents; Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Mario Gonalez
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers;
Additional details: Resident of Las Vegas, NV
Short narrative: According to court documents, Mario Gonzalez first entered the grounds of the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, near the scaffolding that had been erected for the upcoming inauguration. As he left that area, he carried a fire extinguisher, which he subsequently sprayed in the direction of the police trying to control the crowd. Gonzalez was then seen in open-source video footage dropping the fire extinguisher after law enforcement deployed a chemical irritant in the area. He was arrested on Jan. 8, 2024, in Las Vegas, Nevada.
Source description: Charging Documents;

Name of case: United States of America v. Troy Spackman
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting a Federal Officer During Civil Disorder; 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor], 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds [misdemeanor]; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Violent Conduct in a Capitol Building [misdemeanor];
Additional details: Resident of West York, Pennsylvania
Short narrative: On October 12, 2023, Troy Spackman of West York, Pennsylvania, was charged in a criminal complaint "with felony offenses of civil disorder and assaulting, resisting, or impeding federal officers. In addition to the felonies, Spackman is charged with misdemeanor offenses of disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, and act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings" (Department of Justice). According to the United States v. Troy Spackman Statement of Facts, Spackman "went to Washington D.C. in order to attend the rally for then President Donald Trump. He walked from the rally to the U.S. Capitol Building." Videos of Spackman illustrate him with canisters of OC spray, which appeared to be "Combined Tactical Systems ("CTS") MK-9 OC spray" ("United States v. Troy Spackman," Statement of Facts, ¶ 15, pg. 6). Another video "includes a clip that shows a person who appears to be Spackman pointing a canister of OC spray in the direction of uniformed officers from an elevated position" ("United States v. Troy Spackman," Statement of Facts, ¶ 16, pg. 6).
Source description: Charging Documents; News Article; Court Documents; Government Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Carlos Alberto Ayala
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1): Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2): Knowingly, and with intent to impede or disrupt the orderly conduct of Government business; 40:5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G): Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:231(a)(3): Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder;
Additional details: N/A
Short narrative: Carlos Alberto Ayala, 52, of Salisbury, Maryland, was charged with 18:1752(a)(1): Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2): Knowingly, and with intent to impede or disrupt the orderly conduct of Government business; 40:5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G): Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:231(a)(3): Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; for his role in the January 6th protest. According to the press release, "At approximately 2:41 p.m., CCTV footage taken from inside the Capitol building shows a rioter positioned to the right side of the Senate Wing Door, the same area where Ayala was present, jabbing a flag and flagpole at a USCP officer. The USCP officer then grabbed the flagpole and pulled the flag into the building to prevent the rioter from knocking the officer's shield away or injuring other officers" (press release).
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles, Governmental Reports & Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Picciuto
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Obstructing, Impeding, or Interfering with Law Enforcement; 18:1363 Destruction or Injury to Buildings or Property in Special Maritime and Territorial Jurisdiction; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering or Remaining in Any Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence on U.S. Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Kirtland, Ohio
Short narrative: Michael Picciuto, 25, of Kirtland, Ohio is charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia for his involvement in the January 6, 2021 insurrection. According to the press release, "His actions and the actions of others disrupted a joint session of the U.S. Congress convened to ascertain and count the electoral votes related to the 2020 presidential election" (Press Release 1). Michael Picciuto is charged with 18:231(a)(3): Obstructing, Impeding, or Interfering with Law Enforcement; 18:1363: Destruction or Injury to Buildings or Property in Special Maritime and Territorial Jurisdiction; 18:1752(a)(1): Entering or Remaining in Any Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2): Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4): Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D): Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F): Act of Physical Violence on U.S. Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G): Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building.
